(defroutes route-table
  [[["/events" {:get [::events (start-event-stream stream-ready)]}]]])
in : https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-sse.md Does ::events need to be implemented? or is it just an arbitrary symbol?#2016-01-2614:38jonahbentonhey @xlevus. the short answer is that it's an optional part of the routing data structure. see https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-routing.md#verb-maps. ::events is an optional name for that particular route, and see https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-routing.md#route-names for more about route naming.#2016-01-2614:40xlevushmm ok#2016-01-2614:52xlevusI keep getting Exception in thread "async-thread-macro-1" java.lang.ClassCastException: clojure.lang.Keyword cannot be cast to java.util.Locale whenever I do anything in the function passed to start-event-stream. But when I make the body of the function just nil it seems to work fine, and my browser appears to open the EventStream connection fine.#2016-01-2615:00xlevusoh. nope. only happens with timbre. ok.#2016-01-2615:14jonahbentonall well?#2016-01-2615:21xlevusyeah, mostly. Can't seem to call Timbre logging functions within anything that's async. but might be another issue altogether#2016-01-2616:07jplazaCool thanks @frankie ! I‚Äôm still trying to understand why isn‚Äôt this something that comes as part of the library. Or someone builds something on top of pedestal. This is a pretty common use case when developing web apps#2016-01-2616:08frankiesardojplaza: I think they‚Äôve packaged it under the service-tools https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-tools/src/io/pedestal/service_tools/dev.clj#2016-01-2815:01christianromneyre: the ::events (sorry late to the party)#2016-01-2815:01christianromney["/events" {:get [::events (start-event-stream stream-ready)]}]#2016-01-2815:02christianromneythis maps GET requests the url ‚Äù/events‚Äù to (start-event-stream) but also names the route#2016-01-2815:02christianromneyyou can have unnamed routes {:get (start-event-stream stream-ready)}#2016-01-2815:02christianromneyor named routes as above#2016-01-2815:03christianromneyyou name them with a keyword that you can pass to route/url-for#2016-01-2815:03christianromneyin this case, the keyword is namespaced, hence the extra colon :#2016-01-2815:03christianromneyso assuming that file is in ns#2016-01-2815:04christianromney(ns example.routes)#2016-01-2815:04christianromneythen ::events is shorthand for :example.routes/events#2016-01-2815:05christianromneythis allows you to use a generic word like ‚Äòevents'#2016-01-2815:05christianromneywhile avoiding name clashes#2016-01-2815:05christianromneyfrom a hypothetically different namespace, assume you want to redirect someone to that endpoint#2016-01-2815:06christianromneyyou could do#2016-01-2815:07christianromney`(ns example.other (:require [io.pedestal.http.route :as route] [example.routes :as r])) ‚Ä¶ (ring/redirect (route/url-for ::r/events)) `#2016-01-2815:07christianromneymeh forgive the formatting, hopefully the idea is clear...#2016-01-2815:08christianromneyhope that helps someone#2016-01-2912:04xlevus@christianromney: Cheers üíØ#2016-02-2514:53rauhI'm not sure if it's a bug or not. (defrecord Pedestal [service]
  component/Lifecycle
  (start [this]
    (let [server (-> service http/create-server http/start)]
      (assoc this ::server server)))
  (stop [this]
    (http/stop (::server this))
    (dissoc this ::server)))
#2016-05-1619:02donaldballThat‚Äôs my bog-standard component (http being io.pedestal.http). It starts and stops fine once, but fails to restart thereafter, claiming:#2016-05-1619:02donaldball
2016-05-16 14:56:10.754-0400 ERROR org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11NioProtocol Failed to initialize end point associated with ProtocolHandler ["http-nio-8080"]
java.net.BindException: Address already in use
#2016-05-1619:14donaldballFWIW this seems to be specific to the tomcat server type, so plausibly is a bug#2016-05-1619:24donaldballI kinda like the design, but the docs are laughable, and the registration process for interceptors seems haphazard#2016-05-1702:05donaldball(Oh my. FWIW, while I stand by the above, it was intended as a private gripe to another party. I am embarrassed that I accidentally published it here. Had I intended a public critique, I would have been much more thoughtful and respectful.)#2016-05-1713:57tessellator@donaldball: I get the same error when using Tomcat with pedestal+component. Even using a server start/stop/start sequence with the default pedestal-service project has issues when using Tomcat. I would agree this is likely a bug. Would you like to open an issue or drop a note to the mailing list?#2016-05-1714:03donaldballThanks for the confirmation that it‚Äôs not something specific to my environment; I‚Äôll do so.#2016-05-1716:37christianromney@donaldball: the dissoc in the snippet above will cause a regular map to be returned instead of a record. you might prefer assoc w/ nil#2016-05-1716:39christianromneyalso, it's good practice to make the calls idempotent so that calling start on a started component just returns this. ditto for stop on a stopped component#2016-05-1716:51donaldballI go back and forth on the idempotence of lifecycle fns tbqh#2016-05-1716:51donaldballBut the dissoc in this case is preserving the type. Is this behavior new in clojure 1.8?#2016-05-1717:52christianromneynot new functionality (record dissoc). the reason i usually go for idempotent lifecycle is to avoid the exception that's thrown on start when you're already bound to the port and i never have any good reason for not making them idempotent#2016-06-0116:11chrisetheridgeIs there anything special to parse post params in a request?#2016-06-0116:13chrisetheridgei‚Äôm posting to our route, but the params are empty#2016-06-0117:20andrewhr@biscuitpants: have you tried io.pedestal.http.body-params/body-params? It will put form encoded data into request's :form-params attribute#2016-06-0117:24andrewhryou just need to add it to your interceptor chain. Bear in mind body-params is not an interceptor per se, but an interceptor-returning function. This example shows how to use it https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/war-example/src/war_example/service.clj#L20#2016-06-0619:09donaldballDoes anyone else get these kinds of warnings from tomcat when stopping a pedestal war?#2016-06-0619:09donaldball

(def exception-handler
  (error/error-dispatch [context e]
    [{:interceptor ::routes/requires}]
    (assoc context :response {:status 503 :body {:message "System unavailable"}})
    :else (assoc context :io.pedestal.impl.interceptor/error e)))

I have the same problem.#2016-06-1414:07christianromneyi believe it's :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error#2016-06-1414:07christianromneythe code that was assoc'ing ::error moved to this namespace#2016-06-1414:08christianromneywhile a short term fix for you might be to use that key, you might be better off rethrowing.#2016-06-1414:26christianromneythat breaking change is actually in the release notes https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/releases/tag/0.5.0 (first item under breaking changes)#2016-06-1416:30donaldballha, thanks#2016-06-2119:43ikitommiHi. Could it hold the original ex-data under :data or something so the original data could be retrieved later? (defn ^:private read-port?
  [v]
  (satisfies? ReadPort v))

(defn ^:private wrap-for-async
  "Invokes the function yielding the response.  Returns either the context with the :response
  key set, or a channel that will convey the context when ready (if the endpoint function returns
  a channel)."
  [f]
  (fn [context]
    (let [v (f context)]
      (if (read-port? v)
        (go (assoc context :response (<! v)))
        (assoc context :response v)))))
#2016-08-1221:42hlshipSo, this should work: my intereceptor builds off of this: 
(interceptor {:name endpoint-kw
                  :enter (wrap-for-async generate-response)})
#2016-08-1221:43hlshipgenerate-response takes the Pedestal context and returns just the Ring response map, or a channel that conveys that map.#2016-08-1221:43hlshipIt‚Äôs not working in practice; if my handler returns a map, that passes through the interceptors just fine.#2016-08-1221:43hlshipIf it returns a channel that conveys the map, I see a nil passing back up.#2016-08-1221:43hlshipOne moment while I get some logging ...#2016-08-1221:46hlship
DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in begin, :execution-id 13, :line 291}

#2016-08-1221:52hlshipHm. It‚Äôs got to be something in my code, because I see an interceptor around the endpoint get invoked and it has the correct :response key on the context.#2016-08-1221:59hlshipMaybe not ‚Ä¶ it seems like somethings up. Here‚Äôs how I run a request: 
(defn execute-request
  [routes path request]
  (let [interceptors (-> routes
                         (table/table-routes)
                         (route/router :prefix-tree))]
    (-> {:request (merge {:request-method :get}
                         {:path-info path}
                         request)}
        (chain/enqueue [interceptors])
        chain/execute)))
#2016-08-1222:00hlshipThis is part of my test suite. This is returning as expected for requests that don‚Äôt involve any async, but returns nil for those that are async.#2016-08-1222:02hlshipThis might be related: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/430 I need to dig through more of the code to see what ‚Äúgoes async‚Äù really means.#2016-08-1223:00hlshipMy guess is that the stack of interceptors built up in execute-request doesn‚Äôt reflect usage in a real server; I‚Äôm working on end-to-end tests instead.#2016-08-1223:37hlshipEnd to end worked perfectly so it‚Äôs just a matter of my test harness not being up to snuff. It's not notfound route btw.#2016-09-0413:47rui.yanghi, tried to deploy a pedestal to heroku, got exception that no ctor for io.pedestal.http.helper before#2016-09-0413:48rui.yanganyone got similar issue? there is a similar issue in github, the suggestion is to use interceptor directly#2016-09-0413:49rui.yangi tried to write a macro to avoid some duplication in defining handler, no luck#2016-09-0413:49rui.yangwonder if there is some solutions already#2016-09-0504:40jimmy@rui.yang you should post your error log here, maybe someone can help#2016-09-0504:41jimmyRe asking T_T#2016-09-0507:50rui.yangthe exception I got is: No matching ctor found for class io.pedestal.interceptor.helpers$before$fn__6962#2016-09-0507:51rui.yangbut in my codes, there is no direct reference to before or defbefore#2016-09-0507:51rui.yangbut I used defhandler#2016-09-0507:52rui.yangwhich is created by calling defsimpleinterceptordef in pedestal. I am not sure if that‚Äôs the cause#2016-09-0507:53rui.yangusing a macro to create another macro, my brain exploded üòû#2016-09-0508:15rui.yangi solved by remove using defhandler#2016-09-0508:15rui.yangusing a simple macro i wrote to wrap the handler function#2016-09-0613:56geraldodevIt's annoying that exceptions created with ex-info are boxed inside another ex-info, because we need to use guard to capture our ex-info data. Imho (very humble), since core-match is called on ex-data it is data already, a simple map. When catching the exception pedestal could check if it is a ex-info and merge its keys with its data, qualified ‚Ä¶ https://gist.github.com/geraldodev/3a0d16da4b6c8fcdd9af575c9f9d9805#2016-09-0713:03mtnygard@nxqd Really late response on the catchall route, but you can put "/*path" as the last route.#2016-09-0713:04mtnygardI think that has to use the terse syntax, not the table syntax though.#2016-09-1008:45jimmy@mtnygard thanks for pointing out üòÑ I think pedestal needs more love for docs especially for beginner like me üòÑ#2016-09-1009:08jimmy@mtnygard I have this route def 
(defn routes
  [interceptor]
  (route/expand-routes
   `[[["/" {:get index-page}
       ^:interceptors [bootstrap/html-body ~interceptor]
       ["/api" {:post omnext-service}
        ^:interceptors [iinterceptor/om-body-params iinterceptor/om-response]]
       ["/*" {:get index-page}
        ^:interceptors [bootstrap/html-body ~interceptor]]]]]))
I think config it wrong, I got the error Route names are not unique #2016-09-1015:30mtnygard@nxqd The trouble is that both "/' and "/*" are defined to {:get index-page}. That's why they both get assigned the same route-name. Are you trying to set it up so any request that would be 404 shows the index page instead? If so, you might be better off providing a "not-found-interceptor" in your service map. See http://pedestal.io/reference/service-map for details.#2016-09-1100:05jimmy@mtnygard I have defning only /*, however when I request / it doesn't work. I have to have something /index for it to work. Ah, I'm working on a SPA, I don't setup server rendering yet. For now, I would like to forward all others request to the client so the javascript will take care of the routing for me.#2016-09-1122:52geraldodeverror-dispatch core.match is based on (ex-data ex) and captures :exception for which there is no mentioning on documentation or test of error-dispatch#2016-09-1122:54geraldodevI ve got this notes on my error-dispatch: note that match and as a consequence guard is based on (ex-data ex) so inside guard you can skip (ex-data ex) and go straight for (:exception %) which is one of the fields captured by pedestal#2016-09-1517:54mtnygardNew doc published: Routing quick reference http://pedestal.io/reference/routing-quick-reference#2016-09-1521:38mtnygardNew guide published: Defining Routes http://pedestal.io/guides/defining-routes (this uses the table routing syntax)#2016-09-1521:38mtnygardReviews, issues, and pull requests are most welcome.#2016-09-1521:46shaun-mahoodI see some blank spaces in the guide for interceptors - if I wanted to read up on them generally, are there any existing resources you would recommend?#2016-09-1521:46mtnygardCalling it "some blank spaces" is being kind... that guide is nothing but blank spaces as yet. üôÇ#2016-09-1521:47mtnygardYou can get some information from the somewhat outdated guide in the pedestal repo itself. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-interceptors.md#2016-09-1521:47mtnygardA more recent version appears in one of the hello world guides. http://spark-gap:8820/guides/hello-world-content-types#_interceptors#2016-09-1521:47mtnygardOops, local link. One ec.#2016-09-1521:48mtnygardhttp://pedestal.io/guides/hello-world-content-types#_interceptors#2016-09-1521:48shaun-mahoodOk, great!#2016-09-1521:49mtnygardAs you read those, please send me any questions that they don't answer. That'll help me know what to cover.#2016-09-1521:50shaun-mahoodWhile we're on the topic, was there any kind of prior or inspiration for Pedestal interceptors that would be worth looking into for general interest? I can't remember if I've ever seen anything about the genesis of the idea and always have had the assumption that they were invented for Pedestal based on issues with Ring middleware.#2016-09-1521:52mtnygardThey came up through a long series of discussions that many people at Relevance took part in. We looked at things like servlet filters, valves (from Tomcat IIRC), ATG's servlet pipeline.#2016-09-1521:52mtnygardAll of those were very code-centric solutions.#2016-09-1521:52mtnygardWe wanted something that was more like data.#2016-09-1521:52mtnygardWe started talking about continuation-passing systems and the idea of a reified call stack emerged.#2016-09-1521:53mtnygardThings clicked quickly after that. It was easy to see how to implement parts of the framework itself as interceptors. It was also easy to see how we could pause and resume on different threads. Async and SSE was always part of the design space for Pedestal, so interceptors really fit the bill there.#2016-09-1521:55mtnygardMore broadly, I guess you could say interceptors are an example of the Pipeline architecture pattern.#2016-09-1521:59shaun-mahoodCool, that's pretty interesting - reified call stack is a concept that really sits well with me.#2016-09-1621:38mtnygardNew reference doc published: Pedestal architecture overview http://pedestal.io/reference/architecture-overview#2016-09-1919:44ovanReally happy about the focus on building better documentation for Pedestal. I love the architecture and the idea of interceptors but it's been a bit of a hard sell at times because of the limited material to quickly learn and later debug things.#2016-09-1919:57gjnoonanYeah the new docs are great, good work :thumbsup:#2016-09-1920:09mtnygardLet me know what else should be in them. There are quite a few placeholders right now, but I'm sure there are gaps that I don't even have placeholders for.#2016-09-2015:35shaun-mahoodI know Pedestal doesn't officially support Windows, but does anyone know if it currently works with it?#2016-09-2015:42majenfulHappy too for a better documentation. Nevertheless, and despite all the efforts put in, I don‚Äôt really like (I know, my tateste) these ¬´ official¬†¬ª designs. But isn‚Äôt too confusing for new comers that pedestal shares the same http://clojure.org and http://clojurescript.org design ?#2016-09-2015:43majenfulDatomic has its own cool design, I think pedestal should have too#2016-09-2015:43mtnygard@majenful I reused the design in order to get the site out sooner.#2016-09-2015:43mtnygardPlus I'm no designer.#2016-09-2015:43mtnygardIf you have the wherewithal to make some mockups, I would definitely consider a design change.#2016-09-2015:44majenfulOh ok üôÇ, I didn‚Äôt understand like this.#2016-09-2015:44mtnygard@shaun-mahood I know of no reason why it wouldn't work. I think it'll depend more on the underlying network container you use. (E.g., Jetty works great, Tomcat works great. Not sure about others.)#2016-09-2015:45majenfulI‚Äôll think about it, do you have any color sheet or some color values to base on ?#2016-09-2015:46shaun-mahood@mtnygard: Ok that's good - based on the statement on the readme I assumed there would be some other issues as well.#2016-09-2017:37mtnygard@majenful No specific color sheet or values.#2016-09-2222:18crimeministerHi folks, I have a piece of monitoring software making an HTTP request to a Pedestal API. The logs from those requests are pure clutter; is there a way to selectively disable logging for a single route?#2016-09-2222:18crimeministerAlso, +1 from me on the documentation effort#2016-09-2317:06christianromneycheck the logback configuration#2016-09-2317:06christianromney^ @crimeminister#2016-09-2317:51crimeministerCool, thanks @christianromney #2016-09-2317:52christianromneyhappy to help. good luck!#2016-09-2820:10mtnygardNew reference doc posted: interceptors. http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#2016-09-2820:33mtnygardAlso, I think I forgot to post the draft on streaming responses:#2016-09-2820:33mtnygardhttp://pedestal.io/reference/streaming#2016-09-2908:01kirill.salykin@mtnygard thanks!#2016-09-2919:14grzm@mtnygard Thanks for bootstrap -> http! I know it's a small thing in the end, but I know it makes a difference to me üòâ#2016-09-2919:18mtnygard@grzm You're welcome.#2016-09-3018:49souenzzoHi I'm migrating from pedestal .4 to .5 and using the new interceptor logic (` defroutes -> table-routes `) How do I add an error-dispatch handler in this new routeing/handler logic? My actual defroutes looks like this: 
(def err-hand
  (io.pedestal.interceptor.error/error-dispatch [ctx ex] ,,,)
(defroutes r
  [[[^:interceptors [err-hand]
     ["/srv" {:any srv}]]]])
#2016-09-3019:44mtnygard@souenzzo In the table-routes syntax, interceptors are just an ordinary Clojure vector. So one option would be to prepend err-hand at the front of each vector.#2016-09-3019:44mtnygardE.g., 
#{["/srv" :any [err-hand srv]]}
#2016-09-3019:45mtnygardIf you have many routes that gets unwieldy. I often make a helper function that builds the "standard" interceptors that I want every route to have.#2016-09-3019:45mtnygardOf course, the terse syntax still exists and still inherits interceptors and paths down the tree, so feel free to keep using that syntax if it works better for you.#2016-09-3019:51souenzzoI found this. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.1/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor/error.clj#L24 So (def err-inter {:name ::err :error err-hand}) where (defn err-hand [ctx ex] ,,,) . It's not on docs http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors I'm still having some problems in migration but I'm progressing#2016-09-3019:55mtnygardAFAIK, io.pedestal.interceptor.error/error-dispatch is still the right thing to create.#2016-09-3019:56mtnygardI don't think you need to further wrap it with err-inter like that.#2016-09-3019:56mtnygard
(def err-hand
  (io.pedestal.interceptor.error/error-dispatch [ctx ex] ,,,)
should work fine#2016-09-3019:57mtnygardCan you paste more of the code?#2016-09-3020:14souenzzo@eric.vieira will paste#2016-09-3020:14eric.vieira
(def error-dispatch
  (error-int/error-dispatch [ctx ex]
                            (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body (do
                                                                      (log/error ex)
                                                                      (cheshire.core/generate-string (parse-data-exception ex)))})
                            :else (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body (do
                                                                            (log/error ex)
                                                                            (cheshire.core/generate-string (parse-data-exception ex)))})

                            ))

(def interceptor-error-handler
  {:name ::error-handler
   :error error-dispatch
   }
  )
#2016-09-3020:17mtnygardSomething definitely doesn't look right.#2016-09-3020:17mtnygardThe body of error-dispatch should be core.match forms. Here's an example from the test suite:#2016-09-3020:17mtnygard(def service-error-handler (error-int/error-dispatch [ctx ex] [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException :interceptor ::another-bad-one}] (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "Another bad one"}) [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException}] (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "A bad one"}) ;; If we don't match, forward it on :else (assoc ctx :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error ex)))#2016-09-3020:18mtnygard
(def service-error-handler
  (error-int/error-dispatch [ctx ex]
    [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException
      :interceptor ::another-bad-one}] (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "Another bad one"})
    [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException}] (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "A bad one"})
    ;; If we don't match, forward it on
    :else (assoc ctx :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error ex)))
#2016-09-3020:18mtnygardOne sec, let me reformat for clarity#2016-09-3020:18mtnygard
(def service-error-handler
  (error-int/error-dispatch [ctx ex]
    [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException :interceptor ::another-bad-one}]
    (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "Another bad one"})
                            
    [{:exception-type :java.lang.ArithmeticException}]
    (assoc ctx :response {:status 400 :body "A bad one"})
    
    ;; If we don't match, forward it on
    :else
    (assoc ctx :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error ex)))
#2016-09-3020:19mtnygardThe body is in pairs of forms. The first form is a pattern match. The second clause is what to execute if the pattern matches.#2016-09-3020:19mtnygardAnd the return value from error-dispatch is an interceptor, so no need to further wrap it in another interceptor.#2016-10-0314:36ulhi there! i'm trying to make simple proxy endpoint in my service, and write it like this 
(defn image-proxy [request]
  (-> request
      (get-in [:params :url])
      (client/get)
      (deref)
      (select-keys [:status :headers :body])
      (update :headers #(encore/map-keys name %))))

(def routes #{["/proxy" :get [`proxy]]})
But when I visit http://localhost:8080/proxy?url=http://google.com I get an error: `#2016-10-0314:37mtnygardHi @ul. I can help#2016-10-0314:37mtnygardThe error didn‚Äôt come through though.#2016-10-0314:37ulone second, will put it into gist, too big to flood the chat#2016-10-0314:37mtnygardOK#2016-10-0314:39mtnygardThat is a sizeable error all right.#2016-10-0314:39ulEssentially it is Caused by: org.xnio.channels.FixedLengthOverflowException: null#2016-10-0314:39ulWould you mind explaining me? I'm lost honestly speaking#2016-10-0314:40ulI plan to use this proxy endpoint to convey images to my app's canvas. To allow canvas to be snapshotted they must come from my domain, thus need for proxy#2016-10-0314:40mtnygardI‚Äôm looking at the stack trace, and I notice Undertow in the mix.#2016-10-0314:41mtnygardCould you try the same thing with Jetty as the container? Just to see if it‚Äôs specific to Undertow#2016-10-0314:41ulyes, i use io.pedestal/pedestal.immutant#2016-10-0314:41uljust a sec#2016-10-0314:43mtnygardOK, that helps a lot.#2016-10-0314:43mtnygardI think the issue is that when you do (select-keys) from the Google response, you‚Äôre picking up the Content-Length header. But the body is somehow now exactly the same length.#2016-10-0314:44mtnygardThat‚Äôs what those errors each indicate in their own special way.#2016-10-0314:44mtnygardJust that Content-Length doesn‚Äôt match the number of bytes sent#2016-10-0314:44ulAha! Not obvious... Thank you very much! I think I can just drop that header?#2016-10-0314:44mtnygardI think so. The server should fill it in for you#2016-10-0314:45mtnygardI‚Äôd be concerned about some of the other headers that Google offers‚Ä¶ like the privacy policy. IDK if it‚Äôs legit to just pass that along.#2016-10-0314:45mtnygardBut it should work for your images.#2016-10-0314:46ulperhaps the best would be to define whitelist of headers safe to pass, like content-type#2016-10-0314:46ulthank you very much!#2016-10-0314:46mtnygardThat makes sense#2016-10-0314:46mtnygardyw#2016-10-0315:21mtnygardNew doc published. Covers error handling and the pattern-matching error-dispatch macro.#2016-10-0315:21mtnygardhttp://pedestal.io/reference/error-handling#2016-10-0315:21mtnygardAs always, I welcome bug reports and pull requests.#2016-10-0315:23grzmthat looks really useful. It should go to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj now#2016-10-0713:19mtnygardDo you recall which page that link was on?#2016-10-0713:22mtnygardAh, I think I‚Äôve found it. From the ‚Äúservice-interceptors.md‚Äù page, right?#2016-10-0713:22chrisetheridgeyeah this one, sorry, https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-interceptors.md#2016-10-0713:23mtnygardThanks. I will fix that.#2016-10-0713:24chrisetheridgethanks so much!#2016-10-0713:25chrisetheridgeah thank you for the original link#2016-10-0713:27chrisetheridge@mtnygard so is this the inteceptor being spoken about: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L410#2016-10-0713:28mtnygardYes, but it‚Äôs no longer a useful example of adding interceptors, because there are a couple levels of indirection still inside that interceptor.#2016-10-0713:30chrisetheridgeah. is there another newer example?#2016-10-0713:30mtnygardI‚Äôm digging up a link to the API you need for that.#2016-10-0713:30chrisetheridgebasically, we‚Äôd like to drop some interceptors on the route health-check#2016-10-0713:30chrisetheridgeperfect, thank you so much!#2016-10-0713:30mtnygardhttp://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.interceptor/io.pedestal.interceptor.chain.html#var-enqueue#2016-10-0713:30mtnygardBasically, you just call enqueue with the current context and the new interceptors you want to add to the stack#2016-10-0713:31chrisetheridgeokay great. seems simple enough. thank you for the help#2016-10-0713:32mtnygardyw#2016-10-0715:31si14interceptors are basically in every project that I like ‚Äî pedestal, re-frame, Netty (they don't call 'em interceptors, but they are) :)#2016-10-1318:01juliobarrosFrom the guides page http://pedestal.io/guides/developing-at-the-repl 404s. Does that guide still exist?#2016-10-1320:37mtnygard@juliobarros It is under development. You can look at https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/pull/37 for the current draft and discussion.#2016-10-1320:37mtnygardAnd a quicker view of the content. https://github.com/christianromney/docs/blob/eb63b2fc8b2bbfd43424f353604f6fe7a48d56f7/content/guides/developing-at-the-repl.adoc#2016-10-1320:37mtnygardThanks to @christianromney for drafting this one!#2016-10-1320:38juliobarros@mtnygard: thanks!#2016-10-1321:21christianromneyPaul had some great feedback for me that I plan to incorporate soon. If you have anything else to add, please feel free to let me know#2016-10-1721:13eric.vieiraHi, I`m trying to send a request with a :delete params and :body. however, don`t acess body in interception and handler before it changes to table-routes.#2016-10-1721:14eric.vieiraexample: 
(response-for test-utils/service :delete  ‚Äú/entity"  :body  ‚Äú‚Ä¶.‚Äù)

(def routes
  (table/table-routes
    {}
    [
     ["/‚Äú :post (public-interceptors home-page) :route-name :main]
     ["/" :delete (auth-interceptors delete-entidade) :route-name :main-delete]
]
    )
  )
#2016-10-1721:18mtnygardThat part looks OK. What is in the auth-interceptors function?#2016-10-1721:19eric.vieiralist of intercpetors#2016-10-1721:20mtnygardDoes that list include the interceptor returned from the body-params function?#2016-10-1721:20eric.vieira(defn auth-interceptors [handler] [ error-handler/interceptor-error-handler (body-params/body-params) {:name :json-body :enter nil :leave parser/json->body} {:name ::auth :enter auth/token->auth :leave auth/auth->token} {:name :json-edn :enter parser/json->edn :leave parser/edn->json} handler] )#2016-10-1721:21eric.vieirathe problem is not acess body in request :delete .. in :post it is OK#2016-10-1721:23mtnygardAnd you are not doing anything to set the Content-Type header on the test requests, right?#2016-10-1721:24eric.vieirano set#2016-10-1721:24mtnygardI'm going to make a quick test app and see what's going on. I'll be back in a few minutes.#2016-10-1721:25eric.vieiraok#2016-10-1721:26eric.vieirafind error.. miss set :headers {"Content-Type" "application/json"}#2016-10-1721:26eric.vieirathanks#2016-10-1721:26mtnygardI'm glad you found the problem!#2016-10-1819:12scott.haleenIs there a sample of how to handle fileupload or just multipart/form-data with pedestal?#2016-10-1819:13mtnygardThere was some discussion of this in https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/444#2016-10-1819:13mtnygard(At my fingertips because I'm working on a doc that should incorporate that info. Like right now.)#2016-10-1819:13mtnygardüôÇ#2016-10-1819:14souenzzoHello! How do I handle internal erros(exceptions)? curl '' returns text/plain 500 Internal server error Internally: clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Interceptor Exception: URLDecoder: Incomplete trailing escape (%) pattern Can I intercept/handle this to make a custon response?#2016-10-1819:14scott.haleenawesome thanks, I will check that out#2016-10-1819:14mtnygardHi @souenzzo. You sure can. Take a look at http://pedestal.io/reference/error-handling and let me know if it tells you what you need to know.#2016-10-1819:15souenzzoIt seems that this happens before this interceptor#2016-10-1819:17souenzzoMy :else dosen't get this except....#2016-10-1819:17mtnygardWhich :else would that be?#2016-10-1819:20souenzzoMy :else on io.pedestal.interceptor.error/error-dispatch macro. I'ts my first interceptor on (def r table-routes [["/query" :get [err-interceptor query] :route-name :query])#2016-10-1819:21mtnygardInteresting! Give me a minute to try to replicate that.#2016-10-1819:27mtnygardI can definitely reproduce the problem. Looking into a solution now.#2016-10-1819:31souenzzoOn my example is missing the ?. minimal example shoud be localhost/?%#2016-10-1819:38mtnygardOK, I've got an explanation and a solution for you. Which would you like to have first? üôÇ#2016-10-1819:39mtnygardIn the interest of time, I'll start with the solution.#2016-10-1819:39mtnygard1. Instead of putting the error handling in your routes, you will need to have it come early in the chain of interceptors. Before the router, in fact. The way to do this is as follows:#2016-10-1819:40mtnygard- Call io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors with your service map. The result will be a service map with the default interceptors attached.#2016-10-1819:40mtnygard- Prepend your error handler to the :io.pedestal.http/interceptors key in the service map.#2016-10-1819:40mtnygard- Call create-servlet or create-server as normal. The default interceptors will not be appended a second time.#2016-10-1819:41mtnygard2. Explanation: the exception is happening before a route is selected by the router. Thus, your error handling interceptor never gets pushed onto the stack.#2016-10-1819:41mtnygardAs an aside: I'll be updating the error handling reference to cover this case.#2016-10-1821:28mtnygardNew reference document drafted: parameters (query params, body params, and path params)#2016-10-1821:28mtnygardhttp://pedestal.io/reference/parameters#2016-10-1821:28mtnygardThere's a heading that says "placeholder" in there... a commit that removes it is working its way through Travis right now.#2016-10-1910:21rauhSo url-for-routes omits trailing / which are part of my URL. Is this intentional or a bug?#2016-10-1914:34mtnygard@rauh#2016-10-1914:35mtnygard@rauh Interesting... I think that has to do with the path parsing. The trailing / probably gets turned into an empty string in the route's :path-parts. Running a check to verify that now.#2016-10-1914:38mtnygard@rauh Nope, I was wrong. The trailing slash gets elided completely when parsing the route. So by the time you call url-for-routes, there's nothing there to represent that slash.#2016-10-1914:40rauh@mtnygard If it matters: I'm using the new/fast MapRouter#2016-10-1914:41mtnygardI don't think that matters, but I will double-check.#2016-10-1914:42mtnygardOK, so I just confirmed. The router doesn't affect url-for-routes. Which route syntax are you using?#2016-10-1915:22rauh
((router/url-for-routes
   (table/table-routes
     [["/api/"
       :get identity
       :route-name :x]]))
  :x)
;; => "/api"
#2016-10-1915:23rauh@mtnygard ^#2016-10-1915:23mtnygardI would bet that matches on both ‚Äú/api/‚Äú and ‚Äú/api"#2016-10-1915:23rauhNope, 404's#2016-10-1915:24mtnygardHuh. OK.#2016-10-1915:24mtnygardCan you paste the value that table/table-routes returns?#2016-10-1915:24rauh
=> ({:path "/api/", :method :get, :path-re #"/\Qapi\E", :path-parts ["api"], :interceptors [#Interceptor{:name }], :route-name :x, :path-params []})
#2016-10-1915:25mtnygardone sec.#2016-10-1915:26mtnygardOK, now I see what‚Äôs going on. The map-tree router uses :path to match, whereas the prefix-tree and linear-search use :path-re#2016-10-1915:27mtnygardBut url-for-routes reconstructs the path from :path-parts.#2016-10-1915:27mtnygardI‚Äôd definitely call this a bug.#2016-10-1915:27rauhI see. Thanks for checking, should I report?#2016-10-1915:27mtnygardPlease do!#2016-10-1915:27rauhok#2016-10-1915:28mtnygardI can‚Äôt think of a workaround at the moment. How important is that trailing slash to you? üôÇ#2016-10-1916:05rauhI just wrapped it and added a slash üôÇ#2016-10-1916:05rauhNot important, only for my tests...#2016-10-2418:23crimeministerHi folks, does anyone have an example of a trivial or small Pedestal app using component?#2016-10-2419:58mtnygard@crimeminister You are in luck: http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component#2016-10-2420:38crimeminister!!!#2016-10-2420:38crimeministerExcuse me while I wipe the egg off my face‚Ä¶#2016-10-2420:39mtnygardHope it helps.#2016-10-2420:50crimeministerMuch appreciated#2016-10-2421:46hagmonkI'm going a bit mad here with pedestal, I must be doing something wrong#2016-10-2421:47mtnygardYou just caught me before heading out the door. Whatcha got?#2016-10-2421:47hagmonkCaused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No matching ctor found for class io.pedestal.interceptor.helpers$before$fn__23165#2016-10-2421:47hagmonkI'll try to be quick :)(#2016-10-2421:47hagmonküôÇ#2016-10-2421:47hagmonkthrown when I tried to start a debug repl in IntelliJ#2016-10-2421:48hagmonkit's making me wonder if I've deviated from some normal way the pedestal namespaces are imported#2016-10-2421:49mtnygardHmm... it doesn't look like a require problem. It looks like what happens when a macro emits a function value.#2016-10-2421:49mtnygardAre you wrapping anything with macros? Or syntax-quoting your routes, maybe?#2016-10-2421:50hagmonkNo I tried to steer away from the syntax quoting approach#2016-10-2421:50hagmonk
(defroutes
  routes
  [[["/__health" {:get health}]
    ["/api"
     ^:interceptors [auth/configure-authentication auth/check-authentication]
     ["/test" {:get echo}]
     ["/keyword-demo" {:get keyword-demo-route}]]]])
#2016-10-2421:51mtnygardThat seems OK at first glance.#2016-10-2421:51mtnygardCan you paste in the code where you're calling defbefore?#2016-10-2421:52hagmonkThis is all WIP code so forgive weirdness#2016-10-2421:52hagmonk
(defbefore
  check-authentication
  [{:keys [request auth-backends] :as context}]
  (let [req (apply authentication-request request auth-backends)]
    (if (:identity req)
      (assoc context :request req)
      (-> context
          terminate
          (assoc :response {:status 401
                            :body {:message "Unauthorized"}
                            :headers {"WWW-Authenticate" (format "Basic realm=\"%s\"" "Blip")}})))))
#2016-10-2421:53hagmonkbasically I'm wiring up buddy-sign to do JWT authentication with a fallback to LDAP#2016-10-2421:53mtnygardAnd if you comment that out, can you load the namespace?#2016-10-2421:53hagmonkI bet so, but let me confirm#2016-10-2421:56hagmonkYep if I commented out those defbefores it started working. What's weird is that they were working in regular REPL, when I switched to debug REPL that's when they started barfing#2016-10-2421:56mtnygardMy advice would be to rework it from using defbefore. Hang on one minute and I'll show you an example.#2016-10-2421:57hagmonkYah! I wanted to use plain data structures but kept barking my shins on those too üôÇ#2016-10-2421:58mtnygard
(def check-authentication
  {::check-authentication
   :enter
   (fn [{:keys [request auth-backends] :as context}]
     (let [req (apply authentication-request request auth-backends)]
       (if (:identity req)
         (assoc context :request req)
         (-> context
            terminate
            (assoc :response {:status 401
                            :body {:message "Unauthorized"}
                            :headers {"WWW-Authenticate" (format "Basic realm=\"%s\"" "Blip")}}
)))))})
#2016-10-2421:58mtnygardI'm not 100% sure I got the close parens right. I don't have a repl up right now.#2016-10-2421:58mtnygardThis actually removes 2 layers of wrapped macros.#2016-10-2421:59hagmonkfantastic#2016-10-2421:59hagmonkwell, I will continue poking at this and let you get out that door üôÇ super helpful, thanks so much#2016-10-2421:59mtnygardyw. If you still have trouble, send me a direct message and I'll look at it later on.#2016-10-2522:32tetriscodesIs it counterproductive to make to try and make pedestal route handlers components?#2016-10-2522:34tetriscodesI‚Äôm wanting to make a component that can have a database and mqtt client passed in and if specific HTTP routes get hit, it can write to the database and then put a message on an mqtt channel#2016-10-2522:36tetriscodes(def routes (clojure.set/union #{} foo/routes-with-deps-injected))#2016-10-2522:43donaldballI have one router component that builds the route handlers, passing in the required components#2016-10-2522:44donaldballI have thought about going the next step and having each router handler be its own component and take advantage of the component machinery for dependency graphs, but it felt like too much work for too little payoff in my case#2016-10-2522:50tetriscodesDo you have a snippet?#2016-10-2522:50tetriscodesDo you have your routes nested in a subsystem that gets built on start?#2016-10-2523:29christianromney@tetriscodes have a look at this code https://github.com/pointslope/elements/blob/master/src/pointslope/elements/pedestal.clj#L68-L95 The idea is that any components that the Pedestal component depends on are automatically added to the request map by the using-component interceptor.#2016-10-2523:31christianromneyif this is my system definition:#2016-10-2523:32christianromneyyou can see that the Pedestal component depends on :config#2016-10-2523:33christianromneyif I then add the interceptor (using-component :config) to one of my routes, then the handler for that route will find the :config key on the request map with a reference to the configurator component#2016-10-2523:34christianromneyusing this scheme you can expose any component to your handlers (via the request map) simply by making the pedestal component depend on it.#2016-10-2523:35christianromneythis is not "the one true way" to do what you want, but it is "a way" to do so...#2016-10-2523:57tetriscodes@christianromney thank you. I will take a look#2016-10-2601:27donaldballMy route handler ctors are more explicit about their requirements, expecting them to be passed in individually. I like this for the clarity about who depends on what, and to make it easier to provide alternate route handlers when a component happens to not be available.#2016-11-0223:53grantIs there a good way to accept :origin nil on a particular route? Specifically, I wanted to give an AWS ELB a path to do health checks on. Something like /api/heath-check.#2016-11-0302:46jimmydoes anyone here has used clojure pedestal with google cloud endpoints ?#2016-11-0302:50grantI'm pretty new to building web stuff, so please forgive the possibly silly question. What do you mean by "clojure endpoints"?#2016-11-0302:51jimmy@grant Sorry, I meant google cloud endpoints#2016-11-0302:53grantAh, that makes more sense. But no, haven't looked at any of the google stuff I'm afraid.#2016-11-0302:58jimmyyeah, it's pretty much like swagger, it helps us generating a json which is a description of the service, then we can generate client api ( ios, android , web ) based on it. And I find it's faster to use google cloud endpoints than using swagger ( in terms of hosting services ourselves )#2016-11-0303:05grantOh, that is cool. I tried using swagger-api with pedestal, but found that it seemed to get in the way more than it helped.#2016-11-0303:07grantPlus I'm not exposing anything for direct access by anyone else, so there wasn't much advantage except for some pretty docs.#2016-11-0303:20jimmytrue#2016-11-0314:39mtnygardHi @grant, late response b/c I was traveling. When you say :origin nil are you talking about a header?#2016-11-0314:58grantHi Michael. Yes, that is what I was talking about. And I actually figured out what I was trying to do. Just adding the route worked. Though I am still curious if it is possible to do per route origin checking.#2016-11-0315:31mtnygardI don't think there's a direct way to do it in the current routers. There are a couple of ways to solve the problem. They just take a bit more work.#2016-11-0315:32mtnygard1. You could create an "origin router". It would sit in front of two or more regular routers. Instead of looking at the path in the request, it would look at the origin then enqueue one of the other routers. This would work best if you've got several routes that should be treated differently based on origin.#2016-11-0315:33mtnygard2. You could create an origin interceptor. Your router would direct all requests for /api/health-check to the same interceptor vector, but if the origin doesn't match, then the origin interceptor can terminate the request. That would return a 404 exactly as if the route didn't exist.#2016-11-0315:36grantCool. Thanks for taking the time to answer my question. And the new pedestal docs you've been writing have been helpful too, they are appreciated.#2016-11-0323:28grantThis is a rather tangential pedestal question, but not sure there is a better place to ask it. Does anyone know if there are still plans for Paul deGrandis' Vase library to ever make it out into the wild?#2016-11-0421:54mtnygard@grant I can answer that with a "for now" tacked on to the end.#2016-11-0421:55mtnygardWe're using it on three client projects that are hitting production soon. It's working pretty well. So in that sense, it is in the wild. I suspect you mean open-source though. At this time we are not open sourcing Vase.#2016-11-0423:00grant@mtnygard That is pretty much the answer I was expecting, though I was hoping for a different one. üôÇ Thanks for removing the doubt for me, though.#2016-11-0521:55kirill.salykincomponent#2016-11-0714:57crimeminister@grant As someone who was pretty blown away by the talk he did on that approach to API development I would be interested in the answer as well#2016-11-0714:59crimeministerWould love to have that sort of capability available as an Arachne module/plugin#2016-11-0715:01crimeministerAnyone know of any similar projects, by the way? The only thing that springs to mind as remotely comparable is liberator#2016-11-0823:09semperostrying to wire up a StatsD reporter for use with Pedestal‚Äôs built-in metrics; I‚Äôm seeing StatsD report bad lines, as in:

(defn http-test-trigger [triggercomp context]
  (check-value triggercomp (:json-params context))
  (ring-resp/response {:response "success"}))

(defn- routes [triggercomp]
    #{["/api/triggers" :get
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `http-get)]
      ["/api/triggers/:id" :get
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `http-get-trigger)]
      ["/api/triggers/:id" :put
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `http-put-trigger)]
      ["/api/triggers" :post
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `http-post-trigger)]
      ["/api/triggers/:id" :delete
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `http-delete-trigger)]
      ["/api/triggers/check" :post
       (conj intercept/common-interceptors `(partial http-test-trigger triggercomp))]})
#2016-11-1721:25tetriscodesAnyone know why I can‚Äôt put a partial as a route handler?#2016-11-1721:28tetriscodesIf I just use `http-test-trigger and remove the first component argument it works fine#2016-11-1721:45ddeaguiar@tetriscodes You can use a partial but you need to specify a :route-name. I just did a quick test with a new pedestal app generated via lein#2016-11-1721:46ddeaguiarhope that helps#2016-11-1721:49ddeaguiaroh, looking more closely at the code you posted, you need wouldn't quote the partial. I think that's the problem in your example. That and the lack of a :route-name#2016-11-1721:49ddeaguiarThe other routes will use the name of the quoted fn by default#2016-11-1721:49tetriscodesIts the lack of route name#2016-11-1721:49tetriscodestwo different errors#2016-11-1721:50tetriscodesThanks for the snippet#2016-11-1721:50ddeaguiarSure, you had to unquote as well, right?#2016-11-1721:50tetriscodesYes#2016-11-1721:50ddeaguiarok, makes sense.#2016-11-1721:50ddeaguiarGlad to help üôÇ#2016-11-1816:14scott.haleenI asked this on SO as well http://stackoverflow.com/questions/40681590/clojure-pedestal-root-serving-as-application-octet-stream#2016-11-1819:18christianromneyyou should add at least a default "/" route and you can use the resource interceptor#2016-11-1819:20christianromneyhttp://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.service/io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares.html#2016-11-1819:22christianromneyhttp://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.service/io.pedestal.http.html#var-html-body#2016-11-1819:50scott.haleenI added (def routes (route/expand-routes [[["/" ^:interceptors [http/html-body]]]])) but the behavior is still the same#2016-11-2121:46mrcnci‚Äôm getting this error when trying to build an uberjar Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No matching ctor found for class io.pedestal.interceptor.helpers$before$fn__1340#2016-11-2121:47mrcncthe thing that‚Äôs confusing me is that i‚Äôm not even using the before helper#2016-11-2121:50mtnygard@mrcnc I can help, but will need to look at some code with you. Can you share it here or would you prefer to go to a private chat?#2016-11-2121:50mrcnci can share here‚Ä¶what do you need?#2016-11-2121:50mtnygardHow many namespaces do you have in the uberjar?#2016-11-2121:52mrcnclooks like 30#2016-11-2121:52mtnygardHmm. Too many to go through right here.#2016-11-2121:53mrcncwhat namespaces are you talking about? pedestal namespaces or for my app?#2016-11-2121:54mtnygardYour app.#2016-11-2121:54mtnygardSomething in one of them is expanding out to a before or defbefore call at compilation time.#2016-11-2121:55mtnygardThat "no matching ctor" message is what happens when there's a function value emitted as code from a macro. Often due to misplaced quoting.#2016-11-2121:55mtnygardLet's take a look at the namespace with your routes first.#2016-11-2121:58mrcncmy routes are spread over a few namespaces#2016-11-2122:00mtnygardWould you try something for me? Convert the defhandler into just defn on authenticate-user and authorize-user.#2016-11-2122:01mrcncok#2016-11-2122:02ddeaguiarPiggybacking on @mtnygard's suggestion, I'll add that you should avoid using helpers like defhandler because they can lead to weird compilation issues.#2016-11-2122:02ddeaguiarThey're still around for backwards compatibility#2016-11-2122:06ddeaguiarfns can be used as handlers because they extent the IntoInterceptor protocol (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj#L33). This means that your usage of defhandler isn't buying you anything over defn.#2016-11-2122:08mrcncso mtnygard that worked! and thx for the tip @ddeaguiar#2016-11-2122:08ddeaguiarUnfortunately I don't think the docs are very clear about staying away from some of the helpers.#2016-11-2122:08mrcnci think i‚Äôll go refactor all of my usages of defhandler now#2016-11-2122:08mtnygardCool. I've run into trouble with macros and AOT many times before. Uberjar often hits AOT so I had a hunch.#2016-11-2122:08mtnygard@ddeaguiar Would you be willing to file an issue on that?#2016-11-2122:08ddeaguiarStay away from any helpers built using defsimpleinterceptordef.#2016-11-2122:09ddeaguiarSure#2016-11-2122:39donaldballI build all my routes and interceptors at system start time, not at compile time. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs pedestal‚Äôs recommended approach, but I find it much easier to reason about.#2016-11-2123:22ddeaguiaropened https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/483#2016-11-2211:14jimmyhi guys, in pedestal doesn't route /* hits / as well. I have route declaration as /* and it only works with /<something-here> and it doesn't work with /#2016-11-2219:34ddeaguiar@nxqd that's not what I would expect but is how Pedestal behaves. I can't comment on whether this is by design or not.#2016-11-2219:45mtnygard@nxqd @ddeaguiar Does the behavior vary with different routers?#2016-11-2219:51ddeaguiarI had run a quick test across different routers and observed the same behavior#2016-11-2219:59ddeaguiarAlthough I find this behavior odd: 
(def rs (route/expand-routes #{["/*"
                                :get
                                [(fn [req] "test")]
                                :route-name ::test]}))

(route/try-routing-for rs :linear-search "/foo" :get) ;; => nil
#2016-11-2220:00ddeaguiarwhereas a different router finds a match#2016-11-2220:01ddeaguiarI guess the :linear-search router does not support *? I've not looked through the source#2016-11-2300:12jimmy@ddeaguiar @mtnygard Thanks for collaborating on this.Can you guys recommend the best way to design this route, this is what I have tried, and of course it does have problem regarding conflicted routing ( /api and /* ) : 
(defn routes
  [interceptor]
  (route/expand-routes
   `[[["/" {:get index-page}
       ^:interceptors [bootstrap/html-body ~interceptor]
       ["/api" {:post omnext-service}
          ^:interceptors [iinterceptor/om-body-params iinterceptor/om-response]]
       ["/*" {:get index-page}
        ^:interceptors [bootstrap/html-body ~interceptor]]]]]))
#2016-11-2313:18mtnygard@nxqd I've found a way to get what you want. Demonstration at https://gist.github.com/mtnygard/9f77639865592608ed3aa87a42191468#2016-11-2313:19mtnygardThe key here is to use the :not-found-interceptor instead of a wildcard route.#2016-11-2313:33jimmy@mtnygard that's neat, nice tips üòÑ. Thanks#2016-12-0114:59fatihict@mtnygard I'd like to thank you on the pedestal guides. They really helped me a lot üôÇ#2016-12-0121:44mtnygard@fatihict: I'm glad they are helpful! What other guides would be useful?#2016-12-0211:28fatihictI think the setup of the guides is really good. Some guides and/or sections already have a title, but are not written yet. I think those would be useful aswell. If I can help out by reading a draft of new docs I will gladly help.#2016-12-1123:38hagmonkpardon the crosspost from #clojurescript, but is anyone using pedestal with boot-reload? I‚Äôm trying but failing to make these two things work together#2016-12-1708:57jimmyhi guys, is there any good tutorial running pedestal on google app engine ?#2016-12-1904:25jimmyI just found out that pedestal does modify threads and google app engine does have some limitation on modifying thread, we have to use google thread lib instead. This is troublesome -_-#2016-12-2004:16joshjonesHow is an interceptor fundamentally different from a handler, other than the format of "context" versus "request/response"?#2016-12-2004:17joshjonesMy service needs to make a call to another service which could take anywhere from 500ms to 1000ms, and I want to go async instead of blocking and tying up threads. Should the call to the 3rd party service go in an interceptor, or in the handler?#2016-12-2014:13ddeaguiar@joshjones Handlers are special case interceptors that operate on request maps and return response maps. I typically create Interceptors for things like validation and any other pre-processing needed for request handling. Refer to http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors for more info#2016-12-2014:17ddeaguiarIf the implementation requires some sort of post processing (i.e., transformation, etc...) I'd probably implement the 3rd party call in an interceptor, put the result on the request map and perform the transform of the result in a handler.#2016-12-2014:18ddeaguiarUsing channels for async#2016-12-2014:18ddeaguiarI'd also prefer thread vs the go macro because the backing thread pool used by the go macro is limited#2016-12-2014:19ddeaguiarHope this helps!#2016-12-2014:25kirill.salykin@ddeaguiar is it possible to share such interceptors (validation etc)?#2016-12-2014:25kirill.salykin@ddeaguiar I mean, can you please share them? üôÇ#2016-12-2014:26ddeaguiarI can create an example if I don't have any I can share#2016-12-2014:27ddeaguiarBut think of it this way, these are the same operations you'd perform in ring middleware#2016-12-2014:27ddeaguiarThe neat thing about interceptors is that you have access to the interceptor chain and you can manipulate it#2016-12-2014:27ddeaguiardynamically add/remove interceptors#2016-12-2014:27ddeaguiarYou can't do that with ring middleware#2016-12-2014:33ddeaguiar@kirill.salykin The Pedestal docs site includes an example of an interceptor that performs request pre-processing (http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors). The db-interceptor associates a db to the request. In that example, the database value is stored elsewhere in a global var.#2016-12-2014:34ddeaguiarattach-database provides a similar example#2016-12-2014:46kirill.salykinI am just looking for the good intereceptor + validation db interceptor seems simplier to me üôÇ#2016-12-2014:46kirill.salykinwould really approciate if you can share it with me#2016-12-2014:47ddeaguiarOk, I'll dig something up and ping you sometime near EOD EST#2016-12-2014:48kirill.salykinnot urgent#2016-12-2014:48kirill.salykinthanks a lot!#2016-12-2014:49lellisHi everybody, im gonna start implement security in my pedestal app, is friend the best framework to do that?#2016-12-2015:02ddeaguiar@lellis check out https://github.com/propan/geheimtur or https://github.com/funcool/buddy#2016-12-2015:02ddeaguiarI've had good experiences with both using Pedestal#2016-12-2016:23joshjonesThank you @ddeaguiar for the info. Since the 3rd party request will take maybe 500ms and our processing will take significantly less time (probably 30-50ms max), it somehow feels strange to put the 3rd party request in an interceptor, when it will take much longer than the actual handler ‚Äî but it‚Äôs what makes sense, I think, if I‚Äôm reading you correctly.#2016-12-2016:26ddeaguiarI think you can do it in a handler. Just return a channel#2016-12-2016:26joshjonesPotentially dumb question about pedestal ‚Äî since the handler is the last ‚Äúinterceptor‚Äù to run, and it takes a request and returns a response, how to I do post-processing on the request? The interceptors seem to be pre-processing, but they work with context maps, and the handler works with req/resp maps. So how can I post-process the response map?#2016-12-2016:26ddeaguiarInterceptors support :enter and :leave operations#2016-12-2016:26mtnygard@ddeaguiar @joshjones Handlers can't return channels, but interceptors can.#2016-12-2016:27mtnygardThe channel must deliver exactly one context map.#2016-12-2016:27ddeaguiar@mtnygard ah, thanks. Was fuzzy on that.#2016-12-2016:27mtnygardAfter the context map is delivered, then the rest of the :leave functions will be called as normal#2016-12-2016:27joshjonesBut I thought the :leave operation accepts a context map, and returns a context map ‚Äî not a request or response map#2016-12-2016:28mtnygard@joshjones That's right. When a handler returns a response map, Pedestal just attaches that response map to the context map, then starts calling the :leave functions with the updated context map.#2016-12-2016:28joshjonesFantastic, that clear it up, thanks @mtnygard#2016-12-2016:29mtnygardYou're welcome!#2016-12-2016:29joshjonesOur app currently serves a few thousand requests per second, and I‚Äôm trying to improve latency by going async and hopefully pedestal will help with that ‚Äî I think the best thing for me to do here is to write a simple app that utilizes the functionality of some of these pieces, and then I‚Äôll be better informed to ask questions üôÇ#2016-12-2016:31mtnygardJust keep in mind that there are two ways to return a channel:#2016-12-2016:31mtnygard1. If the interceptor returns a channel instead of a context map, then that channel can only deliver 1 value, which must be the new context map. That's the "async" case.#2016-12-2016:32mtnygard2. If the interceptor returns a context map with a response whose body is a channel, every value delivered by that channel is streamed to the caller. That's the "streaming" case.#2016-12-2016:32mtnygardYour description sounds like the async case, so you're on the right track.#2016-12-2016:39joshjonesexcellent, I will use that as a guide :thumbsup::skin-tone-2:#2016-12-2019:33marciolHi guys, I saw that are several ways of building routes on pedestal, this could be verified on this test file: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/test/io/pedestal/http/route_test.clj#2016-12-2019:34marciolSo my question is, how I choose the better way to express the routes of an application, is there a guideline?#2016-12-2020:01mtnygardHi @marciol! The different flavors of routing syntax are there because we've had some "evolution" over time. The "verbose" syntax is not something that anyone should write by hand. It is the most expanded form, mainly intended for internal use by the routers. The "terse" syntax is good if you need to express a deep tree of routes and you want to take advantage of "inheritance" down the tree for interceptors. For most uses, I would steer you toward the "table" syntax. It is the easiest to read and write, at the cost of some redundancy from row to row.#2016-12-2020:03marciolHi @mtnygard my gut feeling sayings that the table syntax is better for most cases, thanks#2016-12-2020:04mtnygardWell, speaking as the person who designed the table syntax, I'm happy to hear that!#2016-12-2020:05marciolgreat!#2016-12-2113:44andrewhrI‚Äôm a big fan of the terse syntax, but I confess it is not the friendliest one for newcomers. Take time to grasp the ‚Äúvector of vectors of vectors‚Äù thing#2016-12-2114:16marciolindentation could help in this case#2016-12-2118:57joshjonesSo I can create a new pedestal project in lein using lein new pedestal-service abc. In that template, the -main function calls server/start with runnable-service, which calls server/create-server, which gives the service-map to create-provider, which gives the service-map to default-interceptors. In default-interceptors, there are default interceptors defined, for example, the not-found interceptor. What if I wanted to have NO not-found interceptor? For a custom one, I‚Äôd just specify it in the service map and it would be the one used, but if I wanted to eliminate some interceptors from the default that I felt I didn‚Äôt need? Can I build my interceptor list from scratch? Would I then call create-server? @mtnygard#2016-12-2118:59mtnygard@joshjones You can definitely build the interceptor list from scratch. http://pedestal.io/reference/default-interceptors shows all the interceptors that get created for you. You're welcome to construct them directly and set the :io.pedestal.http/interceptors key on your service map before calling create-server#2016-12-2921:16ewenHi, when closing a channel returned by an asynchronous interceptor (instead of putting a well formed context in the channel), the interceptor chain hangs, the socket is not closed and no response is returned to the client. Should this be considered a bug ?#2016-12-3103:43mtnygardHi @ewen. I would call that a bug. IMO that should be treated as either a 404 or a 500.#2016-12-3113:12ewen@mtnygard ok I will open a issue for this#2017-01-0918:24bostonaholicare people building web applications with pedestal and deploying to heroku?#2017-01-0918:24bostonaholicis so, any resources you can point me to would be fantastic!#2017-01-1005:32mavbozo@bostonaholic you just deploy pedestal web application as uberjar. here's the doc https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/deploying-clojure-applications-with-the-heroku-leiningen-plugin#2017-01-1005:33bostonaholicthanks @mavbozo#2017-01-1005:34bostonaholicI don't know why I thought a pedestal app would be any different#2017-01-1117:21curtosisPoking my head in after being away for a long while ‚Ä¶ what‚Äôs happening in pedestal-land these days?#2017-01-1121:03rafaelzlisboais there any way to test SSE on pedestal using the io.pedestal.test the tooling?#2017-01-1301:54mtnygard@curtosis Depending on when you last used it, the big story is probably breaking out some parts so they could be used independently of the web framework. E.g., interceptors can now be used in any Clojure application. Pedestal has also grown logging and metrics in recent times. Oh, and 0.5.2 was released today.#2017-01-1301:55mtnygardRelease notes: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/releases#2017-01-1301:55mtnygard@rafaelzlisboa: I don't think io.pedestal.test offers anything for SSE#2017-01-1301:55mtnygardSorry. :-(#2017-01-1313:07martinklepschWhen using interceptors, would it be an anti-pattern to add stuff to the beginning of the queue by recreating it with existing items at the end?#2017-01-1313:18martinklepschI have a situation where I want to do thing A or thing B based on the resulting context from a previous interceptor basically#2017-01-1313:52mavbozo@martinklepsch i don't understand your first sentence but I have made a authenticate-interceptor-->authorize-interceptor chain where I put user data in context inside authenticate-interceptor and the authorize interceptor do things differently based on the rule and user data put by the previous (authenticate) interceptor#2017-01-1313:55curtosis@mtnygard thanks ‚Ä¶ I think I last played with it a few months after the app side went away. So it‚Äôs been a while. üôÇ#2017-01-1314:13martinklepsch@mavbozo What you‚Äôre describing is Interceptor A influencing the behavior of interceptor B. What I‚Äôm trying to figure out is how the result of Interceptor A could influence wether interceptor B or interceptor C is used.#2017-01-1314:14martinklepsch> When using interceptors, would it be an anti-pattern to add stuff to the beginning of the queue by recreating it with existing items at the end? Agreed that this probably wasn‚Äôt very clear. üôÇ The ::queue in the interceptor context is a FIFO queue which means I can‚Äôt add things to the beginning without recreating it completely (I think). Does that make it any clearer?#2017-01-1314:15kirill.salykinas far as I know you can change interceptors queue, similar to what router currently doing#2017-01-1314:15kirill.salykinroutes is interceptor, which updates interceptor queue#2017-01-1314:17kirill.salykinI dont understand this, but maybe it can help you: https://gist.github.com/ohpauleez/15522bc408d8e09cd7657dd768643a5f#2017-01-1314:21martinklepschYou‚Äôre right about the router modifying the queue but it adds interceptors to the end of it not to the beginning#2017-01-1314:22kirill.salykinoh, you want o insert interceptors BEFORE currect?#2017-01-1314:22rafaelzlisboa@mtnygard thanks for replying! do you know what‚Äôs the most common way to test it, even if not using the mock requests from io.pedestal.test?#2017-01-1314:23martinklepsch@kirill.salykin yes#2017-01-1314:24martinklepschI think would get it working so I‚Äôm mostly wondering if I‚Äôm setting myself up for failure with this kind of thing#2017-01-1314:25kirill.salykinmaybe you can always have these intercepters, but they will work only in case of some attr attached to context map? (I assume you want them triggered in :leave state)?#2017-01-1314:27martinklepschyes that would be a workaround but it reminds me a lot of GOTO üòÑ#2017-01-1314:28martinklepsch(I want them triggered in :enter but I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs too important‚Ä¶ not using them in the context of HTTP reqs)#2017-01-1314:28kirill.salykinyes, workaround looks a little like GOTO#2017-01-1314:58martinklepschPosted to the mailinglist: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pedestal-users/j4Sbjmw2cd4#2017-01-1315:01mavbozo@martinklepsch interesting, according to this old guide https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/94632d306fdaac5411a0a1ae13b7c0ce987883e9/guides/documentation/service-context-reference.md#2017-01-1315:02mavbozothere is a key :io.pedestal.impl.interceptor/stack inside context which is - A PersistentList of interceptors which still need to be executed during the 'leave' stage. So long as this value is not empty, the tail of the list will be removed and executed.`#2017-01-1315:03mavbozosuppose your chain is A -> B -> C#2017-01-1315:04mavbozomaybe inside B interceptor you could push the new interceptor X to i.p.i.i/stack so that the leave chain become for example A <- X <- B <- C#2017-01-1315:14curtosisI‚Äôm curious where/why people are picking pedestal to build on these days. Sort of a meta ‚Äúwhere does it fit in the current landscape‚Äù question.#2017-01-1315:42mavbozo@curtosis I feel pedestal features makes my code easier for me to understand. routes as data makes specifying routes and generating url in html pages unified--I don't have to hard code url in html template.#2017-01-1315:48mavbozoroutes as data makes me easier to specify different interceptors for each part of the website inside one route data. for example: my web-app could have different interceptors inside /backoffice and /api path while the rest of the paths /* are for customer#2017-01-1315:54mavbozoinjecting dependencies become easier--just put the required components inside context instead of putting the required components inside :request or :response map. It feels cleaner#2017-01-1315:56mavbozojust my personal feeling about pedestal. I never used modern framework such as Django, RoR, CodeIgniter seriously. Before using clojure, most of my time I maintained and developed non framework PHP web apps.#2017-01-1316:15curtosisthanks, that‚Äôs a helpful way to look at it#2017-01-1316:16curtosismy recent experimenting has been mostly in untangled, which is more of a om.next-centric story#2017-01-1316:17curtosis(not to take anything away from untangled-server, of course; it‚Äôs just first and foremost conceived as a backend for the untangled om.next-based front-end)#2017-01-1316:18curtosisI‚Äôm trying to get a better mental map of where pedestal sits today compared to, say hoplon or luminus (to pick two that come to mind)#2017-01-1319:15dfcarpenterHi everyone, beginner here. 12‚îÇ  ??  {:request-time 6, :repeatable? false, :protocol-version {:name HTTP, :major 1, :minor 1}, :streaming? true, :chunked? false, :reason-phrase Not Found, :headers {Connection close, Date Fri, 20 Jan 2017 19:06:49 GMT, Content-Type text/plain}, :orig-content-encoding nil, :status 404, :length -1, :body Not Found, :trace-redirects []}
#2017-01-2019:09ddellacostaand, the logging message (‚Äùthis shows up‚Äù)#2017-01-2019:09ddeaguiartry adding :status 200 to the response map#2017-01-2019:10ddeaguiarso the not-found interceptor uses the response? predicate https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L84#2017-01-2019:10ddeaguiarwhich checks that the response is a map and that status is an integer#2017-01-2019:11ddellacostaapparently that was it#2017-01-2019:11ddellacostathank you @ddeaguiar#2017-01-2019:11ddellacostaI knew it was something incredibly stupid#2017-01-2019:11ddellacostaand, thanks for the pointers to the relevant code#2017-01-2019:12ddeaguiarWell, I think there may be some opportunity to improve messaging#2017-01-2019:12ddellacostayeah, this cost me almost half a day, it was very frustrating#2017-01-2019:12ddeaguiarsorry to hear that#2017-01-2019:12ddellacostaand it was an incredibly basic mistake#2017-01-2019:12ddeaguiarI do have some suggestions for you#2017-01-2019:12ddellacostapart of that is probably that I failed to read the necessary docs on how you should add responses to the context though#2017-01-2019:12ddellacostawherever those are‚Ä¶I‚Äôm pathological about reading docs after the fact#2017-01-2019:13ddeaguiar1. construct responses using ring's response helper#2017-01-2019:13ddellacostabut yeah, suggestions welcome...#2017-01-2019:14ddeaguiar2. prefer simple handler fns over interceptors for returning responses#2017-01-2019:14ddeaguiarDocs can be found here: http://pedestal.io/.
