It‚Äôs a list so first should be just as good? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.2/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor/chain.clj#L246#2017-01-2307:10martinklepschI‚Äôm doing some, ahem, adventurous stuff I guess and modify the stack (appending something) which the usage of peek complicates because it explicitly requires a PersistentList and anything that comes out of concat is LazySeq/Cons#2017-01-2314:27ddeaguiar@martinklepsch I can only speculate that it's used to decouple the semantics of the operation from the underlying collection type. Is laziness an important property of your implementation?#2017-01-2314:29martinklepsch@ddeaguiar Hey üôÇ laziness is not important, appending is. I ended up using something like this: 
(defn concat-stack [l1 l2]
  ;; (into '(4 5) (reverse '(1 2 3))) ; => '(1 2 3 4 5)
  (into l2 (reverse l1)))
#2017-01-2314:32martinklepsch@ddeaguiar I was initially thinking ‚Äúoh maybe this should be a PersistentQueue‚Äù as well but has repercussions into many places and complicates adding to the front#2017-01-2314:32martinklepsch@ddeaguiar trying to think of a reason you‚Äôd want this decoupled from collection type but when would the stack be something else than a PersistentList?#2017-01-2314:34ddeaguiarYeah, so I'm just speculating. Perhaps @mtnygard could clarify. Unfortunately I personally have not done much work requiring manipulation of the interceptor chain.#2017-01-2314:48ddeaguiar@martinklepsch I had a quick conversation with Paul deGrandis about this. Although the underlying collection type of the stack doesn't change, that's an implementation detail. The current implementation should still work if you changed the collection types of ::queue and ::stack dynamically.#2017-01-2314:50martinklepsch@ddeaguiar to what type would I change it? PersistentQueue is the only one that supports pop/peek afaik?#2017-01-2314:50martinklepschGood to know you‚Äôre sitting close to the source heh üôÇ#2017-01-2314:51ddeaguiarpeek/pop work with lists, queues and vectors#2017-01-2314:52martinklepschright vectors but then the code uses conj to add items to the stack üôÇ#2017-01-2314:52martinklepsch(so vectors are out)#2017-01-2314:53martinklepsch> PersistentQueue is the only one that supports pop/peek afaik? should have included PersistentList#2017-01-2314:59martinklepschYou could change it to PersistentQueue which would make some sense I guess (I can‚Äôt track down the repercussions mentioned earlier, maybe they were in my code not the interceptor code)#2017-01-2315:01martinklepschEither way, this is complaining at a high level, I solved my problem in an acceptable way so no need to discuss more unless more people think it‚Äôs irritating#2017-01-2315:04ddeaguiarWell, thanks for bringing this up. I'm very interested in seeing how your work progresses!#2017-01-2315:05martinklepschMe too üòÑ#2017-01-2315:05martinklepschSo far interceptors are holding up nicely (and I think I‚Äôve abused them a fair bit üôÇ)#2017-01-2513:07christianromneyPedestal context maps (and by extension Ring request / response maps) seem like a perfect use case for clojure.spec#2017-01-2513:11christianromneyi've been bitten more than once when carelessly implementing an interceptor that returns a response instead of a context. clojure.spec can help me enforce that all my interceptors are functions from context -> context#2017-01-2513:11christianromneywould be nice to establish some patterns here and maybe even push that down into the library üôÇ#2017-01-2522:32mtnygard@christianromney I definitely think that's a good use case. We've been holding off on that until 1.9 is released.#2017-01-2522:32christianromneythat makes sense#2017-01-2522:33christianromneythanks for the roadmap update @mtnygard#2017-01-3115:37mtnygardWe've released Vase, an add-on to Pedestal that makes building data-driven microservices easy. Blog post: http://bit.ly/2jqHeV6, Repository: https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase. Clojars: https://clojars.org/com.cognitect/pedestal.vase#2017-01-3115:40ddeaguiarNice!#2017-01-3123:50noogais there any way to define thwo different paths to a single handler using terse syntax?#2017-01-3123:51nooga[‚Äù/‚Äù {:get bar} ‚Äú/foo‚Äù {:get bar}] gives me errors, as well as [‚Äù/foo‚Äù {:put bar :post bar}]#2017-02-0102:53mtnygard@nooga The error is probably coming because those get the same route name assigned to them. Try something like this:#2017-02-0102:53mtnygard#{["/" :get bar :route-name :bar-slash] ["/foo" :get bar :route-name :bar-foo]}#2017-02-0102:53mtnygardor#2017-02-0102:54mtnygard#{["/foo" :put bar :route-name :bar-put] ["/foo" :post bar :route-name :bar-post]}#2017-02-0102:54mtnygard(Note that I switched to table route syntax instead of terse. That's just because I can do table routes off the top of my head, but I always have to look up the terse syntax.)#2017-02-0109:34nooga@mtnygard thanks#2017-02-0111:23noogathat‚Äôs what I though#2017-02-0111:24noogaI just hoped that I can avoid duplicating bar declarations since they should work exactly the same way#2017-02-0314:11dazldhey everyone#2017-02-0314:11dazldwe‚Äôre playing around with vase a little#2017-02-0314:11mtnygard@dazld Great!#2017-02-0314:11dazldquestion - does this do very much without having an actual datomic instance running?#2017-02-0314:11dazldhey @mtnygard was hoping you might be around üôÇ#2017-02-0314:12mtnygardWith no Datomic at all, you can still use the #vase/respond and #vase/redirect literals. They're not terribly interesting by themselves. You can also write your own literals and use the rest of Vase's plumbing.#2017-02-0314:12dazldgot it - this explains a lot#2017-02-0314:12mtnygardIt you're just kicking the tires, you can also use Datomic's in-memory database.#2017-02-0314:13dazldcould you point me at a quickstart for the in-memory db?#2017-02-0314:13mtnygardIt's pretty easy. You just don't run a transactor. üôÇ Then use "datomic:<mem://dbname>" as the URI.#2017-02-0314:13mtnygardYou can call create-database, connect, transact, etc.#2017-02-0314:13dazldoki, time to break out docker üôÇ#2017-02-0314:14dazldI think i have a test licence hanging around still too#2017-02-0314:14mtnygard(You don't even need a test license for the in-memory db.)#2017-02-0314:14dazldoh, awesome#2017-02-0314:15dazldas a suggestion, might want to add this information to the readme\#2017-02-0314:15mtnygardGood idea.#2017-02-0314:15dazld:thumbsup:#2017-02-0314:16mtnygardhttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/issues/26#2017-02-0314:16mtnygardPlease let me know if you bump into any sharp corners.#2017-02-0314:17mtnygardI'll add more to that issue.#2017-02-0314:19dazldhow about a 500 if the datastore isn't available?#2017-02-0314:19dazldor 5xx#2017-02-0314:19mtnygardWhat are you getting now?#2017-02-0314:22dazld200#2017-02-0314:23mtnygardThat does seem odd.#2017-02-0314:23dazldon validate for example#2017-02-0314:23dazldor user#2017-02-0314:23dazldget/post#2017-02-0316:01tetriscodesAnyone have Swagger working with pedestal?#2017-02-0316:02tetriscodesWith spec instead of schema#2017-02-0316:02tetriscodesSimilar to this: https://github.com/nubank/pedestal-swagger#2017-02-0316:22mtnygard@tetriscodes I have a client using pedestal-api, but none with pedestal-swagger.#2017-02-0316:34ikitommithe pedestal-swagger is fork from route-swagger which uses ring-swagger and is used by pedestal-api, which is the most up-to-date impl for pedestal.#2017-02-0316:35mtnygard@ikitommi I might need a diagram to follow that chain.#2017-02-0316:42ikitommihaha. We have done the ring-swagger and now porting it for spec with same api for routing libs (https://github.com/metosin/spec-swagger). Waiting for spec internals to cool down. Should work with pedestal-api nicely. Haven't talked with Frankie about his plans with pedestal-api thou.#2017-02-0316:47mtnygard@ikitommi Very cool! I'll be keeping my eye on that#2017-02-0316:57tetriscodes@ikitommi nice!#2017-02-1318:25mtnygardIf anyone is using Vase, we just added a new literal: #vase/conform. Takes some data out of the context, conforms it to a spec, and reattaches it (possibly at a different key)#2017-02-1318:25mtnygardIt‚Äôs only available on master for a little while. Feedback appreciated.#2017-02-1319:08mtnygardOdd wording on my last message. I didn‚Äôt mean to make it sound like the new feature would go away. I meant that for now, it‚Äôs not in a release or snapshot jar. Just on master.#2017-02-1402:07jimmy@mtnygard I find vase really interesting. It's super convenient to build fast backend API backend by datomic. I will try it out soon this week üòÑ#2017-02-1418:52ikitommi@mtnygard have you thought of conforming with different wire formats as JSON & Transit have different capabilities for presenting data.. Haven‚Äôt seen that (runtime conforming) part on the spec roadmap. Here‚Äôs something we are doing for it: https://gist.github.com/ikitommi/fb3e0200504dd8b635ed7edd0cdbc768#runtime-coercion.#2017-02-1418:56ddeaguiarI think conformance and coercion are two different concepts but they can be related by using s/conformer. I think that strongly couples coercion to your spec definition, though. I could be mistaken.#2017-02-1419:10ikitommiProblem is that there is no coercion in spec. I‚Äôm using a special conformer, which doesn‚Äôt transform anything by default, only if you tell it to (do JSON or String -conversions). Another way would be to take a spec and transform it into a differently conforming spec, e.g. User -> UserJSON, UserString. Currently not 100% proof due to the global spec registry. But something needs to be done IMO. I would be glad if I could toss away my current code for this.#2017-02-1421:54mtnygard@ikitommi Are you talking about this in the context of Pedestal in general or of Vase specifically?#2017-02-1506:37ikitommi@mtnygard well I picked that pushed conforming into Vase, but I think the problem applies for all Clojure http libs/apps.#2017-02-1609:50jimmyregarding vase, if we want to use internal eid in query, is there anyway we can use datomic/pull api ?#2017-02-1714:47oconnHey all. I'm pretty new to pedestal and I'm working on adding authorization to my routes. I was wondering if there was an easy way to solve the following; I have an interceptor that adds permitted roles to context, and then I have an interceptor, :authorization/check-roles, that checks if the current user's roles match any of the permitted roles. The problem I'm running into is finding a way to dynamically add ::check-roles prior to the handler in the execution queue. I've tried using io.pedestal.interceptor.chain.enqueue but this will add my ::check-roles interceptor after my handler. Is there an intuitive way to add an interceptor prior to the handler? Is it ok to modify {:route {:interceptors [...]}} and say add my interceptor right before the handler?#2017-02-1715:27henriklundahl@oconn Can't you always have the authorization interceptor in the chain?#2017-02-1715:30oconnSo I add :authorization/authorize to specific routes and pass in a role set. The problem I‚Äôm facing is when I have a route that is nested under that route that adds additional permissions#2017-02-1715:33oconnthats where ::check-roles was supposed to come into play and check the permissions that have accumulated prior to passing the request off to the handler#2017-02-1715:35oconnBut now that you mention it, is there a simple way to always include ::check-roles right before the handler for each route? I‚Äôm using the terse syntax if that makes a difference.#2017-02-1715:36oconn@henriklundahl#2017-02-1716:28henriklundahl@oconn, I believe I don't understand the setup. When are the roles the user has determined? When are the roles required for being authorized to make the request determined?#2017-02-1716:51oconn@henriklundahl https://gist.github.com/oconn/c38c4c6dfcfa7a98b195ac8ffe423898#2017-02-1716:56oconnThis may be a problem that could be solved by reorganizing my routes or tackling the problem differently.. but I‚Äôd thought I‚Äôd ask and see if there was an easy way to support this.#2017-02-1718:18henriklundahl@oconn, ok, I understand now. I'm not sure, but I think that if you add an interceptor after the router, it will be called after the router but before the handler (in the enter stage).#2017-02-1718:22oconncool, I‚Äôll give that a shot#2017-02-1718:22oconnthanks#2017-02-2311:02rui.yanghi, are there some examples of testing the pedestal application? eg. how to mock the db, how to mock a handler#2017-02-2315:47donaldballWe use http://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.service/io.pedestal.test.html#var-response-for to test issuing http requests against a pedestal app#2017-02-2315:48donaldballWe use component to build our system and build it with in-memory protocol impls or separate instances of e.g. sql databases in our integrated tests#2017-02-2509:29kirill.salykinHi all, I am using pedestal based on Stuart Sierra component. Basically it is only 2 components now: Pedestal and Datomic. I am trying to inject datomic connection to intercepctors chain. But I keep getting this error: "You're trying to use something as an interceptor that isn't supported by the protocol; Perhaps you need to extend it?" 
(defrecord Pedestal [service-map service db]
  component/Lifecycle
  (start [component]
    (print (str "DB:" db))
    (if service
      component
      (-> service-map
          (assoc :http/routes (routes/routes db))
          http/create-server
          http/start
          (assoc component :service))))
  (stop [component]
    (when service (http/stop service))
    (assoc component :service nil)))

(defn routes [db-component]
  (let [session-inter (session {:store (cookie/cookie-store)})
        conn (:conn db-component)
        attach-conn (attach-to-request :conn conn)]
    (route/expand-routes
     #{
       ["/"        :get  [attach-conn session-inter authenticate guard 'root]]
       ["/sign-up" :get  [attach-conn session-inter 'show-sign-up]]
       ["/sign-up" :post [attach-conn session-inter (body-params) keyword-params 'sign-up]]
       ["/sign-in" :get  [attach-conn session-inter 'show-sign-in]]
       ["/sign-in" :post [attach-conn session-inter (body-params) keyword-params 'sign-in]]
       })))

(defn attach-to-request [name obj]
  (interceptor
   {:name ::attach-to-req
    :enter (fn [ctx]
               (assoc-in ctx [:request name] obj))}))
Please advice what I am doing wrong. Thanks!#2017-02-2510:22mavbozo@kirill.salykin i suspect this line (assoc component :service)#2017-02-2510:23mavbozobasically it will be expanded to (assoc (http/start ...) component service) while what you want is (assoc component :service (http/start ...))#2017-02-2510:25kirill.salykin@mavbozo thanks!#2017-02-2510:25kirill.salykinlooks like this is the reason#2017-02-2510:28mavbozoI find it helpful for me to split the Pedestal component into 2 components: Pedestal Service component just for preparing the service map for Pedestal Server component which is responsible for creating/starting/stopping the server#2017-02-2511:16kirill.salykinsounds interesting#2017-02-2511:16kirill.salykinI also found pedestal component from Sierra#2017-02-2511:16kirill.salykintrying this now#2017-02-2511:16kirill.salykinthanks for help!#2017-02-2715:00crimeministerhttp://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component#2017-02-2715:00crimeminister @kirill.salykin this might be helpful ^ (it was for me when I asked similar questions here)#2017-02-2715:01kirill.salykin@crimeminister thanks!#2017-02-2812:49rui.yanghi, wonder if there is some examples of simulating multi-part form submission in testing pedestal application? eg. for testing file uploading. using pedestal's response-for macro.#2017-02-2812:57kirill.salykinHi, is it possible to use function to build routes? I am trying this: 
::http/routes (build-routes)

(defn build-routes
  (route/expand-routes #{[‚Ä¶]}))
But facing this: 
You're trying to use something as an interceptor
that isn't supported by the protocol; Perhaps you need to extend it? {:t nil, :type nil}
#2017-02-2813:46kirill.salykinIs it good approach to build routes this way? 
(def route-table
  #{["/"        :get  ['pages/root]]
    ["/sign-up" :get  ['pages/show-sign-up]]
    ["/sign-up" :post ['pages/sign-up]]
    ["/sign-in" :get  ['pages/show-sign-in]]
    ["/sign-in" :post ['pages/sign-in]]})


(def common-interceptors
  [http/html-body
   (using-component :db)
   (session {:store (cookie/cookie-store {:key "some-key12345678"})})])

(defn build-interceptors [verb interceptors]
  (let [interceptors (apply conj common-interceptors interceptors)]
    (if (= verb :get)
      interceptors
      (into [(body-params) keyword-params] interceptors))))

(defn browser-stack [[path verb interceptors]]
  [path verb (build-interceptors verb interceptors)])

(def routes
  (route/expand-routes (into #{} (map browser-stack route-table))))
#2017-02-2813:55ddeaguiar@kirill.salykin there's nothing wrong with building your routes programmatically, although given your example, I'd build the route-table explicitly. IMO it would be easier to reason about#2017-02-2813:56ddeaguiar@kirill.salykin re: the error you're seeing, it may be due to how you refer to your handlers in the route table. Try using back-ticks instead of single quotes#2017-02-2813:56ddeaguiarthe symbols need to be fully qualified#2017-02-2813:56kirill.salykin@ddeaguiar thanks for response Thought it makes no sens to repeat (body-params) etc#2017-02-2813:57kirill.salykinI see this error only when I am trying to implemet routes as function defn routes []#2017-02-2813:57ddeaguiaryou can capture the common get interceptors in a var if you like#2017-02-2813:58ddeaguiarbut that's a matter of taste#2017-02-2813:58ddeaguiaragain, nothing wrong with programmatically building the routes#2017-02-2813:58kirill.salykinthanks!#2017-02-2814:07ddeaguiar@kirill.salykin also, you don't need to call route/expand-routes#2017-02-2814:08kirill.salykinpedestal will do it for me because set used?#2017-02-2814:09ddeaguiaryeah#2017-02-2814:10ddeaguiarso I suspect what's happening is that the verbose route map produced by expand routes is trying to be expanded again by Pedestal's internals#2017-02-2814:10ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L355#2017-02-2814:15mtnygard@kirill.salykin The message you're getting includes the value and type that Pedestal is trying to convert to an interceptor. The value is nil, so I suspect that your interceptor vector after browser-stack may have some issues. Can you print the value of the set after (into #{} (map browser-stack route-table))?#2017-02-2814:17kirill.salykin@mtnygard everything works I am facing issue if I am trying to use this: 
(def routes
  (route/expand-routes (into #{} (map browser-stack route-table))))
as function, eg : 
(defn routes []
  (route/expand-routes (into #{} (map browser-stack route-table))))
#2017-02-2814:17mtnygardGotcha. Can you show me your service-map declaration?#2017-02-2814:18kirill.salykin
(defn build-routes []
  (fn []
    (doseq [ns-sym (modified-namespaces)]
      (require ns-sym :reload))
    routes))

(def pedestal-config
  {::http/host "0.0.0.0"
   ::http/port 8080
   ::http/type :jetty
   ::http/join? true
   ::http/resource-path "/public"
   ::http/routes (build-routes)})

(defn build-routes []
  (fn []
    (doseq [ns-sym (modified-namespaces)]
      (require ns-sym :reload))
    (routes)))

#2017-02-2814:33ddeaguiarhmm no they don't#2017-02-2814:34ddeaguiaroh wait#2017-02-2814:34ddeaguiaryes#2017-02-2814:34ddeaguiarthat's the handler, though#2017-02-2814:34kirill.salykinyes#2017-02-2814:35mtnygardAh, I see what's happening. `pages/root gets turned into the fully-qualified symbol. If you had that directly in your route table it would still be a symbol when Pedestal turned it into an interceptor.#2017-02-2814:35mtnygardHrm, nevermind... I was on the wrong track there.#2017-02-2814:36mtnygardI'm glad it's working. I'd be happy to take a closer look at the interceptor name thing later on when you've posted the code.#2017-02-2814:37kirill.salykinsure, thanks a lot @ddeaguiar and @mtnygard#2017-02-2814:37ddeaguiarnp üôÇ#2017-03-0312:59julianwegkampAre there examples of handling authentication with pedestal?#2017-03-0313:57mtnygard@julianwegkamp I know some people have had success using Buddy from a Pedestal service. Buddy-auth uses Ring middleware, but it's trivial to turn that into an interceptor. You might get some milage out of http://rundis.github.io/blog/2015/buddy_auth_part2.html#2017-03-0314:04julianwegkampThx @mtnygard. I will take a look at it.#2017-03-0314:06ddeaguiar@julianwegkamp take a look at geheimtur as well. https://github.com/propan/geheimtur#2017-03-0314:07ddeaguiarI‚Äôve worked with both. Buddy requires some minor work to port middleware but it‚Äôs no big deal#2017-03-0314:07ddeaguiaras @mtnygard pointed out#2017-03-0314:07mtnygardGeheimtur is new to me. Will check it out, thanks @ddeaguiar#2017-03-0314:07ddeaguiarnp#2017-03-0314:09ddeaguiarIIRC, I preferred Buddy when working with JWT#2017-03-0314:14julianwegkampThx. It surprises me that there isn't a go-to solution for pedestal. Isn't (some form of) authentication a standard use case for a web application server?#2017-03-0314:18ddeaguiar@julianwegkamp there was a recent discussion re: this in the pedestal-users mailing list. See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pedestal-users/MJL0h4ts_mk for Paul‚Äôs thoughts#2017-03-0314:23julianwegkampthx#2017-03-0314:26ddeaguiarnp#2017-03-0315:58julianwegkampFYI I just added my 2 ct to the discussion in pedestal-users#2017-03-0318:31barisHi all, I‚Äôm playing with vase/pedestal. What‚Äôs the best way to coerce a json value to timestamp/edn-date/java.util.Date within a #vase/transact? I'm looking for sth like the :edn-coerce [‚Ä¶] which is used by #vase/query. Do I really have to use an interceptor for all my edn values like #inst or #uuid within a #vase/transact?#2017-03-0318:32barisLike the one in the petstore-full example?#2017-03-0319:11mtnygardHi @baris. I'm glad you're giving Vase a try. I'm going to dig in to your question together with Paul deGrandis (the main author). He's not on Slack so I'll come back with an answer in a while.#2017-03-0319:12barisThanks a lot @mtnygard#2017-03-0320:03mtnygard@baris It's definitely a limitation of the Transact literal right now. I've entered issue https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/issues/45 to address that. It should accept EDN and Transit as well as JSON.#2017-03-0320:06baris@mtnygard that would be a great enhancement. For the moment I‚Äôm using custom interceptors#2017-03-0320:07mtnygard@baris You might also be able to use the #vase/conform interceptor to do the coercion. That way you don't have to write custom interceptors for each transaction.#2017-03-0320:11baris@mtnygard thanks for the hint. I‚Äôll check the #vase/conform capabilities#2017-03-0613:12jimmy@mtnygard thanks of addressing the problem. This can happen if you send a request without the content-type header.#2017-03-0908:17jimmy@mtnygard regarding spec validation. I just realize that when we write spec for vase, we have to write spec to validate the whole stuff {:payload [::entity-maps]} instead of only for entity-map. I'm not sure if this only happens when I include external specs ( those which are not defined in descriptor ) or not ? And I think this is worth mentioning in docs.#2017-03-0912:33mtnygard@nxqd Yeah, that has more to do with the Transact action than where the specs are defined. If you were validating params to a Query, or using Conform to reshape the results of a query, then that wouldn't apply.#2017-03-0920:00deg@mtnygard, following up on your offer to help at https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/issues/50. Thanks!#2017-03-0920:01mtnygardWelcome @deg!#2017-03-0920:01degSo, it's not clear to me if I need to do any Datomic config to start using Vase. Or, can I just treat it as a black box for a while?#2017-03-0920:02mtnygardIf you just want to use an in-memory database, then you don't have to download or run anything. Can you paste in the value of your :datomic-api key? That will tell us what "storage" you'll be using.#2017-03-0920:03degFrom which file? A quick grep did not find it.#2017-03-0920:03mtnygardIt would be under resources, in a file with ".edn" as the extension.#2017-03-0920:03degmaybe datomic-uri?#2017-03-0920:04mtnygardDoh. Yeah, I'm not going be much help if I mistype things... Yes, :datomic-uri#2017-03-0920:04deg:datomic-uri "datomic:<mem://example>"#2017-03-0920:04degüôÇ#2017-03-0920:05mtnygardOK, the "mem" part of that means you're using the in-memory database. That runs completely inside your Java process so you don't need to set anything else up.#2017-03-0920:05degCool.#2017-03-0920:05mtnygardThe down side, naturally, is that it doesn't persist.#2017-03-0920:05degDoes it also persist to file?#2017-03-0920:05degHmm#2017-03-0920:05degSo, I'll be coming back to a blank slate anytime I restart the program?#2017-03-0920:05mtnygardRight, not only that, but you can create a new memory DB anytime to get a blank state. There's a "dev" mode that does persist to a file. To use that, you'll need to download Datomic Starter or Datomic Free.#2017-03-0920:06degOk. So, looks like the docs are a bit inconsistent about this. I guess in part because Vase development overlapped Cognitect's recent change of tiers.#2017-03-0920:07mtnygardHmm, that's probably true.#2017-03-0920:07degWhere should I read to figure out the simplest way to do this integration?#2017-03-0920:08mtnygardThe "getting started" docs for datomic aren't the greatest (being revised now, in fact) but they should get you going. http://docs.datomic.com/get-datomic.html#2017-03-0920:08degAnd, for the docs, it would be great to have this built in as an option. I suspect for Vase to win, it's going to need to attract a lot of new people to the full Datomic env.#2017-03-0920:08degThanks. Getting late here, and then I'm off for a few days. But, I will tackle this next week and -- I suspect -- will bother you then with more questions. Thanks!#2017-03-0920:08mtnygardYou'll run a thing called a "transactor" as a separate process, then change the :datomic-uri to something like "datomic:<free://localhost:4334/<dbname>>"#2017-03-0920:09mtnygardI'm heading out for Spring Break over the next week, but you can email me at <mailto:mt/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection> in the meantime.#2017-03-0920:09mtnygardCan I ask what led you to consider Vase? I'm always interested in where our users see value.#2017-03-0920:09degEnjoy. (drinks on beach emoji)#2017-03-0920:10degI listen to the Cognicast podcast, and it was talked about a few weeks back. Also, I saw it mentioned in various online places#2017-03-0920:10mtnygardCool! Thanks.#2017-03-0920:11degAnd, I recently wrote a hobbyist CLJ/CLJS project with much too much scaffolding and no DB support, so was receptive to the right tools.#2017-03-0920:12mtnygardhaha ... that's exactly why we made Vase!#2017-03-0920:12mtnygardsame frustration.#2017-03-0920:12degI'm still not totally sure that I buy into the persistent DB idea for dev work, so suspect I'll be cursing it for a while, while I radically refactor early stage code. But, can certainly see how it will win big for production deployments.#2017-03-0920:14mtnygardSo, when you get to unit testing, we've got a cool story... basically you can make a fixture that wraps each test with its own in-memory db. so no need to mock out the database when you can always have an isolated instance. the main trick is generating a dbname via UUID. Like (str "datomic:mem://" (d/squuid))#2017-03-0920:14degThat is cool! Anyway, I'm just entering the foothills of the learning curve.#2017-03-0920:15degRunning late here (I'm seven hours ahead of EST), so I'm gonna drop off now. Thanks again.#2017-03-0920:15mtnygardCheers#2017-03-0920:47souenzzoHey, how to use io.pedestal.interceptor.error/error-dispatchwith datomic? I can't make patterns to catch datomic exceptions#2017-03-0920:49mtnygard@souenzzo If one of your interceptors throws an exception, including one from Datomic, Pedestal's chain handler will catch it and turn it into data. It's that data that you pattern-match in error-dispatch#2017-03-0920:55souenzzoBut datomic exceptions match just on generic :exception-type :java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException or :exception-type :java.lang.IllegalArgumentException (Nothing guarantees me that only datomic exceptions entered here) Then I need to some nested .getCause, ex-data and make another router.... I did not know if there was a standard solution#2017-03-0920:57mtnygardI see what you mean. I suppose you could also match on the interceptor name that's throwing the exception.#2017-03-0920:57mtnygardThere might be another trick to apply. One sec while I look at the source.#2017-03-0920:59mtnygardOK, here's an avenue you might explore. error-dispatch uses core.match under the hood. It tries to unify the exception data against your patterns. The examples are all of basic map matching, but you can use any of the patterns in https://github.com/clojure/core.match/wiki/Overview that would work on the ex-data. That should include guard clauses on .getCause of the underlying exception.#2017-03-1002:13jimmy@mtnygard thanks, I will try it out#2017-03-1007:28rauh@mtnygard Is there a reason pedestal/guides/documentation/routing-terse-syntax.md didn't get rewritten to point to the new docs? It contains some mistakes#2017-03-1007:28rauh(expand-routes is in the wrong ns)#2017-03-1119:26mtnygard@rauh No reason. I'll open an issue to make sure we don't forget about that. #2017-03-1212:53ikitommiIs there an interceptor that would encode response body based on client set headers (`accept` & friends), e.g. based on results of io.pedestal.http.content-negotiation/negotiate-content?#2017-03-1212:55ikitommias the io.pedestal.http.body-params/body-params does decoding for multiple formats...#2017-03-1223:33bradfordHeyas, I'm having trouble with the json parser. My defroutes is: 
(defroutes routes
           [[["/" {:get [::send-counter (sse/start-event-stream sse-stream-ready)]}
              ["/with-id" {:get [::send-counter-with-id
                                 (sse/start-event-stream sse-stream-ready-with-id)]}]
              ["/about" {:get about-page}]
              ["/echo" {:post [(b/body-params) test-channel]}]

              ]]])
but when I compile I get the error

#2017-03-1311:40thegeez@bradford for the route syntax you're using you need#2017-03-1311:40thegeez
["/echo"
  ^:interceptors [(b/body-params)] 
  {:post test-channel}]

Is it possible to stream multiple file uploads to a pedestal server? would that be content-type: multipart/form-data and transfer-encoding: chunked? (sorry, I'm rather new to this). Do I just use the multipart-form-data ring middleware?#2017-03-1508:40alanspringfield@ddeaguiar Where should I start reading the code base to better understand what's going on?#2017-03-1513:12ddeaguiar@alanspringfield I‚Äôd start with the io.pedestal.http ns. Basically work you way back from create-server (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L341) to see things are initialized. Where you go from there is up to you. Good candidates are the io.pedestal.http.route ns (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj) or the io.pedestal.interceptor ns (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj).#2017-03-1513:14ddeaguiarThe code is really clean so it should be pretty easy to follow. Keep an eye out for abstractions as you go through it#2017-03-1513:15ddeaguiarJust having an understanding of what‚Äôs going on in io.pedestal.http goes a long way imo#2017-03-1513:16ddeaguiarKnowing what default interceptors get wired up when is super useful. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L180#2017-03-1513:18ddeaguiarhope that helps#2017-03-1520:48rafaelzlisboaanybody using pedestal sse for broadcasting?#2017-03-1522:58mtnygardHey all, checking in mid-week during spring break here. Catching up on the conversation, so I‚Äôll be shotgunning out on some different topics.#2017-03-1522:58mtnygard@rafaelzlisboa Yes, we‚Äôre definitely using SSE for broadcasting events.#2017-03-1523:07rafaelzlisboawhat‚Äôs the best way to set it up? what i‚Äôm doing is using a mult and tapping the individual channels into a broadcaster main channel, with a watchdog to release them when there is a timeout. just wondering if there‚Äôs an easier way to implement it#2017-03-1523:08mtnygardI‚Äôve not had good luck with mult and tap in the past. There‚Äôs something about them that I don‚Äôt understand. I keep a map with the connected clients. The start-event-stream function lets me identify a disconnect function that I use to clean up the map.#2017-03-1523:10rafaelzlisboahmmm‚Ä¶ then go through the entire map whenever we want to broadcast?#2017-03-1523:10mtnygardYes, with a doseq.#2017-03-1523:10mtnygardIt‚Äôs a map from a per-client key to the channel for that client.#2017-03-1523:11mtnygardHere‚Äôs an excerpt: https://gist.github.com/mtnygard/3c05c26f4cfad420eee6ce32ac03819f#2017-03-1523:15rafaelzlisboanice! I guess right now we‚Äôre at the point of not having good luck with mult and tap hahah. it randomly stops working somedays#2017-03-1523:16mtnygardYeah, I didn‚Äôt track it down far enough but it seemed like I couldn‚Äôt effectively isolate errors/slowdowns on one tap from others.#2017-03-1523:18rafaelzlisboathanks for the tip#2017-03-1523:00mtnygard@alanspringfield Vase builds on Pedestal, so learning Pedestal is definitely a good start. Going through the HTTP namespace as @ddeaguiar suggests is the ‚Äúoutside to inside‚Äù approach. Depending on your learning style, you may also benefit from an ‚Äúinside to outside‚Äù approach‚Ä¶ that would be starting with the interceptors module. Pretty much everything that makes Vase interesting is about building interceptors out of data.#2017-03-1523:01mtnygard@alanspringfield As you get started, please take notes of anything that bites you. Or anything that just bites. The notes from @deg on doc deficiencies have been great. Each time someone goes through the process we can learn from anything that makes them stumble.#2017-03-1523:04mtnygard@bradford I know a few people have done multipart forms that include uploads. IDK if that means multiple parallel uploads. The multipart form upload ring middleware is probably the quickest path to done.#2017-03-1523:07mtnygard@deg The ‚Äúself contained‚Äù part of Vase is meant to refer to dependencies. There is probably a better term for it. As far as the #vase channel‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt know who started it and didn‚Äôt know there was one until you mentioned it.#2017-03-1523:07mtnygardThis channel is normally friendly enough and low volume so I‚Äôd rather not split attention there too.#2017-03-1610:42bherrmann(also posted in #vase) boo‚Ä¶ when I run the vase sample ‚Äúomnext-todo‚Äù - can see the working vase api part.... but where can I access the omnext part?#2017-03-1616:29ddeaguiar@bherrmann from what I can see, this sample only addresses the api needs for an om-next application. I‚Äôm not familiar with om-next‚Äôs ‚Äòdemand-driven‚Äô queries so I can‚Äôt help with that.#2017-03-1616:58bherrmann@ddeaguiar Thanks, that makes sense.#2017-03-1723:20sineerHi! I'm having a hard time trying to get a proper pedestal dev setup up and running...#2017-03-1723:21sineerI set my service route to ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes)) and it routes but whenever I reload code I can never get my updated routes to reslove without killing and restarting the server#2017-03-1723:33sineerI don't get it, I run-dev and I'm in the repl redeclaring interceptors and reloading code but nothing changes! It's not just the route even the content of simple interceptor when reloaded do not change untill I kill and restart jetty üòû#2017-03-1800:26sineerHoly shit I found out what I was doing wrong at last!#2017-03-1800:27sineerIf you don't quote interceptors in routes def they can't be reloaded... It makes senses but I sure had to struggle a lot to figure it out!#2017-03-1800:32sineerMy routes still won't update too.#2017-03-1802:18jimmy@sineer#2017-03-1802:18jimmyhow do you reload your code ?#2017-03-1803:31sineerI'm running the run-dev fn at the repl with my service's route set like ::http/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'routes/master-routes))#2017-03-1803:31sineerI use cider-jack-in and also reploaded.repl#2017-03-1803:32sineerI can deref my master-routes and see what changes in the repl but the jetty process never picks up the routes updates.#2017-03-1918:35degI'm reading through https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/docs/your_first_api.md, trying to grok it all, and cleaning up some small typos. I found two somewhat larger issues, and wanted to check before I trample: 1) It looks like the section "Working with POST data" is duplicated by the material in the later section "Getting data in with transact". The latter seems to be more useful and complete. I'd like to delete "Working with POST data" entirely. 2) The whole presentation of this material is awkward. The ...service.edn file starts with a much more complete set of examples, and the new user is expected to replace sections with shorter pieces. Instead, I think it would be cleaner to change the file to contain the final results suggested by yourfirst_api.md, and to leave the remaining material in comments.#2017-03-2021:03degAwfully quiet today. üôÇ In the template .edn file, is it intentional that :db.install/_attribute :db.part/db is used in the example of a norm? I understand from the docs that this is no longer needed.#2017-03-2021:03mtnygardThat change in Datomic came more recently than the samples.#2017-03-2021:04mtnygardThe samples can be updated as long as we add a note about the minimum revision of Datomic supported.#2017-03-2021:05degIs the minimum version documented somewhere? I'm happy to add in this kind of thing as I'm learning/proofreading, but I've not yet found enough reference docs. The Vase docs still seem to be strongly example driven.#2017-03-2021:06mtnygardRight now there isn't a minimum. You could use Vase on any release of Datomic ever.#2017-03-2021:09degStill, seems wrong to have the :db.install stuff in a beginner's doc. In trying to understand the .edn file, I had to browse through much too much of the Datomic Schema docs in order to just learn that I didn't need to pay attention to that line. üòû (I had tried an exercise of rewriting the complex norm as a simple one, to ensure that I understood it completely. This line was a sticking point. FWIW, so was :unique vs :identity; also only answered by reading through the datomic docs)#2017-03-2021:09mtnygardI think what we need to do is make two docs.#2017-03-2021:10mtnygard"your_first_api.md" today is really meant to be "your first Vase API" for someone who already knows Pedestal and Datomic, but wants to learn Vase.#2017-03-2021:10mtnygardI think you're aiming at something more like the Pedestal getting started guides.#2017-03-2021:11degThat sounds right to me. Also, two .edn files. (See my #2 comment yesterday, about the awkwardness of being instructed to shorten a sample file)#2017-03-2021:11mtnygardNot just two files. Two different directories.#2017-03-2021:12degYup#2017-03-2021:12mtnygardThe minimum necessary for a Vase app is quite small. The template generates a more full-features, production-ready app... but that's not helpful to learn from.#2017-03-2021:13degYup. I was blown away (in a very positive sense) by how little code was in my lein new vase foo.#2017-03-2021:13degIt would make a lot of sense to have two templates.#2017-03-2021:13mtnygardIt's still more than I'd like. üòâ#2017-03-2021:15degThat's a great goal. As a newbie, I've found that one of the weaknesses in the Clojure client/server ecosystem is that it is evolving so quickly and so much knowledge is embedded in the codes generated by templates, that it is very hard to upgrade a project to take advantage of the changing landscape.#2017-03-2021:16mtnygardI agree. It's not just frustrating for a newbie. Way too much capability is tied up in templates and build tool plugins.#2017-03-2021:16degI know I'm going to hit a learning curve in a few days when I try to introduce the client code into my toy Vase project.#2017-03-2021:17mtnygardDo you mean front-end ClojureScript? Or do you mean call-outs to other services?#2017-03-2021:17degUntil now, I've used the framework-like templates that put all the pieces together -- paying the price of manually upgrading each time the landscape improves -- so I don't really know how to hand-code all the goodness of figwheel + cider + production builds + etc. and Vase doesn't have this all rolled together. (for better and worse)#2017-03-2021:19degFront-end Clojurescript. I like the idea that Vase is client-agnostic; it's certainly the right way to go. But, I write my clients in CLJS, and it is very convenient having both sides started by the same template framework. I don't know the right answer.#2017-03-2021:20mtnygardOne thing I'd suggest is this: keep the client app and the Vase service separate. As in, different directories, different project.clj files.#2017-03-2021:20mtnygardThere's no need for them to occupy the same project and it just makes everything harder to configure and build.#2017-03-2021:20mtnygardSo for the front end, feel free to use a figwheel template app. It'll work just fine with Vase services.#2017-03-2021:21mtnygardThey just meet at the URLs.#2017-03-2021:21mtnygardOnce you get a ways down the road, consider creating a third directory, with .cljc files that describe the specs for your data interface.#2017-03-2021:21mtnygardThen include that from both front and back end.#2017-03-2021:21mtnygardThere's a lot of power in creating a metadata driven contract between components.#2017-03-2021:22degIs there a standalone figwheel template? That does sound much more right. My last project was Luminus-based. It was very easy to get started, but I still have no friggin' clue what's going on in the project.clj.#2017-03-2021:22mtnygardYep. lein new figwheel hello-world#2017-03-2021:22mtnygardhttps://github.com/bhauman/figwheel-template#2017-03-2021:24degThx. I'll take a look at that soon. I definitely like the idea of separate, understandable, projects.#2017-03-2104:33souenzzoI'm thinking of making an interceptor to open datomic connection (single db/connecton for all others interceptos/handler/fns. I'll PM you more details in a minute#2017-03-2115:09degFor debugging my Vase app, what is the syntax for a query that returns the entire db?#2017-03-2115:18mtnygard@deg There are two ways to approach this. One is to use the datoms function and just get all datoms in total. The other would be to run a query with [:find ?e ?a ?v :where [?e ?a ?v]]. The second one only works if your whole db fits in memory.#2017-03-2115:19degThanks. Memory is not a problem at this stage; I'd still fit on a PDP-8 üôÇ#2017-03-2115:22degBut, for your datoms solution... where can I get hold of the db? It seems to be passed implicitly in the current query syntax.#2017-03-2115:23degHmm, and for the second solution, I get` Interceptor Exception: :db.error/insufficient-binding Insufficient binding of db clause: [?e ?a ?v] would cause full scan`#2017-03-2115:24mtnygardYou'd do that with an interceptor: #vase/intercept {:name :dump-db :enter (fn [ctx] (assoc ctx :response {:status 200 :body (datomic.api/datoms (-> ctx :request :db) :eavt)}))}#2017-03-2115:24mtnygardAh, that's new.#2017-03-2115:24mtnygardStick with datoms then, I guess.#2017-03-2115:26deg1) So, I assume that's some zealous protection against loading the whole db? Why needed? 2) In you snippet, what is namespace d?#2017-03-2115:27mtnygardEdited. I wrote that off the top of my head, then remembered that it would be evaluated in a context that may not have the usual requires.#2017-03-2115:27mtnygardAs for your first question, I can't answer it. That would be a Q for the Datomic gang.#2017-03-2115:29degSo, with "/dump" I get `Interceptor Exception: You're trying to use something as an interceptor that isn't supported by the protocol; Perhaps you need to extend it?`#2017-03-2115:30mtnygardone minute#2017-03-2115:31mtnygard"/dump" {:get #2017-03-2115:31mtnygardIt's like any other literal... has to have a verb#2017-03-2115:31degoops#2017-03-2115:33degHmm, now the query is not returning. How do I configure jetty's maxidleconnections in a service? Right now I'm doing: 
(def service {:env :prod
              ;; You can bring your own non-default interceptors. Make
              ;; sure you include routing and set it up right for
              ;; dev-mode. If you do, many other keys for configuring
              ;; default interceptors will be ignored.
              ;; :http/interceptors []
              ::http/routes routes
              ;; Root for resource interceptor that is available by default.
              ::http/resource-path "/public"
              ;; Either :jetty or :tomcat (see comments in project.clj
              ;; to enable Tomcat)
              ::http/type :jetty
              ::http/port 8080})

(https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/docs/your_first_api.md#handling-parameters)#2017-03-2214:01degYup, I have read that. Am I missing something? It looks to me like all the parameters are reduced to positional and mandatory by the time they get to the query.#2017-03-2214:01ddeaguiarre: explicit entity ids, I suspect this has to do with Datomic best practices (http://docs.datomic.com/best-practices.html#unique-ids-for-external-keys)#2017-03-2214:02degRe ids, that's what I figured, finally. So, best practice would be not to specify an explicit id unless I need it for some external purpose?#2017-03-2214:03degThis makes complete sense, but is not the first impression that I got from the Vase samples.#2017-03-2214:05ddeaguiarSo setting aside Vase for the moment, If you solely rely on the internal :db/id as an external identifier, it makes data migration more difficult#2017-03-2214:06ddeaguiarI need to think about what this means in terms of a Vase-enabled app, but IMHO it‚Äôs really not a Datomic-specific issue either. It‚Äôs a good recommendation for any backend store that generates identifiers#2017-03-2214:07ddeaguiardatomic has a notion of entity ids and :db/id is just one variant#2017-03-2214:08ddeaguiarSee http://docs.datomic.com/identity.html#entity-identifiers#2017-03-2214:08degI'll need to think about that, in the context of my current toy application. But, assuming that I do want an external id on my entities, does Vase (or Datomic?) give an easy way to generate unique ids atomically?#2017-03-2214:09ddeaguiaryou can generate unique ids that are Datomic index-friendly using (datomic.api/squuid) (http://docs.datomic.com/clojure/index.html#datomic.api/squuid)#2017-03-2214:10degYup, I've seen that Datomic section, but have not fully grokked it yet. So, how would I use squuid in the context of a #vase/transact?#2017-03-2214:11degI think my questions really keep boiling down to "I'm trying to understand how to do things right, but I'm only learning from samples, rather than formal docs that don't yet exist"#2017-03-2214:13ddeaguiarso to assign your own unique id, you‚Äôd need to pass it as part of your entity data in vase transact but#2017-03-2214:13ddeaguiarI think Vase will append a :db/id if it‚Äôs not present as well#2017-03-2214:14ddeaguiarSo you‚Äôd need to include both on transact#2017-03-2214:14ddeaguiarbut I‚Äôd only query by the entity domain identifier#2017-03-2214:15ddeaguiarI need to go back and dig into Vase more deeply. My understanding of the internals is fuzzy so I‚Äôll stop there before I inadvertently lead you astray.#2017-03-2214:16degYes, Vase does seem to append the :db/id. But the samples, e.g. https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/samples/pet-store/resources/petstore-simple.edn, do also have a domain-specific identifier in the schema, but seem to assume that it somehow magically comes from the client, even on creation.#2017-03-2214:16ddeaguiarsure, it needs to come from the client#2017-03-2214:17ddeaguiaror#2017-03-2214:17ddeaguiaryou can add an interceptor that appends it#2017-03-2214:17ddeaguiarI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs a way to specify an attribute that get‚Äôs associated a value automatically upon transaction#2017-03-2214:18ddeaguiarmy instinct tells me that, if anything, that‚Äôs would be done by an interceptor sitting in front of the transact action#2017-03-2214:18ddeaguiarAt least that‚Äôs how I‚Äôd do it if I were building a Pedestal app#2017-03-2214:19degFor the client to do it, would require some kind of guid, not just e.g. a simple counter maintained on the server. (But, as I write this, I'm thinking that I'm being naive, and not addressing scalability. I‚Äôd have to try it#2017-03-2214:25ddeaguiarTo clarify, include both params in the :params collection, and use an or in the :query#2017-03-2214:25ddeaguiarBut I‚Äôve not tried it!#2017-03-2214:26deg[I have to run... back in a bit, one fast reply] I did try or, but failed to get it to work; with an obscure error message.#2017-03-2214:26ddeaguiarhmm, I‚Äôm going to try that later today. I‚Äôm curious#2017-03-2311:20degWell, I found a way to express, but it's ugly. Hope there is some nicer way to do this! ` :get #vase/query {:name :receipts-server.v1/user-get :params [name abbrev email] :query [:find ?e ?attr ?val ?found-email ?found-name ?found-abbrev ;; DBG :in $ ?name ?abbrev ?email :where [(count ?email) ?n-email] [(count ?name) ?n-name] [(count ?abbrev) ?n-abbrev] [(pos? ?n-email) ?p-email] [(pos? ?n-name) ?p-name] [(pos? ?n-abbrev) ?p-abbrev] [(and ?p-email :receipts.user/email) ?attr-email] [(and ?p-name :receipts.user/name) ?attr-name] [(and ?p-abbrev :receipts.user/abbrev) ?attr-abbrev] [(or ?attr-email ?attr-name ?attr-abbrev) ?attr] [(and ?p-email ?email) ?val-email] [(and ?p-name ?name) ?val-name] [(and ?p-abbrev ?abbrev) ?val-abbrev] [(or ?val-email ?val-name ?val-abbrev) ?val] [?e ?attr ?val] [?e :receipts.user/email ?found-email] ;; DBG [?e :receipts.user/name ?found-name] ;; DBG [?e :receipts.user/abbrev ?found-abbrev] ;; DBG ]} `#2017-03-2311:22deg(This is for a slightly harder case than what I asked -- three parameters) And, it still requires that the client pass in the empty parameters too, e.g. #2017-03-2313:05ddeaguiar@deg I did get a chance to explore using optional parameters with an or in a query. Here‚Äôs a snippet https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/d93a81282b60a261a2afb53262a3aeeb#2017-03-2313:07ddeaguiarYou can specify default values for parameters by using a vector instead of a symbol for the parameter 
[[foo :some-default] bar]
#2017-03-2313:07ddeaguiarthe first member of the vector will be the parameter and the second is the default#2017-03-2313:07degThanks. I did not know about the ability to supply default values. Not yet documented? Or did I just miss it in the docs?#2017-03-2313:07ddeaguiarlooking#2017-03-2313:09degRe using :or-join, I did try something similar, which failed, but did not checkpoint that attempt so I'm not sure what I did wrong. (The error was something about using different variables in the two clauses, but I think I did about what you did, so dunno)#2017-03-2313:09ddeaguiarhmm I don‚Äôt see that in the docs but I may have missed it#2017-03-2313:11ddeaguiarWhen you use an or clause in Datomic queries, all the clauses within it need to use the same set of variables#2017-03-2313:11ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs probably why you saw that error#2017-03-2313:11degThen, how does your example work, when one clause uses ?email and the other ?id ?#2017-03-2313:12ddeaguiarI‚Äôm using or-join#2017-03-2313:12degI thought I saw that erro with or-join. Maybe I'm misremembering#2017-03-2313:14ddeaguiarI‚Äôd recommend avoiding overly generalized queries. Queries that include predicates like [?e ?attr ?val]#2017-03-2313:15degI also notice your (pull ?e [*]) clause. I had found pull mentioned in some datomic doc, but had not been able to get the arguments to work for me. Again, I'm puzzled, because I think I tried the same thing in one of my attempts, but it wanted another arg. In any event, pull is also something that should be in the mythical doc I keep harping on. In any event, I'm not tweaking your sample to make sure it works in my file. I'm confused that it looks so close to what I had, yet mine didn't work. Should take me another 2-3 minutes.#2017-03-2313:16ddeaguiarHere‚Äôs a list of some query best practices http://docs.datomic.com/best-practices.html#most-selective-clauses-first#2017-03-2313:16ddeaguiarI‚Äôm not sure if that ones listed there, though#2017-03-2313:17ddeaguiarSince Vase is based on Datomic and Pedestal, It‚Äôs difficult to determine what‚Äôs the essential information to pull from each tech for documentation purposes. Here‚Äôs info on pull http://docs.datomic.com/pull.html#2017-03-2313:18ddeaguiarAnd here‚Äôs more on pull in the context of queries http://docs.datomic.com/query.html#pull-expressions#2017-03-2313:19degYour gist, with obvious mods, works in my app. No surprise. Thanks!#2017-03-2313:19ddeaguiarnp#2017-03-2313:20degI wonder what I did different yesterday, but never gonna know. Probably required the exact level of ignorance I had then.#2017-03-2313:20ddeaguiarone thing is that if email and id are provided and each match a different user, then you‚Äôll get two records back#2017-03-2313:20degYup. In general, the semantics of what I'm asking are pretty fuzzy.#2017-03-2313:20degIs there some way to ensure only one is passed in? I suppose that would be done with a one-liner interceptor?#2017-03-2313:21degActually, with a validator, I guess. right?#2017-03-2313:21ddeaguiarhmm, maybe#2017-03-2313:23ddeaguiarI‚Äôd have to play around with it to say for sure#2017-03-2313:25degok. Don't do so on my behalf; I'm already well past what I need for this toy learning app. But, if you want to expand the docs, it would certainly be great to see examples of this sort. Thanks!#2017-03-2313:26ddeaguiarBTW, are you using the snapshot release of Vase in your app?#2017-03-2313:27degyes, though I've not updated it for a day or two. Why?#2017-03-2313:27ddeaguiarJust checking, because using multiple parameters with query actions is broken on the current, stable release#2017-03-2313:27ddeaguiarit‚Äôs fixed on master#2017-03-2313:27ddeaguiarso I figured you were using the snapshot release#2017-03-2313:28degAh, ok. thanks.#2017-03-2313:28degHow often do you plan to release stable versions?#2017-03-2313:29ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs up to Paul and Mike. I‚Äôd need to follow up with them#2017-03-2313:29degAh, sorry. I thought you were one of the leads.#2017-03-2313:30ddeaguiarNope, just a contributor.#2017-03-2313:31degThen, double thank you. I appreciate all the time and help.#2017-03-2313:31ddeaguiaranytime!#2017-03-2314:59ddeaguiarfyi, https://twitter.com/datomic_team/status/844919159926476801#2017-03-2314:59mtnygard@deg You may enjoy some new Datomic training videos we released today: http://blog.datomic.com/2017/03/new-datomic-training-videos-and-getting.html#2017-03-2314:59ddeaguiarjinx!#2017-03-2314:59mtnygard@ddeaguiar lol#2017-03-2315:22ddeaguiar@deg, btw, I realize that my contrived example shared in the gist was based on your desire to use multiple parameters in an or-like way. I‚Äôve updated the gist to indicate how I‚Äôd likely implement support for looking up a user by email or id. https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/d93a81282b60a261a2afb53262a3aeeb#2017-03-2318:55degI see. Definitely cleaner, for this case; though I was doing this more as a contrived example. Of course, don't forget my friend, Mr. <mailto:/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|jo/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection>. (He's a cousin of Little Bobby Tables (https://xkcd.com/327/).#2017-03-2318:56degOh, and replying to above. Thanks for video links. I'll take a look.#2017-03-2321:02ddeaguiarI‚Äôve got a question for those folks who are interested in Vase.#2017-03-2321:03ddeaguiarWhat would be more useful: 1. Links to critical prerequisite Pedestal and Datomic docs or 2. Just-enough Pedestal/Datomic docs to get started?#2017-03-2321:03ddeaguiarI‚Äôm not sure what 2 would look like atm...#2017-03-2406:29alanspringfieldI would go with 1, that way you don't have to update the Vase docs everytime the Pedestal docs changes#2017-03-2411:46deg1, with a short roadmap doc.#2017-03-2412:24manutter51To follow up on my earlier issue, my fairly new pedestal service started throwing exceptions when starting the REPL, complaining that No matching ctor found for class io.pedestal.http.ring_middlewares$response_fn_adapter$fn__11673. After numerous lein clean, deleting and re-loading dependencies in ~/.m2, and other suggestions, I was still getting the error, but today it stopped happening.#2017-03-2412:25mtnygard@manutter51 I hate when bugs just go away on their own. That means they can come back on their own, too.#2017-03-2412:26manutter51I didn‚Äôt have time this morning to fully test it, but the thing that seems to have done the trick is moving the session configuration to the service map in service.clj. I thought I had done that earlier, but I realized I had added it to the map in server.clj that run-dev merges with the main service map.#2017-03-2412:26manutter51moving the session setting to the right map seems to have fixed the issue#2017-03-2412:27manutter51though I have no clue why that particular cause would have that particular effect.#2017-03-2419:10kennyIs the only way to exit the interceptor chain by throwing an exception? For example, I have 3 interceptors for my route and interceptor1 decides that the request should not be completed right now (maybe it was an invalid request, user not authorized, the server has other processing duties, etc.). Does interceptor1 have to throw an exception in order to stop subsequent interceptors from running, or is there another way?#2017-03-2419:12kennyI believe I found my answer üôÇ http://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.interceptor/io.pedestal.interceptor.chain.html#var-terminate#2017-03-2419:16ddeaguiar@kenny you can also have your interceptor return a response#2017-03-2419:17ddeaguiarOnce an interceptor returns a response, the execution of downstream interceptor :enter fns is terminated#2017-03-2419:18ddeaguiarwhoops#2017-03-2419:18ddeaguiar@kenny not return a response, assoc a response onto the context#2017-03-2419:19ddeaguiarso to state it correctly, once an interceptor assoc‚Äôs a response to the context, the execution of downstream interceptor :enter fns is terminated#2017-03-2419:19kennyAh gotcha. Unless I missed it, I don't believe that was mentioned in the docs.#2017-03-2419:20kennyIs the :leave called of subsequent interceptors?#2017-03-2419:21ddeaguiarso the :leave fn is called for all interceptors that were already executed#2017-03-2419:21kennyMakes sense.#2017-03-2419:22ddeaguiarHmm, I think you‚Äôre right about the docs (http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors), they don‚Äôt mention this.#2017-03-2419:25kennyYeah. I'd think it would go under "Interceptor Return Values"#2017-03-2419:25kennyNot sure if you'd ever want to do this but is it possible to terminate the :leave execution as well?#2017-03-2419:26kennyWait I don't think associng a :response onto the context stops the interceptor flow. I just tried it and my second interceptor got called#2017-03-2419:27ddeaguiarhmm, I do this all the time#2017-03-2419:27kennyThe second interceptor does not get called if I wrap the context with terminate.#2017-03-2419:29kennyYeah the second interceptor is definitely getting called even though the context has a :response assoc'ed on it.#2017-03-2419:29kennyI think that makes sense though.#2017-03-2419:29kennyExplicit termination is much better than implicit. Usually üòâ#2017-03-2419:30ddeaguiarThe interceptor after the one which assoc‚Äôd the response?#2017-03-2419:30kennyYes#2017-03-2419:30kenny
(def echo
  {:name :echo
   :enter
         (fn [context]
           (clojure.pprint/pprint context)
           (let [request (:request context)
                 response (ok context)]
             (assoc context :response response)))})

(def echo2
  {:name  :echo2
   :enter (fn [context]
            (println "echo2")
            context)})

(def routes
  (route/expand-routes
    #{["/foo" :post [echo echo2] :route-name :foo]}))
#2017-03-2419:30kennyecho2 is printed#2017-03-2419:31ddeaguiarhrmm, interesting#2017-03-2419:31kennyIf instead echo calls terminate: 
(def echo
  {:name :echo
   :enter
         (fn [context]
           (clojure.pprint/pprint context)
           (let [request (:request context)
                 response (ok context)]
             (chain/terminate (assoc context :response response))))})
then echo2 is not printed.#2017-03-2419:34ddeaguiarI‚Äôm going to play with this because it doesn‚Äôt behave how I expected. Perhaps things have changed!#2017-03-2419:35kennyYou may be getting unnecessary database load if the chain isn't actually terminating üôÇ#2017-03-2420:04ddeaguiar@kenny are you using a custom chain provider?#2017-03-2420:05ddeaguiaror a default setup using lein new pedestal-service#2017-03-2420:06kennyThis is the ns I'm messing with: http://pastebin.com/eMTkYEwu#2017-03-2420:13ddeaguiar@kenny, so this example (https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/74eed4784848e49fa83179a2086aa9ea) behaves as I described. Because the :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminators coll on the context has a single predicate which is set by the default servlet chain provider. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/41337e41ae773f3c17baeb1c244be13ddf6c28db/service/src/io/pedestal/http/impl/servlet_interceptor.clj#L231#2017-03-2420:13ddeaguiarYour example appears to use the default servlet chain provider as well#2017-03-2420:15ddeaguiarIn my example, when you request you‚Äôll see this in the logs 
16:01:31.660 [qtp2141354770-51] INFO  terminator.service - {:msg "In Terminator", :line 23}                                  ‚îÇ
16:01:31.663 [qtp2141354770-51] INFO  terminator.service - {:terminators (#function[io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor‚îÇ
16:01:31.663 [qtp2141354770-51] DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in check-terminators, :terminate? true, :execution-id‚îÇ
16:01:31.664 [qtp2141354770-51] DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in leave-all, :execution-id 19, :line 239}           ‚îÇ
16:01:31.666 [qtp2141354770-51] DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:interceptor :terminator.service/terminator, :stage :l‚îÇ
16:01:31.666 [qtp2141354770-51] INFO  terminator.service - {:msg "Leaving Terminator", :line 29}
#2017-03-2420:16ddeaguiarI added the following line to my logback.xml file to log what the interceptor chain is doing: 
<logger name="io.pedestal.interceptor.chain" level="DEBUG" />
#2017-03-2420:19kennyI understand why#2017-03-2420:19ddeaguiarbtw, I also recommend using fully qualified symbols in your routes#2017-03-2420:21kennyI copied this function from the guide. 
(defn response [status body & {:as headers}]
  {:status status :body body :headers headers})
If you don't provide headers (e.g. (response 200 "foo")) then it returns {:status 200, :body "foo", :headers {}} which is not a ring response. 
(ring.util.response/response? (response 200 "foo"))
=> false
#2017-03-2420:21kennyInstead you need to do this: 
(defn response [status body & {:as headers}]
  {:status status :body body :headers (or headers {})})
#2017-03-2420:21ddeaguiarBTW, I really appreciate you asking this question. I‚Äôve got a much deeper understanding of chain providers now!#2017-03-2420:22kennyOnce you do that the interceptor chain is terminated when a :response is assoc'ed onto the context.#2017-03-2420:22kennySame here üôÇ#2017-03-2420:22ddeaguiarhrm I think Pedestal needs better response checking#2017-03-2420:23ddeaguiarlike if something‚Äôs assoc‚Äôd to the context as :response but it‚Äôs not a valid response, then it should at least log a warning#2017-03-2420:23ddeaguiarSo, everything that drives Pedestal can be found in the context#2017-03-2420:24ddeaguiarIf you create a custom chain provider and don‚Äôt need terminators, then don‚Äôt add io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminators to the context#2017-03-2420:25ddeaguiarFor example, the Fast Pedestal example creates an initial context https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/fast-pedestal/src/fast_pedestal/fasterjetty_service.clj#L67#2017-03-2420:26ddeaguiarNotice how it lacks some keys#2017-03-2420:27ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs part of a custom chain provider bound to direct-jetty-provider#2017-03-2420:28ddeaguiarSo the nuance is, if you‚Äôre using a the default servlet chain provider, or another chain provider which terminates when a response is assoc‚Äôd to the context, then you don‚Äôt need to call terminate#2017-03-2420:29ddeaguiarI‚Äôll add a quote from ohpauleez > please don't terminate unless the situation is dire#2017-03-2420:30ddeaguiarmeaning, don‚Äôt explicitly call terminate#2017-03-2420:31kennyReally the only time you'd want to terminate is after you have returned a response.#2017-03-2420:33ddeaguiarand that‚Äôs handled for you#2017-03-2420:33kennyRight#2017-03-2420:34ddeaguiarSo another thing to remember is that handlers are interceptors#2017-03-2420:34ddeaguiarSo all of this makes sense, in retrospect#2017-03-2420:34ddeaguiarbut we always put handlers at the end of the interceptor chain#2017-03-2420:35ddeaguiarI‚Äôve actually never tried to put them anywhere else#2017-03-2420:36kennyNot sure if it'd ever make sense to put them anywhere else#2017-03-2420:36ddeaguiarexactly#2017-03-2420:36ddeaguiarIt doesn‚Äôt. Why I‚Äôve never done it#2017-03-2420:39ddeaguiarhehe, this was a great rabbit hole!#2017-03-2420:39kennyOn a side note, this came up because I was considering things like authentication. It's surprising that by default the only Pedestal authentication library geheimtur uses exceptions for control flow: https://github.com/propan/geheimtur/blob/master/src/geheimtur/interceptor.clj#L14#2017-03-2420:41ddeaguiarother auth impls do similar things#2017-03-2420:41ddeaguiarTake buddy-auth as an example#2017-03-2420:41kennyBut it is terrible for perf#2017-03-2420:41ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/funcool/buddy-auth#2017-03-2420:42kennyJust because other libs do it doesn't mean it was the right decision. IMO exceptions should only be used for exceptional things, not logic.#2017-03-2420:42ddeaguiarwhich, btw, I created a sample demonstrating it‚Äôs usage: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/503#2017-03-2420:42kennyhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/samples/fast-pedestal > Avoid throwing exceptions (especially in interceptors)#2017-03-2420:43ddeaguiaryeah, I tend to agree with you#2017-03-2420:43kennyAlso relevant: https://shipilev.net/blog/2014/exceptional-performance/#2017-03-2420:43kennyOne of my fav articles on exception performance.#2017-03-2420:45ddeaguiarSo, for example, with buddy-auth, you don‚Äôt have to throw, you could just return a response as well#2017-03-2420:45ddeaguiarMy sample throws because that‚Äôs the default usage#2017-03-2420:47kennyRight but because they have throwing as a default usage it hints others that the use of exceptions is acceptable for control flow.#2017-03-2420:47ddeaguiartrue#2017-03-2420:48ddeaguiarSo when I write interceptors for things like validation, I short-circuit by returning a response#2017-03-2420:48kennyAnd although it may work, it certainly isn't performant and there loads of articles about why exceptions shouldn't be used for that purpose.#2017-03-2420:48kennyYeah, that's exactly what I would do.#2017-03-2420:48kennyAnyway, the docs definitely need to be updated.#2017-03-2420:49ddeaguiarThanks for the article link. I‚Äôll check that out later#2017-03-2420:50kennyIt's long but I think it's valuable knowledge üôÇ#2017-03-2420:52kennyI'll open an issue in pedestal-docs. If I have time this weekend I'll submit a PR.#2017-03-2420:54kennyAh, looks like you already did üôÇ#2017-03-2420:54ddeaguiarhehe yeah. Feel free to pick it up#2017-03-2614:28deg@ddeaguiar - in you gist a few days back (https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/d93a81282b60a261a2afb53262a3aeeb), what exactly is returned by pull ?e [*]? In my case - where a single result is found, I'm seeing [[[{"db/id":17592186045428,"receipts.user/name":"David Goldfarb","...}]]], but [[]] when there are no matches. It seems that the first case has an extra vector wrapped around it.#2017-03-2614:45degAnother Vase question (unrelated to previous): It looks like, (judging by the example code, e.g. https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/samples/petstore-full/resources/petstore-full-order.edn): :get requests take unadorned keywords as parameters to a #vase/query literal. But :post queries need fully namespaced keywords to pass to a #vase/transact. Is this asymmetry really there, or am I misunderstanding something. If so, why?#2017-03-2615:16mtnygard@deg There's a subtle reason for the difference, and it's reflected in the way those two different literals are formed. A query often uses parameters that come from the browser in a query string (e.g., for a GET, PUT, or DELETE.) These arrive from Pedestal as either :path-params or :query-params. Their names are URL-encoded by the browser and would be part of the request string in most cases. E.g., GET on /users/mtnygard would have a path that bind the last fragment to :id. None of these have anything to do with the Datomic schema or it's attribute names.#2017-03-2615:18mtnygardOTOH, transactions are directly dealing with form data. The :properties key on the transact literal is a whitelist of parameters from the form body that directly name Datomic attributes on the given entity. So they may be namespaced if you define your Datomic schema that way.#2017-03-2615:50deg@mtnygard - That makes sense; or at least each half makes sense in isolation. But, it feels like the is forcing the creation of asymmetric APIs. I don't want to speculate about ways to fix it; I have some ideas, but anything I say will be naive and/or wrong at this stage, but it just has a funny smell to me. Are there any public samples of clients that interact with Vase servers? I'd feel more comfortable expressing an opinion once I see how this is used by folks who know what they are doing.#2017-03-2718:11ddeaguiar@mtnygard, regarding your last comment, when I think of form data, I think of traditional forms and the application/x-www-form-urlencoded and multipart/form-data encodings. I‚Äôm thinking request body is a more appropriate term.#2017-03-2719:40degActually, are there any good samples of CLJS clients that play nicely with Vase servers? (I know the easy answer is "Vase is REST and REST is standard so anything works") but it seems to me that the answer is more subtle than that... namespace issues; sharing schemas between client and server; dev tools and environments; etc.#2017-03-2719:42degI'm wresting many more issues than I would have guessed, trying to write a toy app. Much is my own learning curve, so I'm not yet sure which (if any) of the gaps are real.#2017-03-2719:42ddeaguiarHmm, I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd say Vase is REST. Folks throw around that term loosely nowadays.#2017-03-2719:43ddeaguiarI think the exclusion of the term REST in the README is done on purpose#2017-03-2719:44degYou're right. I should have said something like Vase makes it easy to write REST-like and similar APIs that are designed to play nicely with any standard language for the client app, rather than forcing clients to be CLJS#2017-03-2719:44ddeaguiarre: clients, theoretically any client will do. There is a sample that is intended to be used with Om.next#2017-03-2719:44ddeaguiaralthough Om.next is sorely under documented üòû#2017-03-2719:46ddeaguiarReagent is pretty easy to learn/use https://github.com/reagent-project/reagent#2017-03-2719:46degBut, my point -- reinforced by what you just said -- is that Vase's focus is "any client will do". It makes it very easy to inter-operate, but may lose some of the extra advantages that come from using one language and, more importantly, one dev environemnt, across the client and server.#2017-03-2719:46degYes, I use reagent. That part is not the problem.#2017-03-2719:48degIt's more issues like: - namespaced keywords have suddenly become interesting in Clojure 1.9, but I don't yet have a good model of how to play nicely with them. - Sharing schemas across client and server encourages a three project design (client, server, and a shared code library including the schema). But, the minute I have two Lein packages in my CLJS environment, and actively edit both of them, then a lot of the niceties of Figwheel and friends just disappear.#2017-03-2719:53degMy immediate problem is that the ecosystem is so vast and fragmented, that I don't know yet if (1) I'm hitting known gaps or (2) I'm doing things stupidly/unconventionally, so I'm banging my head against unusual problems or (3) tools/practices do exist to solve my problems, but I've simply not found them yet.#2017-03-2719:55ddeaguiarhmm so you don‚Äôt have to have different lein projects. You can share code that‚Äôs in a cljc file. See https://github.com/clojure/clojurescript/wiki/Using-cljc#2017-03-2719:55ddeaguiarIt depends on the system you are building#2017-03-2719:56ddeaguiarBut you don‚Äôt have to lose tooling support#2017-03-2719:57mtnygard@deg @ddeaguiar I do recommend multiple modules (possibly in different repos) for the client, server, and shared. I can offer ‚Äúleiningen checkouts‚Äù as a feature that eases the pain of using code across libraries. That allows you to avoid repeated ‚Äúlein install‚Äù commands on every code change.#2017-03-2719:57mtnygard@deg Also, if you have a REPL open to a process, you can reload a namespace that belongs to a library just the same way you would reload a namespace from the local project. It just replaces symbol definitions in the JVM.#2017-03-2719:58mtnygardBut more broadly, I sympathize. There are so many different permutations of web framework, client library, build tooling, etc. that it‚Äôs hard to find one project that shows a canonical way to connect the parts.#2017-03-2719:59mtnygardI‚Äôm working on that as I have time available. E.g., there are several projects on my personal github profile that illustrate different combinations of tech.#2017-03-2719:59mtnygardFor example: https://github.com/mtnygard/todo-backend-pedestal-vase#2017-03-2720:00mtnygardBut I don‚Äôt have any public projects that connect the front end because that‚Äôs a new area for me. I‚Äôm just learning the best ways to do that myself.#2017-03-2720:00degMy previous project used luminus + reagent/react + figwheel + cdier , etc. It was all very nicely integrated and easy to develop. The one tooling downside was that the project.clj was a complete bear. Except for adding new libraries, I was afraid to touch any part of it.#2017-03-2720:01degThis time, I'm playing with Vase. I'm attracted by its leaner feel and better separation of concerns. But, I'm discovering now that this comes with a price.#2017-03-2720:01mtnygardI have a non-public project that uses Reagent and figwheel on the client. Vase and custom interceptors on the server. CIDER for everything.#2017-03-2720:01mtnygardIt‚Äôs just not something I have the right to open up.#2017-03-2720:02mtnygard(Oh, and there‚Äôs an Electron client, to boot.)#2017-03-2720:02degWould you be able to get the rights to release a stripped down version of it?#2017-03-2720:02mtnygardMost likely. It‚Äôll be a week or so before I can publish anything though.#2017-03-2720:02ddeaguiarMaybe we create an issue to add a sample to the Vase repo?#2017-03-2720:02ddeaguiarI‚Äôd be happy to pick that up as well#2017-03-2720:02mtnygard@ddeaguiar Without question.#2017-03-2720:03ddeaguiarOk. I‚Äôll add it#2017-03-2720:03mtnygardI think the samples right now kind of miss the mark. They‚Äôre either too isolated or too esoteric.#2017-03-2720:03deg(FWIW, in my consulting business, I've long had a clause in my contracts distinguishing between code that belongs to my clients and code that belongs to my library -- and I've always kept the right to add my library while working on client projects. In decades of doing this, I've never had a client complain, and it added value for them and all future clients)#2017-03-2720:04mtnygardYep, we have the same. There‚Äôs still a notification process though.#2017-03-2720:06degI managed to get away without the notification clause. But, that may have just been a combination of luck and small/intimidated clients. A few much larger companies forced us to sign their contracts, and kept things more isolated, so the point was moot.#2017-03-2720:06degBut, I digress. üôÇ#2017-03-2720:07degI'm happy to help out with making samples more usable. I think my outside perspective will help catch holes -- if nothing else, I'll be helping myself learn better.#2017-03-2720:09ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/issues/65#2017-03-2720:22mtnygardOK, authorization procured. Now I need a few hours to strip it down to a manageable sample.#2017-03-2805:49jimmyis this example relevant ? or we all change to use component reload workflow now ? https://github.com/pedestal/samples/tree/master/auto-reload-server#2017-03-2813:18ddeaguiar@nxqd That sample repository is deprecated.#2017-03-2813:18ddeaguiar> These samples are deprecated All maintained samples can be found within the Pedestal repository, with further documentation on the Pedestal site.#2017-03-2813:23ddeaguiarUsage of Stuart Sierra‚Äôs reloaded workflow is great when using his Component library although the ideas are more generally applicable#2017-03-2813:50jimmy@ddeaguiar ah, my bad.#2017-03-2813:50ddeaguiarNot sure about that. I wonder how many folks inadvertently make that mistake#2017-03-2813:51jimmyI do use reloaded workflow, but I always think it would be great that new comer knows about it and it should be integrated by default within pedestal.#2017-03-2813:54ddeaguiarI tend to use component-based systems quite frequently but I‚Äôve also found Pedestal‚Äôs support for reloading routes while developing quite good and sufficient for most situations.#2017-03-2813:56ddeaguiarI think the goal with Pedestal is that, once you start a server, you shouldn‚Äôt need to restart it to make changes to your handlers/interceptors#2017-03-2813:56ddeaguiarPaul talked about this somewhere. I can‚Äôt recall off-hand#2017-03-2813:59ddeaguiarBTW, service-tools does include ns watching and reloading utilities (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-tools/src/io/pedestal/service_tools/dev.clj), but I have to admit that I don‚Äôt really use them#2017-03-2814:00ddeaguiarIt‚Äôs included as a dev dependency in projects built with the pedestal-service template#2017-03-2814:00mtnygardThere's also this: http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component#2017-03-2814:01ddeaguiarYeah, true!#2017-03-2814:20jimmythanks guys üòÑ#2017-03-2814:23ddeaguiarI‚Äôd like to update that guide at some point. I‚Äôm now using component.repl vs reloaded.repl#2017-03-2814:23ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/stuartsierra/component.repl#2017-03-2814:23ddeaguiarI prefer it because it supports the convention of using a dev ns#2017-03-2814:33degAnother newbie-biting error message: I'm not sure if this one is best caught by Vase or Datomic...
