One of them has a null value, but the error message does not help me know which one: `ERROR i.p.http.impl.servlet-interceptor - {:msg "Dev interceptor caught an exception; Forwarding it as the response.", :line 313} clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Interceptor Exception: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: :db.error/nil-value Nil is not a legal value at clojure.core$ex_info.invokeStatic(core.clj:4725) at clojure.core$ex_info.invoke(core.clj:4725) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$throwable__GT_ex_info.invokeStatic(chain.clj:33) ...`#2017-03-2814:36ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs best caught by Datomic imo, but i recall seeing the tuple in question in the error message when that‚Äôs happened to me. So far, all of my server-side "code" has been just data in the .edn file.#2017-03-2815:15ddeaguiarYou can define an interceptor using the #vase/intercept tagged literal#2017-03-2815:15ddeaguiaror define it externally and include it, IIRC#2017-03-2815:17ddeaguiarBe aware of the rough edges around interceptors defined with #vase/intercept. How do I know the :db/id if I don't even know if the entity exists yet?#2017-03-2815:33mtnygard@deg I'd recommend using an attribute that uniquely identifies the entity in question, but not the db/id.#2017-03-2815:34mtnygardhttp://docs.datomic.com/identity.html talks about uniqueness and identity attributes. The short version is that using :db/unique :db.unique/identity on an attribute means that any new assertions with that value for the attribute get merged into any existing entity. It's upsert for free, basically.#2017-03-2815:36ddeaguiarThanks for clarifying @mtnygard. I thought I had seen some code in Vase that assoc‚Äôd a :db/id if it wasn‚Äôt present in a submitted entity.#2017-03-2815:36mtnygardHmm... let me double-check that.#2017-03-2815:37degI'm hitting a blind spot here. According to the your_first_api doc, I need to add :db/id in my my transact properties, iff I don't want to create a new object. But, my client does not know if it needs to create a new object then ....#2017-03-2815:37ddeaguiaryeah, that won‚Äôt work#2017-03-2815:37ddeaguiar@mtnygard try it with the sample Petstore app#2017-03-2815:37ddeaguiarI get this error message when I try to upsert 
Caused by: datomic.impl.Exceptions$IllegalStateExceptionInfo: :db.error/unique-conflict Unique conflict: :pet-store.pet/id, value: 1 already held by: 17592186045422 asserted for: 17592186045424
#2017-03-2815:38mtnygardI'm looking at com.cognitect.vase.actions/process-id right now. Basically, it says if there's no db/id on the transaction, then a tempid will be assigned. If an entity has a tempid and uses the same value for a :db.unique/identity attribute, it is supposed to be merged.#2017-03-2815:39mtnygardI think the issue is that pet-store uses :db.unique/value when it should use :db.unique/identity.#2017-03-2815:40degAnother, maybe related question. Thanks for catching that, I should have known!#2017-03-2815:49mtnygardThat's a defect in the sample.#2017-03-2815:51ddeaguiarI didn‚Äôt realize the code in the transact action conditionally assoc‚Äôd a :db/id based on the presence of an identity attribute. That totally makes sense and is smart to boot!#2017-03-2815:54deg@mtnygard, so, re your tempid answer above. So, if I want to add a maybe new entity, I need to: - Try to get it - If found, update with whatever changes I have - If not found, create it - After creating it, if I need to do anything else with the entity, either get it again, or have other unique property I can use to identify it#2017-03-2816:02mtnygard@deg You're going to have to start assigning correlation-id's to your posts here... I think we're getting out-of-order and interleaved responses.#2017-03-2816:03mtnygardLet's start from your needs. In your domain, is there a "natural" key for your entities?#2017-03-2816:04degIn most cases, yes; the name of the object. I'm still playing as I code, so I'm not sure that the answer is always yes.#2017-03-2816:05mtnygardOK, when there is a natural key: use the :identity option in the schema. When POSTing such an entity, use the attribute. It will upsert every time based on that attribute.#2017-03-2816:05degTo a large extent, I'm writing this as a learning exercise, so my goal will often be to push the tool to the edge.#2017-03-2816:06mtnygardWhen other entities need to refer to it, use a lookup ref as described in http://docs.datomic.com/identity.html as the value of the ref attribute that should point to that object.#2017-03-2816:06mtnygardWhen querying, just use the object name attribute.#2017-03-2816:07mtnygardIf you can do that in every case, then you shouldn't need to touch the db/ids.#2017-03-2816:08degok. I'm going to dive into my keyboard to reorganize my code this way. Back in a bit if I hit snags. Thanks!! (Feels like I'm commandeered this channel as my private support line!)#2017-03-2816:09mtnygard@deg No worries. Also, I've confirmed that the paragraph you mentioned ("The JSON packet above, because it does not contain a :db/id field refers to a new entity and the return value from the Vase service will return its newly created :db/id. On the other hand, the following JSON refers to an existing entity in the database:") is just plain wrong.#2017-03-2816:09mtnygardBut at the same time, there's something hinky about the response body from the transact action.#2017-03-2818:17deg@mtnygard Nice improvements to the your_first_api doc in your changes today! A couple of bits that are still potentially unclear: - One note: Vase tracks which schemas it has already applied - this is hinting at deep concept that won't be obvious to many readers: that the schemas are tuples in the database rather than static definitions. It would be great to explain this, along with why/what, earlier in the doc. - ...treats it as a new entity and attaches a tempid - What is a tempid?#2017-03-2820:56ddeaguiar@deg this is an implementation detail, but Vase uses for tracking schemas (https://github.com/rkneufeld/conformity). I exemplified with response-for because I did not test "in the real world"#2017-03-3016:02ddeaguiar‚Äù/path?foo=&bar=123"#2017-03-3016:03ddeaguiaryou are missing the = after foo#2017-03-3016:03ddeaguiarso what I pasted is what url-for would emit#2017-03-3016:04ddeaguiar(url-for ::web/foo-bar :query-params {:foo nil :bar 123})#2017-03-3016:04ddeaguiarin tests you do something like this to create a url-for helper#2017-03-3016:06ddeaguiar
(def url-for (http.route/url-for-routes web/routes)
#2017-03-3016:06ddeaguiaryou may need to expand your routes#2017-03-3106:07jimmyhi guys, in pedestal, sometimes they use ::server in service map sometimes ::http. What is the different ?#2017-03-3106:12rauh@nxqd I think they're just differently aliased. Check out the ns :requires#2017-03-3106:14jimmyoh my, it's my bad. THanks !#2017-03-3113:07mtnygard@nxqd The ::server convention came from the early days of Pedestal and Clojure, when we didn't have very strong conventions about namespace aliases. More "modern" Clojure usage says you should use the last part of the namespace as the alias, so we've changed the templates to conform with that convention. That gives us ::http as the alias for io.pedestal.http.#2017-03-3116:26jimmy@mtnygard great answer as always#2017-04-0106:00bradfordHi! I'm getting an odd error message at compile time:#2017-04-0106:03bradfordInvalid token: ::http/routes, which is rather odd. Here's the log and code: http://bit.ly/2oJmQgi#2017-04-0106:04rauh@bradford You should require pedestal with :as http for the keywords to be pedestal namespaced keywords#2017-04-0106:06bradford@rauh That was it! thanks#2017-04-0106:38bradfordOK, new prob. I'm getting no response (not a 404), when I POST to localhost:8080/recs. The code's pretty simple, though... any ideas? http://bit.ly/2olEzOr#2017-04-0114:03ddeaguiar@bradford defroutes is considered deprecated. You should use def with the tersre route syntaxt as follows: 
;; Terse/Vector-based routes
(def routes
  `[[["/" {:get home-page}
      ^:interceptors [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body]
      ["/about" {:get about-page}]]]])
#2017-04-0114:03ddeaguiarI recommend using the table syntax instead. See http://pedestal.io/guides/defining-routes#_a_note_about_routing_syntax#2017-04-0114:04ddeaguiarRefer to http://pedestal.io/reference/table-syntax#2017-04-0114:04ddeaguiarHope this helps#2017-04-0114:10ddeaguiarOne other thing, although the example in the table-syntax reference uses route/expand-routes, don‚Äôt use it in your route definition#2017-04-0114:11ddeaguiarPedestal will expand routes for you on start up if it‚Äôs default-interceptors fn is called. Which is probably in most cases since I suspect that overriding the default interceptors is less common.#2017-04-0114:11ddeaguiarI‚Äôm going to create an issue in the http://Pedestal.io guides about that#2017-04-0114:14ddeaguiarBut, you‚Äôll need to explicitly expand routes if you want to create and use a url-for helper in your tests.#2017-04-0115:07ddeaguiarFor those interested in auth samples, the geheimtur demo app has been updated to use the latest version of Pedestal. See https://github.com/propan/geheimtur-demo#2017-04-0115:09ddeaguiarGeheimtur has also been updated (https://github.com/propan/geheimtur).#2017-04-0120:02bradford@ddeaguiar thanks!#2017-04-0302:29jimmyDo you guys know if I assign ::http/interceptors [] , even it's an empty vector, then when there is an error, the only message I got is : Internal server error : no response. if I don't have ::http/interceptors, it returns a nice stack trace for me to debug. What is the right way to provide default interceptors on current service ?#2017-04-0305:32jimmyhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Cf-STRvFy8 Great talk, cannot wait to see pedestal chain on clojurescript !#2017-04-0305:58rauh@nxqd Just update conj the ::http/interceptors after you put called the default-interceptors. (Without the :http/interceptors since if default-interceptors sees that map key it won't do anything.)#2017-04-0305:59jimmy@rauh thanks.#2017-04-0318:19borkdudeIs content negotiation + coercion a manual practice like described in http://pedestal.io/guides/hello-world-content-types or is there some provided sane defaults in Pedestal?#2017-04-0318:30ddeaguiar@borkdude, AFAIK that‚Äôs how it‚Äôs done.#2017-04-0319:21crimeministerHi all, is this the right place for Vase-related questions or should I take it to #vase?#2017-04-0319:23ddeaguiar@crimeminister not sure who‚Äôs using #vase. I think this is the right place for now.#2017-04-0319:23crimeministerCool!#2017-04-0319:25crimeministerAm wondering about the possibility of using specs defined in an external library; getting Unable to resolve spec: :com.example/some-spec when I try. Anyone know if this is supported?#2017-04-0319:26crimeministerI should go spelunking, but figured it couldn't hurt to ask first ;)#2017-04-0319:27ddeaguiarSo I assume you mean specs that are registered via s/def, correct?#2017-04-0319:27crimeministerYes#2017-04-0319:28ddeaguiarIf so then I don‚Äôt see why that wouldn‚Äôt work. I imagine you need to require the appropriate namespaces before reading in the vase descriptor(s)#2017-04-0319:28crimeministerCool, I will give it another whirl, thank you#2017-04-0319:32crimeministerThat worked, much appreciated#2017-04-0319:32ddeaguiarnp, glad to help!#2017-04-0319:33crimeministerAm wondering: would it make sense to provide a list of namespaces to require as part of the Vase edn config?#2017-04-0319:36ddeaguiarI think that‚Äôs app-specific. You normally won‚Äôt need much more than what‚Äôs defined in the service.clj file which is created by the Vase lein template.#2017-04-0319:37ddeaguiarRemember specs are registered globally. They‚Äôre actually stored in an atom defined in the spec ns.#2017-04-0319:38ddeaguiarThey get registered when the ns they are defined in is evaluated#2017-04-0319:39ddeaguiarThis means that specs defined in your descriptor(s) are also available elsewhere in your Vase-enabled app#2017-04-0319:39crimeministerAgreed, just thinking that on occasion it might be useful to specify a namespace to evaluate as part of Vase config so the spec can be used by a #vase/validate without a having to touch server/service.clj. Minor thing though.#2017-04-0319:40crimeministerDidn't realize that was how spec was implemented; interesting#2017-04-0319:40ddeaguiarOh, I see what you are asking for#2017-04-0319:41crimeministerI have several apps all using shared specs in a library, just pulling those into the Vase microservice I am playing with#2017-04-0319:43ddeaguiarHmm, IMO the convenience does not outweigh the trouble of implementing and supporting such a feature.#2017-04-0319:44crimeministerQuite likely, and not sure how common this pattern is anyways#2017-04-0319:44crimeministerNo doubt others will chime in if it might be useful ;)#2017-04-0319:44ddeaguiarvery true!#2017-04-0320:39borkdudeDoes anyone got an example how to load resources from a jar? I tried this: 
(def font-awesome-webjars-resource-path ‚ÄúMETA-INF/resources/webjars/font-awesome/4.7.0‚Äù)
‚Ä¶
service-map {::http/routes routes
                            ::http/type   :jetty
                            ::http/join?  false
                            ::http/resource-path "/public"
                            ;; Doesn't work yet
                            ::http/default-interceptors [(middlewares/resource
                                                          font-awesome-webjars-resource-path)
                                                         ]
                            ::http/port port}
#2017-04-0322:48crimeministerI think you might want to look at , specifically (io/resource ‚Ä¶)#2017-04-0322:48crimeministerAm in transit, otherwise would post a more substantial example, sorry#2017-04-0409:40borkdudeWhat‚Äôs wrong in this expression? 
(route/expand-routes [[["/foo" {:get foo}]]])
#2017-04-0409:45borkdudeHmm, this worked: (defroutes routes [[["/foo" {:get foo}]]])#2017-04-0409:46borkdudeApparently I needed to quote the vector before calling expand-routes#2017-04-0413:09ddeaguiar@borkdude, defroutes has been deprecated. You shouldn‚Äôt call route/expand-routes if Pedestal‚Äôs default-interceptors are being applied since it will expand routes for you. I also recommend using the table route syntax as described here: http://pedestal.io/guides/defining-routes#_a_note_about_routing_syntax#2017-04-0413:16degWhat is the recommended way to share a Vase schema with my CLJS client code?#2017-04-0413:25deg(e.g., for client-side validity testing)#2017-04-0413:39ddeaguiarHrm, I don‚Äôt know of a recommended way. There‚Äôs the Validation action but that doesn‚Äôt involve sharing schema.#2017-04-0413:41ddeaguiarYou could share specs between Clojure Clojurescript code but there are some caveats to that. I can‚Äôt comment on the practicalities of it since I‚Äôve not done it.#2017-04-0414:06degThe validation action is server-side validation. Often, I'll want some preliminary validation on the client-side too. Even the most basic client needs to know, e.g., whether an input field should be text, password, or numeric. It makes sense to me that this should be driven by the same DRY knowledge as the Vase schemas. But. this doesn't seem to be easy to do, at least not while following the conventions in the Vase samples I've seen.#2017-04-0415:33mtnygard@deg My vision for that is that Vase will be able to generate a Swagger spec to describe itself. Full disclosure though: it's on the roadmap but not being worked right now.#2017-04-0415:54deg@mtnygard That sounds like a very good thing, but I think it may be both too much and too little. Too little: Swagger's syntax is richer than Vase's, so I guess you are talking about a one-time tool to generate an initial Swagger spec. Too much: I envision something simpler - a natural way to compose the Vase .edn file from smaller pieces, some of which would be natural to share with the client code. (My use case is a server and client evolving simultaneously and owned by the same team).#2017-04-0416:14malchYeah, I'd also want to pass some values to the Vase edn - datomic-uri, for instance. I'm wrapping my whole application in integrant (same with Component, doesn't matter) and would like to pass this config to my server component#2017-04-0419:27borkdude@ddeaguiar I was actually using Pedestal-API which adds another layer of macros to be confused by üôÇ#2017-04-0520:00curtosis@rauh looking back to your ::http/interceptors statement, that‚Äôs the problem I think I‚Äôm having right now. Can you say more about what that should look like?#2017-04-0605:32rauh@curtosis Make sure you understand clojure syntax. :foo/bar is a normal namespaced keyword with foo being the namespace. ::foo/bar however resolves to the namespace of the alias foo#2017-04-0612:50curtosis@rauh I do understand that. What I wasn‚Äôt getting (but do now) was how the default-interceptors interacted with ::http/interceptors ‚Äì specifically, that ::http/interceptors takes manual control and doesn‚Äôt include the defaults.#2017-04-0612:51curtosiswhich was sort of what you were saying, but it didn‚Äôt quite parse for me there. got it now!#2017-04-0621:13degWhat is returned by :find (pull ?e [*]) in a #vase/query? It seems to have more levels of nesting than I see in the Datomic pull documentation. I'm just ignoring the seemingly unused bits of the structure, but this feels like I'm doing something very wrong: 
(defn response-from-pull [pull-response]
  (let [relevant (first pull-response)
        cruft1 (next pull-response)
        cruft2 (not-empty (remove nil? (map next relevant)))]
    (when (or cruft1 cruft2)
      (prn "ERROR: Unexpected pull response: " pull-response))
    (mapv first relevant)))
#2017-04-0623:58ddeaguiar[*] returns a map containing all top level keys of an entity plus the keys of any component attributes.#2017-04-0623:59ddeaguiarRefer to http://docs.datomic.com/pull.html#wildcard-specifications#2017-04-0623:59ddeaguiar@deg ^^#2017-04-0700:40mtnygard@ddeaguiar Looking for a sanity check. #vase/transact properties do not allow for defaults. However, Datomic doesn‚Äôt allow nils in transactions. That means we can‚Äôt have optional properties to a transact. Seems like an oversight to me. I want to add the same defaulting syntax to transact‚Äôs properties that query‚Äôs params has. Does anything there sound like it violates the principle of least surprise?#2017-04-0713:23ddeaguiar@U06BLR1C6, I‚Äôm biased by my knowledge of Datomic, so I think it does violate the principle of least surprise. It would make Query and Transact more symmetrical, though. However, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a good enough reason to make it a supported feature. It‚Äôs also something that can be easily implemented on the client side. I‚Äôd hold off unless there‚Äôs a demand for it.#2017-04-0713:24ddeaguiarIf anything, nils should be filtered out. I don‚Äôt know if this is a property of #vase/transact or not#2017-04-0715:16mtnygardFiltering nils is a good idea. I‚Äôll do that now because it‚Äôs the smaller change to behavior.#2017-04-0701:45imetallicaHi everyone, I'm not being able to make Pedestal reload code on changes from the default project template. WARN io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor - {:msg "The pipe closed while async writing to the client; Client most likely disconnected.", :line 111, :src-chan #object[clojure.core.async.impl.channels.ManyToManyChannel 0x23572315 "clojure.core.async.impl.channels.ManyToManyChannel@23572315"]}
#2017-04-0813:37ddeaguiar@kenny, I don‚Äôt have a lot of experience with SSE, but I think so. See https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/359. Pedestal cleans up everything it creates when shutting down an SSE stream and it provides a hook via the on-client-disconnect option which can be set when starting the event stream.#2017-04-0813:39ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/5b2450f67b3ea5ad8e853467e6305cee5125497c/service/src/io/pedestal/http/sse.clj#L211#2017-04-0813:41ddeaguiarthe doc-string states that on-client-disconnect takes an arg but the code indicates it‚Äôs a no args fn.#2017-04-0813:50ddeaguiaractually#2017-04-0813:50ddeaguiarI‚Äôm wrong#2017-04-0813:51ddeaguiarThe on-client-disconnect function does take one argument, the context.#2017-04-0813:51ddeaguiarRefer to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/5b2450f67b3ea5ad8e853467e6305cee5125497c/service/src/io/pedestal/http/sse.clj#L199#2017-04-0816:58mtnygardI added https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Cf-STRvFy8 to http://pedestal.io#2017-04-1022:40kenny@ddeaguiar Hmm, I'm not sure what's happening then. That would let the library use its version but the application's version would automatically override it.#2017-04-1217:26souenzzoI finally understood :provided#2017-04-1218:31bahulneel@mtnygard I've never really understood how scopes work, is there a place I can go to learn?#2017-04-1218:47ddeaguiar@bahulneel refer to https://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introduction-to-dependency-mechanism.html. Maven is used under the covers#2017-04-1218:48bahulneel@ddeaguiar Would explain why I've had little success in finding documentation üôÇ, thanks for the help.#2017-04-1218:59ddeaguiarnp!#2017-04-1219:07ddeaguiar@bahulneel I more exact answer is that Lein uses https://github.com/cemerick/pomegranate under the covers. Pomegranate wraps Sonatype Aether. The scopes are Maven scopes (https://github.com/cemerick/pomegranate/blob/pomegranate-0.3.0/src/main/clojure/cemerick/pomegranate/aether.clj#L632). So the Maven docs are still a good place to look.#2017-04-1219:13ddeaguiarAnd I suppose the :dependencies vector in project.clj is more precisely referred to as a vector of Maven coordinates.#2017-04-1219:26bahulneelThanks all#2017-04-1220:21degHey, so I just watched https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Cf-STRvFy8. But it might be better to implement a stateful interceptor#2017-04-2018:24ddeaguiarYou can create a record that implements the IntoInterceptor protocol https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj#L23#2017-04-2018:24mtnygard@hagmonk I'll also put in a plug for the pedestal.log module as a way to convey the metrics out of the process#2017-04-2018:25ddeaguiar@mtnygard true, pedestal.log has metrics support#2017-04-2018:25hagmonkooh, see I knew I was missing something#2017-04-2018:25ddeaguiaractually that would probably be easiest, no?#2017-04-2018:25ddeaguiareach :enter/:leave fn could emit a metric#2017-04-2018:26mtnygardwell, I don't want to get you too excited... the interceptor chain provider doesn't track metrics. that is still up to your interceptors.#2017-04-2018:27ddeaguiaryes, but you‚Äôre free to emit metrics using pedestal.log from your lifecycle implementations#2017-04-2018:28ddeaguiargiven that, I‚Äôd use a higher-order fn which does that and wraps the :enter/:leave impls#2017-04-2018:28hagmonkit seems to use dropwizard which is perfect, the wrapper looks nicer than metrics-clojure anyway#2017-04-2018:29hagmonkso I could create an interceptor chain, then map a wrapper fn that handles metrics over that#2017-04-2018:29hagmonkor investigate an IntoInterceptor record#2017-04-2018:30ddeaguiarhrm, I‚Äôll redact my IntoInterceptor record recommendation. At least for now#2017-04-2018:30ddeaguiarI think it‚Äôs simpler to use a metrics wrapper#2017-04-2018:31ddeaguiarOf course I‚Äôm designing this off the top of my head. The key insight is to use pedestal.log‚Äôs metric support#2017-04-2018:31hagmonkI think it's simpler too, but I'm learning a lot by reading the pedestal source#2017-04-2018:32ddeaguiargreat stuff to be found there!#2017-04-2018:32hagmonkI'm executing this chain on top of an Apache Ignite cluster so I'm pondering if I can capitalize on that somehow#2017-04-2018:33ddeaguiarNot familiar with Apache Ignite so I can‚Äôt comment#2017-04-2018:34hagmonkideas will come to me as I implement, more just thinking out loud üòâ#2017-04-2018:40hagmonkI've been musing on this idea for general Clojure functions, but maybe interceptors are a better context. That idea was attaching metadata to functions that simply says "time how long this takes", or "attach this Failsafe policy", or "rename the thread of execution inside this function"#2017-04-2018:40hagmonkseems like I could build that on top of interceptors way easier than trying to figure out how to do meta magic on top of naked clojure functions#2017-04-2018:41mtnygardI agree. üôÇ#2017-04-2018:41hagmonkI suspected you might üòâ#2017-04-2018:47hagmonkoh, the interceptor queue is an instance of the furtive clojure.lang.PersistentQueue. - Integration with "" for querying and tailing server log and syslog messages. See the Papertrail section in the online help for more details.
- Remote files can be opened when lnav is built with libcurl v7.23.0+

I have a query containing 
`
:query [:find [(pull ?e [*]) ...]
        :where [?e :user/name]]
` It sometimes returns a vector of my tuples, and other times returns a seq whose first is the vector of tuples. Clarification: I'm not yet sure what I mean by "sometimes". I'm seeing these different results in different machines and environments (Ubuntu vs Docker on Ubuntu vs Mac; all built from the same repo, but...) so I assume I've changed some moving part that affects this behavior.#2017-04-2316:46degHmm, just realized that I might have been faked out by browser caching. (I had returned from vacation, back to a machine that had last run before I made some server changes). But, I'm still curious exactly what that pull syntax is supposed to return.#2017-04-2317:05souenzzoIt's #datomic stuff but pull returns a map. In this case, you r using a query that calls pull. http://docs.datomic.com/query.html#sec-5-7#2017-04-2317:07souenzzo:find [?s ...] will always return a coll of ?s. In this case, ?s was a pull and pull's returns map's, so a coll of map#2017-04-2318:19deg@souenzzo , thanks. But, why does a bare :find (pull ?e [*]) return a *more* nested structure? (IIRC, it had two more levels of vector wrapped around the vector).#2017-04-2318:49souenzzoDatomic query by default return's "a set of tuples of result" (`#{[<result1>][<result2>]}`). I also have no idea why, and very curious to know.#2017-04-2318:51souenzzoI already researched a little about this and found nothing ... If you find some explanation, please share üôÇ @deg#2017-04-2409:53degLike the old joke goes, I was wrong to say I was wrong. ... Yesterday's problem was not browser caching. I really was seeing different pull results from different instances of my server code. Turns out that the real issue is that I'm using the Vase 0.9.1-SNAPSHOT, and the behavior changed two weeks ago, after I had last refreshed it on one of my machines. The change occurred in one of the three commits on April 6-7, and results in a pull query returning one less level of wrapping. The new behavior seems more correct to me, but is an incompatible change. See /upload -- it's just giving me :options and :upload instead of :bytes: 
;; Wire root URL to sse event stream
;; Wire /custom URL to sse event stream with custom event-id setting
(defroutes routes
  [[["/register" {:get [::send-counter (sse/start-event-stream sse-stream-ready 20 10 {:on-client-disconnect close-conn})]}]
    ["/about" {:get about-page}]
    ["/echo"
     ^:interceptors [(b/body-params)]
     {:post test-channel}]
    ["/upload"
     ^:interceptors [(m/multipart-params {:store byte-a/byte-array-store})]
     {:post upload}]]])
#2017-04-2912:20rui.yangHi, wonder if there is any way to automatically do type casting in routing, e.g. for :path-params#2017-04-2912:21rui.yangseems that pedestal always return path-params as string#2017-04-2912:22rui.yangbut for route /orders/:order_id, ideally, :order_id could be Integer. If without type casting, postgresql will complain cannot compare integer with char.#2017-04-2912:22rui.yangCurrently, I have to do it manually.#2017-04-2917:02skylarThanks @ddeaguiar, that helps a lot#2017-04-3011:03degIn a Vase app, can I query Datomic from an interceptor? If so, where do I find the Datomic object? It does not seem to be in the context passed to the interceptor.#2017-04-3020:31ddeaguiar@deg a Datomic connection and db should be accessible on the request. It‚Äôs attached by the insert-datomic interceptor. Refer to https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/ddb45e042cd12f1eb9e73b227727d46f81e3c0a6/src/com/cognitect/vase/routes.clj#L41 and https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/ddb45e042cd12f1eb9e73b227727d46f81e3c0a6/src/com/cognitect/vase/datomic.clj#L33#2017-04-3021:03degThanks. I see it now, staring me in the face. 'scuse me one second while I tease myself for not seeing it earlier.#2017-04-3021:05danielcomptonIs vase suitable publishing directly to the internet with appropriate auth, or is it intended to sit behind the firewall as a microservice that is consumed by other systems?#2017-04-3021:05danielcomptonI'm looking at https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/f49c4ac9299ef48e57a9613da089784ddd08af5c/docs/design.md#authorization-and-external-requests#2017-04-3021:20danielcomptonIf I want to apply authz to several resources without duplicating that code (and possibly forgetting it), should I split those resources into their own .edn file and apply a :vase.api/interceptors to that file?#2017-05-0103:02bradfordHow do I disable secure-headers middleware? this does not seem to do it: 
(def service {:env prod :io.pedestal.http/secure=-headers nil ::http/routes routes ::http/type :jetty ::http/port 8080}
#2017-05-0103:10danielcompton:io.pedestal.http/secure=-headers -> :io.pedestal.http/secure-headers?#2017-05-0103:16bradford@danielcompton Yup, I'm a genius#2017-05-0110:01degI either have a typo that I can't see, or I misunderstand how Pedestal interceptors work. I have an interceptor that modifies Vase query results to return them as a cvs string, rather than as a data structure. It gets back to my client as the raw string, rather than as the transit that the client expects. It looks like the problem is that modifying the context's :result in an interceptor somehow interrupts the interceptor chain, causing remaining interceptors not to run. In this code, including the update-in (rather than merely returning context) causes trace-context not to trigger, and returns the raw string generated by my csv function. What am I doing wrong? If it's a typo, I sure can't see it. If it is not legal to modify :response, then how do I generate results? 
;;; From .edn file

                "/csv-history" {:get [
#2017-05-0112:03malch@deg try assigning :response inside the :leave function#2017-05-0112:03malchhttp://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#2017-05-0112:06degThanks, I'll try that right now. But (despite having read that doc a few times) I don't see that requirement. (The only hint I see is the last line of the doc "Because a handler takes one kind of thing (request) and returns a different kind of thing (response), it can only be used in the last position of a stack.") What is the underlying logic that prevents assigning :response in the :enter?#2017-05-0112:08malchI don‚Äôt know that logic exactly but I‚Äôm guessing that :response acts like a result in a web stack#2017-05-0112:13malchActually that makes sense - you should assoc :response inside the last interceptor of your stack (it‚Äôs :leave function) and only update it inside other interceptors#2017-05-0112:18malchAnd here it is in the code (`terminator-injector`) https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/impl/servlet_interceptor.clj#L364-L377#2017-05-0112:25degI'm not familiar with how a result acts in a web stack, but I guess that some mechanism looks for the existence of :response and aborts calling the :leave queue if a response already exists? In any event, you are obviously correct. That change solved half my problem. As expected, I now see calls to generate-csv/enter, trace-context/enter, trace-context/leave, and generate-csv/leave. All good so far. But, my client is still receiving the text/plain result, rather than the correct transit results. My guess is that I'm putting the wrong thing in response. Maybe I'm not supposed to supply the headers and status? Or maybe just give the body without any map wrapping it?#2017-05-0112:28degUgh, I think I found what's going on... https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L150 Looks like the body is only converted to Transit if it is a collection, not a string! Why?#2017-05-0112:30degYup, that was it! I wrapped my body in {:cvs ...} and I'm good now.#2017-05-0112:32degSo, questions for the gurus: - Why does Pedestal not allow a bare string to be passed back via transit? - Should Interceptors be better documented, explaining how and when to return a response? Where? In the Vase docs, or Pedestal, or both?#2017-05-0112:53rauh@deg a string isn't valid JSON. Need to be either an (JS) array or a (JS) map.#2017-05-0112:54degIs that true of Transit too? I've seen that the transit library will happily take a bare string.#2017-05-0112:55degThere is even an example of this in readme of the transit library https://github.com/cognitect/transit-clj#2017-05-0112:57degAh, but this is transit+json, so I guess it uses json as bearer and needs to be valid json too?#2017-05-0113:04rauh@deg the transit interceptor checks with (coll? body) so that's the problem. Though, it seems the updated JSON RFC also does allow single strings now.#2017-05-0113:04rauhSo you could do it by just setting the Content-Type header yourself.#2017-05-0113:04degYup, the coll? check is the imediate problem. My question was why code was there.#2017-05-0113:05rauhOh you linked the coll? check yourself. Didn't click the link üôÇ#2017-05-0113:06degIt was easier just to wrap my result in a map, than to change the Content-Type. The latter would have meant playing with cljs-ajax to figure out what make it happy. Its handling of random content-types is somewhat, umm, random.#2017-05-0113:07rauhFWIF I don't see the point of the cljs-ajax library. üòï#2017-05-0113:07degI use re-frame/http-fx, which depends on it.#2017-05-0113:08degAnd the re-frame stuff is nice enough, that I'm generally happy to put up with its opinionation. (if that's a word üôÇ )#2017-05-0113:08degOf course, that cost me too much time today, so...#2017-05-0113:09rauhYeah not sure I'd wanna lock myself into using a http-fx library. What about retries, offline queuing etc?#2017-05-0113:10degDunno yet. I'm still writing toy code, mostly for the sake of exploring Vase + Pedestal + re-frame + ...#2017-05-0113:19malch@rauh Is there a cljs library that provides retries and offline queuing?#2017-05-0113:21rauh@malch there is goog.net.XhrManager but detecting if the browser if offline is difficult. I think there is a few JS libs#2017-05-0113:22malch@rauh Thanks, will take a look myself simple_smile#2017-05-0310:49rauhThis is pretty cool in combination with metrics and interceptors: https://gist.github.com/paulirish/a76ac17fc211b019e538c09d8d827691#2017-05-0311:51jimmy@rauh that's pretty neat#2017-05-0422:57crimeministerI am curious if anyone knows of a better way to prepend interceptors to the chain so that they execute right after the current interceptor, and if not would there be interest in supporting that capability in Pedestal? https://gist.github.com/crimeminister/14d87055b893cb1c0c11dd3eb5f84458#2017-05-0502:18hagmonk@crimeminister I've started using pedestal interceptors for non-web stuff and I'd certainly find that useful#2017-05-0506:42kirill.salykin@hagmonk very curious what you are using it for?#2017-05-0510:15hagmonk@kirill.salykin basically I have a data processing pipeline, so I now set that up as a chain of interceptors#2017-05-0510:16hagmonkwhich allows me to specify the steps using data, and do other things like wrap the interceptors in metrics and logging#2017-05-0510:16hagmonkso I actually have each interceptor wrapped in another one that times step execution, adding that to the context map as we go. Very handy.#2017-05-0510:17kirill.salykinindeed, thanks!#2017-05-0510:20hagmonkI made a function that takes a symbol (which points to a function) and turns it into an interceptor: 
(defn make-interceptor [sym]
  (let [int-fn (deref sym)
        int-nm (-> sym str (str/split #"/") last keyword)
        int-id (uuid/v1)
        ent-fn (fn [ctx]
                 (-> ctx
                     (assoc-in [:timings int-nm] (System/currentTimeMillis))
                     int-fn
                     (update-in [:timings int-nm] #(- (System/currentTimeMillis) %))))]
    (interceptor {::chain/execution-id int-id
                  :name                int-nm
                  :enter               ent-fn})))
#2017-05-0513:44crimeministerhagmonk: I will use this, thanks. Makes me want a nice way for evaluating pipeline performance more generally, e.g. an easy way to run criterium on every interceptor fn and on the pipeline as a whole.#2017-05-0517:19hagmonkYeah! I think there's a ton of stuff you can do. For instance I'm trying to spec the context map as it goes, so this make-interceptor can be subjected to generative testing. Having a generative test that runs across my whole pipeline would be kind of mind blowing, and could be interesting for performance testing too.#2017-05-0513:37crimeminister@hagmonk I have been using Onyx with its onyx-local-rt for setting up data processing pipelines, but I like the idea of the Pedestal interceptor chain becoming more of a first class citizen. It will be easier to embed, for one thing.#2017-05-0514:03degIn Vase, why is it required to give a :name to each interceptor in the service edn file? It seems that this often just adds noise that I don't directly care about.#2017-05-0514:26mtnygardPaul has just cut a release of Vase. 0.9.1 is on Clojars, along with an update of the template project.#2017-05-0521:14curtosisany tips on where to look for why an interceptor crashes with a stack overflow?#2017-05-0521:15curtosisor, perhaps better, how to trap it so it doesn‚Äôt overflow the stack?#2017-05-0522:48curtosishrm.. turns out it wasn‚Äôt directly an interceptor problem, but still not sure why pedestal was dumping a massive overflowing stack trace.#2017-05-0602:42danielcomptonPedestal wraps exceptions maybe?#2017-05-0623:57bradfordWhere is the source for Pesestal + Netty interceptor?#2017-05-0816:33mtnygard@bradford Late reply (I‚Äôve been OOO). In the end (after I realized I needed to deref the var) it was when someone here helped me figure out that cider-refresh doesn't work well with pedestal and I started to use cider-load-buffer instead.#2017-05-1212:28mtnygard@sineer Oh, that‚Äôs interesting! I never ran into that because I just habitually use cider-load-buffer.#2017-05-1221:52hagmonkAre there any libraries available that help define routes and documentation, parameter validation and docstrings, etc, but with these features: a) expressing all that goop as pure data, b) sharing it with CLJS for interactive docs, c) using pedestal to generate / process interceptors that do most of the heavy lifting#2017-05-1221:52hagmonkBecause I'm about to write one ‚Ä¶ I want to write a single piece of data that describes my route, then some code that implements the logic, then walk away and be done#2017-05-1221:53mtnygard@hagmonk That's on my wish list. Pretty much exactly as you described.#2017-05-1221:53mtnygardBut maybe with a twist...#2017-05-1221:53mtnygardI've been thinking of it in parts like this:#2017-05-1221:54mtnygard1. A library to describe routes as data. This exists in the form of Vase. We just need to think about how to surface the specs about request bodies.#2017-05-1221:54mtnygard2. The ability for Pedestal routes to have extra data that Pedestal doesn't care about, but carries along.#2017-05-1221:55mtnygard3. A library that can consume that data and generate UI & Swagger spec from it.#2017-05-1221:55mtnygard-end-#2017-05-1222:02hagmonkI'm currently at this point where I use the content-type detection and either serve up json, or serve up a full blown CLJS SPA that lets you explore the whole data structure. It also includes individual timings of each pedestal interceptor so I can locate problems.#2017-05-1222:03hagmonkSo I started falling pretty hard for this idea of the self describing API, or the self reporting application, and wondered how close I could get to having this all spun off for free#2017-05-1222:03mtnygardwow, that sounds fantastic#2017-05-1222:04hagmonkI don't think there's anything proprietary in here, so, a screenshot:#2017-05-1222:06hagmonkso the CLJS thing I wrote is cool (and my first CLJS project) in that I've just implemented a bunch of multi methods to handle different key types that come across the wire. So it's the same page for every single route, and as long as each route coughs up the right shape of data, you get a free web viz out of it#2017-05-1222:06mtnygardright#2017-05-1222:06mtnygardnice and generic, open to extension#2017-05-1222:06hagmonk(and I cheat and just stuff the data into a transit json encoded body attribute, no websocket here üò¨)#2017-05-1222:08mtnygardIf you were going to express your routes, docs, & validation as data, what would it look like? Still very much alpha.#2017-05-1222:11mtnygardhttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/fern#2017-05-1222:12mtnygardThe basic idea is to write something by hand that's easier, then grab a key and pull a tree out of the flatter file.#2017-05-1222:12mtnygardI have an experimental fork of Vase to try using this format as a more human-friendly representation than straight .edn#2017-05-1222:13hagmonkOh man, weavejester is going to have to update integrant üôÇ#2017-05-1222:13mtnygardWhat is integrant?#2017-05-1222:13hagmonkhttps://github.com/weavejester/integrant#2017-05-1222:14hagmonki'm using it in my apps now, I like it a lot#2017-05-1222:14hagmonkIt feels like a subset of fern after my very superficial skim through your page#2017-05-1222:14mtnygardThere's some definite similarity.#2017-05-1222:14hagmonkless dogmatic than component, less hope-and-pray than mount#2017-05-1222:15mtnygardBut fern is only about making it easier to write nested data structures.#2017-05-1222:15mtnygardIt looks like Integrant does more#2017-05-1222:15hagmonkright, it just so happens that integrant is using such a structure for app config bootup goop#2017-05-1222:18hagmonkI can see fern being really great for composing data structures together, for sharing and reusing parts of structure. I‚Äôll think more on this too üëç#2017-05-1412:12degWhat is the recommended way to handle user authentication in a Vase app?#2017-05-1421:55danielcompton@deg I think interceptors?#2017-05-1421:56danielcomptonhttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/docs/design.md#authorization-and-external-requests#2017-05-1421:56danielcomptonMy plan was to put an authn interceptor on the root, and authz interceptors on each vase route#2017-05-1421:57danielcomptonBut doing authorization that way seems a bit tricky#2017-05-1422:08degYup, I assume interceptors. Way lower on all ratios.#2017-05-1515:33mtnygardThat‚Äôs across loopback, physical gigE connections, and AWS#2017-05-1619:04jfntnDoes anyone have an example of injecting component dependencies into a service handler?#2017-05-1619:05jfntnIn ring I used to inject everything in a server component and close over the dependencies when making the routes.#2017-05-1619:05jfntnNot sure that‚Äôs the best approach with pedestal since it seems like a good use-case for an interceptor‚Ä¶?#2017-05-1619:07ddeaguiar@jfntn Unfortunately this guide is still pending http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-component-handlers-and-dependencies but I think your approach will work#2017-05-1619:08jfntnYes I saw that, which is why I asked here üôÇ#2017-05-1619:09ddeaguiarYou can have an interceptor which assoc‚Äôs the pedestal component to the context allowing downstream interceptors to pull the requisite dependencies off it#2017-05-1619:10ddeaguiarSome of the links specified here are instructive: http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component#_in_the_wild#2017-05-1619:10ddeaguiarI‚Äôm also working on an alternative implementation for this. I hope to release it soon and update the guide#2017-05-1619:12jfntnAh I missed those links, thanks#2017-05-1619:12jfntnIs that the patter you were referring to @ddeaguiar https://github.com/pointslope/elements/blob/master/src/pointslope/elements/pedestal.clj#L95 ?#2017-05-1619:21ddeaguiarSo I‚Äôm now preferring the approach outlined here: https://github.com/ddeaguiar/component-pedestal/tree/route-provider#2017-05-1619:22ddeaguiaragain this is a work in progress but the idea is that components provide routes. Component-specific routes include interceptors which provide access to dependencies#2017-05-1619:23ddeaguiarBe aware that the usage described there demonstrates a handler accessing dependencies but I‚Äôm going to change that to be an interceptor instead#2017-05-1619:23ddeaguiarby making dependencies accessible via the Context, you gain dynamic dependency mgmt which makes testing easier#2017-05-1619:23ddeaguiarimo anyways#2017-05-1619:24ddeaguiarBut I‚Äôve used the implementation demonstrated in the Elements project with success as well#2017-05-1619:26ddeaguiarFYI, the code in the master branch of the component-pedestal repo was really experimental. The implementation is cute but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good idea to decouple components from their usage in interceptors/handlers.#2017-05-1619:55jfntnThat‚Äôs nice, had a similar RouteProvider protocol with our ring version and I liked it, but I‚Äôm not sure how if I like having per-route component injectors, I think I‚Äôd rather always add the union of all deps to the context and forget about it#2017-05-1619:58ddeaguiarThen the approach implemented by Elements, which is based on Stuart Sierra‚Äôs component-pedestal exploration, is for you.#2017-05-1620:00jfntnLooks good to me, thanks @ddeaguiar !#2017-05-1620:00ddeaguiarnp üôÇ#2017-05-1623:58kennyWhat is the recommended way of handling parse failures from io.pedestal.http.body-params/body-params? i.e. When a request contains invalid JSON causing Cheshire to fail parsing it. I see two options: 1. Write my own version of the body-params interceptor that wraps the call to parse-content-type in a try/catch. 2. Add an error interceptor to the interceptor chain that looks for parse failure exceptions and attaches a :status 400 to the :response. I don't really like option 2 because it forces you to have to remember that if you use the body-params interceptor you must also use the error interceptor. I'm just wondering what you guys typically do.#2017-05-1702:09v3gadoes anyone here have any small apps such as a blog or forum written with pedestal? Preferably pedestal and component?#2017-05-1707:16kirill.salykin@jfntn I am using this approach https://gist.github.com/kirillsalykin/485403344bf85e5cb820ff4c91cdae0b#2017-05-1709:00kirill.salykin@kenny maybe this would help? http://pedestal.io/reference/error-handling#2017-05-1712:37degIn my Vase app, after I define my schema, I'd like to populate it with some domain data. {:control-server/clock
   {:vase.norm/txes [
#2017-05-1713:33mtnygard@decim I‚Äôve got this sample app https://github.com/mtnygard/todo-backend-pedestal. One of the more popular ones being the approach demonstrated in @kirill.salykin‚Äôs gist https://gist.github.com/kirillsalykin/485403344bf85e5cb820ff4c91cdae0b#2017-05-1715:39ddeaguiarwhich is very similar to Stuart Sierra‚Äôs component.pedestal approach#2017-05-1716:10jimmy@ddeaguiar I see that we always have an example of using pedestal + component ( or like the one you posted above ) somewhere. However, it's not easy to find for beginner. So the better approach might be gathering those examples under pedestal repo ( under examples ) or a wiki page of external examples. What do you guys think ?#2017-05-1719:18gerstreeI need a little guidance on the use of vase. The documentation states "API-specific data that is persisted in the database is owned by that API". How should I interpret this. Is Vase at all suited to make existing data in an existing schema available as per REST API? Should other applications not touch this data anymore, thus requiring a redesign of let's say an existing web application?#2017-05-1721:08mtnygard@gerstree That might be over-interpreting the statement. Since Datomic provides strong consistency, there shouldn‚Äôt be a problem accessing the data from a mixed API.#2017-05-1721:09mtnygardIf you have an existing schema, you can definitely use Vase to set up query and transaction routes against it. The only limitation is that it‚Äôs kind of hard to use transactor functions from Vase APIs, so if you need those to make atomic changes, you‚Äôll have to write an interceptor by hand or use the #vase/interceptor syntax.#2017-05-1721:10mtnygard@nxqd Re: pedestal + component examples‚Ä¶ my preference would be a pull request on https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs#2017-05-1721:11mtnygardThe ‚ÄúCommunity‚Äù page is meant for collecting that type of thing.#2017-05-1800:11v3ga@nxqd absolutely, i‚Äôve been tearing github apart looking for an example#2017-05-1800:12v3ga@mtnygard thanks, that should do, i‚Äôll take a look back at earlier posts as well. thanks#2017-05-1811:44gerstree@mtnygard Thanks, so it's definitely worth diving into Vase to provide an API for an existing application?#2017-05-1813:00mtnygard@gerstree I think so, but it will depend on how much logic is in your application. Vase is really meant to be a quick, easy way to shuttle data from HTTP into and out of Datomic. If you need more logic than Vase provides, you can use custom interceptors. The descriptor will start to get unwieldy when the chains are long.#2017-05-1813:00mtnygardOne thing I‚Äôve done is use Vase to describe a bunch of the ‚Äúdumb‚Äù routes that pump data back and forth, but then use hand-written routes to handle the more interesting cases.#2017-05-1813:01mtnygard(I‚Äôll post a gist with some bits that might come in handy for that)#2017-05-1816:04jfntnI don‚Äôt have a logging setup in my project yet, if I want pedestal to print debug info I‚Äôll have to configure logback with an xml file is that correct?#2017-05-1816:06ddeaguiaryes#2017-05-1816:07ddeaguiarapps generated through the lein templates will have a logback config#2017-05-1816:09jfntnThis one? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/701fb2c52a97c3335a57544746af05eba02f4c23/service-template/src/leiningen/new/pedestal_service/logback.xml#2017-05-1816:09ddeaguiaryeah#2017-05-1816:11jfntnthanks, will take a look#2017-05-1816:11ddeaguiarüôÇ#2017-05-1816:19jfntnAh that worked, thanks @ddeaguiar#2017-05-1816:20jfntnI guess I can‚Äôt ignore jvm logging libraries anymore :0#2017-05-1816:21ddeaguiarYeah. I little logback knowledge goes a long way üôÇ#2017-05-1816:29jfntnThis is a sidetrack, but I‚Äôve been logging everything as edn maps using pr-str for a while and it‚Äôs been really useful, are there any reasons why you would NOT want a custom logback appender to do that?#2017-05-1816:38ddeaguiarSo I‚Äôve been using lnav with this config https://github.com/ddeaguiar/dotfiles/blob/master/shell/.lnav-formats/pedestal_log.json#2017-05-1816:38ddeaguiarI‚Äôve not found a need to implement a custom appender thus far but I suppose it depends on the need#2017-05-1816:43jfntnnot familiar with that, does it parse the lines into data structures to make it easier to navigate them?#2017-05-1816:57ddeaguiaryep#2017-05-1816:58ddeaguiarwell it at least pretty prints them#2017-05-1816:58ddeaguiaryou can expand/collapse lines#2017-05-1816:58ddeaguiarand you can query your logs#2017-05-1817:43jfntnInteresting, do you think you could do something like that before writing to the file or there would be too much overhead?#2017-05-1818:06ddeaguiar@jfntn not sure I follow#2017-05-1818:33jfntnHa sorry missing some context here. In the previous rev of our backend we wrote a very simple logger that‚Äôd take a single clojure map and write it as edn. What was great about it was that consuming the logs was simple as something like (map edn/read-string (line-seq "app.log")) and then you can filter etc. What wasn‚Äôt so great was that our app logs were special snowflakes and we had to handle them separately from the logs printed by all our dependencies. I didn‚Äôt know of lnav but what I‚Äôm wondering now is could we apply the same kind of processing where a regexp gets parsed into a map, but do it before writing and turn all our libraries‚Äô logs into edn maps.#2017-05-1818:59ddeaguiar@jfntn lnav supports different formats and provides many predefined ones. It uses the format that matches the current log file.#2017-05-1819:00ddeaguiaryou can get as fancy as you like#2017-05-1819:01ddeaguiaryou can also configure it to work with Papertrail although I‚Äôve not tried that#2017-05-1822:02kennyI can't quite figure out why if I include io.pedestal.http/dev-interceptors , I always get a 403 Forbidden with any of my routes even though I have set ::http/allowed-origins to (constantly true). Any ideas why this would be happening?#2017-05-1822:04kennyThe problematic interceptor is io.pedestal.http.cors/dev-allow-origin. Though, all it is doing is setting the request origin to an empty string if it doesn't exist. I don't see how that would affect the (constantly true) function.#2017-05-1822:07kennyThe interceptors in the service map that causes the 403 are these: 
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor/exception-debug}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.cors/dev-allow-origin}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http/log-request}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.cors/allow-origin}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http/not-found}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares/content-type-interceptor}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.route/query-params}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.route/method-param}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.secure-headers/secure-headers}
#Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.route/router}
If I remove #Interceptor{:name :io.pedestal.http.cors/dev-allow-origin} everything works A-OK.#2017-05-1822:30kennyI figured it out... I called default-interceptors before I overrode the ::http/allow-origins key.#2017-05-1823:16bherrmannboo cant destructure ‚Ä¶. [{:keys parama paramb} (:params request)] wont work as params are strings‚Ä¶..#2017-05-1823:23jfntn@bherrmann you can use :strs instead of :keys#2017-05-1900:52jimmyjfntn: wow ! I just learn something new today üòÑ#2017-05-1823:24bherrmannTHANKS#2017-05-1907:08gerstree@mtnygard Thanks for the direction. I'll dive into Vase then and find out how easy it is to get data in and out of the existing schema with Vase. Your snippets show how easy it is really to mix and match with Pedestal routes as a fallback. Great!#2017-05-2022:15jfntnWhat‚Äôs the best way to cancel the rest of the interceptor chain and return a response in the :enter fn of an interceptor?#2017-05-2022:44jfntnHa~ io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate#2017-05-2101:41jfntnConfused by that comment: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/497#issuecomment-284405795 What‚Äôs the recommended way to stream a response if core.async is discouraged? The guides don‚Äôt seem to mention that#2017-05-2205:22julianwegkamp@jfntn I think I remember reading that you shouldn't use io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate but instead just add a :response to the context.#2017-05-2214:05mtnygard@jfntn @julianwegkamp When using Pedestal to build web services, you can either use terminate or attach a response. That‚Äôs because the servlet-interceptor always attaches a terminator function that looks for the response.#2017-05-2214:06mtnygardBut if you remove or replace that terminator function with your own custom function, you can still use terminate.#2017-05-2214:06mtnygardOr, if you use interceptors for something other that web services, you can use terminate or define your own terminator functions. (I‚Äôve got a library where I use Pedestal interceptors for Kafka messages‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs no natural terminator function there so I use terminate when needed.)#2017-05-2214:10julianwegkampthx @mtnygard. Is this the Kafka library Paul mentioned in his talk and will it become publicly available?#2017-05-2214:10mtnygardYes, and yes.#2017-05-2214:12mtnygardI just don‚Äôt have any particular schedule for releasing it. It‚Äôs very raw at the moment and I don‚Äôt want to get people‚Äôs expectations up too much.#2017-05-2214:32mtnygardOK, well, I have a schedule now.#2017-05-2214:32mtnygardI opened it up as a beta about 2 minutes ago.#2017-05-2214:32mtnygardhttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/pedestal.kafka#2017-05-2214:32mtnygardBut unfortunately, I have to run so I can‚Äôt answer any questions until tomorrow.#2017-05-2214:45julianwegkampThx. Just looking at your code will be interesting enough I assume. Will try to make some time in the coming week...#2017-05-2215:04jimmy@mtnygard I opened a PR to add heroku to pedestal service template so beginner can try out new service and get it on production quickly.#2017-05-2312:26mtnygard@julianwegkamp I wrote a quick readme for pedestal.kafka yesterday morning. This morning I realized that I pushed it to the wrong repo. (My private fork instead of the public one.) There's now a readme that has pointers into the code.#2017-05-2312:26mtnygard@nxqd I'll make sure Paul looks at that. He maintains the template.#2017-05-2321:44cap10morganIs there a way to get the ::env value from an interceptor?#2017-05-2321:46cap10morganshort of putting it into an atom or something#2017-05-2321:47cap10morganOr, in case I'm going about this all wrong, how would one make an interceptor behave differently based on env?#2017-05-2400:25mtnygard@cap10morgan The env key doesn't really do anything. It's kind of a leftover from an age long ago. #2017-05-2400:25mtnygardTo make an interceptor behave differently, I'd do 2 things. #2017-05-2400:26mtnygard1. Put an interceptor at the head of the chain that uses a real env value to attach a map to the context. That map would be your environment config. #2017-05-2400:27mtnygard2. Have your interceptors look for specific config values rather than just "what env am I in"#2017-05-2400:27mtnygardThat way your choice of config mechanism is independent of how your interceptors are written. You can change either one separately. #2017-05-2402:26cap10morganOK, makes sense. Thanks!#2017-05-2413:02manutter51Does anybody have some good example code for using Pedestal with transit as an API back end?#2017-05-2415:42jfntnI have an fdef spec for an enter fn that I use in an interceptor, and for some reason it doesn‚Äôt seem to check the args when invoking the service-fn in tests with (st/instrument) on. Is there anything pedestal specific that could be causing this, or should I look somewhere else?#2017-05-2415:59jfntnHmm even s/assert doesn‚Äôt run in the enter fn, only s/assert*#2017-05-2419:10souenzzoCompilerException java.lang.AssertionError: Assert failed: In row 1, there were unused elements (:extra :stuff). I'm using "#{["/foo" :get [fns] :route-name :bar :extra :stuff]}"#2017-05-2514:45jfntnI have a core.async chan of database rows I‚Äôd like to return as my response body, but the content type should be transit+json and I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs possible to encode the channel properly?#2017-05-2514:46mtnygard@jfntn Hmm‚Ä¶ I think there are a couple of parts there. You should be able to set the Content-Type header directly in your response map.#2017-05-2514:46mtnygardThere‚Äôs also an interceptor that should emit the correct encoding‚Ä¶ one sec while I look it up.#2017-05-2514:48mtnygardio.pedestal.http/transit-json-body#2017-05-2514:49mtnygardWhat is the data type that the channel messages will be? You may need a transducer on the channel to turn a JDBC object into a map for the transit-json-body#2017-05-2514:51jfntnSo the chan will contain one map per row (from cassandra through the alia library). I should have added that I was hoping I could stream the response and have it end up on the client as a vector/collection#2017-05-2514:52mtnygardAh, I see. But the whole collection of rows will never be a single data structure in memory, right?#2017-05-2514:52jfntncorrect#2017-05-2514:52mtnygardThat does complicate things.#2017-05-2514:53jfntn^^#2017-05-2514:53jfntnMy first attempt was to transduce the chan with transit/write but the client ends up reading the first map only#2017-05-2514:55mtnygardI can‚Äôt think of a really clean way to do it. You might be able to cheat a bit though.#2017-05-2514:55mtnygardIf your transducer emits a \[ before the first row, and a \] after the last row, then the client will think it‚Äôs got a single collection.#2017-05-2514:55jfntnI could accumulate the results in memory and return a data strucute just to get it to work now, but it‚Äôd be great to know whether this could be solved in the future since our responses will get bigger over time#2017-05-2514:55jimmy@souenzzo you can map the extra information to route-name-extra map. Then you can get those extra information in any interceptor: 
(def route-name-extra-map 
  {:route-name-a [...]})
#2017-05-2515:10souenzzonxqd: I'm using it. But on route will be way easier to see mistakes.#2017-05-2514:56jfntn@mtnygard hmm let me try that#2017-05-2515:16jfntn@mtnygard ah it works, but I need to interpose commas between rows#2017-05-2516:49cap10morganIs there a way to mount a route table into another one? so, if I have a defroutes in one namespace, and I want to mount all those routes at a particular path in the master service/routes table, how would I do that?#2017-05-2516:51mtnygard@cap10morgan You‚Äôll have to defer expanding the routes, so just use def instead of defroutes. At that point, the route table is just data so you could update the path portion with a map and string concatenation#2017-05-2516:52cap10morgan@mtnygard OK, thanks. Does that seem like a bug?#2017-05-2518:16cap10morganAnd I'll add, print-routes only shows one / separating those path components, so at least that part of the system seems to consolidate them.#2017-05-2518:17cap10morganthis is with 0.5.2#2017-05-2614:25jfntnIs there an existing benchmark that would exercise write-body-async in the servlet-interceptor ?https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/impl/servlet_interceptor.clj#L101#2017-05-2614:26souenzzowhere I find "stage" on context-map?#2017-05-2614:27jfntnWas thinking of addressing some of the problems pointed out in https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/497 but I don‚Äôt know if there are existing benchmarks that could help measure before and after#2017-05-2621:56jfntnWe‚Äôre using the service-fn during tests but we‚Äôre still starting the server, is it possible to just bypass that?#2017-05-2820:44ddeaguiarjfntn: Don‚Äôt call start on the created server. If you‚Äôre using component you can conditionally call start based on a setting or pass in start/stop fns during component creation. An example of the later can be found here: https://github.com/pointslope/elements/blob/master/src/pointslope/elements/pedestal.clj#L87.#2017-05-2820:45ddeaguiarI used to be a stickler about this but I‚Äôve become less so as of late. Now I just let the server start up using a random port.#2017-05-2705:09bradfordHow do I disable secure headers? This doesn‚Äôt seem to work: 
(def service {:env :prod
              ::http/enable-csrf nil
              ::http/secure-headers nil
              ::http/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}
              ::http/routes routes
              ;; Root for resource interceptor that is available by default.
              ::http/resource-path "/public"
              ;; Either :jetty or :tomcat (see comments in project.clj
              ;; to enable Tomcat)
              ::http/type :jetty
              ::http/port 8080})
#2017-05-2820:52ddeaguiarbradford: That doesn‚Äôt work because of this https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L233. I think your best bet is to pass in options that configure the the security headers to be less restrictive. Refer to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L258 and https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/secure_headers.clj#L161.#2017-05-2714:42lilactownso I've created a new project with the lein template, and fired up the repl with lein repl, (def serv (run-dev)). when I make a change to server.clj, my repl isn't reloading the source.#2017-05-2714:43lilactowni'm following this guide: http://pedestal.io/guides/developing-at-the-repl#2017-05-2715:23lilactownOK, so I need to (require 'my-namespace.server :reload). that command should be in the docs#2017-05-2915:28bherrmannHumm. I‚Äôd like to add a library at start time ‚Ä¶. is there a way to do that?#2017-05-2915:29bherrmannjava -classpath mylib.jar -jar myproject.jar#2017-05-2915:29bherrmannthats not effective, I assume it is because the internal Jetty thing uses its own classloader and ignores the JVM classloader#2017-05-2922:47mtnygard@bherrmann According to the man page for ‚Äòjava‚Äô: >When you use this option, the JAR file is the source of all user classes, and other user class path settings are ignored.#2017-05-2922:47mtnygardFor -jar#2017-05-2922:48mtnygardSo you might get results by putting both jars in -classpath and using your main class as the argument#2017-05-3000:11bherrmann@mtnygard Thanks, that hit the nail on the head!#2017-05-3000:12bherrmannThe mylib.jar is actually oracles jdbc library‚Ä¶ which they are a pita about not sharing via maven central‚Ä¶ so I have to include out of band instructions for oracle users.#2017-05-3018:34lellisHi all! Its possible to use Interceptor in websocket route?#2017-05-3018:36mtnygardHi @lellis. You might find https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/samples/jetty-web-sockets helpful.#2017-05-3018:38mtnygardYou can use interceptors directly by calling http://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.interceptor/io.pedestal.interceptor.chain.html#var-execute with a context that you devise.#2017-05-3018:42lellisNice! Ty @mtnygard !#2017-05-3022:10pedroteixeirahello, is there some way to pass :allow-symlinks? to the interceptor that already serves files from sources ::http/resource-path ?#2017-05-3022:10mtnygardLet me look into that @pedroteixeira.#2017-05-3022:13pedroteixeirathanks, really appreaciated - don't know yet where to look this up in the code#2017-05-3022:13mtnygardnp.#2017-05-3022:14pedroteixeiraI'm not sure if I should create a new interceptor for this case#2017-05-3022:14mtnygardThe interceptor supports it if you call io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares/fast-resource directly like this: 
(middlewares/fast-resource "public" {:follow-symlinks? true})
#2017-05-3022:14mtnygardThat will return you the interceptor you want.#2017-05-3022:15mtnygardThe second part is to use that instead of the default resource interceptor.#2017-05-3022:16mtnygardSo I suggest: 1. Leave ::http/resource as nil in your service map. 2. Construct your own interceptor. 3. Call io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors to construct the default interceptor stack. (This is normally done by create-server) 4. Conj your interceptor into the defaults. 5. Start the server.#2017-05-3022:16mtnygardIt'll probably take less than 5 lines of code. üôÇ#2017-05-3022:50souenzzoThere is a standard way to use Edn on query string?#2017-05-3022:51mtnygard@souenzzo What would be an example of such a query string?#2017-05-3112:43souenzzomtnygard: I want for example, send and UUID on query string.#2017-05-3121:58mtnygardThe parameter will always arrive as a string. But you could run it through clojure.tools.reader.edn/read-string. If you wanted to do this in general, you could write an interceptor that parsed a set of query parameters (provided at construction time).#2017-06-0213:12souenzzoSo, "bar"}... Obviously with attention to URL encode I'm unsure if there was some default interceptor already.#2017-06-0213:15souenzzofor path-params. may be a thing? Then I read-string on all values. It sounds like a good idea?#2017-05-3023:26pedroteixeira@mtnygard trying something along the lines, can you shed some light? 
(http/create-server 
   (update
     (http/default-interceptors service-map)
      ::http/interceptors
       #(conj % (ring-middlewares/fast-resource "public" {:follow-symlinks? true}))))
I got the code from the guide on the side that used defrecord Pedestal#2017-05-3023:28mtnygardLooks reasonable. Is it working?#2017-05-3023:28pedroteixeiraI think I got something wrong cause getting exception java.nio.file.StandardOpenOption cannot be cast to [Ljava.nio.file.OpenOption_ for any GET#2017-05-3023:29mtnygardThat looks like a bug in the interceptor itself. #2017-05-3023:29pedroteixeiraI was looking for examples in ways to conj an interceptor into the default ones#2017-05-3023:29mtnygardAre you using Jetty?#2017-05-3023:29pedroteixeirayes - is it the preferred/easy option?#2017-05-3023:30mtnygardYes it is#2017-05-3023:30mtnygardThe exception says that someone is passing a single OpenOption where the API requires an array of them. #2017-05-3023:30mtnygardThat's not something you did. #2017-05-3023:31mtnygardIt's probably a problem in the fast interceptor.#2017-05-3023:32mtnygardI'm at dinner now but can take a look in about an hour. #2017-05-3023:33pedroteixeirais there an easy way to use ring.util.response/resource-response as the interceptor?#2017-05-3023:33pedroteixeiraI see on the default interceptors, it is used instead of the fast-response#2017-05-3023:33mtnygardYes, but it doesn't have the follow-symlinks option. #2017-05-3023:34pedroteixeirathe ring version recently added it, I can see it on the source it now has one > https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/blob/ecf06c142ee4195756f94b780c238f3a917b3b8d/ring-core/src/ring/util/response.clj#L318#2017-05-3023:35mtnygardAh, ok. I can help in a while. Or in the meantime you could copy the function that builds the regular resource interceptor. (Right above fast-resource) and modify it to use the new middleware. #2017-05-3023:37pedroteixeiraok thanks for the help üëç - I will try copying the resource/resource-request to add the new arg, if there is a better way, let me know#2017-05-3023:55pedroteixeirait worked fine but had to copy to include support for the new arg 
(defn resource-request
  "If request matches a static resource, returns it in a response map.
  Otherwise returns nil."
  {:added "1.2"}
  [request root-path & [{:keys [loader]}]]
  (if (#{:head :get} (:request-method request))
    (let [path (subs (codec/url-decode (request/path-info request)) 1)]
      (-> (response/resource-response path {:root root-path :loader loader :allow-symlinks? true})
          (head/head-response request)))))
#2017-06-0520:55jfntnWhat‚Äôs the expand-routes syntax for a catch-all on the path?#2017-06-0620:48mike_ananev@mtnygard hi! have some troubles with io.pedestal.log.I have custom StatsD reporter and i want to init default-recorder. As mentioned in doc's I set JVM var to "-Dio.pedestal.log.defaultMetricsRecorder=verita.util.metrics/rc"#2017-06-0620:48mike_ananevwhere rc is 0-arity fn which returns custom-recorder var#2017-06-0620:49mike_ananevduring repl start i've got stacktrace#2017-06-0620:50mike_ananevI can resolve ((resolve (symbol "verita.util.metrics/rc")))#2017-06-0620:51mike_ananevin other repl without init of io.pedestal.log.defaultMetricsRecorder and it returns MetricsRegistry object#2017-06-0620:52mike_ananevbut if init, then code ((resolve (symbol ns-fn-str)))) in default-recorder is crushed#2017-06-0620:56mike_ananevin this example https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/helloworld-metrics/src/helloworld_metrics/service.clj i can't find the place where io.pedestal.log.defaultMetricsRecorder is inited#2017-06-0819:15v3gadoes anyone have any medium sized pedestal apps that run on top of boot?#2017-06-0920:30lxsameerhey guys, does pedestal's router supports bidirectional route resolving ? for example, can I get the url related to a specific function ?#2017-06-0920:54ddeaguiar@Ixsameer the handler name is used as the route name by default. This can be overridden by specifying :route-name#2017-06-0920:55ddeaguiarthis allows you to get the url for a handler via url-for#2017-06-0922:13lxsameerthanks#2017-06-1021:46lxsameeris it ok to use components with pedestal ? or the better approach is to convert them to interceptors ?#2017-06-1119:47ddeaguiar@lxsameer, if you are referring to the Stuart Sierra Component library then yes, it‚Äôs perfectly acceptable to use that with Pedestal. Refer to http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component for details.#2017-06-1120:50lxsameerthanks#2017-06-1419:36bradfordHey, I'm seeing really strange behavior from SSE channels. The time it takes for something to go from SSE->Client increases linerally with the heartbeat interval. For instance, a message will take 2 seconds, then 4, then 6, then 8... etc indefinitely. I invoke my stream with 
(sse/start-event-stream sse-stream-ready 1 (async/sliding-buffer 4) {:on-client-disconnect close-conn})
and put data into it with 
(defn add-work-item [request ip]
  (async/put! event-ch {:name "request" :data (generate-string request)} ))

I've ended up leaving a bunch of stuff in older systems when I really want it in Clojure.#2017-06-1521:48ddeaguiarnp!#2017-06-1620:49hlshipIs there a general strategy for streaming intermittent data that's compatible with use of interceptors? I'm looking for the best way to handle GraphQL subscriptions, where we want to periodically put a blob of JSON into the response (probably driven by a core.async channel). But at the point where this executes, there's a couple of other interceptors on the stack that should be involved. Looking at http://pedestal.io/reference/streaming my best bet may be to return a callback function and stream the content, but them I'm duplicating a bunch of logic that (in the normal, non-subscription case) is inside a couple of interceptors .. .things like choosing a status code, and converting from Clojure data to JSON. Thoughts?#2017-06-1620:50hlshipThe SSE code would be good, but is not compatible with GraphQL clients, which simply expect the stream of JSON blobs.#2017-06-1620:50hlshipAnd I also would like to know when the client closes the connection, so that we can do some cleanup.#2017-06-1621:12hlshipDigging deeper ... looks like web sockets are a valid approach for GraphQL subscriptions.#2017-06-2022:45mpenethlship: try to push for the open issue about ws to be fixed (reported in february). Atm it might allow 8 slow ws consumer or producer to exhaust/lock the async go threadpool (blocking IO in async/go blocks issues). Basically a potential DOS issue.#2017-06-2022:48mpenetI checked back today and was surprised to see it s still open#2017-06-2023:11hlshipYou mean this? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/497#2017-06-2106:09mpenetYes#2017-06-2022:45mpenethlship: try to push for the open issue about ws to be fixed (reported in february). Atm it might allow 8 slow ws consumer or producer to exhaust/lock the async go threadpool (blocking IO in async/go blocks issues). Basically a potential DOS issue.#2017-06-1711:19henrikWhat‚Äôs the correct way of dealing with‚Ä¶ 
Refused to load the script '' because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'unsafe-inline' 'unsafe-eval' 'strict-dynamic' https: http:". 'strict-dynamic' is present, so host-based whitelisting is disabled.
‚Ä¶? ClojureScript seems to make Chrome go into pouty mode.#2017-06-1711:21henrikI assume it‚Äôs something to do with all the document.writes in app.js.#2017-06-1713:39jimmy@henrik check this issue https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/499#2017-06-1713:45henrik@nxqd cheers, that actually did it! Though turning it off seems like cheating. You can do a little research about secure header, the default one is too strict in my opinion.#2017-06-1713:50henrikEither way, it seems like the Leiningen template could do with an update to fix this for dev mode.#2017-06-1713:55jimmyyeah, true#2017-06-1714:14henrikDone.#2017-06-1805:14henrikMan, Pedestal is challenging to use.#2017-06-1805:32henrikSo, why does ‚Ä¶ 
(def routes `{"/" {:interceptors [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body]
                   :get home-page}})
‚Ä¶ serve the page correctly, while‚Ä¶ 
(def common-interceptors [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body])

(def routes `{"/" {:interceptors common-interceptors
                   :get home-page}})
‚Ä¶ generates an exception?#2017-06-1805:45henrik(working from the Lein template)#2017-06-1912:22deg@henrik. Looks like you've quoted common-interceptors in the second case.#2017-06-1913:09henrikOh, right, so now I‚Äôve learned about backtick.#2017-06-1913:10henrikWhy are the routes quoted to begin with? I‚Äôm working from the leiningen template. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/service-template/src/leiningen/new/pedestal_service#2017-06-1916:16ddeaguiar@henrik, I‚Äôve not looked at the impl for map-based routes so I can‚Äôt comment on them. My preference is the tabular routing syntax. I find them much easier to grok.#2017-06-1916:33henrikFair enough. In the case of tabular routes, the back tick sits on the routing function itself. In the ‚Äúhello world‚Äù guide, there‚Äôs no back tick: 
(def routes
  (route/expand-routes                                   
   #{["/greet" :get respond-hello :route-name :greet]}))
In the template, the routing is split between service.clj: 
;; Tabular routes
(def routes #{["/" :get (conj common-interceptors `home-page)]
              ["/about" :get (conj common-interceptors `about-page)]})
and server.clj: 
(-> service/service ;; start with production configuration
      (merge {‚Ä¶
              ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes))
              ‚Ä¶}})
What‚Äôs the deal with the back-ticks in the first file and the deref in the other? Why are they there and what do they do?#2017-06-1916:38ddeaguiarThe backticks in service.clj lead to fully qualified symbols that get resolved here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj#L49#2017-06-1916:39ddeaguiarThe deref allows routes to be reloaded without having to restart the server#2017-06-1916:39ddeaguiaryou can make changes and load the service ns again#2017-06-2118:44jjttjjI'm having a hard time to get a clojurescript frontend working for the vase-component sample app. GET requests work fine, but i've tried several different ways to POST a new "pet" to the db without any luck. (http/post ""
               {:form-params
                {:payload [{:pet-store.pet/id 101
                            :pet-store.pet/name "harry"
                            :pet-store.pet/tag "harry's tag"
                                          }]}
                :content-type :json})
