Tutorials all go without it, but the lein template uses it.#2017-06-2213:36ddeaguiar@shaun-mahood, I recommend using the tabular route syntax it‚Äôs more verbose but easier to grok. With that syntax you will need to syntax quote symbols which refer to your function handlers . Refer to how the IntoInterceptor protocol is extended for rationale (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj#L27). The guides also use expand-routes. I don‚Äôt recommend doing that in most cases. This issue explains why: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/66.#2017-06-2215:41shaun-mahoodddeaguiar: Thanks for the help, that clears up some of my confusion but I still have a couple questions. I created a gist with them at https://gist.github.com/smahood/d0c8e120a28bd070b739022aeeecfec2 Would you mind taking a quick look?#2017-06-2217:36ddeaguiarleft some comments#2017-06-2218:26shaun-mahoodGreat, thanks - I guess http://pedestal.io/reference/table-syntax#_detailed_reference might just need updating. Any reason you would do things like Example B rather than Example A?#2017-06-2218:32ddeaguiarNot that I can think of.#2017-06-2218:44shaun-mahoodOk, then at least I'm not missing anything fundamental - thanks for the help!#2017-06-2218:48ddeaguiarSo keep in mind that the ExpandableRoutes protocol has been extended to sets (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L360) which leads to table/table-routes being called under the covers for you.#2017-06-2218:49ddeaguiaryou need to call table/table-routes here (https://gist.github.com/smahood/d0c8e120a28bd070b739022aeeecfec2#file-pedestal-routing-question-clj-L13) because you are using a vector. The ExpandableRoutes protocol has been extended to vectors but it assumes the vectors use the terse route syntax#2017-06-2218:49ddeaguiarTBH, I‚Äôm not the biggest fan of extending the core data structures in this way. I find it leads to confusion.#2017-06-2218:50ddeaguiarbut it is convenient#2017-06-2219:13shaun-mahoodAhh, that explains things a lot more clearly. Thanks again!#2017-06-2219:13ddeaguiarnp üôÇ#2017-06-2217:34mgrbyteTrying to figure out how one would use datomic's :db.fn/cas in vase; i see that if you can, it's not via #vase/transact since that will only work with :vase/assert-entity and :vase/retract-entity - can anyone point me in the right direction? thanks!#2017-06-2316:09jjttjjIs there a way to use specs defined elsewhere in the vase edn file under :vase/specs?#2017-06-2421:58lxsameerhey guys, how can I use pedestal's fast-resource ?#2017-06-2421:58lxsameerand what is the responsiblity of :http/resource-path ?#2017-06-2501:17bherrmannHuh. I'm wondering what the vase dev's workflow is?#2017-06-2713:51ddeaguiarSo I don‚Äôt think the workflow is that different that when you work with a traditional Pedestal service. Just reload the service namespace after making any changes to the vase edn file.#2017-06-2713:52ddeaguiarAt least as long as you are running your service in dev mode (i.e., via run-dev)#2017-06-2713:55mgrbyte@ddeaguiar ah ok. I don‚Äôt recall what that does under the covers#2017-06-2714:46ddeaguiarcider-load-buffer is mapped to C-c C-k for me#2017-06-2714:54mgrbyteI similarly run this in cider connecting (repl runing separately in the terminal). Had missed that run-dev will return the service-map and one can (server/stop service-map) and re-restart#2017-06-2715:04ddeaguiarSo I just did a quick test using the vase lein template#2017-06-2715:04ddeaguiaryou don‚Äôt even need to explicitly reload#2017-06-2715:05ddeaguiarany changes to the vase edn file will be picked up on next request#2017-06-2715:06ddeaguiarThis is because the value of ::server/routes is a fn and evaluated on every request (https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/template/src/leiningen/new/vase/server.clj#L52)#2017-06-2715:15mgrbytehmm#2017-06-2715:15mgrbyteNot happening for me.#2017-06-2715:18mgrbyteperhaps it's because I'm using the mutliple vase resource files as per the petstore-full sample?#2017-06-2715:24ddeaguiarhmm, I wouldn‚Äôt think so. if your service map routes value is a function, it will be executed on every request. If that function loads vase resource files, then they‚Äôll get loaded on every request#2017-06-2715:34mgrbytestill no joy. I stop and restart the repl, and I see my changes (w/no errors). changing my edn resource file alone, no changes seen. üòï#2017-06-2715:34mgrbytewill see if I can re-produce from a clean project/template.#2017-06-2715:42ddeaguiarwierd#2017-06-2715:44mgrbyteso can confirm this doesn't work. I'm a n00b at pedestal üôÇ#2017-06-2716:01mgrbyteok, having read the code think I've got a good idea how this will work. thanks for your help and patience @ddeaguiar üôÇ#2017-06-2717:12ddeaguiarGlad you were able to figure things out @mgrbyte. When in doubt stick to what‚Äôs done in the Pedestal/Vase lein templates. Sometimes the examples stray from that and it‚Äôs unclear why.#2017-06-2721:18jjttjjSorry to be asking endless vase newbie questions here. I can't tell if this is a datomic problem or a vase problem but I keep getting a back the following kind of response when I'm trying to post to create new entities {"whitelist":[{}],"transaction":[[13194139534318,50,"2017-06-27T19:46:27Z"]]}#2017-06-2721:18jjttjjis that indicative of an issue with the schema?#2017-06-2913:41mtnygardHey all, I've been away for a while, will try to catch up and answer some of the questions that have been posted here in the last couple of weeks. This is my one day in Slack before heading out on vacation until mid-July. If you post a question here and don't get an answer, I'd encourage you to post to the pedestal-users list. (https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/pedestal-users)#2017-06-2913:47mtnygard@mpenet Regarding the double-colon... without a namespace you get a keyword in the current namespace. But ::http/port uses whatever the local alias http expands to. So as long as there was a (require '[io.pedestal.http :as http]) then ::http/port expands to :io.pedestal.http/port.#2017-06-2913:48mtnygard@lxsameer The docs do suck, but we can make them better. I added https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/78 to make sure we document resource and fast-resource.#2017-06-2913:49lxsameer@mtnygard good, I'm happy to help with it as much as i can#2017-06-2913:49mtnygard@mgrbyte As you've deduced, #vase/transact is limited to assert and retract. There are three ways you can go:#2017-06-2913:50mtnygard1. Create a new reader literal in your own namespace. This is the high-effort approach but will give you something that feels native to Vase.#2017-06-2913:50mtnygard2. Use #vase/intercept to write an interceptor directly in your Vase file. This will get a little wordy but it definitely works.#2017-06-2914:07mgrbytemtnygard: Thanks for these pointers üëç So, to check I understand correctly; I could write my own fn which does d/transact w :db.fn/cas and call that within #vase/intercept?#2017-06-2914:09mtnygardYes, exactly.#2017-06-2914:09mgrbytegreat, thanks üôÇ#2017-06-2914:17mgrbyteAttempting to write a custom interceptor #vase/intercept just to test I've got this down, I do: 
#vase/intercept  {:name :roscoff.service/intercept
                        :enter (fn [ctx]
                                 (roscoff.service/intercept ctx))}
#2017-06-2914:18mtnygardThat looks like it should work. You just need to make sure you require roscoff.service before you load the descriptor file.#2017-06-2914:18mgrbytewhich work (that "intercept" fn just does a println right now - but I always get "Not found" from the client (even tho the fn is being called as I see the prints in my repl)#2017-06-2914:19mgrbyteI assume I'm not obeying the contract/interface for vase/intercept - I assumed it should return the ctx#2017-06-2914:19mtnygardThe 404 is probably because you're not supplying a response anywhere. Pedestal assumes that if no interceptor adds a response, it means the request can't be handled.#2017-06-2914:20mtnygardYes, the interceptor should definitely return the ctx#2017-06-2914:34mgrbytehmm. So I thought: (assoc ctx :response {:my-key "some data"}) would be enough to add a response, but still get the not found. thanks for all your help here.#2017-06-2914:34mtnygardIt needs a body. Try (assoc ctx :response {:body {:my-key "something"}})#2017-06-2914:48mgrbyteNo idea what I've not got right, but that work either üòï#2017-06-2914:51mgrbyteaha#2017-06-2914:51mgrbyteSo I changed it to ` (assoc ctx :response (ring-resp/response "{:something 1}")))`#2017-06-2914:51mgrbyteand that does work#2017-06-2914:52mtnygardHmm. All that does is create a map with a body and a status. So I must be misremembering... Pedestal must be looking for a :status on the response too.#2017-06-2914:53mgrbyteyep - that does the trick (requries status too)#2017-06-2914:54mtnygardSorry about that.#2017-06-2914:54mgrbyteSo I have :vase.api/interceptors [io.pedestal.http/json-body] and a custom #vase/intercept working now, which I think gives me the basis to not re-invent/fork vase (which I was considering!)#2017-06-2914:54mgrbyteno, thank you! üíØ üôÇ#2017-06-2913:51mtnygard3. Write a function in your own namespace and use #vase/intercept in your Vase file to call that function.#2017-06-2913:52mtnygardI've got some changes in the works that will make it easier to add new interceptors and literals, but that's still a few weeks away from landing in master. If you want a sneak peek you can check my fork at https://github.com/mtnygard/vase/tree/fern-input#2017-06-2913:54ddeaguiarKeep in mind that troubleshooting errors with #vase/intercept defined interceptors is difficult#2017-06-2913:54ddeaguiarat least atm#2017-06-2913:54mtnygard@jjttjj I think you're asking if you can define specs in regular namespaces, then refer to them in Vase under the :vase/specs key. If you've registered the specs, then you can use them in validate literals even without referring to them in the :vase/specs key.#2017-06-2913:59mtnygard@shaun-mahood I hope the new section in the hello-world-content-types guide helped with the transition to cond->. LMK if it's still too big a jump.#2017-06-2914:06mtnygard@shaun-mahood Re: syntax quoting. You can provide a fully-qualified symbol in a route and Pedestal will assume you want to use a keyword with the same namespace and name as your route name. That's the only place it works. That's only needed if you use a "handler function" in the last position and let Pedestal turn it into an interceptor. Personally, I prefer to write my interceptors directly and provide a :name key in the map. It's largely a matter of style.#2017-06-2914:07mtnygard@lxsameer I've created https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/79 about extending Pedestal via protocols.#2017-06-2914:08mtnygard@lxsameer The short answer is: the best protocol to extend is Interceptor. The second-best is IntoInterceptor. If you're doing something fancy with routing then RouterSpecification is interesting.#2017-06-2914:08mtnygardIf you want to do something custom with response bodies, you can extend WriteableBody or WriteableBodyAsync to any kind of arbitrary object.#2017-06-2914:13mtnygard@shaun-mahood I've added an issue for the docs about syntax-quoting. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/80#2017-06-2914:17mtnygard@jjttjj Re: payload for the vase-component sample. The payload must actually be json. I don't know why the docs imply that EDN works for input. I'm kind of surprised that it didn't work when you used the json content-type though. Do you still have the client-side code around? If so, can you share it with me?#2017-06-2914:24shaun-mahood@mtnygard: Thanks, I'll take a read through and follow up on that issue if I still don't understand the syntax quoting details. The change to the cond-> bit in the docs was much clearer too!#2017-06-2914:30lxsameer@mtnygard nice, I'm trying to create a router#2017-07-0117:15souenzzoThere is some "helper/default interceptor" to create Content-Length? My current body is a string from hiccup#2017-07-0216:46jjttjj@mtnygard just wondering, in reference to https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/issues/78 is it by design that Vase only accepts json payloads? I do see that there's a PR related to this. I'm attempting to call a vase api from a cljs app and it's possible but a bit awkward at the moment with the namespaced keys everywhere etc.#2017-07-0216:48jjttjjWhat attracts me to Vase was it's "Everything as EDN data" attitude so it was kind of unexpected to me to find that this doesn't extend to communication with the client#2017-07-0312:41martinklepschIf anyone feels like reviewing a simple PR: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/526 üôÇ#2017-07-0522:39shaun-mahoodThis seems like a dumb question, I assume I'm missing something pretty basic. With my route defined as 
(def routes #{["/about" :get `about]})
, I get a response when I go to localhost:8080/about but a not found at localhost:8080/about/ Any ideas on what I should be changing here?#2017-07-0522:40souenzzo/about, /about/ and /about/:foo are 3 different routes#2017-07-0522:42shaun-mahoodIs there an easy way to combine /about and /about/ into one handler while still leaving /about/:foo available for something else? Or is that a bad idea for some reason?#2017-07-0522:43shaun-mahood@souenzzo: Also, thanks for letting me know that I'm getting an expected response - I thought I was just doing something dumb as the routing library I am most accustomed to (in another language) treats those as the same thing.#2017-07-0522:51souenzzoI had this problem a while back. I solved it this way: #{["/foo" :get foo-handler :route-name :foo-handler]["/foo/*" :get foo-handler :route-name :foo-handler*]}#2017-07-0523:02shaun-mahood@souenzzo: Thanks, I'll give that a try#2017-07-0523:21bherrmannHumbug. I wonder what series of incantations I need to do to upload a file. http://pedestal.io/guides/uploading-files#2017-07-0523:28bherrmannHumm... google for the win? https://github.com/scotthaleen/pedestal-file-upload#2017-07-0600:01danielcompton@shaun-mahood I'd recommend middleware to redirect from trailing to non-trailing (or vice versa if you prefer)#2017-07-0600:52shaun-mahood@danielcompton: Good idea! My love for re-frame interceptors is a huge part of what drew me to pedestal :)#2017-07-0713:49skylarWhat is the best way to secure Pedestal REST-endpoints?#2017-07-0715:03shaun-mahood@skylar: I haven't gotten to using it yet, but https://github.com/propan/geheimtur has been recommended to me when I asked about it earlier.#2017-07-0715:10shaun-mahoodAre there any examples of how to use the resource ring-middleware (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/ring_middlewares.clj#L142) or any of the other ring-middleware that takes an argument? It's just different enough from the examples I can find (for both ring and pedestal) that it's giving me a bit of difficulty figuring out. I think I'm almost there but not sure yet if what I'm trying is just a terrible mess compared to what it could be.#2017-07-0717:42ddeaguiar@shaun-mahood, the ring resource middleware is used when :io.pedestal.http/resource-path is set on the service-map. Refer to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L256. All the middleware adapters in the io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares namespace are just functions which return interceptors. To use them, you would invoke the functions when building your interceptor chain. A lot of them are configured through the default-interceptors fn, though. Take a deeper look there for more details. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L181#2017-07-0717:44ddeaguiar@skylar another authentication option is Buddy (https://github.com/funcool/buddy). There‚Äôs a PR which includes an a Buddy auth integration sample project. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/503.#2017-07-0719:37shaun-mahood@ddeaguiar: Maybe I'm going down the wrong path then - what I'm trying to do is grab a file from the local filesystem (not in the resource-path) and serve that file. My thought was that I could use one of the existing ring-middlewares and pass in the specific file path. At this point I've got an interceptor that grabs the info from the request and does a query to find the file-path and adds that to the context, and I want to have that file-path sent to the resource middleware (or one of the alternatives) - so for now I'm trying to just wrap it with another interceptor that passes in the file-path. My first thought was to just put the argument (or the path to the context) into the interceptor chain directly, but I couldn't find a way to do that. What you posted above helps since I was making one wrong assumption already, so thanks!#2017-07-0721:31bherrmannHarumph... the war example seems broken.... https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/527#2017-07-0721:31bherrmannany ideas on how to poke at this one?#2017-07-0722:07mtnygard@bherrmann I'll take a look at this. I've needed to understand how war deployment works for a while. (I never worked on that part before.) What I see at the moment looks like a missing Jar file for the servlet API.#2017-07-0722:21mtnygard@bherrmann OK, I figured out what was going on. In the war example, we don't have Jetty in the dependencies. That's so the war file doesn't contain a complete copy of Jetty, Tomcat, etc.#2017-07-0722:21mtnygardInstead, there's a profile in project.clj that you need to add for REPL based development only.#2017-07-0722:21mtnygardSo if you run 'lein with-profile +jetty repl' you get the desired behavior.#2017-07-0722:22mtnygardI've pushed an update to the readme that clarifies this process.#2017-07-0722:22mtnygardAs an aside, one thing I'd really love to have is build automation that could start up and test each of the samples during a CI build...#2017-07-0722:34souenzzo
((io.pedestal.http.route/form-action-for-routes
   #{["/" :get (fn [_] {:status 200 :body "Hello"}) :route-name :main]}) :main)
ExceptionInfo Route not found clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4617) I'm missing something?#2017-07-0722:35mtnygard@souenzzo I think form-action-for-routes needs the fully-expanded routes. Can you try the same thing with the value of (:io.pedestal.http/routes service-map) after starting the service?#2017-07-0722:42souenzzo
(let [routes #{["/" :get (fn [_] {:status 200 :body "Hello"}) :route-name :main]}
      service {::bootstrap/routes routes
               ::bootstrap/join?  false
               ::bootstrap/type   :jetty
               ::bootstrap/port   8080}
      server (bootstrap/create-server service)]
  ((io.pedestal.http.route/form-action-for-routes (::bootstrap/routes server)) :main))

I'll try to get them work on my current project.#2017-07-1015:30ddeaguiar@vijayakkineni, I‚Äôm going to assume you are using a servlet-based Pedestal implementation. There are two ways you can do this. You can either get the :body of the request map found on the context via the :request key or call getInputStream on the HttpServletRequest found on the context via the :servlet-request key. The former is more idiomatic.#2017-07-1015:42vijayakkineni@ddeaguiar thank you.#2017-07-1015:56ddeaguiar@bradford I don‚Äôt have a direct answer for you but I suspect this is going to depend on the interceptor chain provider being used. I‚Äôm curious as to what your use case is? You may also want to post your question to the Pedestal user group for additional feedback.#2017-07-1016:27bradford@ddeaguiar I'm looking to build streaming/chunked requests that are not a multipart/form-data#2017-07-1216:48jimmyhi guys, can we do with-redefs with response-for to unit test routes in Clojure? I tried but the function doesn‚Äôt seem seem to be redefined.#2017-07-1217:27ddeaguiar@nxqd I generally avoid with-redefs in tests as it changes the root value of a Var. One consequence of this is that it makes running tests in parallel impossible. I prefer using dynamic vars with binding. I‚Äôm guessing you are trying to stub out a function call. In that case consider your tests as feedback indicating that there‚Äôs an opportunity to explicitly introduce some abstraction and associated dependency.#2017-07-1217:30ddeaguiarThat being said, I don‚Äôt see why with-redefs would not work with response-for as long as you are targeting an application-specific var. The interceptor chain is still being executed.#2017-07-1301:19jimmy@ddeaguiar thanks a lot for the info. I would love to know how you unit test route without stubbing? Actually, in my case I use with-redefs to redefine a function.#2017-07-1313:38ddeaguiar@nxqd I typically test my routes in the context of an integration test. If I‚Äôm understanding your question correctly, you are trying to that your routes match incoming requests. To test route matching, you don‚Äôt need to use all the machinery provided by response-for, you can test against a router implementation directly. There are a number of ways to do this and I‚Äôll share a gist shortly which illustrates them.#2017-07-1313:55ddeaguiar@nxqd https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/bed92b8f34b7e93f15cd0e5548d783ae#2017-07-1319:17lxsameerdoes any one used pedestal's logging library ? is it any good ?#2017-07-1319:21donaldballThere are things I like about it and things I don‚Äôt#2017-07-1319:25lxsameercan you share your experience with me please ?#2017-07-1319:25lxsameerI'm trying to choose between timbre, pedestal.log and logback#2017-07-1319:29lxsameer@donaldball ^#2017-07-1319:33donaldballRequiring inline keyvals for everything is a little annoying particularly if you have the log data in a map already, and configuration is always more than a little hit or miss. Given my druthers, I‚Äôll use unilog to configure logback and call it a day, but in a pedestal project I‚Äôll bow to convention and use its logger.#2017-07-1319:34lxsameer@donaldball can i use it as slf4j backend ?#2017-07-1423:07bherrmannbah I want to do something like a "flash message" after a redirect. I can use a session or even a cookie to make this happen. Is that what you were after? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-war-deployment.md#step-two-configure-your-servlets#2017-07-1713:49chris_johnsonIs it possible to get access to the log in a Vase :query statement (e.g. to create a route like user-count-as-of that takes an #inst as a param)?#2017-07-1715:06bradford@danielcompton Hrm, close. We run as jetty .jars though.#2017-07-1715:07mtnygard@chris_johnson Do you mean the Datomic log?#2017-07-1715:36chris_johnson@mtnygard I do - or some way to get an asOf version of the database for a given :query#2017-07-1715:36mtnygardThere's a way, with just a little bit of trickiness.#2017-07-1715:37chris_johnsonThat's fine#2017-07-1715:37chris_johnsonI was just about to say "It doesn't have to be easy" hehe#2017-07-1715:37mtnygardThe #vase/query action will use whatever database is present in the context map.#2017-07-1715:38mtnygardA very early interceptor puts the current db value in there via something like (assoc-in ctx [:request :db] (d/db conn))#2017-07-1715:38mtnygardBut you could add an interceptor of your own to update that key with whatever db value you want.#2017-07-1715:40mtnygardSo something like (update-in ctx [:request :db] d/as-of (get-in ctx [:request :params :when])) might do the job#2017-07-1715:40chris_johnsonThat is precisely the information I needed - thank you! #2017-07-1715:40mgrbyteIs :vase/norms the right place to describe partitions and "seed-data" in a vase app?#2017-07-1715:41mtnygard@mgrbyte Yep. That's exactly what I've done in another API.#2017-07-1715:41mgrbytethx @mtnygard I must be messing up the syntax üòõ#2017-07-1715:42mtnygard@mgrbyte I can take a look if you're able to make a gist or paste the code in a private message.#2017-07-1715:42chris_johnson(Context for interested parties: I am building some "dashboard" style endpoints off an existing Datomic db that eschews keeping timestamp attributes on entities in favor of being able to just to ask for the time slice you want)#2017-07-1715:42mtnygard@chris_johnson Nice!#2017-07-1715:44chris_johnsonI am also very interested in the mention I saw of someone working on a Lambda provider for Pedestal for this project - pull the app page out into S3, Vase service in Lambda... if I get something like that built I will certainly report back to the group. :)#2017-07-1715:45mtnygard@chris_johnson Paul deGrandis is working on that very thing. The last time I spoke to him, he said there was something subtle that had to be done with class loaders to get Lambda to be happy with Pedestal. I think his work is going to show up in Pedestal itself some time soon(-ish).#2017-07-1716:15lxsameerpedestal's way of logging is so annoying#2017-07-1718:16ddeaguiar@lxsameer can you clarify?#2017-07-1718:27chris_johnsonSo here‚Äôs something I have trouble knowing what I did wrong with:#2017-07-1718:27chris_johnsongiven this interceptor: 
#vase/intercept {:name :my-awesome-api.v1/db-as-of
                                                  :entry (fn [ctx]
                                                           (let [db (-> ctx :request :db)
                                                                 as-of (datomic.api/as-of db (get-in ctx [:request :params :when]))]
                                                             (update-in ctx [:request :db] as-of)))}
#2017-07-1718:28chris_johnsonI get 
ERROR i.p.http.impl.servlet-interceptor - {:msg "Dev interceptor caught an exception; Forwarding it as the response.", :line 313}
clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Interceptor Exception: Assert failed: (valid-interceptor? %)
	at clojure.core$ex_info.invokeStatic(core.clj:4725)
#2017-07-1718:28mtnygardOne thing I see right away is :entry should be :enter#2017-07-1718:28chris_johnsonhaha#2017-07-1718:30chris_johnsonIndeed, and the answer was right there in the stacktrace too, if only I had been able to look right at :entry and :enter and see that they were different. Brains: really good at lots of things! But not all the things.#2017-07-1718:51ddeaguiarHmm, I‚Äôm getting errors when using clojure version 1.9.0-alpha15and up with Pedestal version 0.5.2. I‚Äôm not exactly sure why#2017-07-1718:52mtnygardwhat kind of errors?#2017-07-1718:53mtnygardBelieve it or not, I think I've seen that before.#2017-07-1718:53ddeaguiarthe clojure spec error eludes me‚Ä¶#2017-07-1718:53mtnygardThere was a version of core.async that pulled in a library that used bad syntax in a refer-clojure clause#2017-07-1718:53mtnygardThere's a newer core.async that depends on a newer version of that library that fixes the syntax#2017-07-1718:54ddeaguiarcould it be that Pedestal depends on the old version?#2017-07-1718:54mtnygardDo you have a direct dependency on core.async?#2017-07-1718:54mtnygardIf not, then Pedestal 0.5.2 must depend on that older version.#2017-07-1718:54ddeaguiarI do not#2017-07-1718:54ddeaguiarI can exclude core.async and depend on the latest version to see#2017-07-1718:55mtnygardSee https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/505#2017-07-1718:55ddeaguiarhah#2017-07-1718:55ddeaguiarI was looking for an existing issue but I didn‚Äôt check the closed ones üòï#2017-07-1718:55mtnygardI wish we had a state for issues that was "fixed but not released"#2017-07-1718:56ddeaguiaragree#2017-07-1719:35chris_johnsonFor people intrigued or horrified by my questions this morning, here is the (apparently, I still have no tests around this) working interceptor to take in a path-param specifying a date and update your Vase route‚Äôs DB to be as-of that time: 
#vase/intercept {:name :your-awesome-api.v1/db-as-of
       :doc "Takes a timestamp and updates the db for this request to be `as-of` that timestamp"
       :enter (fn [ctx]
                    (update-in ctx [:request :db] (constantly (datomic.api/as-of
                    (get-in ctx [:request :db])
                    (clojure.instant/read-instant-date (get-in ctx [:request :path-params :when]))))))}
Usage then looks like #2017-07-1719:38chris_johnson(assumes your route looks like some-query-route-as-of/:when)#2017-07-1808:43lxsameer@ddeaguiar The way pedestal logging works is annoying as a library it should provide some means to customize its logging. Also it's hard to find what you what in those huge strings#2017-07-1814:03ddeaguiar@lxsameer re: log customization, the pedestal.log library is just a wrapper around the slf4j-api. Pedestal services created via the pedestal-service lein template have a dependency on logback. Logging is configurable via the logback.xml config file. Is there something specific you are having trouble configuring?#2017-07-1814:04ddeaguiar@lxsameer re: viewing the logs, I recommend using lnav (http://lnav.org/). I‚Äôve created a lnav formatter based on the lnav java formatter. You may find it useful. https://github.com/ddeaguiar/dotfiles/blob/master/shell/.lnav-formats/pedestal_log.json#2017-07-1814:06lxsameer@ddeaguiar yeah. As a library it would be nice for pedestal to instead of logging hand the logs to the user to handle and has a default handler . I know that sl4j is a wrapper and i can use other logger backend to setup my logging#2017-07-1814:07lxsameer@ddeaguiar but that's not the case , because for example for my current use case, i don't want pedestal logging, so I have to either blacklist the namespace in my logger or change the way of logging#2017-07-1814:08lxsameerbut if pedestal instead of logging directly just send the log data to a function provided by the user#2017-07-1814:08ddeaguiarIf I understand correctly, you don‚Äôt want to see logging for any pedestal namespace, correct?#2017-07-1814:08lxsameerit would be much easier to handle#2017-07-1814:08lxsameer@ddeaguiar no, just some of them#2017-07-1814:10ddeaguiarOk, so you‚Äôve already mentioned one option which is to update your log config to suppress logging from specific namespaces.#2017-07-1814:11ddeaguiarI personally find that to be a satisfactory solution. However, there is another option#2017-07-1814:11ddeaguiarYou can create your own logging implementation and plug it into Pedestal. All you have to do is implement a protocol https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/log/src/io/pedestal/log.clj#L29#2017-07-1814:17ddeaguiarCheck out the ns doc-string for details on how to configure that: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/log/src/io/pedestal/log.clj#L14#2017-07-1814:18ddeaguiarI think that provides the flexibility you are looking for#2017-07-1814:20lxsameeryeah it does . I'll return with my idea about how pedestals logging should be as soon as i done with it, It much easier to communicate via code üôÇ#2017-07-1814:22ddeaguiarSure! If adding the config file to the resources dir does not suit your needs, you should be able to add the file to the classpath when starting the service. A forcing function for me to use the REPL.#2017-07-2001:50bherrmannStu's recent presentation on this topic was interesting. He never leaves the repl... like for years.... https://vimeo.com/223309989#2017-07-2006:33jimmyThanks for the link. (I am using a library that uses timbre) but it only logs empty strings#2017-07-2120:57mtnygard@mitchelkuijpers We don't guarantee that local dev will match real lambdas exactly, but that's the main idea. We're also looking at ways to streamline Pedestal apps on Lamdba for better performance/cost ratio.#2017-07-2120:58mtnygardAnd it works with CodeStar so you can do everything really cloud native if you like.#2017-07-2121:38mitchelkuijpersYeah we use cloudformation ourselves but it has some support for it? Not really sure what codestar is#2017-07-2121:39mitchelkuijpersSeems like an abstraction on top of it#2017-07-2121:39mtnygardCodeStar is https://aws.amazon.com/codestar/#2017-07-2121:40mtnygardWeb driven IDE for AWS applications#2017-07-2121:42mitchelkuijpersAh ok, is it very tied to codestar or is it just used for the example?#2017-07-2121:42mtnygardNot tied. The new sample aims at AWS Lamdba. You can do local dev in your preferred IDE. You also have the option to use CodeStar.#2017-07-2121:43mitchelkuijpersAh cool#2017-07-2121:43mitchelkuijpersThis was our main concern when looking at lambda, fixing the development flow#2017-07-2212:14souenzzoWe can also do a response-for on pedestal with a lambda-like env, right?#2017-07-2414:52mtnygard@souenzzo If I‚Äôm reading your question correctly, then yes. Paul does all his dev locally in a REPL using response-for. Then he packages and deploys it as a lambda.#2017-07-2501:08hlshipI don't get the AWS Lambda idea ... doesn't Lambda start up a new container for each request? Or run a new command for each? Isn't that the worst possible thing with Clojure for JVM?#2017-07-2501:08hlshipHopefully I'm just unaware of some Lambda features.#2017-07-2501:11hlshipOk, dived into the docs and now understand it a bit better. The container instance may stick around for a bit, but should still be stateless.#2017-07-2501:12hlshiphttp://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-introduction.html#2017-07-2502:26danielcompton@hlship yeah it sticks around for a while, depending on request rate#2017-07-2502:27danielcomptonYou'd still be quite vulnerable to high startup latency#2017-07-2502:28danielcomptonAlso, AFAICT each request runs in a separate container, so if you have spikes in concurrency, they will either wait in line, or fire up another container https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38016683/aws-lambda-and-java-concurrency#2017-07-2502:50andrewhr@hlship if you have some time, I recently watched this talk[1] and found it quite informative. The TL;DR is that containers are snapshot and are long-lived, a @danielcompton said, and can be reclaimed and restarted after some time - no matter what. [1]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GINI0T8FPD4#2017-07-2516:51mtnygard@hlship @andrewhr @danielcompton We will soon be able to choose Pedestal in CLJ or CLJS. Using CLJ on Lambda does suffer from startup time but throughput under load is better. CLJS starts up fast but doesn‚Äôt handle the same volume.#2017-07-2516:51mtnygardSo for bursty workload or low-volume apps, CLJS is going to be better. For continuous workload CLJ will be more cost effective and have higher throughput.#2017-07-2517:57mitchelkuijpershttps://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/pull/76 Is there any reason this is not merged? This currently prevents me from using vase üòû#2017-07-2520:18lxsameerapparently websocket support is not good enough, does any one know how can I get the session in the on-text callback ?#2017-07-2521:36hlshipI hit some similar problems w.r.t. the way you set up web sockets. I hope to submit a PR that opens it up a bit for approaches that don't quite match what the current code supports. See https://github.com/walmartlabs/lacinia-pedestal/blob/4b92d5caeb0289677d74c128ceb9445509da7733/src/com/walmartlabs/lacinia/pedestal.clj#L390 and https://github.com/walmartlabs/lacinia-pedestal/blob/4b92d5caeb0289677d74c128ceb9445509da7733/src/com/walmartlabs/lacinia/pedestal/subscriptions.clj#L359 for my approach.#2017-07-2521:38lxsameerCan I use pedestal router with a pure ring application ?#2017-07-2614:04julianwegkamp@lxsameer You can implement a custom WebSocketListener to get the context in ws callback#2017-07-2619:10lxsameeris it easy to use Pedestal router in a pure ring application ?#2017-07-2619:21ddeaguiar@lxsameer Pedestal exposes a router through an interceptor, which has different properties as compared to a middleware fn. There are a number of router implementations in the Pedestal code base and they all implement the Router protocol (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route/router.clj#L15). However, the router implementations have certain expectations. Firstly, they take a collection of expanded routes. Secondly, find-route is executed against a request map that has, at minimum, a :path-info and :request-method key. I don‚Äôt think :path-info is a standard ring request key.#2017-07-2619:22ddeaguiarThe result of find-route is the matched route. It‚Äôs the responsibility of the caller to then execute the interceptor chain associated with it.#2017-07-2619:23ddeaguiarPedestal‚Äôs router interceptor impl actually enqueues the interceptors from the matched route#2017-07-2619:24ddeaguiarGiven that, it may be possible to leverage a router implementation directly for it‚Äôs route matching capabilities#2017-07-2619:25lxsameerthanks#2017-07-2619:25ddeaguiarWhat‚Äôs really required for route matching from the expanded route is the :path key#2017-07-2619:25lxsameerApparently I have to give up on Pedestal and use ring instead#2017-07-2619:26ddeaguiarbut you would still need to do some request map xform to create the add the :path-info key#2017-07-2619:27ddeaguiarHere‚Äôs a snipped which captures the minimum requirements for route matching. I posted this sometime ago in response to a route testing inquiry https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/bed92b8f34b7e93f15cd0e5548d783ae#file-route_testing-clj-L30.#2017-07-2619:28ddeaguiarI prefer Pedestal‚Äôs interceptor semantics over traditional middleware and found it fairly easy to port exiting middleware to interceptors#2017-07-2619:29ddeaguiarI‚Äôve also found that I‚Äôve been able to use libraries in Pedestal that were built with ring in mind. Take Liberator as an example#2017-07-2619:30lxsameer@ddeaguiar thanks#2017-07-2619:31ddeaguiarBut I wouldn‚Äôt recommend mixing interceptors and middleware in an app because it would detract from the conceptual integrity of the system#2017-07-2619:31ddeaguiarnp#2017-07-2619:31lxsameer@ddeaguiar I think Pedestal is really cool, but there are several problems which really bother me#2017-07-2619:32lxsameerfor example websocket support is really awful at the moment, I ended up writing lots of enhancement to make it work as i want#2017-07-2619:32lxsameerdocumentation is not good#2017-07-2619:32ddeaguiarI definitely recommend raising them and it would be best to do so in the Pedestal user group as commentary there is durable#2017-07-2619:32lxsameerBut it's a really good choice to create a traditional web service#2017-07-2619:33ddeaguiarYes, documentation can definitely be improved and is something that I‚Äôve been trying to help with. It‚Äôs just a bandwidth issue#2017-07-2619:33ddeaguiarI‚Äôve not done much with the websocket implementation to develop an opinion just yet.#2017-07-2619:35ddeaguiar@lxsameer, out of curiosity, do you have a websocket implementation you prefer which you can provide for comparison purposes?#2017-07-2619:37lxsameer@ddeaguiar Immutant and jetty supports websocket but to be honest those are just some implementation which are low level . But as a cool tool I suggest Sente which is more like a higher level tool and#2017-07-2619:37lxsameersupports several backends like immutant , http-kit, aleph and several others#2017-07-2619:37ddeaguiarI‚Äôve heard of Sente. I‚Äôll check it out, thanks#2017-07-2619:39lxsameerüòâ#2017-07-2910:28andrea.crottihow do I actually get code reloading to work in Pedestal?#2017-07-2910:29andrea.crottiI just used the default template and used run-dev#2017-07-2910:29andrea.crotti
(defn run-dev
  "The entry-point for 'lein run-dev'"
  [& args]
  (println "\nCreating your [DEV] server...")
  (-> service/service ;; start with production configuration
      (merge {:env :dev
              ;; do not block thread that starts web server
              ::server/join? false
              ;; Routes can be a function that resolve routes,
              ;;  we can use this to set the routes to be reloadable
              ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes))
              ;; all origins are allowed in dev mode
              ::server/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}})
      ;; Wire up interceptor chains
      server/default-interceptors
      server/dev-interceptors
      server/create-server
      server/start))
#2017-07-2910:29andrea.crottibut it doesn't seem to be reload the code no matter what I do#2017-07-2910:30andrea.crottiI'm actually running the server in the terminal and use Emacs+cider, so the two things are not actually linked up, but I thought it would still reload when some code changes anyway#2017-07-2917:36ikitommihmm‚Ä¶ pedestal doesn‚Äôt work with the latest clojure.spec? 0.5.2 fails with [org.clojure/clojure "1.9.0-alpha17"] due to a broken ns-form.#2017-07-2918:44lxsameerare you sure? I‚Äôm pretty sure i‚Äôm going completely in the wrong direction. https://gist.github.com/anonymous/c4de71f08f3993143c67cbee3e0205d7#2017-08-1114:03souenzzoYou may use interceptors http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors For example ["/" :get [hiccup->html homapage] :route-name ::homepage]] Where: (def hiccup->html {:name ::hiccup->html :leave (fn [ctx] (update-in [:response :body] the-hiccup-fn))}) And homepage returns just the [:div "hiccup"] divs#2017-08-1313:44andrea.crottiI just switched from ring to pedestal#2017-08-1313:45andrea.crottiand realised that doing so I lost my sentry integration which was done with this https://github.com/sethtrain/raven-clj#2017-08-1313:45andrea.crottiis it possible to use the same wrap-sentry logic somehow?#2017-08-1618:25souenzzothere is somehow to get a now/`instant` from context? I‚Äôm comparing routing libraries, bumped into this in my test data. Surely a bad practise, but I believe it should still work. Bug or intentional? 
(require '[io.pedestal.http.route.definition.table :as table])
(require '[io.pedestal.http.route.map-tree :as map-tree])
(require '[io.pedestal.http.route.router :as router])

(router/find-route
  (map-tree/router
    (table/table-routes
      [["/:a" :get (constantly "") :route-name ::ping]
       ["/evil/ping" :get (constantly "") :route-name ::evil-ping]]))
  {:path-info "/evil/ping" :request-method :get})
; nil

I guess somehow it should be wired to the router, similar in case of ring/compojure#2017-08-2318:36thegeez@pwrflx I use figwheel with pedestal, but I don't run lein figwheel. I run cljs-repl and cljs-start in the repl to start figwheel. And with (go) / (reset) etc I start pedestal with a component system: https://github.com/thegeez/clj-board/blob/master/dev/clj/user.clj#2017-08-2409:02pwrflx@thegeez I see, so you are bringing up your own jetty and then make figwheel work on that, instead of asking figwheel to bring up it's own jetty and configure your routes in addition to what figwheel needs. Right?#2017-08-2410:11thegeez@pwrflx no, figwheel start its own jetty and the pedestal app also starts its own jetty. No routes/handlers from the pedestal app are served by figwheel in my setup#2017-08-2410:13pwrflx@thegeez Didn't you constantly run into cross-origin issues with that? I mean the javascript running will need to use the API provided by pedestal that's on a different origin (in practice it's both localhost but the port number is different, which was enough to trigger cross-origin issues for me..)#2017-08-2410:22thegeezI see no warning/error about that in chrome. Also figwheel only sends messages to reload js sources. Any calls in those js sources are to the same app origin (port 8080 for the app in dev). figwheel uses port 3449#2017-08-2410:25pwrflx@thegeez ah ok I start to get it now. You're using pedestal's Jetty to both server the API and all javascript resources. Figwheel's jetty is just used to have the connection to the repl and notify the browser to reload the javascript (and that reloading I guess also takes place on 8080)#2017-08-2410:28thegeezyes#2017-08-2411:03pwrflx@thegeez this sounds cool. Is there a way to set a base path for the router? So if I set up a base route of /foo, and define a route in a router table /bar, the final route is /foo/bar?#2017-08-2918:14slpssmI should mention that I‚Äôm new to pedestal. I should also say I‚Äôm actually trying to set a base path for lacinia-pedestal. I‚Äôd like to use /s/graphql rather than /graphql as the exposed endpoint.#2017-08-2919:51slpssmI think this is going to take a pull request to lacinia-pedestal since the javascript is hard coded to /graphql#2017-08-3012:43slpssmActually, I wouldn‚Äôt mind knowing the answer to this. Is it possible to set a base path?#2017-08-3016:21mtnygardHi @slpssm. It‚Äôs not possible to set a base path directly, in the way that you‚Äôre asking. But, if you can get to the route data structure before creating the server (or calling expand-routes directly) then you can use ordinary Clojure data functions to manipulate the routes.#2017-08-3016:22mtnygardFor example, with table route syntax, the path is the first part of every route so you could map (update 0 #(str base %)) across the table.#2017-08-3018:43slpssm@mtnygard Yup! That‚Äôs exactly what I did. üôÇ#2017-09-0401:47eoliphantHi, I‚Äô,m just getting into vase and I‚Äôm wondering how schema updates are managed. (defn attach-database [uri]
  (let [conn (db/connect uri)]
    {:name ::attach-database
     :enter #(assoc % ::connection conn ::db (d/db conn))}))
#2017-09-1410:50kommenas per http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#2017-09-1410:50kommenbut later:#2017-09-1410:50kommen> A handler does not have access to the full execution context. Therefore, it cannot manipulate the interceptor queue or stack.#2017-09-1410:52kommenso how is the handler supposed to use the database? the way I‚Äôd do it would be to then just to assoc the db onto the request instead of the context, but I was wondering what‚Äôs best practice for this#2017-09-1411:11martinklepsch@kommen hey üôÇ I haven‚Äôt used Interceptors for HTTP much but the request is just part of the context. When you define your handler, can you tell where the :request is taken out/put back in?#2017-09-1411:14martinklepsch@kommen I skimmed the docs for a bit but couldn‚Äôt find any places where this was done implicitly#2017-09-1411:14martinklepsch@kommen here are some examples of injecting a db-connection also http://pedestal.io/guides/your-first-api#2017-09-1411:37kommen@martinklepsch yes, the request is just part of the context, but I was wondering because of the example above if adding it there is considered good practice#2017-09-1411:38martinklepsch@kommen I don‚Äôt thing there‚Äôs anything inherently wrong with it but you may want to restrict handlers to only receive the request so that they cannot meddle with the queue/stack#2017-09-1411:39kommendoing all the processing in the interceptors as in the your-first-api example is interesting, but really doesn‚Äôt sit right for me as it seems it loads the routes table with a lot of logic#2017-09-1411:40kommen@martinklepsch ok, thanks a lot for your opinion!#2017-09-1411:42martinklepsch> it loads the routes table with a lot of logic not sure I understand - the table is still just data but the processing of requests is done with interceptors, right?#2017-09-1411:43martinklepschas far as I understand all ‚Äúprocessing‚Äù is done via interceptors ‚Äî unlike with middleware there isn‚Äôt really this one function at the center of things#2017-09-1411:46kommenI meant that routes end up like this:#2017-09-1411:46kommen
["/todo/:list-id"           :get    [entity-render db-interceptor list-view]]
     ["/todo/:list-id"           :post   [entity-render list-item-view db-interceptor list-item-create]]
     ["/todo/:list-id/:item-id"  :get    [entity-render list-item-view db-interceptor]]
#2017-09-1411:48kommenwhich seems to me it will be easy to miss stuff here. but I might also be missing something still#2017-09-1412:03martinklepsch@kommen I‚Äôd expect there to be ways to add interceptors to a selection of routes but even if not you still can use functions to provide the list of interceptors#2017-09-1515:08mtnygard@kommen If you're using handlers, then it is totally fine to assoc the DB and connection onto the request.#2017-09-1515:09mtnygardWe support handler functions because they're familiar to people who come from Ring or Rack#2017-09-1515:09mtnygardBut a handler function really just gets wrapped into an interceptor that passes the request to the handler and assoc's the return as the response. In other words, it's purely a convenience.#2017-09-1515:10mtnygardIn my own apps, I don't use handlers. I just write everything as interceptors. I find that gives me more opportunities to make small interceptors that I can recompose for different routes. (That's what the example in your-first-api does.)#2017-09-1609:51kommen@mtnygard thanks a lot!#2017-09-1901:43cap10morganIs there a way to plug a pedestal service (routes and all) into lein-figwheel's ring-handler?#2017-09-1912:32mtnygard@cap10morgan I'm not sure what that means. I've used lein-figwheel, but just for serving up the CLJS app. I normally run the back end (with Pedestal) in a separate process.#2017-09-1914:27cap10morgan@mtnygard Yeah, that's what I'm trying to avoid (the separate process). lein-figwheel has a :ring-handler value you can set in project.clj, but I'd love to have it go through my pedestal routes, etc. rather than having to plug it into the ring-handler-esque guts of an interceptor (i.e. just the fn of a request that returns a response). My goal is to keep things simple for my team. The more I can give them one command to run (ideally the one that everyone else's examples online also run) to spin up their dev environments, the better. So if lein figwheel could be made to interact with the pedestal service w/o needing to run a separate command, that would be great (even if it's not via :ring-handler).#2017-09-1914:31ddeaguiar@cap10morgan here‚Äôs the link I meant to post re: Figwheel + Component: https://github.com/bhauman/lein-figwheel#scripting-with-component#2017-09-1914:31ddeaguiarThat may be useful to you#2017-09-1914:32cap10morgan@ddeaguiar thanks I'll check it out#2017-09-1914:35cap10morganThe message I'm getting is that neither pedestal nor (lein-)figwheel are going to help me do this. üôÇ This is a helpful starting point for achieving a similar goal though, so thanks.#2017-09-1919:36johnI'm using ring-redis-session (https://github.com/clojusc/ring-redis-session) with pedestal and the :session/keyof the request parameter does not appear to be accessible anywhere (that I can find) until a second request comes through. Has anyone experienced anything like that?#2017-09-1919:39mtnygard@john That sounds very strange. How is the client sending that parameter?#2017-09-1919:43john@mtnygard I thought the ring-redis-session middleware was attaching the session key to :session/key in :request on the server side.#2017-09-1919:44mtnygardHmm. OK, let me look at the source for that library for a second.#2017-09-1919:45johnThanks! One more strange aspect: the :session/key always remains nil unless I add some content to :request :session in some interceptor#2017-09-1919:47mtnygardI‚Äôm looking https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/blob/master/ring-core/src/ring/middleware/session.clj#L24 at ring-sesison#2017-09-1919:48mtnygardIn bare-session-request, it only attaches the :session/key if an existing session was found.#2017-09-1919:48johnIt could be that the initial request is required so that my dummy data in the :session key gets placed. Then the second request succeeds. However, if I try to put data in the :session key very early in the interceptor chain, that does not suffice.#2017-09-1919:48mtnygardSo on the first request, there isn‚Äôt a session yet#2017-09-1919:48johnah#2017-09-1919:48mtnygardYour handler can return a response with a session, at which point ring-session will send that cookie down. The client returns it on the next request and bare-session-handler finds the existing session for you#2017-09-1919:48mtnygardA caution: if you ever return a response with no session, then any existing session gets deleted!#2017-09-1919:49johnunderstood#2017-09-1919:52johnThanks!#2017-09-1919:52mtnygardyw#2017-09-2011:50souenzzoThere is some cljs alternative for pedestal?#2017-09-2012:40andrewhrI only know about https://github.com/frankiesardo/tripod. "mock" a server?#2017-09-2622:52kennyIs there a way to set cookies when using io.pedestal.test/response-for?#2017-09-2622:59kennyLooks like it's possible by reversing https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/blob/master/ring-core/src/ring/middleware/cookies.clj#L54 though that'll be a bit of a pain.#2017-09-2623:01danielcompton@kenny I've done some similar reverse engineering with Yada#2017-09-2623:01danielcomptonanother option possibly for integration testing is kerodon/peridot#2017-09-2623:03kennyNot at integration testing yet üòâ#2017-09-2623:16kennyFor those curious, it's pretty simple: 
(test/response-for service :post "/command" :headers {"cookie" "access-token=compute.test.jwt"})
#2017-09-2623:32kennyAnd a handy function for creating such headers: 
(defn cookie-header
  [cookie-map]
  {"cookie" (str/join ";" (map (partial str/join "=") cookie-map))})
#2017-09-2714:54mtnygardI often end up creating a double handful of functions to build various kinds of requests.#2017-09-2714:54mtnygardCookies, different content types, auth headers, etc.#2017-09-2920:59viniciushanaHey, quick one but I feel like I'm missing something terribly obvious: I'm defining routes using table syntax, but I'm a pickle trying to make Pedestal find out route names by the handlers. A simple sample is: 
(defn current-version
  [{{config :config} :components}]
  {:status 200 :body {:version (config/version config)}})

...
 
["/api/version" :get (conj public-interceptors current-version)]
Above code breaks that the last interceptor had no name and there is no explicit :route-name. What could be done differently on the handler function to allow Pedestal to infer the route name? I was under the impression that it used the symbol's name but that doesn't seem to be the case.#2017-09-2921:31viniciushanaGot it: I gotta provide the handler fn as a symbol (with a backquote), then it works.#2017-09-2921:32viniciushana
["/api/version" :get (conj public-interceptors `current-version)]

If it‚Äôs one team, then I keep front end and back end in the same project. If it‚Äôs two teams, then two projects.#2017-10-0413:53zallinhey everyone. does pedestal out of the box support interceptors scoped by request method and not by verb map ? cant find anything in docs on that regard ..#2017-10-0413:54zallin["/:id" ^{:interceptors [load-order-from-db]} {:get view-order :put update-order}]#2017-10-0413:55zallinhere interceptors will be invoked for both get and put methods#2017-10-0413:55zallinwhat if i want to create interceptor that only works for put method for instance ?#2017-10-0413:56mtnygard@zallin You can definitely do that.#2017-10-0413:56mtnygardIt would look like this:#2017-10-0413:56mtnygard
["/:id" ^{:interceptors [load-order-from-db]}
           {:get view-order
            :put [put-only-intc update-order]}]
#2017-10-0413:56mtnygardIt‚Äôs much easier to express in table routing syntax.#2017-10-0413:57zallinok thanks ! will try that#2017-10-0413:57mtnygard
["/:id" :get [load-order-from-db view-order]]
["/:id" :put [load-order-from-db put-only-intc update-order]]

The API was defined and released long ago. So we‚Äôre kind of stuck with the linear router#2017-10-0914:44mtnygardBut so far the performance has been good enough that we didn‚Äôt get fancy#2017-10-0914:45mpenetand to make it more difficult it's not on pedestal, we do use interceptors tho#2017-10-0914:46mpenetanother gem of a lib#2017-10-0914:46mtnygardThat‚Äôs interesting. I haven‚Äôt heard of anyone doing that before. What are you using to accept HTTP requests? And what are you using for routing now?#2017-10-0914:47mpenetjetty 9 but we have a lot of internals that rely on old tricks and we do things differently with ws#2017-10-0914:47mpenetahh for routing: moved from clout to bidi recently#2017-10-0914:47mpenetbut bidi is a bit resource hungry it seems#2017-10-0914:48mpenetand there are some bits I d prefer different#2017-10-0914:48mtnygardSo you write bidi handlers that call interceptor chains?#2017-10-0914:49mpenetyes more or less. we have a resource abstraction that can load an interceptor chain and use it#2017-10-0914:49mpenetwe have doc & specs on top of it#2017-10-0914:49mtnygardNice#2017-10-0914:49mpeneta bit like yada, but somewhat different#2017-10-0914:49mpenetresponse spec, request spec etc#2017-10-0914:51mpenetI will have to play with the route mixing tomorrow, I hope this can be written in a somewhat declarative way without having to mess with interceptors too much#2017-10-0914:53mtnygardGood luck. I would just rewrite/proxy the ambiguous routes to other paths that are resolvable with non linear routers without relying on ordering#2017-10-1014:39zallinhey @mtnygard , regarding advice you gave me about http method specific interceptors#2017-10-1014:40zallinin terse syntax I get assertion error 
Caused by: java.lang.AssertionError: Assert failed: This vector for the verb map has extra elements. The leftover elements are (my-ped.service/home-page) from the original data [my-ped.service/identity-ic my-ped.service/home-page]
#2017-10-1014:40zallinwhile it works fine in table syntax#2017-10-1014:42mtnygardTerse syntax usually trips me up somewhere or other.#2017-10-1014:42mtnygardI think it will work if you do this:#2017-10-1014:43mtnygard
{:get ^interceptors [other-interceptor] [:unique-route-name handler]}
#2017-10-1014:43mtnygardBut it might have to be like this:#2017-10-1014:43mtnygard
{:get ^{:interceptors [other-interceptor]} [:unique-route-name handler]}

^:key
just sets key to true in meta#2017-10-1014:57zallinI think this case we ve worked out should be reflected in doc , because now it says "The value of each key is either a handler function or a list of interceptors."#2017-10-1014:57zallinhttp://pedestal.io/reference/routing-quick-reference#_terse_syntax#2017-10-1014:58mtnygardWhat happens if you try a vector like [:unique-route-name interceptor interceptor handler]?#2017-10-1014:58mtnygardMaybe the problem was just missing the route name at the beginning‚Ä¶#2017-10-1014:58zallinlet me try#2017-10-1015:00zallinno it is the same assertion error#2017-10-1015:03mtnygardThanks for trying those variations out. (def routes
  `[[["/" {:get ^{:interceptors [identity-ic]} [:my-route home-page]}
      ^:interceptors [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body]
    ["/about" {:get about-page}]]]])
identity-ic is not added into interceptors vector, checked it via expand-routes.#2017-10-1015:32zallin:face_with_rolling_eyes:#2017-10-1015:32mtnygardOK. It‚Äôs time for me to consult the source instead of working from memory.#2017-10-1015:35mtnygardHere‚Äôs the syntax straight from the tests:#2017-10-1015:35mtnygard`clojure#2017-10-1015:36mtnygard
{:get [:terminal-intercepted ^:interceptors [interceptor-1 interceptor-2] request-inspection]}
#2017-10-1015:37mtnygardSo it‚Äôs a boolean metadata flag for :interceptors attached to an ordinary vector, nested inside the verb‚Äôs action vector#2017-10-1015:37mtnygard(sheesh)#2017-10-1015:37zallinomg#2017-10-1015:37mtnygardSee, this is why I made the table syntax!#2017-10-1015:37mtnygardI can never remember how to put the terse syntax together.#2017-10-1015:40zallinI will try to use table syntax for a while, it is clearly more obvious but also quite verbose#2017-10-1015:46mtnygardThis sounds sarcastic when written in text, but I mean it sincerely. We‚Äôre always interested in better ways to use data to describe configuration like routes. If you are able to find a representation that reduces duplication but doesn‚Äôt create the confusing overloaded syntax of the terse format, please let me know. We can plug new routing parsers in pretty easily.#2017-10-1015:49mpenetstill working on the use of the router standalone: I am stuck on a weird thing that seems somehow intentional, it seems that a route defined for /foo/bar/ will only match /foo/bar (notice the missing trailing slash)?#2017-10-1015:50mpenetit uses this regex internally apparently #"/\Qfoo\E/\Qbar\E"#2017-10-1015:50mtnygardI wouldn‚Äôt call it intentional, necessarily, but it is for real.#2017-10-1015:50mtnygard/foo/bar is a different resource than /foo/bar/baz#2017-10-1015:50mpenetit's odd to say the least#2017-10-1015:50mtnygardOddly, specs differ in their opinion about /foo/bar/#2017-10-1015:51zallinwell we at http://health-samurai.io often use https://github.com/niquola/route-map#2017-10-1015:51mpenetthe route is super clear/simple#2017-10-1015:51mtnygardWeb servers historically treat that as an alias for some subordinate like /foo/bar/index.html#2017-10-1015:52mpenetwell our proxy rewrite reqs when they are missing the trailing /, that makes it tricky to use#2017-10-1015:52mtnygardBut for an API, it‚Äôs not clear whether ‚Äú/foo/bar/‚Äù should mean ‚Äú/foo/bar‚Äù or ‚Äú/foo/bar/some-default‚Äù#2017-10-1015:52mpenetin a pure routing context, if the route is defined for /foo/bar/ it should match /foo/bar/#2017-10-1015:52mpenethttp or else#2017-10-1015:53mpenetimo#2017-10-1015:53mtnygardHmm‚Ä¶ I found this issue that claims trailing slashes should be supported now. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/477#2017-10-1015:54mpenetmaybe there's some sanitizing done at a lower level in the http bits, but the router does not support it#2017-10-1015:55mtnygard@mpenet Which router are you using?#2017-10-1015:55mpenetlinear for now#2017-10-1015:55mpenetbut they all compile to the same regex I believe#2017-10-1015:56mtnygardI‚Äôm looking at the source now to figure out why Paul‚Äôs comment doesn‚Äôt match the behavior you‚Äôre seeing.#2017-10-1015:57mtnygardOK, it looks like that issue doesn‚Äôt really apply. It talks about routes defined with a trailing slash, but requests that don‚Äôt have it.#2017-10-1015:59mpenetthe trailing / or not imho should be a user level concern, you design your routes in one way and let either a proxy or middleware deal with it#2017-10-1015:59mtnygardI understand what you‚Äôre saying.#2017-10-1106:30mpenetshould I open an issue about this?#2017-10-1106:31mpenetthe issue you mentioned makes it look like it could be by design tho#2017-10-1106:41mpenetactually it does work with the map tree router, but not the linear#2017-10-1106:41mpenetI guess it deserves an issue then#2017-10-1106:53mpenet@mtnygard fyi https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/538#2017-10-1311:36kuzmin_mHi! I have a interceptor A and a interceptor B. These interceptors defined as maps. I want to make interceptor C as composition of A and B. How can I do this?#2017-10-1612:23dazldwould (merge A B) not work?#2017-10-1612:23dazldoh, that was friday#2017-10-1612:26dazldi guess it wouldn't too..#2017-10-1612:30ddeaguiarYou don‚Äôt compose interceptors in this way. It‚Äôs idiomatic to chain them.#2017-10-1612:45kuzmin_mCan I create interceptor C that enqueue A and B before next interceptor? chain before: X Y chain after: C X Y chain at runtime: A B X Y#2017-10-1612:46kuzmin_mMust I manually create a new interceptors queue? üòÉ#2017-10-1612:55ddeaguiarYou can manipulate the interceptor queue from within an interceptor#2017-10-1612:56ddeaguiarso you can decide to enqueue additional interceptors based on some condition#2017-10-1612:56ddeaguiarThe interceptor queue is accessible through the context map#2017-10-1613:05kuzmin_mhttp://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.interceptor/io.pedestal.interceptor.chain.html 
enqueue
(enqueue context interceptors)
Adds interceptors to the end of context's execution queue. Creates
the queue if necessary. Returns updated context.
It's queue. I can't push items to begin of queue. I can only create new one.#2017-10-1803:09chris_johnsonkuzmin_m I don‚Äôt think ddeguiar is suggesting that you call enqueue, but rather that you fetch the ‚Äúcurrent‚Äù interceptor queue out of the context map and do side-effecty things to it#2017-10-1803:11chris_johnsonThis is something I‚Äôve done working with Vase, to allow for really, really inefficient time-series REST endpoints by taking in a time param from an endpoint and reaching into the context map of the Vase route to replace the Datomic db with an d/as-ofd DB value#2017-10-2016:47CescoHi guys, I‚Äôm new here üòÑ I have a question about the short-circuit logic. It seems to be not working in the way I understand it. I‚Äôm on 0.5.3 and if I try to return a response from any interceptor, the next one is called and ends up overriding the already set response.#2017-10-2016:48CescoIs there anything that needs to be enabled in order to make it work as it‚Äôs written on the docs? I already spent few hours on this without finding a solution#2017-10-2017:28jjttjj@francesco686 are you calling io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate prior to providing the response? Like this: 
(if-not (= id expected-id)
  (-> context
      io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate
      (assoc :response {:status 401 :body {:message "Unauthorized"}})))
#2017-10-2019:27Cesco@jjttjj no, I thought this step was not need. Also going back to the 24th of March, some guys in this channel were actually saying it was not needed. Link: https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/pedestal/2017-03-24.html#2017-10-2019:45Cescoah, found out, I was missing the :headers key on the response object. Without that, the terminator interceptor is not injected.#2017-10-2019:47Cescounfortunately also this one fails. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/content_negotiation.clj#L172 I‚Äôm gonna open a PR now‚Ä¶#2017-10-2020:09Cescohttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/540 here we go üôÇ#2017-10-2314:03souenzzo@jjttjj I use this https://funcool.github.io/buddy-sign/latest/#signing-data + a custom/simple interceptor that take a token on enter and write the user-id on :request, and update/write it back on headers on leave. after this authentication, I have another authorization interceptor that get user-id + route from context, and "do a complex stuff"#2017-10-2315:58ddeaguiar@jjttjj, I‚Äôve got a PR open with Pedestal that adds a Buddy Auth example (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/503). You may find it useful.#2017-10-2316:32jjttjjGreat thank you both!#2017-10-2406:31ddeaguiarnp üôÇ#2017-10-2517:23souenzzo#2017-10-2517:24mtnygardThanks for the poke. Mostly about version updating. Now uses Clojure 1.9.0-beta3#2017-10-2723:33thosmosI'm having some trouble with CSP errors in running lacinia-pedestal in a generic pedestal 0.5.3 service. I've attempted to add a CSP policy like ::http/secure-headers {:content-security-policy-settings {:script-src "*"}} into the service config, but I'm still getting errors about the policy being too restrictive: Refused to load the script '' because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src 'unsafe-inline' 'unsafe-eval' 'strict-dynamic' https: http:". 'strict-dynamic' is present, so host-based whitelisting is disabled. Any suggestions?#2017-10-2723:57thosmosI figured it out: I was using lacinia-pedestal's provided pedestal-service function to generate the service map which already ran ::http/create-server on it using the default pedestal CSP, and apparently, the service config needs to be altered before that step even though the output of that is still just a map...#2017-10-3117:26hlshipIn retrospect, it shouldn't do the http/create-server call. What do you think about adding an option (to lacinia-pedestal) to turn that off?#2017-10-3117:27hlshipAlternately ... we're still alpha, an incompatible change would be to just drop the http/create-server step entirely, leave that the caller's responsibility.#2017-11-1020:59billI‚Äôm using a body-params interceptor to populate the request‚Äôs :json-params. ‚úì (I‚Äôm a noob) What if I want to get at the request‚Äôs :body as a String? I see the :body isa HttpInputOverHTTP: https://www.eclipse.org/jetty/javadoc/current/org/eclipse/jetty/server/HttpInputOverHTTP.html But I don‚Äôt know out to get a String or a Reader out of that thing. Rather than digging directly into the Java stuff, I wondered if there was some interceptor or helper type fn to do that‚Ä¶ (I realize that in general, I may be dealing with a MIME multi-part request and oy I just don‚Äôt want that complication, but I do, nevertheless need the content of the first part, as a String)#2017-11-1021:05billI‚Äôve seen the ‚Äúecho‚Äù handler but it punts on the issue: http://pedestal.io/guides/your-first-api#2017-11-1021:09billhmm HttpInputOverHTTP isa InputStream‚Ä¶#2017-11-1023:33kennyI have a route that looks like this: 
["/subscribe" :get [(http-sse/start-event-stream stream-ready)] :route-name :subscribe]
where stream-ready is defined like this: 
(require '[clojure.core.async :as async])
(require '[io.pedestal.http.sse :as sse])

(defn stream-ready
  [event-chan ctx]
  (async/go-loop []
    (async/<! (async/timeout 1000))
    (sse/send-event event-chan "example" "test")
    (recur)))
In the browser I created an EventSource object and set the onmessage handler to just print out the event result. I get a new event message once per second. The event data looks something like this "[B@100394d9", however. That looks a whole lot like how Clojure prints out Byte arrays. I'm wondering if Pedestal is incorrectly serializing SSE messages. These are the Pedestal dependencies that I have: 
[io.pedestal/pedestal.service "0.5.3"]
[io.pedestal/pedestal.route "0.5.3"]

Thanks!#2017-11-2009:01nblumoeHey, the Jetty websocket implementation passes the message payload as the only argument to the :on-text handler. This means that identifying the client which sent this message depends on the payload: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/e9230c3a49b7036b195267c7c24b0c4881c941b5/jetty/src/io/pedestal/http/jetty/websockets.clj#L74 Instead this could also be done by passing the Session to the handler, too. (ns user
  "The user gets loaded by the repl by default, just helps with testing queries out..."
  (:require [api.schema :as s]
            [com.walmartlabs.lacinia :as lacinia]
            [com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal :as lp]
            [io.pedestal.http :as http]
            [clojure.walk :as walk])
  (:import (clojure.lang IPersistentMap)))

...

(defn start-server
  [_]
  (-> schema
      (lp/pedestal-service {:graphiql true})
      http/create-server
      http/start))
I've tried doing something like: 
(defn start-server
  [_]
  ( as-> schema pipe-val
      (lp/pedestal-service pipe-val {:graphiql true})
      (merge  pipe-val { ::http/allowed-origins { :allowed-origins (constantly true)}})
      (http/create-server pipe-val)
      (http/start pipe-val)))
And it doesn't seem to work#2017-11-2420:36luskwater@amilner42 You may have already looked at this, but if not‚Ä¶ https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/samples/cors#2017-11-2420:38amilner42That was how I came up with what I tried :S ‚Ä¶ This is the first code I ever wrote in clojure so I‚Äôm kinda learning as I go‚Ä¶#2017-11-2420:40amilner42Based on: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/cors/src/cors/server.clj#L34#2017-11-2420:44luskwater@amilner42 Can't do much for you at the moment: I'm sitting in a general store near Lancaster, PA, waiting for my wife. I recall a CORS setting or interceptor in code generated by lein vase for a Vase project. Might be worth looking at it. #2017-11-2420:45amilner42Ok no worries, thanks. I‚Äôll generate that and see if it helps#2017-11-2420:47amilner42Ya they seem to do the same thing in the Vase template#2017-11-2421:06amilner42Oh I think this worked: 
(defn start-server
  [_]
  (-> schema
      (lp/service-map {:graphiql true})
      (merge { ::http/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}})
      http/create-server
      http/start))
It looks like lp/pedestal-service was calling create-server, so that‚Äôs why it wasn‚Äôt working‚Ä¶#2017-11-2421:07luskwaterüëç #2017-11-2421:25amilner42Ya that was it‚Ä¶ugh so dumb. Thanks#2017-11-2613:07michael zhouA strange error, anyone knows about the error? Thanks.#2017-11-2715:23mtnygardHi @zhoumin79. That is a strange error. Are you using the same JVM version on Mac and Windows?#2017-11-2813:04michael zhou@mtnygard Yes.All use JDK1.8.#2017-12-0120:55luskwaterAll of the attempts generate ‚ÄúNot found‚Äù#2017-12-0121:32ddeaguiar@luskwater the describe-api route should be something like this /[api root]/version. If you use lein new vase foo to create your service, then the describe-api route will be available as /api/foo/v1. The relevant code for this is found https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/src/com/cognitect/vase/routes.clj#L95 and https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/master/src/com/cognitect/vase/routes.clj#L80. Hope this helps!#2017-12-0121:34luskwaterSo it's just the bare root, w/o /describe-api. Excellent, thank you#2017-12-0121:42ddeaguiarnp#2017-12-0620:38admayAnyone on here using lacinia-pedestal?#2017-12-1218:20souenzzohttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/jetty-web-sockets/src/jetty_web_sockets/service.clj#L58 How to know the ws-session or send-ch on on-text?? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/3a3c1a27235b8aac16538fc411f360b92af1f524/jetty/src/io/pedestal/http/jetty/websockets.clj#L69 on-text should receive 2 args, this and txt, not?#2017-12-1413:37souenzzoBump!#2017-12-1414:24thegeezFWIW, I agree, and wrote another websocket listener that calls a callback on on-text with a connection-id: https://github.com/thegeez/clj-board/blob/master/src/clj/net/thegeez/clj_board/system/websocket.clj#L49#2017-12-1413:37souenzzoBump!#2017-12-1312:38pasihey guys.
