Granted#2017-12-1413:40mpenetI dont think so: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/jetty/src/io/pedestal/http/jetty/websockets.clj#L75#2017-12-1414:05oconnHey all. I‚Äôve been fighting with route matching for a bit and I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm missing something pretty simple. I have the following two routes; 
["/v1/org/self"    :get (conj common (xpa-org/get-organizations-self))]
["/v1/org/:org-id" :get (conj common (xpa-org/get-organization)) :constraints {:org-id uuid-constraint}]
When I make a request to /v1/org/self it always appears to only want to match the second route (`/v1/org/:org-id`). I believe I could turn /v1/org/self into /v1/org/self/orgs and it would work, but I‚Äôm trying to figure out if the above is possible without changing the structure of my routes. The expanded routes do include both.#2017-12-1415:44ikitommi@oconn wildcards always override others, by design, but not with linear-router. Agree that it's not right.#2017-12-1415:47oconnOk cool, thanks for the insight#2017-12-1415:49ikitommiI think it woudn't with either /v1/orgs/self/orgs either. Wildcards are REALLY greedy.#2017-12-1415:50donaldballThere is the :constraints metadata#2017-12-1415:50oconnyeah I think I‚Äôm going to go with /v1/orgs/self/orgs but it would be nice to weight them somehow#2017-12-1415:51oconnYeah so above I am using constraints but it returns a 404#2017-12-1415:51oconnafter failing the constraint on :org-id#2017-12-1415:51donaldballhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/routing-terse-syntax.md#constraints#2017-12-1415:51donaldballWhat‚Äôre your constraints?#2017-12-1415:51oconn:constraints {:org-id uuid-constraint}#2017-12-1415:52oconnwhich is‚Ä¶#2017-12-1415:52donaldballoh, hah, sorry, too early üòõ#2017-12-1415:52oconn#"[0-9a-f]{8}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{4}-[0-9a-f]{12}"#2017-12-1415:53donaldballFWIW that‚Äôs not specified as metadata, no idea if it will actually work in that form#2017-12-1415:56oconnI believe the constraint is being applied. When I remove it and make a request to /v1/org/self the request is routed through the /org/:org-id handler. Then when I add it I end up receiving a 404#2017-12-1415:56ikitommiIf there is a wild route, it masks all static routes.#2017-12-1415:56luskwater@donaldball I think that is a legitimate ‚Äúconstraint clause‚Äù as mentioned in the docs somewhere (just read it): http://pedestal.io/reference/routing-quick-reference#_table_syntax#2017-12-1415:57ikitommieven If the static path has more segments.#2017-12-1415:57luskwaterIt would mask the static routes unless you use {:io.pedestal.http/router :linear-search} I think#2017-12-1415:58ikitommiyes, https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/532#issuecomment-324881362#2017-12-1415:58luskwaterand the non-wild route precedes the wild one#2017-12-1415:58donaldballHa ha wow. I guess you could put the switch in your route handler for the ‚Äúself‚Äù case#2017-12-1415:58donaldballif you added it to your regex#2017-12-1416:59shaun-mahoodIs anyone aware of any existing projects to get pedestal interceptors into ring?#2017-12-1417:07mpenetWe use the interceptor lib with a custom jetty adapter here#2017-12-1417:08mpenetWe dont use specific interceptor "instances" from pedestal tho#2017-12-1417:51shaun-mahood@mpenet: Are you using it with a bunch of existing ring middleware, or is everything custom interceptors?#2017-12-1418:32ikitommihow would interceptors work with ring? I think middleware is the equivalent to interceptor, but fundamentally different. But it's relatively easy to write code that could be used as either one.#2017-12-1418:33ikitommiI think Pedestal = Interceptors.#2017-12-1418:37fmindPedestal is data oriented. Fundamentally, interceptors are hash map with an :enter and :leave keys that point to functions. It's up to pedestal to combine and execute these interceptors. One nice thing is thar pedestal works with core.async. And if tomorrow, we find a better way that core async, we could replace the execution engine without changing interceptor descriptions.#2017-12-1418:38fmindOn ring, middleware are simple functions. They take the next handler as a parameter, and execute it when they want. They can perform task before our after the next function execution.#2017-12-1418:38shaun-mahood@ikitommi: The main issue I have with ring middleware is how understandable/visible it is - every time I have tried to set add new middleware to a ring project I end up spending a bunch of time moving things around so that things are applied in the right order, or enabling/disabling middleware until things work. It's difficult to know what is actually happening without diving into the code, and I've found it painful to figure out where and how I want to log things related to them.#2017-12-1418:39fmindBut by doing so, you cannot control the execution. Ring start the first handler through a simple functions call. You can't plug something like core.async easily #2017-12-1418:40shaun-mahoodI want to be able to inspect the stack of earlier interceptors to see how my data has changed, and see what is still remaining to be run.#2017-12-1418:42ikitommii agree, but If you take Interceptors instead If mw, is it Ring anymore? (your original question)#2017-12-1418:42ikitommiI'm using both, depending on a project.#2017-12-1418:42ikitommiand writing libs that support both styles.#2017-12-1418:45ikitommiand you can inspect & reorder mw-chains too, but only before the chain is created. Once it's chained, it's just a fn.#2017-12-1419:53fmindI started to learn Pedestal and I'm a bit confuse about some Clojure librairies#2017-12-1419:54fmindI want to develop an API oriented web stack, and I think Pedestal is a good start for that purpose#2017-12-1419:54fmindbut then, there is many librairies like liberator, vase and lacinia. I don't know which one to integrate, and I can't find pros and cons on the internet#2017-12-1419:55fmindis vase compatible with lacinia ? is there a way to switch to another DB than datomic ?#2017-12-1419:55fmindand on the client side, what is the quickest way to integrate with Clojurescript ? om.next ? fulcro ?#2017-12-1419:56fminddo you know some templates that combine these tools ?#2017-12-1419:57mtnygard@fmind I sympathize. There are a plethora of options and not a lot of "stacks" that offer pre-integrated components.#2017-12-1419:57mtnygardI'm one of the maintainers of Vase & Pedestal, so I have a personal preference toward those. Vase is quite tied to Datomic in its current state, though.#2017-12-1419:57fmindyes ... the Clojure community takes modularity to hearth, but it's not the most productive option for quick development#2017-12-1419:58fmindand there is a lot of back-up from experienced programmers who met the problem these technologies try to address#2017-12-1419:59luskwaterNothing prevents you from - creating your own data-readers so you can have #fmind/jdbc action literals (or the like) - adding an interceptor that hangs a pooled Connection on the context and takes it back on the way out - don‚Äôt know about quickest way: I was hoping to use Vase, but find that my client‚Äôs standard server framework (Java) is heavy and burdensome, but perhaps must be used#2017-12-1420:00fmindI like the design of vase, but I'm afraid that the dependence to REST and Datomic will bite me on the long term#2017-12-1420:00mtnygard@fmind I understand. What are your technology constraints? (E.g., are you restricted to certain DB?)#2017-12-1420:02fmindI work in a research environment and I have few tech constraints. I'm quite found of Datomic, but we can't pay the price for Datomic pro#2017-12-1420:02ordnungswidrigLiberator maintainer here, just keep in mind that liberator (and anything that runs on the ring model) works perfectly fine with pedestal. You‚Äôll lose some of the async / non-blocking properties of pedestal, though.#2017-12-1420:03mtnygardI've been working on an evolution of Vase that makes it easier to add new actions that go beyond Datomic. That's at https://github.com/mtnygard/vase/tree/fern-input#2017-12-1420:03mtnygardNot released yet, but in a usable state.#2017-12-1420:03fmind@mtnygard @ordnungswidrig thanks for your feedbacks#2017-12-1420:04fmindI want to start small with a small web app that provides both REST and GraphQL end points.#2017-12-1420:05fmindmy plan was to start with Pedestal + Lacinia and see which of vase liberator would be the best fit#2017-12-1420:05ordnungswidrig@mtnygard vase-fern looks very promising. I will dig into that very likely.#2017-12-1420:06ordnungswidrig@fmind I‚Äôm thinking for a while now how to bring the niceness of liberator to the pedestal world but I‚Äôve yet to hit a sweet spot. Maybe I‚Äôll have a bright moment over the holidays üòõ#2017-12-1420:08mtnygard@ordnungswidrig If you want to chat about it, hit me up. I like what Liberator brings!#2017-12-1420:08fmindThe good thing with Clojure is that it's easy to test stuff. I will try to use both lib and see what is the best fit#2017-12-1511:09souenzzohttps://youtu.be/qijWBPYkRAQ#2017-12-1420:09fmindWould you have any recommandation for the client side with Clojure script ?#2017-12-1503:01imetallica@fmind reagent + re-frame#2017-12-1506:14fmind@imetallica what's your opinion on om.next and fulcro ?#2017-12-1511:34imetallica@fmind I don‚Äôt have an opinion, I‚Äôve never used them.#2017-12-1603:22chris_johnson@fmind The second- and third- most recent episodes of the defn podcast (https://defn.audio) are interviews with David Nolen (one of the main contributors to om.next) and Tony Kay (author and maintainer of fulcro), respectively. Having listened to both, I think you would be really well-served to hear each of their takes on pros, cons, and most critically what problems each library is trying to solve and what tradeoffs their authors chose to make in building them.#2017-12-1603:28chris_johnsonIt‚Äôs not ‚Äújust use Rails, mang‚Äù as simplicity of answers go, but I really do feel that one of the really important benefits of working in and with the Clojure community is that you have both access to the really powerful and generous minds that build the tools we use, and the leisure time - thanks to the quick work our sharp tools make of most mundane programming tasks- to really dig into the hows and whys of the tools you choose to add to your personal arsenal. Very, very few communities of working engineers in this era of technology have anything akin to what‚Äôs available to the working Clojurist; you owe it to yourself to at least once arrive at a decision about using library B over library A because you understand both and not because Google PageRank or a co-worker pointed you to one or the other. üòá#2017-12-1604:28donaldballI have written some in om.next and always have the experience where I read the docs and think I get it, then switch over to the code and have no idea what to do. The fundamental ideas are very good but I am not at all sure about the api tbh.#2017-12-1608:00fmind@chris_johnson I think the core principles of the Clojure community are wonderful: simplicity, modularity, innovation. The community managed to create both mature language and a nice lab to test new ideas#2017-12-1608:01fmindIn the area of web development, the community pushed some nice ideas: the react architecture, query on the client side, management of state ...#2017-12-1608:04fmindit takes time and efforts to appreciate all these innovations. I do it during my free time, and I enjoyed learning through projects like Pedestal and om.next#2017-12-1608:08fmindbut in term of productivity, I would love to have some sane defaults I could use in my projects#2017-12-1608:09fmindthat's why I appreciate the feedback from experienced developers on their tech choice#2017-12-1609:05ikitommiHi. Would it be a good idea to lift Interceptors out of Pedestal into a more common concept for Clojure? Like Ring, which defines just a spec that different libs could use - and produce Interceptors that can be used with other libs - like Ring. Currently, I know at least 5 different interceptor runners, inspired by Pedestal, but bit different. I don‚Äôt think this helps in the big pic. There are :before and :afters, :in & :outs, different keys for errors, queues, stacks etc.#2017-12-1609:08ikitommiThe interceptors are a separate module, but still it has deps to things like core.async, pedestal.log etc. which are opinions that not everyone agrees. Also, the keys are namespaced to Pedestal (`:io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error` etc.)#2017-12-1611:12souenzzo@ikitommi checkout io.pedestal.interceptors.chain/execute#2017-12-1612:01ikitommi@souenzzo thanks for the pointer! It nicely describes the how the interceptor should look like, but not the context. Context has things like ::queue, ::error and ::stack. Re-frame has :queue and :stack etc. Writing a portable interceptor that does error-handling requires to access the ::error.#2017-12-1612:06souenzzothe also this issue https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/487#2017-12-1612:07ikitommithanks!!#2017-12-1612:03ikitommiI think programming against a contract (like https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/blob/master/SPEC) instead of a helper api makes things more portable.#2017-12-1612:06ikitommiMy 2 cents would be to use non-qualified keys for the context (`:queue`, :stack, :error etc.) like Ring does. This also enables perf optimizations as the context could be a Record with fast access to that info. Re-reading via a hash-lookup makes the chain execution much slower.#2017-12-1612:10souenzzoP.S.: I'm using the ctx/`chain` concept in various/non-http context in my app.#2017-12-1612:10ikitommicool. the pedestal chain or just the concept?#2017-12-1612:18souenzzoone "own" chain, to interact with #datomic (when I implemented, I did not know that pedestal chain was easy to use), and a websocket chain, using chan/execute.#2017-12-1818:35souenzzoThere is some standard approach to instrumentation/spec validation on context?#2017-12-1819:27luskwaterQuestion: I‚Äôm trying to lein uberjar a project created with lein new vase ...: I‚Äôve changed the Datomic URL in the .edn definition to use a transactor running in another process. lein uberjar connects to Datomic and it never finishes the task. (Change the URL back to an in-memory DB, and it starts and then exits and generates an Uberjar.) Would anyone be able to help me generate the Uberjar?#2017-12-1819:53ikitommi@souenzzo request & response validation or context keys in general?#2017-12-1819:57souenzzowhen instrumentation is on, check/valid/exception keys based on a spec.#2018-01-1000:00hlshipA question about#2018-01-1000:03hlshipPedestal routing. One of my handlers is not getting invoked. Here's (mapv #(take 2 %)) of my routes (a set, in table format): 
[("/assets/graphiql/*path" :head)
 ("/graphql" :post)
 ("/assets/graphiql/*path" :get)
 ("/graphql" :get)
 ("/" :get)]
But when I have a client GET /assets/graphiql/graphiql.css, I get a 404, as in, it's not matching.#2018-01-1000:03hlshipIf I pprint out the expanded route: 
{:path "/assets/graphiql/*path",
  :method :get,
  :path-constraints {:path "(.*)"},
  :path-re #"/\Qassets\E/\Qgraphiql\E/(.*)",
  :path-parts ["assets" "graphiql" :path],
  :interceptors
  [{:name nil,
    :enter
    #object[io.pedestal.interceptor$eval21530$fn__21531$fn__21532 0x277af0a3 "io.pedestal.interceptor$eval21530$fn__21531$fn__21532@277af0a3"],
    :leave nil,
    :error nil}],
  :route-name :com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal/graphiql-get-assets,
  :path-params [:path]}
(that's just the key entry)#2018-01-1000:05hlshipAll my other routes work fine.#2018-01-1000:08hlshipOk, I don't think this is a Pedestal problem. I think some part of my app is overriding the route hash I generate.#2018-01-1000:15hlshipIt was two different things in my application; Pedestal is working fine, of course.#2018-01-1101:43caleb.macdonaldblackhttp://pedestal.io/reference/servlet-interceptor Says this: Before invoking the :enter functions, the servlet interceptor sets up a ‚Äúterminator‚Äù predicate on the context. It terminates the interceptor chain when the context map returned by an interceptor has a response map attached. My server has this: 
(ns wp-server.server
  (:gen-class)                                              ; for -main method in uberjar
  (:require
    [io.pedestal.http :as server]
    [io.pedestal.http.route :as route]
    [wp-server.service :as service]
    [wp-server.datomic :as datomic]))

(defonce runnable-service (atom nil))

(defn -main
  "The entry-point for 'lein run'"
  [& args]
  (println "/nConnecting to datomic...")
  (datomic/connect!)
  (println "\nCreating your server...")
  (reset! runnable-service (server/create-servlet service/service))
  (server/start runnable-service))

(defn create-runnable-dev-service
  "The entry-point for 'lein run-dev'"
  [& args]
  (println "\nConnecting to [DEV] database...")
  (datomic/connect-dev!)
  (println "\nCreating your [DEV] server...")
  (-> service/service
      (merge {:env                     :dev
              ::server/join?           false
              ::server/routes          #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes))
              ::server/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}
              ::server/secure-headers  {:content-security-policy-settings {:object-src "none"}}})
      server/default-interceptors
      server/dev-interceptors
      server/create-servlet))
My service looks like this: 
(ns wp-server.service
  (:require
    [datomic.api :as d]
    [io.pedestal.http :as http]
    [io.pedestal.http.body-params :as body-params]
    [io.pedestal.http.route :as route]
    [ring.util.response :as ring-resp]
    [wp-server.datomic :as datomic]
    [wp-common.client :as wp-common-client]
    [wp-common.core :as wp-common-core]
    [clojure.spec.alpha :as s]
    [ring.util.response :as ring-response]))

(def home-page
  {:name  :home-page
   :enter (fn [context]
            (prn "TWO")
            (assoc context :response {:status 200 :body "Hello, world!"}))})

(def common-interceptors [datomic/db-interceptor (body-params/body-params) http/html-body])

(defn create-spec-validator
  [spec]
  {:name :validate-spec
   :enter
         (fn [{{:keys [:edn-params]} :request :as context}]
           (prn "ONE")
           (if-let [explained (s/explain-data spec edn-params)]
             (assoc context
               :response {:status 400 :body explained})))})


(def routes #{
              ;["/" :get (conj common-interceptors `home-page)]
              ["/clients" :post (conj common-interceptors (create-spec-validator ::wp-common-client/schema) home-page)]
              ["/db-test" :get (conj common-interceptors `db-test-page)]
              ["/about" :get (conj common-interceptors `about-page)]})

(def service {:env                     :prod
              ::http/routes            routes
              ::http/type              :jetty
              ::http/port              5000
              ::http/container-options {:h2c? true
                                        :h2?  false
                                        :ssl? false}})
When sending a request to localhost:5000/clients with a body that does not pass spec, the create-spec-validator interceptor adds a response to the context. I have confirmed this by logging the context in the home-page interceptor. I would expect the home-page interceptor to be skipped as per documentation. This does not happen. Instead the :enter function of the home-page interceptor is called and the response overwritten. Why isn‚Äôt the home-page interceptor being skipped when the create-spec-validator prior to it is returning context with a response?#2018-01-1102:12caleb.macdonaldblackthe SO post for this is https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48198671/pedestal-early-termination-is-not-working#2018-01-1102:28caleb.macdonaldblackI need to use io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate. We believe those docs are out of data#2018-01-1102:32luskwater@caleb.macdonaldblack Might not be an issue here, but your :validate-spec interceptor does not return the context on a successful validation. If you return nil, does Pedestal assume the unmodified context?#2018-01-1102:45luskwater@caleb.macdonaldblack Here you go: the :response has to be a valid response according to ring.util.response/response?, so it needs to be a map with :status and :headers: 
(defn response?
  "True if the supplied value is a valid response map."
  {:added "1.1"}
  [resp]
  (and (map? resp)
       (integer? (:status resp))
       (map? (:headers resp))))
#2018-01-1217:08hlshipI've gotten tripped up before by omitting the :headers key. It's easy to miss if you don't start with ring.util.response/response.#2018-01-2512:03nblumoeIs there a way to add interceptors to the websocket route with an implementation like https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/jetty-web-sockets/src/jetty_web_sockets/service.clj ?#2018-01-2513:13souenzzo@nblumoe it's very easy to use io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/execute for ANY propose. just (let [initial-ctx {....}] (chain/execute initial-ctx [inter1 inter2]))#2018-01-2513:34nblumoeHm, right. I guess I actually rather have the problem of getting the correct context there. üòÑ#2018-01-2513:41nblumoeI would like to use an interceptor-chain which has access to my system map (using integrant). But when ws-path is defined, the system hasn‚Äôt been initialized yet.#2018-02-1322:30hlshipI'm trying to do something pretty tricky with pedestal routers and interceptors. Essentially, part of my application is routed based on stateful data that can change at any time.#2018-02-1322:31hlshipSo I have a traditional (static) router, then an interceptor that builds (as needed) another router and adds it via io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/enqueue#2018-02-1322:32hlshipBut I'm seeing that execution doesn't match my expectations.#2018-02-1322:34hlshipWhat I see is execution of the router, then execution of my interceptor, then execution of interceptors in a route matched by the router.#2018-02-1322:36hlshipThat's a lot to process;#2018-02-1322:36hlshipBUT line 7 shows the router :enter step#2018-02-1322:37hlshipAnd that's where I'd expect the router to match paths and choose a route, and add that route's interceptors/handler to the execution chain.#2018-02-1322:38hlshipAnd those interceptors will put a :response into the context, which should trigger an unwind through the :leave events of all the interceptors so far.#2018-02-1322:38hlshipBut then on line 9, we see app-router enter stage, which to mind mind shouldn't take place.#2018-02-1322:39hlshipThen on line 11 we start to see the interceptors chosen by the router start to execute.#2018-02-1322:42hlship... and now I'm reading the code for chain and answering some of my own questions.#2018-02-1322:48hlshipSo I think what happens is that the router and the app-dispatcher are enqueued initially. The router executes, matches a route, and adds its interceptors to the execution chain after the other app-dispatcher interceptor. app-dispatcher executes it's :enter stage, but does nothing THEN the route interceptors hits their :enter stage.#2018-02-1322:49hlshipSo I think I can get what I want by moving some logic in app-dispatcher to a :leave step instead, and only if there's no :request already.#2018-02-1322:53hlshipAh, I think I can stay in the :enter phase, but check to see if there's already a matched route.#2018-02-1323:12hlshipYep, that's working nicely.#2018-02-1402:54chris_johnsonNow I really wish I wasn‚Äôt Slackin‚Äô on iOS where it is a giant pain to copy a wall of text off and DM it to myself.#2018-02-1402:55chris_johnsonI might never need that capability, but if I ever do I‚Äôm going to remember reading this whole tale start to finish and not remember the magic bit at the end.#2018-02-1417:40hlshipSlack is the ultimate rubber duck ü¶Ü#2018-02-1415:00logistarkHi all, is Pedestal still under development?#2018-02-1417:41hlshipAny notes on the site generation tools for Pedestal? I just contributed a trivial documentation PR but am in a mood to write some more.#2018-02-1417:49hlshipUgh. Turns out I was contributing docs to the wrong repo.#2018-02-1418:55hlshiphttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/pull/101#2018-02-1617:33chris_johnson@nooga I believe (constantly true) will do what you want there#2018-02-1617:34noogaI'll try that! Thanks!#2018-02-1722:13nooga@chris_johnson but then I need to add the header manually right?#2018-02-1722:14chris_johnsonHm, I might be thinking of the wrong key, hang on a second#2018-02-1722:15chris_johnsonAre you sure you‚Äôre looking at ::http/allow-origins and not ::http/allowed-origins?#2018-02-1722:16chris_johnsonHere‚Äôs a service map from a very simple Pedestal server (actually just the Pedestal endpoint shim from a Vase project) that illustrates the idea I‚Äôm thinking of:#2018-02-1722:16chris_johnson
(defn service-map
  "Returns initial service map for the Pedestal server."
  []
  {::http/type   :jetty
   ::http/port   8080
   ::http/join?  false
   ::http/allowed-origins (constantly true)})
#2018-02-1722:17chris_johnson^^ that service allows any CORS origin and the server sends the appropriate headers to all callers, at least as far as it‚Äôs been tested#2018-02-1722:19noogaof course I meant ::http/allowed-origins#2018-02-1722:22noogahow does it know to set the headers based on that (constantly true)?#2018-02-1722:38chris_johnsonIf you look at cors.clj : https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/7d3895d0ed06f47555644ed560a49b1ab311d7ab/service/src/io/pedestal/http/cors.clj#L48#2018-02-1722:40chris_johnsonWhat happens is the value of allowed-origins gets passed through normalize-args, which if you pass it a sequence of strings, creates you a fn that checks for membership in that sequence: (fn [origin] (some #(= % origin) (seq arg))))#2018-02-1722:40chris_johnsonbut if you pass it instead a fn, that fn gets called with the origin in question and the truthiness of its return value determines whether the origin is allowed#2018-02-1722:41chris_johnsonso (constantly true) means ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even care anymore, anyone can come in, fine‚Äù (or more charitably, ‚Äúthis is a dev server, let‚Äôs worry about security later‚Äù) üòÑ#2018-02-1722:42chris_johnsonYou could also, I imagine, take advantage of this to have your CORS header check do something dynamic, if you were willing to eat the overhead of a dynamic call of some kind for every network request#2018-02-1722:44noogaah, I see#2018-02-1722:44noogaawesome#2018-02-1722:44nooga!#2018-02-2020:01noogahow can I get request body as a string in pedestal?#2018-02-2020:02noogaI see body-params#2018-02-2020:02noogabut there‚Äôs no text ‚Äúparser‚Äù there#2018-02-2020:50noogalol, nevermind, it‚Äôs slurp#2018-02-2023:37dadairDoes anyone know of any resources for handling websocket-sessions in pedestal? I‚Äôve followed the jetty-websockets sample, but it does not cover tying websocket handlers (`:on-text`, :on-close, etc) to a particular session (only :on-connect). For instance, how to identify the client that caused :on-close to fire due to an idleTimeout (to allow for session cleanup, etc)?#2018-02-2023:40dadairI‚Äôve found https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/pedestal-users/websocket%7Csort:date/pedestal-users/IOc-WKkTFLM/6ga8vcTiAgAJ, but not sure how one would go about implementing a custom listener to track the session#2018-02-2100:39souenzzoLacinia-pedestal do websocket, with code reuse with pedestal interceptors. #2018-02-2101:06dadairthanks! taking a look at that now#2018-02-2119:28hlshipIt seems like the Pedestal implementation is built around a somewhat specific use case, but it was reasonable to work around it.#2018-02-2119:29hlshipI've been embracing io.pedestal.log for a new project and really like the idea of logging as pure data ... there's a freedom that comes from not thinking in terms of user-readable messages, but instead, machine-interpretable events. Anyway, one thing I find missing in io.pedestal.log is support for a MDC (message diagnostic context).#2018-02-2220:02mitchelkuijpersHave you tried Cambium for this? We use this exactly for data based logging#2018-02-2119:30hlshipI would love to see a dynamic var containing a map of event keys/values that would be merged with those supplied by the call to log/debug and friends.#2018-02-2119:31hlshipUse case is primarily a request correlation id; I would like to set a rid at request inception and be able to see what rid across all logged events (many of which are asynchronous).#2018-02-2119:31hlshipI have cycles to put together a PR, but would love to hear from the gate keepers first.#2018-02-2119:33hlshipAlso, even a simple map may not be perfect, in some ways I'd prefer a delegate function that could be passed the event map and could return a modified event map prior to pr-str and passing it off to SLF4J.#2018-02-2119:35hlshipIn the past, I've tried to hack this kind of thing using Logback's MDC support, but it ends up being a battle of the thread-locals (Clojure dynamic bindings vs. Java thread locals used to store the MDC).#2018-02-2217:52polymerisHi#2018-02-2217:53polymerisHow did you get started with Pedestal?#2018-02-2217:53polymerisDocumentation seems kind of poor http://pedestal.io/guides/crash-course#2018-02-2217:54polymerisI see the Microservices with Clojure has one chapter about pedestal, but it seems overkill to buy the book just for that#2018-02-2218:05dadair@polymeris the guides/samples have been my go-to as I learn pedestal http://pedestal.io/guides/your-first-api http://pedestal.io/samples/index. That "First API" guide looks useful, except it seems to be missing an explanation of core concepts. I'll try the videos first#2018-02-2218:16dadairCore concepts are here http://pedestal.io/reference/index#2018-02-2218:17dadairParticularly, http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors http://pedestal.io/reference/architecture-overview http://pedestal.io/reference/chain-providers http://pedestal.io/reference/error-handling#2018-02-2218:18dadairhttp://pedestal.io/reference/context-map#2018-02-2218:19polymerisoh, great#2018-02-2218:19polymerisYes, that's exactly what I need to get started#2018-02-2218:20polymerisThanks a lot#2018-02-2818:33souenzzoCan I get from context map the name of the "actual" interceptor?#2018-02-2818:55andrzejsliwaany idea how to override logback in tests?#2018-03-0100:30hlshipIf logback finds a logback-test.xml on the classpath, it uses that instead of logback.xml. So put a copy in dev-resources. I start with this: 
<configuration scan="true" scanPeriod="1 seconds">

    <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
        <encoder>
            <pattern>%-5level %logger - %msg%n</pattern>
        </encoder>
    </appender>

    <root level="warn">
        <appender-ref ref="STDOUT"/>
    </root>

</configuration>
#2018-03-0214:29andrzejsliwaThx!#2018-02-2819:03andrzejsliwaok I found it#2018-02-2819:04andrzejsliwa{:profiles {:test {:jvm-opts ["-Dlogback.configurationFile=test-logback.xml"]}} just switched to different config#2018-02-2822:57dadair@souenzzo yes, see the print out of the context in the following example: 
dev> (require '[io.pedestal.interceptor.chain :as chain])
nil
dev> (def a {:name :a :enter (fn [ctx] (clojure.pprint/pprint ctx) ctx)})
#'dev/a
dev> (def b {:name :b :enter identity})
#'dev/b
dev> (chain/execute (chain/enqueue {} [b a]))
#:io.pedestal.interceptor.chain{:queue <-()-<,
                                :execution-id 114,
                                :stack
                                ({:name :a,
                                  :enter #function[dev/fn--47949]}
                                 {:name :b,
                                  :enter
                                  #function[clojure.core/identity]})}
{}
dev> (chain/execute (chain/enqueue {} [a b]))
#:io.pedestal.interceptor.chain{:queue
                                <-({:name :b,
                                    :enter
                                    #function[clojure.core/identity]})-<,
                                :execution-id 115,
                                :stack
                                ({:name :a,
                                  :enter #function[dev/fn--47949]})}
{}
dev>
#2018-03-0100:23souenzzoI'm already picking up from the stack. Just digging about a more "standard/clean" way to do üôÇ tkx#2018-03-0117:14eraserhdIs there a way to filter pedestal exceptions when running tests? Mine are currently about 8000 lines long, I think.#2018-03-0119:02ddeaguiar@eraserhd you‚Äôll need to dynamically change the logging level during your test runs. You can even do it at a per-test level but you‚Äôll need to write code for that either way#2018-03-0119:04ddeaguiarI‚Äôve typically done this through a with-log-level macro#2018-03-0119:14eraserhdThis is for the exceptions shown as test results?#2018-03-0119:16eraserhdAs in, "expected: 42, got: #error { ... 8000 lines ... }"?#2018-03-0119:35ddeaguiaryou got the error as a response body?#2018-03-0119:35ddeaguiar@eraserhd ^^#2018-03-0119:35ddeaguiarmy comment was about log file noise#2018-03-0119:36eraserhdYeah, I'm not looking at the logs. The error is an exception thrown from io.pedestal.test/response-for#2018-03-0119:36eraserhdThe test runner prints it at the REPL, which is painful.#2018-03-0119:37ddeaguiarah hmm#2018-03-0119:53ddeaguiarI‚Äôm not sure of what the best solution is there other than setting the max stack trace depth at jvm startup#2018-03-0912:53urzdsHi! Is this the right place to ask questions about Lacinia?#2018-03-0912:55urzdsSpecifically, I am wondering why resolver-map is a function, in https://lacinia.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial/init-schema.html#schema-namespace It appears it is rather static, i.e. not requiring to be executed at run time.#2018-03-0913:17souenzzo@urzds it's a lacinia question. I think that #graphql is the right channel yes, it's "static" in this example#2018-03-0913:26urzds@souenzzo Thanks!#2018-03-1221:02noogaI‚Äôm writing a defbefore that uses a component, what‚Äôs the best way to pass the component inside?#2018-03-1221:05mtnygard@nooga Something I usually end up doing is write an interceptor to attach the whole system map to the context.#2018-03-1221:06mtnygard(defn attach-system [system-map] {:enter (fn [context] (assoc context :system system-map))})#2018-03-1221:06mtnygardSomething like that.#2018-03-1221:06mtnygardThen it goes at the front of the interceptors for every route#2018-03-1221:09noogagotcha#2018-03-1414:48dadairAs an example with non-component systems, I‚Äôve adopted the following pattern using Integrant: 
(defmethod ig/init-key ::inject-bus [_ {:keys [bus]}]
  {:name ::inject-bus
   :enter (fn [ctx] (assoc ctx :bypass.events/bus bus))})
then I can pass that interceptor around the system map as needed#2018-03-1414:48dadairso the bus component is closed over in the interceptor creator, which will inject the component into the context map when entered#2018-03-1221:10noogathe other would be to capture the component (defn my-before [component] (helper/before (fn [context] ... component ...))#2018-03-1221:10mtnygardYes#2018-03-1221:11mtnygardBasically the same idea. You can decide how much to close over when creating the interceptor.#2018-03-1221:11mtnygardFWIW, the "helpers" are kind of discouraged now. They really obscured the fact that interceptors can be just plain, simple maps.#2018-03-1221:15noogato be honest I just snatched some random example and now I‚Äôm trying to make it work üòÑ#2018-03-1221:15noogait might be an old example#2018-03-1221:15mtnygardVery likely. It's hard to out SEO the older blog posts.#2018-03-2012:29ddeaguiar@amarjeet, FWIW, I find it easiest to deploy Pedestal services to ElasticBeanstalk in a Docker container.#2018-03-2012:47amarjeet@ddeaguiar I think I can try that#2018-03-2012:47amarjeetthanks#2018-03-2013:45ddeaguiarThe lein pedestal-service template creates a Dockerfile which should be suitable for most cases. Keep in mind that EB uses nginx to proxy all requests to your container so you may need to create an nginx config file if you need control over that.#2018-03-2014:15amarjeetokay, just started with this. lets see if I can make it work#2018-03-2014:47ddeaguiarIt should be straight forward. You‚Äôll just need to create a Dockerrun.aws.json file. I recommend using the eb cli for pushing change to you environment.#2018-03-2014:51amarjeettried building docker image, its not been able to build. Error: `Get https://registry-1.docker.io/v2/: dial tcp: lookup http://registry-1.docker.io on 192.168.65.1:53: read udp 192.168.65.2:45426->192.168.65.1:53: i/o timeout Docker image could not be built.`#2018-03-2014:53amarjeetm updating docker - lets see#2018-03-2015:03amarjeet@ddeaguiar any clear way to create a jar build? I am getting this error - javax/servlet/http/HttpServletRequest#2018-03-2015:04amarjeeti tried lein uberjar#2018-03-2015:15ddeaguiarCreating an uberjar should just work. You need to undo the changes you made to create a war file#2018-03-2015:19amarjeetI will try by creating a fresh pedestal service app#2018-03-2016:38amarjeetAre both the situations incorrect, in terms of config?#2018-03-2017:10amarjeetUberjar issue resolved#2018-03-2017:40amarjeetHey @ddeaguiar I am able to run the docker image locally, but the beanstalk is not recognizing Dockerfile when I am deploying standalone.jar#2018-03-2017:40amarjeetI am doing it via the beanstalk consol#2018-03-2017:50ddeaguiar@amarjeet did you create a Dockerrun.aws.json file?#2018-03-2017:52amarjeetno, i thought Dockerfile would work#2018-03-2017:52ddeaguiarnope, you need one more piece#2018-03-2017:52ddeaguiarhttps://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/create_deploy_docker_image.html#2018-03-2017:53ddeaguiar
You can provide Elastic Beanstalk with only the Dockerrun.aws.json file, or with a .zip archive containing both the Dockerrun.aws.json and Dockerfile files. When you provide both files, the Dockerfile describes the Docker image and the Dockerrun.aws.json file provides additional information for deployment as described later in this section.
#2018-03-2017:53ddeaguiarso there are a couple ways to do this, you can deploy your docker image to an ecs registry repo or build the image at deployment time#2018-03-2017:53ddeaguiarI do the later when working with EB#2018-03-2017:54amarjeetso, it seems like the configs in this file are created when I was creating the beanstalk environment, so any specific part of the config should I mention (thats is mandatory) in the .json file#2018-03-2017:54ddeaguiarThe config you need in that file is minimal#2018-03-2017:55ddeaguiarit will amount to environment variable mappings (if any), port mappings, memory settings and log mount points#2018-03-2017:55amarjeethmm, okay#2018-03-2017:55amarjeetwill just try#2018-03-2017:55ddeaguiarmy recommendation is to just first deploy a vanilla pedestal-service#2018-03-2017:56ddeaguiaronce you have that working, then deploy your app which can have external dependencies#2018-03-2017:56amarjeetmake sense#2018-03-2017:56ddeaguiaryou can then tailor your eb config to create the roles required to access aws services, etc#2018-03-2017:56amarjeethmm, yeah#2018-03-2017:57amarjeetgonna try this#2018-03-2121:51mvIs there a good example of implementing auth{oriz|entic}ation in pedestal apps?#2018-03-2209:01ouvasam@mv Hi, I did found this post, but not sure if it is the best way... https://juxt.pro/blog/posts/securing-your-clojurescript-app.html#2018-03-2213:11ddeaguiar@mv some time ago I created a PR for with an auth example: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/503#2018-03-2213:12ddeaguiarI also suggest checking out https://github.com/propan/geheimtur#2018-03-2503:44souenzzoMy pedestal@jetty gives 404 for every OPTIONS. There is how "enable" the OPTIONS response?#2018-03-2504:10souenzzoI find the io.pedestal.http.cors namespace then the dev-interceptors that use it. Fixed üôÇ#2018-03-2719:44TravisAnyone know how to properly use pedestal-api in combination with testing using response-for ? I am unclear on how to properly implement url-for ?#2018-03-2913:20ddeaguiar@camechis I‚Äôve not used pedestal-api but as long as you have routes you should be able to generate a url-for test helper#2018-03-2913:20TravisThnx, I think I got past it#2018-03-2913:20ddeaguiarok, cool#2018-03-3013:22mtnygardI've just release Vase 0.9.3 to Clojars. It bumps the Clojure version to 1.9 and moves us to the newly release Datomic free version that closes a security bug.#2018-03-3020:56mvSeeing some issues with clojure spec when moving up to 0.9.3, is there anything specific I need to do?#2018-04-0513:55pithylessI‚Äôm trying to use io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/execute to define a pipeline of sync/async actions (outside of a regular web request). If I have a catch-all error interceptor (`{:error (fn [ctx ex] ..)}`), it works fine when I throw an exception in :enter or :leave, unless the enter/leave handler is async (returns a go chan). Should it work? Or do I need a different error-handling approach for async?#2018-04-0514:10pithylessI can do it explicitly with a try/catch inside the async/go block, but is there a better way?#2018-04-0514:10pithyless
:enter (fn [ctx]
            (let [ch (async/chan)]
              (async/go
                (try+
                 (async/>! ch (do-some-async-work ctx))
                 (catch Object err
                   (async/>! ch (assoc ctx :io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/error
                                       (ex-info "Async Error" err))))))
              ch))
#2018-04-0519:38mtnygard@pithyless It's supposed to use the same error handling whether you return a channel or a context. Can you share a repro case?#2018-04-0613:08pithyless@mtnygard Does this suffice? https://gist.github.com/pithyless/51897363f5b6171a6d8e6368c60ab085#2018-04-0613:09mtnygard@pithyless Thank you, this is excellent. I will look into it later today.#2018-04-0616:41dadair@pithyless I could be wrong, but don‚Äôt you just want to return the channel returned from the go? not provide an explicit extra channel?#2018-04-0616:42dadaire.g., 
(def do-work-async
  {:name :do-work-async
   :enter (fn [ctx]
            (let [ch (async/chan)]
              (async/go
                (async/>! ch
                          (if (:async-error ctx)
                            (assert nil "Async error")
                            (assoc ctx :async :ok))))
              ch))})
should be 
(def do-work-async
  {:name :do-work-async
   :enter (fn [ctx]
            (async/go
                (if (:async-error ctx)
                    (assert nil "Async error")
                    (assoc ctx :async :ok))))})
I haven‚Äôt tested and edited the code in slack so parens are probably wrong#2018-04-0616:42dadairfrom the pedestal reference guide: http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#_interceptor_return_values#2018-04-0616:43dadair
(def third-party-auth
  {:name ::third-party-auth
   :enter (fn [context]
            (if (:session context)
              context
              (go
                (assoc context :auth-response (call-auth-system context))))})
they implicitly return a channel because the (go ..) returns a channel#2018-04-0616:44pithyless@dadair in this case, having the async/go return would be sufficient; but it makes no difference - error is the same#2018-04-0616:45mtnygard@pithyless There could be another difference. The assert is going to throw an exception that will be silently swallowed by the inner go. Nothing at all is going to come out of the channel if that happens.#2018-04-0616:46mtnygardBut now that I look at it... I'm not sure how the assert would get caught outside any go block. I will have to take a fresh look at the Pedestal source to understand.#2018-04-0616:48pithyless@mtnygard @dadair so without the explicit channel, just returning an implicit async/go channel, we see something like this:#2018-04-0616:48pithyless
Async error...
Exception in thread "async-dispatch-5" java.lang.AssertionError: Assert failed: Async error
nil
[OK] Handling error.
clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Async Interceptor closed Context Channel before delivering a Context
 at clojure.core$ex_info.invokeStatic (core.clj:4739)
    clojure.core$ex_info.invoke (core.clj:4739)
#2018-04-0616:50mtnygardI was just looking at the line of source that throws that exception. üôÇ#2018-04-0616:51mtnygardIf you want the exception to be processed with Pedestal's error handling, I guess you need to catch Throwable and attach it to the context map before putting the context map into the channel.#2018-04-0616:51mtnygardI don't think we have that documented very well. üòû#2018-04-0616:52pithylessDo you mean, the way I wrote about it yesterday? https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C0K65B20P/p1522937421000780#2018-04-0616:53mtnygardYes, but without the extra channel.#2018-04-0616:53pithylessright, fair enough#2018-04-0616:54pithylessso yeah‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs not obvious from the documentation as it‚Äôs written now :]#2018-04-0616:54mtnygardThis part really doesn't behave the way I'd expect it to. And the docs are definitely misleading.#2018-04-0616:54mtnygardSorry you had to struggle with this.#2018-04-0616:54mtnygardWe'll try to make it better.#2018-04-0616:55pithylessno problem; I just assumed I was doing something wrong üôÇ#2018-04-0616:55mtnygardI've got to run. Feel free to send me a DM if you run into more trouble.#2018-04-0616:56pithyless@mtnygard thanks for your help! interceptor.chain/execute is still a really nice way to decomplect a workflow üôÇ#2018-04-0920:27hlshipSo ... no commits since Oct 2017, what's up?#2018-04-0922:23dadairAnd is there anything we can do to help?#2018-04-1113:20mtnygard@hlship Mainly just that Paul (the primary steward until now) has to devote his time to personal life for the foreseeable. Just curious.#2018-04-1113:56ikitommiboth. re-frame has interceptors, but bit different, (`:before` and :after and with bit different semantics) and would be great for Clojure/Script story to be able to run ~same web apps on both server targets.#2018-04-1113:57ikitommiThere are at least two ports of pedestal interceptors, just bit different.#2018-04-1113:58ikitommiwe have some libs that suppot both ring and ‚ÄúPedestal-style intereptors‚Äù.#2018-04-1116:22hlshipI found that, when implementing GraphQL subscriptions for Lacinia, using Pedestal web sockets, there existing API was quite opinionated and I had to do a kind of "end run" around the preconceptions: https://github.com/walmartlabs/lacinia-pedestal/blob/5fa4c02be0c9fb97ebfb288e3dd5eda12d09f07e/src/com/walmartlabs/lacinia/pedestal.clj#L608#2018-04-1116:22hlshipIt feels like there's a simpler API buried in there, and the current API should be a convenience layer on top of that.#2018-04-1215:35souenzzo+1 to cljs/spec support#2018-04-1203:23dadairI agree with @hlship re: websockets. I actually only eventually figured out how to do it by replicating most of his Lacinia pedestal ws code, otherwise beforehand I was pretty lost on how to implement stateful WS connections#2018-04-1600:42caleb.macdonaldblackWe are testing against our routes and test logs are being bloated by http request logs. Is there any way to disable logging in pedestal for tests?#2018-04-1602:30mvAre there any popular examples of a pedestal application with a cljs frontend in the same codebase?#2018-04-1707:07joost-diepenmaat@caleb.macdonaldblack you should be able to disable logging for particular namespaces in logback.xml#2018-04-1707:08joost-diepenmaatif you want to do that only for test, what you can do is configure a separate test-resources dir containing a different logback.xml, and include that test-resources dir in your resources config for the ‚Äútest‚Äù profile (that‚Äôs assuming you‚Äôre using leiningen - boot and tools.deps should allow similar strategies)#2018-04-1707:10joost-diepenmaatalternatively, log requests to a different log file that you can ignore üôÇ#2018-04-1707:38caleb.macdonaldblack@joost-diepenmaat Thanks. I think that‚Äôs what I was looking for. üôÇ#2018-04-1712:58ddeaguiar@caleb.macdonaldblack you can also do this on a per test level using something like this: https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/ebe46de1215134c28c59#2018-04-1712:59ddeaguiarthis is useful to squelch logging for tests that verify errors.#2018-04-1713:53caleb.macdonaldblack@ddeaguiar Oh wow thanks. I‚Äôll check it out#2018-04-1713:58ddeaguiarnp! It‚Äôs one of the test utils I typically bring into a project#2018-04-1905:33mvHas anyone gotten figwheel working with pedestal? I haven‚Äôt found any examples#2018-04-1907:59joost-diepenmaatdo you mean pedestal-app or pedestal server?#2018-04-1908:07joost-diepenmaat@mv as far as I know pedestal-app is not really maintained anymore, for server side stuff with a clojurescript frontend I‚Äôve found it easiest to set up 2 different projects where the frontend code has its own figwheel server and the ‚Äúcustom‚Äù server stuff is on another process.#2018-04-1908:09joost-diepenmaatIn production it turns out that usually you‚Äôd deploy the frontend app on some other server than the backend service (app on S3, with caching/CDN) so you need to make sure that that works anyway.#2018-04-1908:47thegeez@mv this project uses pedestal (server) and figwheel: https://github.com/thegeez/clj-board where figwheel is started from the repl (see dev/clj/user/clj), instead of through lein fighweel#2018-04-1913:00ddeaguiar@joost-diepenmaat yep, pedestal-app is no longer maintained. I‚Äôve also found the two project approach (front end, service) to be the preferred approach as well. /cc @mv#2018-04-1917:00mvThanks all!#2018-04-1917:04mv@joost-diepenmaat in case of a split codebase, have you ever experienced that you wanted shared code, and how did you deal with that?#2018-04-2004:11joost-diepenmaat@mv Yeah I have. What I like is to have 2 Leiningen projects in the same code repo and then there are multiple ways to share code. You can symlink shared files/dirs or include a shared src tree in your src paths. Alternatively you can set up a common dependency project but I don‚Äôt like the extra hassle when you‚Äôre not releasing the common code. #2018-04-2004:12mvThat makes sense#2018-04-2119:17mtnygardANNOUNCEMENT: @ddeaguiar recently joined Cognitect and is now a core contributor to Pedestal! He's been a great member of the Pedestal community for a long time, so I'm thrilled that he's taking a strong role here.#2018-04-2123:02ddeaguiarThanks @mtnygard üôÇ#2018-04-2405:21ikitommiwhat is the use case for io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares/fast-resource? It seems to expect that the resources are in a file system, so it doesn‚Äôt work from uberjar?#2018-04-2416:41ddeaguiar@ikitommi I‚Äôll follow up on this but my understanding is that fast-resource is intended to target large files which, by definition, should probably not be in your jar file.#2018-04-2517:35kennyDoes anyone have any idea about this exception? 
java.lang.NullPointerException in Interceptor :io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor/stylobate
I have never seen that interceptor. Full stack trace: https://pastebin.com/W9BuQv6A#2018-04-2518:07kennyThis exception has something to do with the elements array passed to String/join being null. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/request.clj#L27 (enumeration-seq (.getHeaders servlet-req key)) is null.#2018-05-0115:38mtnygard@kenny Checking in late here, but that exception seems like a bug. Would you be willing to submit an issue on Github?#2018-05-0115:40kennySure.#2018-05-0115:41kennyI think it happens when you use response-for with a header value set as nil.#2018-05-0116:00kennyhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/554#2018-05-0316:11tianshuI'm very interest in pedestal, I want to write a web server with core.async. is there any examples for pedestal with core.async? also, i'm curious about how to deal with jdbc with core.async.#2018-05-0316:11tianshuthanks for any help.#2018-05-0316:40ddeaguiarHi @doglooksgood, I‚Äôm glad to hear about your interest in Pedestal! I recommend reading through the Pedestal documentation, in particular the section on interceptor return values (http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#_interceptor_return_values). Unfortunately, I don‚Äôt have a sample project to point you to but I just created an issue (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/104) to track getting that done.#2018-05-0316:45ddeaguiarIn a nutshell, Pedestal interceptors support going async. You just need to return a core.async channel which will yield an updated context#2018-05-0316:46tianshuthat's great, if I understand correct, pedestal can use core.async channel as a response. so basically i can use a go in handler and do everything I want?#2018-05-0316:46tianshuI found on the document that I can return channel in interceptors#2018-05-0316:55ddeaguiarTo be clear, you cannot return a channel as a response.#2018-05-0316:55ddeaguiarin other words#2018-05-0316:56ddeaguiarIf you have a handler function, it can‚Äôt return a channel. But an interceptor can return a channel which will return a context map at some point#2018-05-0316:57tianshuhttp://pedestal.io/reference/streaming#_using_a_core_async_channel_as_the_response this part looks confusing#2018-05-0316:58ddeaguiarHm, I need to look into that because the following does not work 
(defn home-page
  [request]
  (async/go
    (ring-resp/response "Hello World!")))
#2018-05-0316:58ddeaguiarwhile this does 
(def home-page
  (i/interceptor
   {:name ::home-page
    :enter (fn [ctx]
             (async/go
               (assoc ctx :response (ring-resp/response "Hello World!"))))}))
#2018-05-0316:58ddeaguiarbut I will follow up#2018-05-0317:00ddeaguiarah#2018-05-0317:03tianshuokay, I'll take a look#2018-05-0317:04ddeaguiar@doglooksgood I‚Äôm mistaken, when working with servlets you can return a channel as the response body#2018-05-0317:04ddeaguiarbut not as the response#2018-05-0317:06ddeaguiarSo this works 
(defn home-page
  [request]
  (-> (async/go "Hello World!")
      ring-resp/response
      (ring-resp/content-type "text/html")))
#2018-05-0317:06ddeaguiarBut this behavior is specific to servlet interceptor chain providers#2018-05-0317:07ddeaguiarBut I tend to use interceptors in these cases as opposed to handler functions#2018-05-0317:08tianshuwhat does servlet means here?#2018-05-0317:08tianshuuse with some container like tomcat?#2018-05-0317:08ddeaguiarbasically if you use jetty, tomcat or immutant to host your pedestal app#2018-05-0317:09ddeaguiarYou don‚Äôt need to deploy your app as a war. You can start up a container to run it. Jetty is the popular choice and the default#2018-05-0317:10tianshu
(defn index [request]
  {:status 200
   :body (go "hello")})

(def routes
  (route/expand-routes
   #{["/index" :get index :route-name :index]}))

(def service-map
  (-> {::http/routes routes
       ::http/type :immutant
       ::http/port 8890}
      http/default-interceptors
      http/dev-interceptors
      http/create-server))

(mount/defstate server
  :start
  (http/start service-map)
  :stop
  (http/stop server))

(comment
  (mount/start #'server))
I just tried with this, but it failed. the error is Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No implementation of method: :default-content-type of protocol: #'io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor/WriteableBody found for class: clojure.core.async.impl.channels.ManyToManyChannel#2018-05-0317:12ddeaguiarHmm, change :immutant to :jetty#2018-05-0317:12tianshulet me have a try#2018-05-0317:12ddeaguiarit should still fail#2018-05-0317:19tianshuyes, I can't start when use jetty#2018-05-0317:20tianshuvery strange#2018-05-0317:24ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs strange. Found the source of this: expand-routes takes this additional map with :host and :port keys. If I pass it I see the aforementioned issue. If it‚Äôs not passed everything works as expected.#2018-06-0411:54martinklepschSpecifying the host and port as part of the URL does not seem to fix this#2018-06-0412:04martinklepsch
(pdt/parse-url ‚Äúlocalhost:8888/‚Äú)
;; {:scheme nil, :host ‚Äúlocalhost:8888‚Äù, :path ‚Äú‚Äù, :query-string nil}
#2018-06-0412:05martinklepschSo the hostname in test-servlet-response includes the port if provided. And the port is always set to -1: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/6b2faef808c66573e1fde564017ab1dbde1018c8/service/src/io/pedestal/test.clj#L109-L110#2018-06-0412:18martinklepschPatch üëá https://gist.github.com/martinklepsch/9314308cfed88dcdd5a5429265df487d#2018-06-0412:19martinklepschI don‚Äôt know if this should be added but it works. I‚Äôll probably just not pass the {:host ,,, :port ,,, :scheme ,,,} map in testing environments#2018-06-0412:24martinklepsch(because otherwise I‚Äôd also have to specify host/port for test requests and I don‚Äôt want to bother for now)#2018-06-0414:08martinklepschOpened an issue here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/570 included a link to a patch but not sure if it‚Äôs the right thing to do.#2018-06-0411:51souenzzo@martinklepsch reload "all" your namespaces#2018-06-0413:26martinklepschAnother thing I stumbled upon: The default terminator is ring-response/response which checks for a :status key and a :headers key. Is there a particular reason setting headers is required for termination?#2018-06-0414:08martinklepschOpened an issue here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/570 included a link to a patch but not sure if it‚Äôs the right thing to do.#2018-06-0414:38martinklepschIs it intended that url-for doesn‚Äôt throw if the supplied params are lacking some? 
(url-for :artifact/version :path-params {:group-id ‚Äúx‚Äù})
; ‚Äú/d/x/:artifact-id/:version‚Äù
#2018-06-0415:11martinklepschI‚Äôm not sure in what situation you‚Äôd want this behavior. Very confused that this is the default.#2018-06-0614:42martinklepsch@U0FL657GR Do you know if this is intentional? Do you think a PR to either be strict by default or at least make that configurable would be welome?#2018-06-0616:12ddeaguiar@martinklepsch I can‚Äôt say if that‚Äôs intentional or not but I can‚Äôt see why we‚Äôd want that. Can you open an issue? I‚Äôd wait for further feedback before opening a PR. In general, when there are doubts I‚Äôd recommend opening an issue before starting a PR.#2018-06-0616:17ddeaguiarActually#2018-06-0616:17ddeaguiar@martinklepsch I bet this is by design#2018-06-0616:18ddeaguiarpretty sure this is the code https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L252#2018-06-0616:18ddeaguiarand : is a valid character in a path segment (refer to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-3.3)#2018-06-0616:19ddeaguiarso there‚Äôs no way for Pedestal to know if that is a param or part of the path segment#2018-06-0616:26martinklepschbut path-params are passed as a map so there is a way to tell if a given param has been supplied or not.#2018-06-0616:28martinklepschyou can pass a value with a colon and it will be regarded as a path param.#2018-06-0616:28martinklepschWhat‚Äôs done now is just using the key as the value which just seems wrong to me :thinking_face:#2018-06-0616:29martinklepschand yes that code you found is the right one, the (get path-params % %) being the culprit of the whole thing#2018-06-0616:34martinklepschconsider this: 
((route/url-for-routes (route/expand-routes #{["/thing/:id" :get nop :route-name :thing :constraints {:id #"[0-9]+"} ]}))
   :thing :path-params {:foo :bar})
the constraint says digits only but since it‚Äôs just using (str :id) it returns a url as if everything worked as intended#2018-06-0623:13ddeaguiar@martinklepsch while using the key as a value may seem wrong to you it‚Äôs consistent with what‚Äôs contained in the :path-params collection once the route is expanded. Your example does contain additional information which could be used by Pedestal to infer that :id is a path param and is numeric. This information could be used during url generation to let the user know information was missing. Outside of such information I think the current implementation makes a reasonable compromise. I think you should open an issue so that we can solicit additional feedback.#2018-06-0707:55martinklepschOpened an issue: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/572#2018-06-0713:23ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2018-06-0414:39willierHi, the documentation for request-map (http://pedestal.io/reference/request-map) says that :params is ‚ÄúAlways Present‚Äù#2018-06-0414:40willierHowever, (:params request) returns nil#2018-06-0414:41willierI am using the body-params interceptor and passing application/json and can see (:json-params request) just fine#2018-06-0414:43willierHow can I work with params in a content-type agnostic way?#2018-06-0414:47martinklepschI‚Äôm not sure I fully understand the docs for :params but if you want to work with params in content type agnostic way you have a few options: 1) define a simple get-params function that gets all parameter maps you care about and merges them 2) define an interceptor that does the same and stores the result somewhere in the context#2018-06-0414:50willieryea i was hoping that the :params key would provide 1)#2018-06-0414:51willier
Merged map of path, query, and request parameters.
seems to suggest so#2018-06-0414:53martinklepschYeah, understand your confusion, the docs could use some love there I guess#2018-06-0414:56willieri will play around with it a bit more and hopefully not have to resort to writing my own function‚Ä¶#2018-06-0414:56willierthanks#2018-06-0415:00martinklepschwriting your own function shouldn‚Äôt be so bad üôÇ#2018-06-0419:32martinklepschWas a little bit bugged by coupling my routes to the server namespace as that quickly led to cyclic deps. Ended up with this, which I‚Äôm liking so far: https://github.com/martinklepsch/cljdoc/commit/089b5fc20065607327b36d2dc570ee4702bb90a3#diff-2b617a32cb2ee893338f526bde351be6 üôÇ#2018-06-0511:14vemvHi! Cannot reproduce in a clean project sadly.#2018-06-0614:04ddeaguiarAh good to know. Glad you find it.#2018-06-0613:45souenzzoabout jetty / ws example https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/jetty-web-sockets/src/jetty_web_sockets/service.clj#L61 When the server receives a on-close, how it know the "origin" of this message (to remove it from ws-clients atom)????#2018-06-0613:48souenzzoI think that in there https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/3a3c1a27235b8aac16538fc411f360b92af1f524/jetty/src/io/pedestal/http/jetty/websockets.clj#L68 Should be (f this status-code reason)#2018-06-0616:29dadair@souenzzo You basically need to close over your own machinery, @hlship has a good example in his lacinia-pedestal project that I was able to emulate for my own project, see here https://github.com/walmartlabs/lacinia-pedestal/blob/master/src/com/walmartlabs/lacinia/pedestal/subscriptions.clj#L414#2018-06-0616:36dadairHere‚Äôs an example from my own project: 
(defn socket-listener
  "Core listening function for websocket connections/requests."
  [logger idle-timeout auth raw-input-queue sockets {:keys [pub!]}]
  (fn [req resp _]
    (let [[claims jwt-token] (user/authenticated? req auth)
          socket-id (transport/new-socket-id)
          socket-in-ch (async/chan)
          socket-out-ch (async/chan 10)
          socket-kill-ch (async/chan)
          skt (transport/make-socket
               socket-id
               (user/parse-claims claims)
               socket-out-ch
               jwt-token)
          on-connect (fn [session send-ch]
                       (let [remote-addr (.getRemoteAddress ^WebSocketSession session)
                             extra-time 60
                             timeout-ms (utils/s->ms (+ idle-timeout extra-time))]
                         (logger/log logger :report ::connect {:remote remote-addr})
                         (.setIdleTimeout ^WebSocketSession session timeout-ms))
                       (sockets/socket-sender socket-out-ch send-ch socket-kill-ch)
                       (sockets/socket-receiver socket-in-ch
                                                socket-out-ch
                                                raw-input-queue
                                                socket-kill-ch
                                                send-ch
                                                {:idle-timeout idle-timeout
                                                 :socket-id socket-id})
                       (if claims
                         (let [system-topic (transport/make-topic "bypass/system" {})]
                           (swap! sockets sockets/register-socket skt [system-topic]))
                         (do
                           (async/put! socket-out-ch (transport/envelope-unauthorized))
                           (async/<!! (async/timeout 1000))
                           (async/close! send-ch))))]
      (ws/make-ws-listener
       {:on-connect (ws/start-ws-connection on-connect)
        :on-text (fn [raw]
                   (logger/log logger :info ::received {:message raw})
                   (async/put! socket-in-ch [raw socket-id]))
        :on-error (fn [cause]
                    (logger/log logger :warn ::error {:cause cause}))
        :on-close (fn [code reason]
                    (logger/log logger :report ::closed {:code code :reason reason})
                    (let [topics (get-in @sockets [:socket-id->topics (:id skt)])]
                      (swap! sockets sockets/unregister-socket skt)
                      (async/put! socket-kill-ch :kill)
                      (run! async/close! [socket-kill-ch socket-in-ch socket-out-ch])
                      (pub! (socket-closed-evt skt topics))))}))))
#2018-06-0720:23hagmonkare there any plans for a pedestal deps.edn file so I can consume the current work-in-progress stuff? Should I file an issue?#2018-06-0721:28ddeaguiar@hagmonk IMO yes but I‚Äôve not talked to Paul or Mike about this. Is there any discussion happening about combining vase + ions?#2018-06-0813:05ddeaguiar@lanejo01 nothing concrete but I‚Äôm sure it will happen. I‚Äôll keep folks posted here once I have more information.#2018-06-0819:25twashingDoes anyone know how to turn off the Content-Security-Policy header?#2018-06-0819:26twashingInterceptors I took from an example are io.pedestal.http.body-params/body-params and io.pedestal.http/html-body.#2018-06-0819:26twashingBut my response header still includes Content-Security-Policy: object-src 'none'; script-src 'unsafe-inline' 'unsafe-eval' 'strict-dynamic' https: http:;.#2018-06-0819:36martinklepsch@twashing you can pass ::http/secure-headers {:content-security-policy-settings {:object-src "'none'"}} or similar in the service map#2018-06-0819:40twashingHmm, that doesn‚Äôt quite work. But I think it‚Äôs close‚Ä¶ Now I can‚Äôt find any reference in the docs. http://pedestal.io/reference/index#_securing_a_pedestal_application#2018-06-0819:40twashingDid you just dig through the code?#2018-06-0819:40twashing@martinklepsch Thanks btw :)#2018-06-0819:41martinklepschsome of it is documented here: http://pedestal.io/reference/service-map#2018-06-0819:41martinklepschSome other I dug out of this mailing list thread: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pedestal-users/caRnQyUOHWA#2018-06-0819:41twashingAh ha#2018-06-0819:49twashing@martinklepsch Did the trick. Thanks mate!#2018-06-0819:49martinklepschnp üôÇ#2018-06-0917:27ikitommicould someone explain the :bindings in the context map? what is the use case for them?#2018-06-0917:27ikitommi> As accepted by clojure.core/with-bindings. Prior to delegating execution to any interceptor, the interceptor framework will ensure that the bindings specified in this map are installed using clojure.core/with-bindings. If this map is altered and included in the returned context from an interceptor, the new bindings in the map will be installed as thread local bindings prior to another interceptor‚Äôs execution.#2018-06-0917:53souenzzoif you do (bindings [db (get-db)] (run-query)) then you can create a chain like [interceptor-get-db handler-run-query]#2018-06-0918:51ikitommithanks. Is there a case where that is better/recommended over to just assoccing in the db-con into context and thus making the binding explicit? Thread locals are really slow both to read & write.#2018-06-1021:35twashingIs there an example of Pedestal websockets with transit? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/samples/jetty-web-sockets#2018-06-1021:35twashingThe out-of-the-box one, only accepts Strings and ByteBuffers. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/jetty/src/io/pedestal/http/jetty/websockets.clj#L19#2018-06-1023:59twashing^^^ All good. I just stiched something together with https://github.com/cognitect/transit-clj .#2018-06-1406:56mkvlrdoes anybody have a recommendation for logging requests using pedestal? Should we do that through jetty or pedestal with log-request? With rails we‚Äôve used and liked https://github.com/roidrage/lograge#2018-06-1513:32ddeaguiar@mkvlr if you are not setting :io.pedestal.http/interceptors in your app‚Äôs service map, you will by default use log-request for request logging. This is set when default-interceptors is called during service startup (see here https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L205-L206). You also have the opportunity to override the request logger.#2018-06-1514:58mkvlr@ddeaguiar yep, so far we‚Äôre using that but it doesn‚Äôt log request time, ip etc.#2018-06-1515:00mkvlrmight be nice to have that included by default#2018-06-1515:05ddeaguiarI was going to suggest opening an issue for this request but I think you should bring it up on the Pedestal user group first. Can you do that? Paul monitors that channel and he should chime in there.#2018-06-1515:06mkvlrsure, will do. Thanks and have a good weekend!#2018-06-1515:10ddeaguiaryou too!#2018-06-2200:16hlshipI kind of remember seeing an issue that an async interceptor that adds a :response to the context doesn't trigger the leave state; I'm seeing this, where interceptor #1 adds a valid :response key to the context inside a go block, and interceptor #2 still executes normally (causing big problems for my app).#2018-06-2200:18hlshipI've added more logging, and in the enter of my second interceptor: 
:parse-query :response {:status 400, :headers {}, :body {:errors [{:message "Stored query not found."}]}}
So my first interceptor is terminating correctly, by adding a valid :response key, but my second interceptor is still executing.#2018-06-2200:21hlshipWith more logging: 
05.558 DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:interceptor :com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal/query-source, :stage :enter, :execution-id 11, :fn #object[com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal$pass_query_through_query_source$fn__26193 0x3fff323d "com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal$pass_query_through_query_source$fn__26193@3fff323d"], :line 50}
:store-result #object[clojure.core.async.impl.channels.ManyToManyChannel 0x6778b666 "clojure.core.async.impl.channels.ManyToManyChannel@6778b666"]
:assoc-bad-request-response
05.559 DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in process-all, :handling :enter, :execution-id 11, :line 154}
05.560 DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:interceptor :com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal/query-parser, :stage :enter, :execution-id 11, :fn #object[com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal$query_parser_interceptor$fn__26164 0x310e7b84 "com.walmartlabs.lacinia.pedestal$query_parser_interceptor$fn__26164@310e7b84"], :line 50}
:parse-query :response {:status 400, :headers {}, :body {:errors [{:message "Stored query not found."}]}}
05.561 DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in check-terminators, :terminate? true, :execution-id 11, :line 96}
05.561 DEBUG io.pedestal.interceptor.chain - {:in leave-all, :execution-id 11, :line 241}
I'd expect the :in check-temrinators to occur after the query-source interceptor, but it get delayed until the query-parser interceptor. The first is async, the second is standard.#2018-06-2200:27hlshipNote: this is in 0.5.3, I'm checking 0.5.4 now.#2018-06-2202:28hlshipSeems to be present in 0.5.4#2018-06-2613:08ddeaguiar@U04VDKC4G sorry for the delayed response but I‚Äôve been traveling. Refer to the release notes for details https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/releases/tag/0.5.4#2018-07-0214:35martinklepschIs there a function in pedestal (or any of it‚Äôs dependencies) that will return the path part of a given URL?#2018-07-0214:54martinklepschTo step back a bit: I‚Äôm trying to see if the referer url matches any of my defined routes. Any suggestions welcome üôÇ#2018-07-0214:59ddeaguiar@martinklepsch the key :path-info should be on the request map. I think that‚Äôs what you are looking for.#2018-07-0214:59martinklepsch@ddeaguiar that works for the current incoming request but i‚Äôm interested in operating on the referer of the request#2018-07-0215:01ddeaguiaras in the Referer header?#2018-07-0215:01martinklepschyes#2018-07-0215:01ddeaguiarAFAIK you‚Äôll have to pull that header value directly#2018-07-0215:02ddeaguiarah#2018-07-0215:02ddeaguiarok#2018-07-0215:02ddeaguiari understand what you want#2018-07-0215:02ddeaguiarsorry, you want to take a url and get the path-info essentially#2018-07-0215:02martinklepschmore general problem to give some context: I want to allow users to use URLs like /some/thing/CURRENT where CURRENT is resolved based on the referer and a redirect to the actual ‚Äúcurrent‚Äù thing is returned#2018-07-0215:02martinklepschhope that makes some sense#2018-07-0215:03martinklepsch> sorry, you want to take a url and get the path-info essentially yeah, and that‚Äôs the simpest part of it I guess, I duct-taped it with some regexes now but thought there‚Äôs probably something built in#2018-07-0215:04ddeaguiarPath info is calculated on a per-container basis. There‚Äôs a ContainerRequest protocol which is implemented for servlet containers#2018-07-0215:04ddeaguiarso for example, here‚Äôs the impl for servlets https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/23b2144e72f122793531192ee2079c095de71002/service/src/io/pedestal/http/request/servlet_support.clj#L26-L31#2018-07-0215:06ddeaguiarEssentially you‚Äôd need to know what the context path is for the referrer to do a similar thing#2018-07-0215:11martinklepschEnded up with this now which feels somewhat hacky but at least it gives me back a map with info about the parsed route: 
(route/try-routing-for (routes identity {}) :map-tree "/d/reagent/reagent/0.8.1" :get)
#2018-07-0221:31ddeaguiar@martinklepsch you may find parse-path to be helpful https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/f89d0abe244d0e8385d66a697724ef56180a00e5/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route/path.clj#L35.#2018-07-0221:32ddeaguiarsample usage 
(require '[io.pedestal.http.route.path :as route.path])

 (def parsed-path (route.path/parse-path "/foo/:id/:baz"))
 ;; {:path-constraints {:baz "([^/]+)", :id "([^/]+)"},
 ;;  :path-params      [:id :baz],
 ;;  :path-parts       ["foo" :id :baz]}

 (route.path/path-regex parsed-path)
 ;; #"/\Qfoo\E/([^/]+)/([^/]+)"
#2018-07-0221:35martinklepsch@ddeaguiar Interesting, are you suggesting to build my own match-route based on my route information and that function?#2018-07-0221:35martinklepschIn case you haven‚Äôt seen this message: https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C0K65B20P/p1530544463000434#2018-07-0221:35ddeaguiarpreferably this would be easier to do. I‚Äôm looking into that now#2018-07-0221:36ddeaguiarthis fn gets you part of the way there#2018-07-0221:36ddeaguiarto match routes you need a route specification#2018-07-0221:36ddeaguiarboth in bidi and in pedestal#2018-07-0221:37ddeaguiarbut I think in your case you are dealing with referer urls right? These are not routes in your app, correct?#2018-07-0221:39martinklepschthey might not be but I‚Äôm specifically trying to handle the case that they are part of my app (for which I need to match them against my route table#2018-07-0221:40ddeaguiarI brought up these fns as an option for parsing paths arbitrarily.#2018-07-0221:41ddeaguiarI‚Äôm unclear as to what the route fn is in your example: 
(route/try-routing-for (routes identity {}) :map-tree "/d/reagent/reagent/0.8.1" :get)

You can leverage a specific routing impl directly#2018-07-0221:43martinklepschI‚Äôm using that little indirection of passing a resolver to decouple the definition of the routes table from the actual handlers#2018-07-0221:44ddeaguiarIf you look at what try-routing-for does, it creates a router of a specific type and invokes the :enter impl#2018-07-0221:44martinklepschI need it because I want to determine route-name and path-params for an arbitrary path-info string like "/some/uri"#2018-07-0221:44ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/f89d0abe244d0e8385d66a697724ef56180a00e5/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L501-L506#2018-07-0221:44martinklepschyes that‚Äôs what I ended up using üòÑ#2018-07-0221:46martinklepschIt does what I need but it seems undocumented and that ;;; Help for debugging comment makes me think that I might be abusing it for things it wasn‚Äôt intended for#2018-07-0221:47ddeaguiarI think it‚Äôs perfectly acceptable to use a router directly. I don‚Äôt think you need to bother with try-routing-for#2018-07-0221:47ddeaguiarone sec, let me experiment#2018-07-0221:49martinklepschI‚Äôll head to bed but thanks for looking into this. That should answer your questions.#2018-07-1109:28LightlightWhen using websockets with pedestal and jetty, any tips on keeping track of sessions so I can send message to a specific connection?
