When I'm running the server with lein run und call the endpoint with curl everything is working fine. But when I'm using response_for the :edn-params isn't filled. Any ideas?#2018-07-1212:06jcf@david_clojurian one thing to look out for when using response-for is the request map is different to the one you'd get from a 'real' request. If you're using things like Accept/Host headers etc. in your code that may cause issues.#2018-07-1212:30david_clojurian@jcf The body is empty. When I'm looking at the code of pedestal io.pedestal.test/servlet-response-for I'm not sure that the body is processed at all. response_for isn't working for me when I want to do a POST with a body.#2018-07-1212:31jcfWhat does your test code look like?#2018-07-1212:31jcf
(io.pedestal.test/response-for app :body "foo")
#2018-07-1212:31jcfSomething like that?#2018-07-1212:32david_clojurian
(let [r (response-for service :post "/test-suites"
                          :body "{:test-suite/name        \"Suite-Name\"}"
                          :headers {"content-type" "application/edn"})
          uri (str "/test-suites/" (-> r
                                       :body
                                       (edn/read-string)))]
      (-> r
          :status
          (= 200)
          (is (-> r :body))))
#2018-07-1212:34jcf
(is (= 200 (:status r)))
(is (= 'foo (:body r)))
#2018-07-1212:34jcfIf you haven't already, add some logging to your code inside your route/interceptor that logs the context. Let's see what's there.#2018-07-1212:35jcf
(def log-context-interceptor
  {:name ::log-context-interceptor
   :enter (fn [context] (log/debug :context context) context)})
#2018-07-1212:36jcfSomething like that'll if you don't have somewhere to add the logging already. Then you can add that to your interceptor chain.#2018-07-1212:37jcfBTW, if you want to short-circuit tests when the status isn't 200 etc. this pattern can work quite well: 
(when (is (= 200 (:status response))
          (with-out-str (clojure.pprint/pprint response)))
  ;; These test assertions won't be executed if the status isn't 200.
  (is (= 'foo (:body response))))
#2018-07-1212:38jcfUseful if you've got loads of assertions you don't need to check if things are utterly broken. üôÇ#2018-07-1212:41jcf@david_clojurian the Content-Type header in that response map is "".#2018-07-1212:41jcfEmpty string in both the request and the response from the looks of it.#2018-07-1212:41david_clojurianBut I set it#2018-07-1212:42david_clojurianAs you saw before#2018-07-1212:42jcfTry it with the "Content-Type" capitalisation just to make sure that's not it.#2018-07-1212:42jcfRing always lowercases things but either Aleph and/or Pedestal sometimes don't.#2018-07-1212:43jcf
(def ^:private secure-headers
  {"Content-Security-Policy" "object-src 'none'"
   "Strict-Transport-Security" "max-age=31536000; includeSubdomains"
   "X-Content-Type-Options" "nosniff"
   "X-Download-Options" "noopen"
   "X-Frame-Options" "DENY"
   "X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies" "none"
   "X-XSS-Protection" "1; mode=block"})

(def ^:const ^:private html+utf8 "text/html;charset=UTF-8")

(deftest hello-world
  (t/with-system [{:keys [service]} (t/system)]
    (let [response (t/response-for service :get "/fmt")]
      (when (is (= 200 (:status response))
                (t/pprint-str response))
        (is (= (assoc secure-headers "Content-Type" html+utf8)
               (:headers response)))))))

(deftest about
  (t/with-system [{:keys [service]} (t/system)]
    (let [response (t/response-for service :get "/api/site/v1/about")]
      (is (= 200 (:status response)))
      (is (= (assoc secure-headers "Content-Type" "text/plain")
             (dissoc (:headers response) "vaserequest-id")))
      (is (= "This came from site.edn!"
             (:body response))))))
#2018-07-1212:44jcfThat's some test code in one of my personal projects. I'm using the HTTP header capitalisation, and those tests pass.#2018-07-1212:45jcfI wrap response-for to make it take a proper map because kvs are not very nice to work with.#2018-07-1212:46david_clojurianWith capitalisation everthing works fine! Thank you very much. üòÄ#2018-07-1212:46jcfYou're welcome!#2018-07-1212:46jcfHope you have fun with Pedestal. It's a great piece of software.#2018-07-1212:48david_clojurianYes it is. I love the simplicity of the serverside events. Very impressive.#2018-07-1710:02joseI have one route where I want to skip the secure-headers default interceptor, but for all the others, I want to use the default interceptors. is it possible for an interceptor to remove another interceptor from the execution queue? (or in this case, just the :leave function)#2018-07-1714:28michael zhouHi all, what might cause the error?#2018-07-1714:28michael zhouclojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: java.lang.ClassCastException in Interceptor :io.pedestal.http.secure-headers/secure-headers - java.lang.Integer cannot be cast to clojure.lang.Associative at clojure.core$ex_info.invokeStatic(core.clj:4739) at clojure.core$ex_info.invoke(core.clj:4739) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$throwable__GT_ex_info.invokeStatic(chain.clj:35) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$throwable__GT_ex_info.invoke(chain.clj:32) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$try_f.invokeStatic(chain.clj:57) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$try_f.invoke(chain.clj:44) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$leave_all_with_binding.invokeStatic(chain.clj:254) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$leave_all_with_binding.invoke(chain.clj:237) at io.pedestal.interceptor.chain$leave_all$fn__10637.invoke(chain.clj:268) at clojure.lang.AFn.applyToHelper(AFn.java:152) at clojure.lang.AFn.applyTo(AFn.java:144)#2018-07-1714:28Joe Lane@jm301 If you just need uni-directional data flow from server => client and can settle for http posts on client => server then the SSE work done with pedestal is REALLY high quality. It even lets you pick up where you left off if you‚Äôre streaming ordered data by providing an identifier for the last payload you received.#2018-07-1714:29Joe Lane@zhoumin79 Looks like you‚Äôre using an integer somewhere that secure-headers is expecting a hashmap#2018-07-1714:30michael zhou(def csp-header (sec-headers/content-security-policy-header {:default-src ‚Äú‚Äòself‚Äô‚Äù :font-src ‚Äú‚Äòself‚Äô https://at.alicdn.com‚Äù :connect-src ‚Äú‚Äòself‚Äô <ws://localhost:3449/>‚Äù :style-src ‚Äú‚Äòself‚Äô ‚Äòunsafe-inline‚Äô‚Äù :object-src ‚Äú‚Äònone‚Äô‚Äù :script-src ‚Äú‚Äòself‚Äô ‚Äòunsafe-inline‚Äô ‚Äòunsafe-eval‚Äô https: http:‚Äú})) ;; Consumed by xlight.server/create-server ;; See http/default-interceptors for additional options you can configure (def service {:env :prod ::http/routes routes ::http/type :jetty ::http/port 8080 ::http/resource-path ‚Äú/public‚Äù ;::http/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)} ;::http/allowed-origins [‚Äú*‚Äù] ;; Content Security Policy (CSP) is mostly turned off in dev mode ::http/secure-headers {:content-security-policy-settings csp-header} ::http/container-options {:h2c? true :h2? false :read-only? false ;:keystore ‚Äútest/hp/keystore.jks‚Äù ;:key-password ‚Äúpassword‚Äù ;:ssl-port 8443 :ssl? false} })#2018-07-1714:31michael zhou@lanejo01 my secure-headers config, when I delete an item,it triggers this error. Wrong config?#2018-07-1714:33michael zhou(reg-event-fx :delete-user (fn [ [ user-id]] {:http {:method DELETE :url (str ‚Äú/users/‚Äù (clj->js user-id)) :ignore-response-body true :success-event [:navigate-to-home-page]}}))#2018-07-1714:34michael zhouThe user deleted.But it shows the above error and this#2018-07-1714:34michael zhouINFO i.p.http.impl.servlet-interceptor - {:msg ‚Äúsending error‚Äù, :message ‚ÄúInternal server error: exception‚Äù, :line 215}#2018-07-1714:36michael zhou;(db/delete-user {:userid 778}) (defn delete-user [request] (let [id (get-in request [:path-params :id])] (db/delete-user {:userid (Integer/parseInt id)})))#2018-07-1714:41michael zhouDo anyone have a clueÔºü Thanks.#2018-07-1714:47Joe LaneWhich version of pedestal are you running?#2018-07-1714:47michael zhou[io.pedestal/pedestal.service ‚Äú0.5.4‚Äù] [io.pedestal/pedestal.jetty ‚Äú0.5.4"]#2018-07-1714:48Joe LaneAre you running the dev server or in production mode?#2018-07-1714:49michael zhoulein run--- prod mode#2018-07-1714:53Joe LaneThe result from your delete-user function is likely the number of rows affected as a count correct? The result from delete-user must be a map.#2018-07-1714:53Joe LaneIts getting mad because the csp leave handler happens to be trying to call functions on the result of delete-user, which is an integer.#2018-07-1714:54Joe Lanedelete-user in this scenario is a handler#2018-07-1714:54Joe Lanein pedestal terminology#2018-07-1714:55Joe LaneSo I looked at a sample project#2018-07-1714:56Joe Lanethe result of delete-user needs to be a response object, like from the ring project#2018-07-1714:56Joe LaneSee here https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/tracing-interceptor/src/tracing_interceptor/service.clj#2018-07-1714:57Joe LaneYou‚Äôve almost got it, you just need to return the right thing from delete-user#2018-07-1715:01michael zhou@lanejo01 thank you very much. I see.#2018-07-1715:01michael zhou(http/json-response (db/delete-user {:userid id}))#2018-07-1715:03Joe LaneDid that end up workin for you @zhoumin79?#2018-07-1715:06michael zhouYes.Thanks.#2018-07-2321:10dadairI‚Äôm trying to serve three separately defined pedestal services on a single server, but each service should be on a unique port (e.g., 8001 for service1, 8002 for service2, 8003 for service3, etc). Is this possible with the standard server-construction helpers?#2018-07-2321:16ddeaguiar@dadair nope, Pedestal does provide an escape hatch to specify Jetty configuration. You can possibly do it that way. I‚Äôve never had the need to do this so unfortunately I can‚Äôt give more details#2018-07-2416:48kennyI have an async interceptor that returns a channel. For example: 
(def my-async-interceptor
  {:enter
   (fn [context]
     (println "start processing")
     (async/go
       (println "inside go block")
       ;; imitate some time consuming process
       (async/<! (async/timeout 10000))
       (assoc context :response {:status  200
                                 :body    "ok"
                                 :headers {}})))})
If I get a bunch of these request piled up (the go block takes some time to return), then the println inside the go no longer prints "inside go block" but "start processing" is still printed. Any idea why this would happen?#2018-07-2417:51ddeaguiar@kenny the backing threadpool for go is small. I suggest using thread with io-bound operations. Keep in mind that once you go async, the remaining interceptors are processed on a go thread once your async interceptor returns.#2018-07-2418:43kenny@ddeaguiar Do you recommend for handlers that could have lots of longish (~10s) requests pending to simply be "synchronous"? i.e. no go block?#2018-07-2419:03ddeaguiar@kenny no, I‚Äôd move those off the servlet thread. I typically perform any heavy-lifting/integration in interceptors and limit the final handler to response handling#2018-07-2419:06ddeaguiarif you have longish operations, you can use thread instead.#2018-07-2419:06kennyNot sure I totally understand what you mean. In my case my handler sends a message to an external service that processes the request. The handler then takes the response from the external service and constructs a HTTP response. All of that is happening in the final handler in the interceptor chain.#2018-07-2419:07ddeaguiarso you can move the integration piece to an interceptor and leave the response processing to the handler#2018-07-2419:07kennyWhy would that make a difference?#2018-07-2419:08ddeaguiarJust communicating how I normally split up work. Either way, use thread not go#2018-07-2419:08ddeaguiarcaveat is this#2018-07-2419:09ddeaguiarif your handler returns a channel then that channel is expected to return a response body#2018-07-2419:09ddeaguiarif an interceptor returns a channel, then that channel is expected to return a context map#2018-07-2419:10ddeaguiarI tend to avoid io-bound operations on the serving thread and go blocks#2018-07-2419:10ddeaguiarbest to keep those free#2018-07-2419:11ddeaguiarparticularly if integrations take ~10s#2018-07-2419:12kennyMost often they will take a much shorter time 0-2s but sometimes it may take ~10s.#2018-07-2419:13ddeaguiarstill 2s is a long time#2018-07-2419:13ddeaguiarI‚Äôd also consider introducing a circuit-breaker#2018-07-2419:14kennyIs that more than a simple timeout?#2018-07-2419:14ddeaguiarthe pattern is more than that but a timeout is a good start#2018-07-2419:15ddeaguiarThat may be enough though. It depends on what your needs are#2018-07-2419:16kennyThe way it is written now is it waits for a response from the external service for up to 10s, if no response is returned when 10s is hit then an error response is returned.#2018-07-2419:17ddeaguiarDepending on what type of system you are building and the traffic you expect, you can end up exhausting your thread pool#2018-07-2419:18ddeaguiarif, for example, the system you are integrating with goes down for a long period of time#2018-07-2419:18ddeaguiarwith a circuit breaker you can detect errors and trip the breaker causing additional requests to fail fast#2018-07-2419:18ddeaguiarthen you can test some requests to see if the situation has been resolved#2018-07-2419:19ddeaguiarand either close the breaker or leave it tripped#2018-07-2419:19ddeaguiarHystrix is commonly used here https://github.com/Netflix/Hystrix/wiki#2018-07-2419:20ddeaguiarbut there‚Äôs a bit of ceremony involved so you‚Äôd use something like this if you really need it#2018-07-2419:21kennyIf the threadpool gets exhausted, what happens to additional requests that come in?#2018-07-2419:23ddeaguiarI suppose you‚Äôll see some form of queueing. You‚Äôll see response times go up.#2018-07-2419:24kennyHmm. Any idea how easy it'd be to exhaust the thread pool?#2018-07-2419:25ddeaguiarIf you use go, pretty easy since it‚Äôs small (like 8ish threads)#2018-07-2419:25ddeaguiarAFAIK, thread is unbounded so you are limited by your system#2018-07-2419:28ddeaguiaryou can change the pool size for go#2018-07-2419:28kennyIt sounds like thread is the right approach here.#2018-07-2419:28ddeaguiarI‚Äôve never worked outside of the defaults here#2018-07-2419:28kennyWhat do you mean?#2018-07-2419:29ddeaguiarI‚Äôve never changed the default threadpool size in core.async#2018-07-2419:29ddeaguiarbut you can http://clojure.github.io/core.async/#clojure.core.async/#2018-07-2419:29ddeaguiar
go blocks are dispatched over an internal thread pool, which
defaults to 8 threads. The size of this pool can be modified using
the Java system property `clojure.core.async.pool-size`.
#2018-07-2419:30kennyOh. Why would I want to do that over using thread?#2018-07-2419:30ddeaguiarJust pointing out it‚Äôs possible. I wouldn‚Äôt#2018-07-2419:31ddeaguiarthe heuristic I use for choosing between go and thread are: cpu-bound -> go, io-bound -> thread#2018-07-2419:32kennyThat's quite useful! I'll change to thread for IO ops. Thanks.#2018-07-2419:32ddeaguiarnp!#2018-07-2715:25curtosisodd pedestal behavior: I have one version that starts up and binds to :&lt;port&gt;. My current version starts up and *only binds to localhost:<port>. I can‚Äôt see where I‚Äôm doing anything different between the two ‚Äî I never set ::http/host explicitly.#2018-07-2715:25curtosisAny clues where to look?#2018-07-2715:55curtosisobviously can work around it by passing in 0.0.0.0, but I‚Äôm curious why it worked before and doesn‚Äôt now.#2018-07-2718:08bherrmannmaybe different profiles?#2018-07-2718:14curtosisI looked at those, but I really didn‚Äôt touch those that I could see.#2018-07-2718:14curtosisI should dig through the uberjars and see what got included differently#2018-07-2718:24jonahbenton@curtosis check this commit: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/commit/6270df0e07aefa93a5aa9987aad749e508723c10#2018-07-2718:25curtosisthat would be the right place, but I wasn‚Äôt specifying host explicitly anywhere (that‚Äôs how I fixed it)#2018-08-0119:49skratI'm kind of lost in interceptors, I would like to log response status code and duration, how can I do that?#2018-08-0119:51ddeaguiarYou can create an interceptor with an :enter and :leave implementation which, on enter, appends a timestamp to the context and, on leave, calculates the difference and logs it as well as the status code#2018-08-0119:52ddeaguiarUnfortunately response timings are not available out of the box#2018-08-0119:52ddeaguiar@skrat ^^#2018-08-0119:53skrat@ddeaguiar excellent answer, I'll give it a try#2018-08-0120:05souenzzoYou can add some headers then it will appear on chrome/firefox network tab 
(def http-timming-header
  {:name  ::http-timming-header
   :enter (fn [ctx] (assoc-in ctx [:request :inst] (new Date)))
   :leave (fn [{{:keys [inst]} :request
                :as            ctx}]
            (let [diff (-> (time.coerce/to-date-time inst)
                           (time/interval (time/now))
                           (time/in-millis))]
              (assoc-in ctx [:response :headers "Server-Timing"]
                        (format "app=%s; \"My App\"" diff))))})
#2018-08-0119:53ddeaguiarüôÇ#2018-08-0120:48martinklepschI wonder what approaches are there if you want to measure the time taken for every interceptor individually.#2018-08-0120:49martinklepschInterleave :chain with appropriate interceptors? Update :enter & :leave handlers of interceptors to include this?#2018-08-0121:03ddeaguiarI suppose you can do that. The interceptors I‚Äôd be must interested in instrumenting are the ones I created. If anything, I‚Äôd create an interceptor helper fn which allowed me to create instrumented interceptors but personally I‚Äôve never had the need for anything like that.#2018-08-0121:05skratI don't see any use cases for that, for performance tuning you can use profiler#2018-08-0121:07ddeaguiaryep#2018-08-0213:58dadairI‚Äôm having an issue getting CORS working; I‚Äôve followed the guides and the service map has ‚Äò:io.pedestal.http/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}‚Äô, but I get a 404 on browser OPTION pre-flight#2018-08-0213:59dadairNot sure where I‚Äôm going wrong here#2018-08-0216:26curtosis@dadair I saw that with pedestal-lacinia. IIRC pre-flight means the browser is rejecting it before sending it along. In my case it was sending a query that didn‚Äôt match the API spec. Maybe that helps you narrow down the problem point?#2018-08-0216:47dadairDo I need to define a catch-all :option route? From looking at the pedestal CORS code, I thought it handles all of this in interceptors that are pre-router#2018-08-0217:35dadairFound the problem(s): 1. I was setting the ::http/allowed-origins key after applying the default interceptors function (which relies on the presence of the key to add the appropriate interceptor) 2. I was providing my own :interceptors [] key, which was preventing default-interceptors from defining the defaults to begin-with (I thought this would add, rather than prevent)#2018-08-0221:25dadairAre there any unexpected consequences one should be aware of when running multiple pedestal-jetty servers (different ports) in a single JVM? Outside of general performance considerations.#2018-08-0221:26dadairWe‚Äôre trying to trim our proliferation of services by combining services into a single/less JVMs (we don‚Äôt expect huge load). I have multiple servers running, and everything seems to be fine, just wanted to make sure there wasn‚Äôt going to be anything biting us in the butt later#2018-08-0221:57jonahbentonYou can have as many or as few ports open as you want, and certainly webapp containers usually host many services at once- but logically services can have lots of singleton resources- connection pools, caches, etc- and distinct lifecycles- before this/after that- and dependencies. Obviously there's additional context but my knee jerk would be to make them really one service- one port, one lifecycle, etc, easing the transition pain with a load balancer or proxy if need be- or fitting into the war-container pattern. Two microservices on two ports in one jvm- again absent additional context- feels like a doesn't end well situation to me.#2018-08-0300:15dadairDuct/integrant seems to be keeping the singletons/lifecycle management manageable, so I‚Äôll keep pushing it and see how it goes. Worst case I could combine the routes into a single server and prefix each service with a path prefix.#2018-08-0516:37skratIs there a way I can get a ring handler fn from pedestal service-map?#2018-08-0618:08mtnygard@skrat I think the :service-fn key might have the value you're looking for.#2018-08-0618:09mtnygardBut I haven't tried it... that's off the top of my head.#2018-08-0621:17ddeaguiarThe ::io.pedestal.http/service-fn is an implementation of the Servlet.service method. I think you‚Äôll need to write your own interceptor chain provider to support a pedestal service as a ring handler.#2018-08-0913:06jmayaalvHI, i am trying to pack a pedestal app that uses deps.edn and keep getting:

From localhost, everything works#2018-08-2115:26souenzzoBump! There is no changelog for 5.4 üòï https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2018-08-2108:12ikitommihow can one test interceptor chains which have async steps?#2018-08-2112:16ddeaguiar@ikitommi you can use response-for with async interceptors. Refer to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/270a9e49e556b0f2af0bb58ec7a422873c3d065c/service/test/io/pedestal/http_test.clj#L306-L326#2018-08-2116:32ddeaguiarah that‚Äôs my fault. You can find release notes here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/releases/tag/0.5.4#2018-08-2117:43souenzzoMaybe a warning in #557 once it is potentially breaking#2018-08-2118:11ddeaguiarUpdated the release notes to be more explicit about this. Thanks!#2018-08-2118:11ddeaguiarand sorry!#2018-08-2116:33ddeaguiar@souenzzo ^^#2018-08-2116:33ddeaguiarI will look to update the changelog as well#2018-08-2116:55ikitommi@ddeaguiar thanks. But I‚Äôm poiking with the interceptor chain directly.#2018-08-2116:56ikitommi
(require '[io.pedestal.interceptor.chain :as pc])
(require '[io.pedestal.interceptor :as pi])
(require '[clojure.core.async :as a])

(-> {:kikka "kukka"}
    (pc/enqueue [(pi/interceptor {:enter identity})])
    (pc/execute))
;=> {:kikka "kukka"}

(-> {:kikka "kukka"}
    (pc/enqueue [(pi/interceptor {:enter (fn [ctx] (a/go ctx))})])
    (pc/execute))
;=> nil
#2018-08-2116:57ikitommiIt works if I add a custom interceptor as first into the queue and write the value into a promise which i deref outside of the chain, but looking for a better way.#2018-08-2117:02ddeaguiarIC, I recall having a workaround for testing requests satisfied by async interceptors before response-for handled them but it eludes me atm. I‚Äôll try and remember#2018-08-2117:07ddeaguiar@ikitommi here‚Äôs what I did in the past. I tend to avoid with-redefs but I found this useful. I‚Äôm sure there are better ways, though.#2018-08-2117:09ddeaguiarit‚Äôs tightly coupled with the Pedestal‚Äôs underlying impl so that‚Äôs gross#2018-08-2117:09ddeaguiarbut hey, I was in a pinch üôÇ#2018-08-2117:10ikitommiyes it‚Äôs bad üôÇ#2018-08-2117:10ikitommiI think that could be interesting outside of tests too, as the interceptor chain can be run as standalone too.#2018-08-2117:11ikitommiOne solution would be to add a second arity to execute with a second argument which is a callback called when all done.#2018-08-2117:12ikitommi
(let [on-complete (promise)]
  (-> {:kikka "kukka"}
      (pc/enqueue [(pi/interceptor {:enter (fn [ctx] (a/go ctx))})])
      (pc/execute on-complete)
  (deref on-complete 1000 ::timeout))
#2018-08-2117:13ddeaguiarI need to go back and better understand the change made to support async response-for testing#2018-08-2117:13ikitommibut, just wondering how it‚Äôs intended to be used, not needing this feature.#2018-08-2117:17ddeaguiarbecause the solution is going to be around stubbing the async context#2018-08-2218:17jaihindhreddy-duplicateHi all, can I connect to a MySQL database asynchronously in an interceptor?#2018-08-2219:10hlshipSomething I noticed when upgrading from 0.5.3 to 0.5.4 was that Pedestal is now intolerant of nils in the interceptor list; previously it would skip over the nils, but now it fails. I had to change some setup code, that had some conditional parts in it, to filter out the nils before passing them to io.pedestal.http/create-server.#2018-08-2618:08lxsameerhey folks, how can I provide a list of default interceptors for all the handlers which gets merge with what ever interceptors list that handler provides ?#2018-08-2619:00hlshipI'd say that kind of thing is out of Pedestal's set of responsibilities. This kind of thing is typically solved in code: write a function that returns the routes, pass the default interceptors into that function, build the routes w/ those interceptors and your handlers.#2018-08-2619:02hlshipAlternately, you could start with the routes and write code that walks the set and modifies the entries to add the interceptors but that will be much more clumsy than just building the data structure right the first time.#2018-08-2619:34lxsameerthanks#2018-08-2707:51martinklepschMight misunderstand but there is a default-interceptors option IIRC. Maybe that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for? #2018-08-2712:58ddeaguiarFollowing up on what @U050TNB9F said, while Pedestal does provide default interceptors, you can override those default interceptors by specifying your own ‚Äòdefault‚Äô interceptors by assoc‚Äôing them to the service map via the io.pedestal.http/interceptors key.#2018-08-2715:01hlshipTo hopefully clarify: the default interceptors carry request processing through some initial steps, and ends with the router; the router takes it from there to find a specific route, and each route can have its own customized interceptor stack, terminating with a handler.#2018-08-2717:51souenzzoHey. When I do ?foo[]=33&foo[]=55 pedestal generates :query-params {:foo[] [33 55]} (brackets are part of foo keyword) Is it a bug or a feature? A PR allowing rails vec-strategy on query params (as a opt-in) will be welcome? https://github.com/JulianBirch/cljs-ajax#get-specific-settings#2018-08-2907:58lxsameerhey folks, i‚Äôm using pedestal router only. how can I use middleware/fast-resource with it. do I need to add a new route for resources ?#2018-08-2921:25ddeaguiarNo but the fast-resource interceptor needs to come before the router interceptor#2018-08-2921:25ddeaguiar@lxsameer ^^#2018-08-2921:25ddeaguiarotherwise the router interceptor will try and match the request and return a 404#2018-08-2921:28ddeaguiarJust to add more context, the presence of :io.pedestal.http/resource-path in the service map leads to the resource interceptor to be conj‚Äôd onto the interceptor coll when io.pedestal.default-interceptors is invoked and :io.pedestal.http/interceptors is not present.#2018-08-2921:30ddeaguiarThe value of :io.pedestal.http/resource-path is used to create the resource interceptor as follows: (middlewares/resource resource-path)#2018-08-2921:31ddeaguiarso you can essentially do the same thing but using io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares/fast-resource#2018-08-2921:31ddeaguiarYour container needs to support async NIO responses#2018-08-2921:36hlshipWe've noticed that a route that's a handler function, where the handler returns nil, results in a 404 response. That's just what we want BUT are curious if that is intentional behavior.#2018-08-3013:12ddeaguiarThe default not-found interceptor will return a 404 response if a valid response is not found on the context. This is by design. A valid response is a map with a :status. I think the doc-string for the default not-found interceptor can be improved since "An interceptor that returns a 404 when routing failed to resolve a route." does not fully capture this behavior.#2018-08-3017:02ikitommiAre there any examples of writing an alternative router impl for Pedestal?#2018-08-3017:02ikitommithe default router says: 
(defprotocol RouterSpecification
  (router-spec [specification router-ctor]
    "Returns an interceptor which attempts to match each route against
    a :request in context. For the first route that matches, it will:
    - enqueue the matched route's interceptors
    - associate the route into the context at :route
    - associate a map of :path-params into the :request
  If no route matches, returns context with :route nil."))
#2018-08-3017:03ikitommihow is the :route used by other components? I don‚Äôt think I would have anything like that (or at least in a format pedestal would understand). Is it ok just to push :path-params and enqueue the interceptors?#2018-08-3017:56ddeaguiar@U055NJ5CC I don‚Äôt have the answers to this question. Try asking in the Pedestal Users group as well?#2018-08-3018:03ikitommiok, thanks @U0FL657GR #2018-08-3017:24ikitommialso, if a route is matched, but a handler returns nil,. do I check this in the :leave by checking that there is a :response and it's nil, right?#2018-08-3017:41ikitommiseems so, by looking at the not-found mentioned here#2018-08-3019:56lxsameerhey folks what's the correct way to merge to vector of interceptors ? is there any helper function ?#2018-08-3019:59ddeaguiarinto?#2018-08-3020:02ddeaguiar@lxsameer I‚Äôve found the core collection fns to be sufficient. It‚Äôs just data#2018-08-3020:04lxsameerbut it's not gonna eliminate the duplicates , is it ?#2018-08-3020:05ddeaguiarnope, you do need to write that. There are no helpers that I know of#2018-08-3020:06lxsameerthanks buddy#2018-08-3020:07ddeaguiarnp!#2018-08-3108:01ikitommiIs there a reason why handler can‚Äôt return a core.async channel?#2018-08-3113:12ddeaguiar@ikitommi you can return a core.async channel as the response body in your handler if the container implementation implements the WriteNIOByteBody protocol. See http://pedestal.io/reference/response-bodies.#2018-08-3113:12ddeaguiarJetty and Immutant do#2018-08-3113:28ikitommithanks @ddeaguiar I think there are three async-cases: 1) interceptor returns a async context => works 2) handler function returns a async response => doesn‚Äôt 3) response has a async body => works (didn‚Äôt test thou)#2018-08-3113:29ddeaguiaronly 1 and 3#2018-08-3113:35ikitommiok, thanks.#2018-08-3113:36ddeaguiarnp!#2018-09-0212:41lxsameeris there any way to debug the router interceptor ? to see why it does not match any routes ?#2018-09-0309:51ddeaguiar@lxsameer I put together a gist sometime ago describing various ways to test routes. https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/bed92b8f34b7e93f15cd0e5548d783ae. I think you‚Äôll have to step through processing to get insight as to why routes are not matching.#2018-09-0309:51ddeaguiar#2018-09-0311:03lxsameer@ddeaguiar awesome, thanks man#2018-09-0311:23ddeaguiarnp!#2018-09-0419:57dadairIs there a particular reason the default content negotiation interceptors use content-type specific params keys (e.g., :json-params), instead of using a standard :params key, so that later code doesn‚Äôt need to know where the content was placed?#2018-09-0508:41ddeaguiarI think part of the answer is going to be about avoiding parameter collisions. For example, what to do if both query and post params are submitted. Pedestal‚Äôs position is to leave merging of params up to the user through the creation of an interceptor if that capability is desired.#2018-09-0620:45cap10morganHas anyone published metrics from pedestal (like connection count) to Prometheus?#2018-09-0709:45ddeaguiar@cap10morgan I have not but you may be interested in https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/568#2018-09-0713:22orestisI‚Äôm seeing some really weird behaviour with io.pedestal.http/transit-json-body and family of interceptors: 
< Content-Type: application/transit+json;charset=UTF-8
< Transfer-Encoding: chunked
<
* Connection #0 to host localhost left intact
["~#list",[["^ ","~:_created","~m1421289895000","~:_id"‚èé
#2018-09-0713:23orestisThe response should be around 250 entries, but instead it seems like the transit encoder stops after a few bytes.#2018-09-0713:24orestisThis is the handler: 
(defn get-sites [req]
  (let [db (database/get-connection)
        sites (mc/find-maps db "sites")]
    (ring-resp/response sites)))
‚Äî I can verify that sites contains all the data, and if I use instead edn-response I get everything.#2018-09-0713:24orestisThe route is composed this way: 
["/sites" :get (conj [http/transit-json-body] `get-sites) :route-name :sites-get]

If you had set the interceptors directly then default-interceptors may have not added the CORS interceptors?#2018-09-1718:41deadghostany interceptors to keyify request headers?#2018-09-1719:06deadghostparticularly cookies because it's in some-key=some-value; format#2018-09-1719:06deadghostdon't want to be reinventing wheels when this almost 100% is already written somewhere#2018-09-1719:07deadghostI looked through the default interceptors stack and don't see any that would apply#2018-09-1719:08deadghostwould be great if there's a supplementary list of often used interceptors#2018-09-1719:43ddeaguiar@deadghost you‚Äôll have to write your own interceptor to keyify headers in general but you‚Äôll be interested in the cookies interceptor. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/ring_middlewares.clj#L73-L78#2018-09-1719:43ddeaguiarIt just wraps the rings cookie middleware#2018-09-1719:44ddeaguiarThere are other useful interceptors in the io.pedestal.http/ring_middlewares ns as well. http://pedestal.io/api/pedestal.service/io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares.html#2018-09-1808:54deadghostyeah thanks, got cookies working#2018-09-1904:35caleb.macdonaldblackCan I run pedestal behind something other than a http server, such as an AWS lambda or a cli tool? (defn interceptor?
  [o]
  (= (type o) Interceptor))
#2018-09-2009:03orestisYou might want to use (satisfies? IntoInterceptor t) which is what io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor uses to as a pre-condition.#2018-09-2009:03orestishttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor.clj#L78#2018-09-2009:06mavbozoi tried to update to pedestal 0.5.4 from 0.5.3 and io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/enqueue threw AssertionError in my codebase because I enqueue hash-map based interceptor like my hello-world example above#2018-09-2009:07mavbozo#2018-09-2009:07orestisI guess you have to wrap attach-guid with a call to interceptor.#2018-09-2009:09orestisso sth like (io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/enqueue ctx [(io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor hello-world)])#2018-09-2009:09orestisNB: I‚Äôm just looking at the source, I haven‚Äôt actually tried any of this üôÇ#2018-09-2009:10mavbozoyup, wrapping my hash-map based interceptor with i.p.i/interceptor works#2018-09-2009:11mavbozoit's because in pedestal 0.5.3 the pre assertion doesn't work https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.3/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor/chain.clj#L273-L281#2018-09-2009:12mavbozoit's fixed in 0.5.4 which throw assertion errors in my codebase https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.4/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor/chain.clj#L273-L281#2018-09-2009:23mavbozoshould we change io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor? implementation to using (satisfies? IntoInterceptor t) so that the implementation correctly satisifies pedestal interceptor reference?#2018-09-2118:03ddeaguiar@mavbozo the underlying implementation is intended to work with an Interceptor record as opposed to implementations that satisfy IntoInterceptor. The intent is to minimize checks at the time of execution. I consider the ability to enqueue things that implement IntoInterceptor but are not an Interceptor record to be unintended. It‚Äôs appropriate to use the io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor constructor when creating interceptors.#2018-09-2306:10jaihindhreddy-duplicateWhat's the idiomatic way to think about side effects (talking to the database, and others over the network) when organizing code with interceptors?#2018-09-2312:17mavbozo@ddeaguiar thank you for the explanation#2018-09-2312:25mavbozo@jaihindh.reddy i find making smaller interceptors that do side-effects and naming the interceptors by what side effects they do helps, like get-user-from-db , send-welcome-email#2018-09-2318:30deadghosthttps://gist.github.com/deadghost/fc8ef2ab52d0946fc09a6402497cbad4#2018-09-2318:31deadghostI tried moving interceptors from my route handlers to my string#2018-09-2318:35deadghostmy print in coerce-body doesn't trigger so it doesn't even seem to get called#2018-09-2318:37deadghostboth content-negotiate and coerce-body are from doc examples#2018-09-2318:37deadghostand work fine if used in a route stack#2018-09-2406:05mavbozo@deadghost you put those 3 interceptors at the end of interceptor chain, ex: ::http/interceptors becomes [... your-interceptors ... mw-cookies intc/content-negotiate intc/coerce-body].#2018-09-2406:07mavbozohttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.4/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L272-L277#2018-09-2406:08mavbozoabove contain example to add interceptor(s) to interceptors based on the options given then creates routing interceptor and finally conj those interceptors to :io.pedestal.http/interceptors key in the service map#2018-09-2419:41deadghostended up I vaguely remember that all this configuration is only needed to create the default interceptor stack, otherwise you‚Äôre on your own.#2018-09-2508:50orestisAt this point I‚Äôd break out the debugger, if you can.#2018-09-2510:24deadghosthttps://gist.github.com/deadghost/cbf49f2faa50ba56e8a43cda3326538b#2018-09-2510:24deadghostI must be doing something fundamentally wrong#2018-09-2510:25deadghostbecause with just that inspect interceptor and the router interceptor`#2018-09-2510:25deadghostnothing gets printed#2018-09-2510:25deadghostinspect works as a route interceptor as well#2018-09-2510:25deadghostbut not as a default interceptor#2018-09-2511:37orestisI suspect that the issue is the way you create your default interceptor/servlet stack.#2018-09-2511:39orestisLooking at https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L254, it seems that some of those interceptors are wrapped with interceptor, some are passed extra arguments, etc. It‚Äôs not clear in your server snippet what are you passing in.#2018-09-2511:43orestisI‚Äôm not an expert in pedestal and this part of the code seems quite hairy to me, so I can‚Äôt help any further there ‚Äî other than to suggest that it might make sense to adopt the official way to do things?#2018-09-2511:49deadghost@orestis found the problem#2018-09-2511:49deadghostit's a really stupid mistake#2018-09-2511:50deadghostI've been editing the production interceptors instead of the dev#2018-09-2511:50deadghostwhat a waste of two days#2018-09-2511:58orestisWe‚Äôve all been there üôÇ#2018-09-2512:46mavbozoüòÖ my recent stupid mistake was I wasn't aware that servlet-interceptor terminates chain execution when it encounters valid ring-response in context's :response, the executors removes the rest of the :queue from the context and starts processing :leave stages. I should have properly read servlet-interceptor reference here http://pedestal.io/reference/servlet-interceptor#2018-09-2512:47deadghost@mavbozo my current issue is I have an authentication interceptor that does attach a non-nil :response but it doesn't appear to short-circuit#2018-09-2512:53mavbozo@deadghost woops.. I made mistake above. by reading the servlet-interceptor codes I found that servlet-interceptor terminates when it encounters valid ring-response in the context's :response. I've edited my message above.#2018-09-2512:55mavbozothis is the relevant code https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.4/service/src/io/pedestal/http/impl/servlet_interceptor.clj#L232-L234#2018-09-2513:00deadghost@mavbozo huh thanks for the tip#2018-09-2513:00deadghostapparently my response doesn't pass ring-response/response?#2018-09-2513:02deadghostyeah my :headers can't be nil#2018-09-2513:06deadghostok finally got pedestal reasonably set up#2018-09-2513:07deadghostI can finally close like 20 pedestal tabs#2018-09-2514:45stathissiderisis there any compelling reason to keep body params named after their content type? I‚Äôm tempted to add an interceptor that will just rename everything to :body-params so that I can have an API that will serve both edn and json requests through the same code#2018-09-2514:52ikitommi@stathissideris if you are interested in 3rd party addons, there is a pedestal-compatible interceptor doing just that in Muuntaja library, muuntaja.interceptor.format-interceptor#2018-09-2514:52ikitommihttps://github.com/metosin/muuntaja/blob/master/modules/muuntaja/src/muuntaja/interceptor.clj#2018-09-2515:42stathissiderisThanks, I‚Äôm interested in 3rd party party interceptors, even if it‚Äôs just as an example!#2018-09-2514:54ddeaguiar@stathissideris the Pedestal philosophy around this sort of thing is: If something is separate, keep it separate. If something can be customized via an interceptor, keep the base code as basic as possible. So adding an interceptor which does what you‚Äôve stated is perfectly acceptable. There has been some back-and-forth internally as to whether such helpers should be included in Pedestal core. As of now they won‚Äôt.#2018-09-2515:40dadair@stathissideris I had the same problem and for a while had my own helper interceptors to consolidate it. Ive since moved to muuntaja as @ikitommi referenced and Ive been very happy with it.#2018-09-2515:45stathissideris@ddeaguiar thanks, that makes sense, it‚Äôs trivial to add a basic interceptor to achieve it anyway. I like the design decision. I just wanted to make sure I wasn‚Äôt missing something #2018-09-2520:44deadghostyeah I was also wondering about the content type body params thing#2018-09-2520:46deadghostthird party interceptors haven't been easy for me to discover#2018-09-2607:15stathissiderismaybe there aren‚Äôt that many in circulation üôÇ#2018-09-2608:08ikitommimaybe they should be listed in http://pedestal.io/community/index?#2018-09-2608:17ikitommihttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/pull/116/files#2018-09-2614:38ddeaguiarmerged. Thanks!#2018-09-2610:37orestisSo cool. I never knew all those things. Thanks!#2018-09-2618:19dadairHow are people using async-interceptors? What use cases? I‚Äôve yet to use any and I‚Äôm curious if any parts of my system could be improved through their use.#2018-09-2619:09ddeaguiar@dadair for long running operations. When these are io bound prefer going async via thread instead of a go block. So take integrating with a 3rd party service as an example that has a high response time. You don‚Äôt want to block your main request processing threads with this work. Integrate with this service in an interceptor that goes async via thread and return a channel as the context. At some point that interceptor will complete and push an updated context, presumably with some information it collected from the service, to the channel. Processing will continue. Keep in mind that all downstream processing once you go async happens on a thread from the go thread pool.#2018-09-2619:13dadairgreat thanks @ddeaguiar#2018-09-2619:14ddeaguiarnp!#2018-09-2619:27ikitommihow is backpressure handled in the thread case? how is it handled in the go case? with thread - 100req/sec coming in and 1 thread taking 1sec to complete, there will be soon thousands of threads causing the system to crash?#2018-09-2619:49ddeaguiarPedestal just provides a mechanism for going async. The situation you described by @ikitommi, is possible. So I suppose the answer is more nuanced. Leverage timeouts to avoid waiting an unreasonable amount of time (this is app specific). Depending on the service you are implementing you may need to layer on some form of back pressure to avoid running of threads.#2018-09-2619:50ddeaguiarTaking additional precautions, like leveraging circuit breakers, would be a good idea as well#2018-09-2705:46ikitommithanks @ddeaguiar for the detailed description. I think for 99% apps, this is not a problem, but still -not having a out-of-the-box solution / guide for this is not good for the clojure + web story in general - many non-clojure solutions have this inbuit. In Clojure, at least Aleph & Catacumba claim to have this.#2018-09-2705:59stathissideris@ikitommi I‚Äôm not entirely certain, but I think yada provides back-pressure out of the box#2018-09-2706:00ikitommiI believe it‚Äôs the Aleph, that it‚Äôs built on.#2018-09-2706:14stathissiderisyeah, that‚Äôs how I remember it as well#2018-09-2713:01stathissiderisso what‚Äôs the preferred method for defining default interceptors? I dislike the terse syntax, so I guess I should define them at the service level?#2018-09-2715:17dadairI conj onto ::http/interceptors in the service map after I have already called (default-interceptors)#2018-09-2812:22stathissiderisso the terse syntax is not very readable (imho) and has the whole weirdness with symbols etc. On the other hand the table syntax does not allow for hierarchical paths and for applying interceptors to groups of endpoints. I came up with something that may be a good compromise between the two, what do you think? (untested code) https://gist.github.com/stathissideris/179181223988eab1eaeb469461e0da79#2018-09-2812:23stathissiderisalso, no macros, yay for data!#2018-09-2813:24mavbozo@stathissideris the mechanism is quite similar to what I do: traversing all the routes and adding common interceptors to them. Data For the Win!!!#2018-09-2813:24stathissideris:thumbsup:#2018-10-0616:04lxsameerhey folks how can i debug a router ?#2018-10-0617:24jvtriguerosWhat do you mean by debug a router? Is your route not being hit?#2018-10-0617:48lxsameeryes#2018-10-0617:54jvtriguerosWell, since that's all that info we have, is any route being hit?#2018-10-0617:56lxsameerno, I can use url-for to get the routes and stuff like that but an actual request does not hit any route#2018-10-0618:13jvtriguerosI would advise to start with the simplest example, and see if that works. Without seeing your code, it's pretty much a game of 20 questions üôÇ#2018-10-0701:40dadairIf you post how you are building your service map that will likely lead to us identifying the issue#2018-10-0808:16kommenso, what‚Äôs the way to go to use pedestal with clojure 1.10-beta1?#2018-10-0808:17kommenit looks like we‚Äôd need a version containing https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/commit/64b8f877590c8bb66341544728da576d8e33124f#2018-10-0808:18kommenbut there doesn‚Äôt seem to be a ‚Äú0.5.5-SNAPSHOT‚Äù published and pedestal lacks deps.edn files to we could use the version from git master#2018-10-0903:58jvtriguerosYou could try using JitPack: https://jitpack.io/#pedestal/pedestal#2018-10-0906:20jimmyIf you just need it for local testing and build, you just need to clone and build locally. #2018-10-0907:14kommenno, I‚Äôd like to deploy it to staging or even to production#2018-10-0908:40kommenI‚Äôll give jitpack a shot, thx @jvtrigueros#2018-10-0919:00jvtrigueros@kommen Yeah sure, no problem, that's how I get around libraries that have merged the code to master but haven't released a version yet. JitPack is great!#2018-10-1114:44martinklepschWhat‚Äôs the right way to add one interceptor globally without replicating default-interceptors in a codebase? #2018-10-1115:05ddeaguiarcall io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors before io.pedestal.http/create-server and manipulate the io.pedestal.http/interceptors collection in between#2018-10-1115:05ddeaguiarThe router is the terminal interceptor so add your interceptor(s) before that#2018-10-1115:05ddeaguiar@martinklepsch ^^#2018-10-1115:06ddeaguiarThis is how dev-interceptors are added in the pedestal-service template https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-template/src/leiningen/new/pedestal_service/server.clj#L27-L28#2018-10-1115:35mkvlr@ddeaguiar do you have plans to push a release with the fixes for Clojure 1.10 soon? Looks like RC-1 is now out.#2018-10-1115:36mkvlrHaving trouble to import pedestal through JitPack‚Ä¶#2018-10-1115:37ddeaguiarNothing concrete yet. Let me bring that up internally and report back here.#2018-10-1115:37mkvlr@jvtrigueros do you happen to know how I can just import pedestal.log from JitPack?#2018-10-1115:38mkvlrI currently have com.github.pedestal/pedestal {:mvn/version "e6b6286c6b"} in my deps.edn#2018-10-1115:39mkvlrtrying to replace io.pedestal/pedestal.log {:mvn/version "0.5.4"} with a version from git#2018-10-1115:39jvtrigueros@mkvlr I've only used JitPack with Leiningen. I don't know if works with clj deps, I've never used it before, does it allow you to add custom repositories?#2018-10-1115:40mkvlryeah, I have that working#2018-10-1115:40mkvlrbut I‚Äôm not sure it works for repositories where the file is in a subpath, i.e. https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/tree/master/log#2018-10-1115:41ddeaguiar@mkvlr if you are using deps.edn why not specify a pedestal git-sha1 directly?#2018-10-1115:41ddeaguiarno need to use JitPack#2018-10-1115:42mkvlr@ddeaguiar wouldn‚Äôt the have to be a pom.xml or deps.edn in the pedestal repo for that to work?#2018-10-1115:43ddeaguiarah yeah, right.#2018-10-1115:43ddeaguiarwell here‚Äôs an alternative#2018-10-1115:43ddeaguiarcreate a fork and add a deps.edn#2018-10-1115:43mkvlrright! forgot about that#2018-10-1115:44ddeaguiarIn the meantime I‚Äôll discuss cutting a release internally#2018-10-1115:44mkvlrgreat, thank you!#2018-10-1115:46ddeaguiarnp!#2018-10-1115:54mkvlrio.pedestal/pedestal.log {:git/url "" :sha "5ab1c9770472694f94d0835cda412ba753b28809"} if someone else wants to use it#2018-10-1115:58orestisCommitting a deps.edn directly in pedestal doesn‚Äôt need a release, right? Would such a PR be accepted?#2018-10-1116:54ddeaguiar@U7PBP4UVA possibly but I recommend opening an issue first#2018-10-1116:01jvtrigueros@mkvlr FWIW here's what you would need if you wanted to make it work with JitPack: 
{:deps      {com.github.pedestal/pedestal {:mvn/version "e6b6286c6b"}}
 :mvn/repos {"jitpack" {:url ""}}}

I tried this, but body is nil (body is only a single line payload)#2018-10-3001:05rakyiI‚Äôm trying to verify requests from Slack https://api.slack.com/docs/verifying-requests-from-slack#2018-10-3002:25rakyito answer my own question body-params intercepter was reading the InputStream first so it couldn‚Äôt be read again in further interceptors#2018-11-0219:58ccannjust started learning pedestal and it looks awesome, I wish I had known about it sooner üôÇ metal#2018-11-0219:59ccannthank you @mtnygard for the awesome Your First API tutorial#2018-11-0416:59mtnygard@ccann You're welcome!#2018-11-0417:00mtnygardBTW, I'd love to hear about your learning experience. Especially anything you struggle with or wish you had known earlier.#2018-11-0417:00mtnygardYou can post thoughts here, as issues on the doc repo, or email me at <mailto:/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection|/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection>#2018-11-0515:21ccannwill do#2018-11-0508:29orestisIs there a guide somewhere on how to create new adapters? I wonder how hard would it be to get Pedestal running on Aleph.#2018-11-0601:12mtnygardI don‚Äôt have a guide, but there are examples for Tomcat, Jetty, and Immutant. #2018-11-0522:41ccanni‚Äôm trying to figure out the best way to test my API with pedestal. I see the io.pedestal.test/response-for function for mocking requests to the server. Is there a way to use ring.mock? or a way to pass headers to response-for?#2018-11-0522:46ccannah, I see you can pass :headers as the last argument#2018-11-0614:48eraserhdHeader names are case sensitive when you use response-for, which is easy enough to work around but a potential surprise.#2018-11-0614:48eraserhd@ccann ^^#2018-11-0615:57ccannthanks @eraserhd, I did pick up on that pretty quickly üôÇ#2018-11-0616:01ccannOne thing that was surprising was how to define interceptors. I wrote an interceptor that looked something like this: 
(def logger
  {:name :logger
   :enter (fn [context]
            (with-out-str (clojure.pprint/pprint (:request context)))
            context)})
and added it to my interceptor chain in the server map configuration. But pedestal threw an assertion error saying one of the interceptors in the chain wasn‚Äôt an interceptor. Indeed the others are records and mine is a map, but what I absorbed from the docs was that you can write interceptors with maps as such. I ended up finding the io.pedestal.interceptors.helpers namespace in the source and the macros looked pretty nifty, so I rewrote my logging interceptor (I know there is one of these already available) with defbefore and my handlers with defhandler. Now I‚Äôm wondering if it makes more sense to use the macros in general vs just maps vs before, after, etc. I‚Äôm not sure what‚Äôs the most idiomatic#2018-11-0616:02mtnygard@ccann Do you still have the code around from when the map didn't work in your interceptor chain?#2018-11-0616:03mtnygardThe best way to turn a map into an interceptor is by calling io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor on it. Anything that is in a route's interceptor vector has that done automatically. But I wonder if there are places where we aren't doing that.#2018-11-0616:04mtnygardIOW, I'd like it to "just work" without using the (mildly deprecated) macros in helpers#2018-11-0616:11ccann@mtnygard I do! it‚Äôs basically just 
(-> service-map
          http/default-interceptors
          http/dev-interceptors
          (update ::http/interceptors into routes/interceptors))
where routes/interceptors is a vector of [log-request (body-params) json-body] the first being my logger, the actual implementation of which was: 
(def log-request
  {:name :log-req
   :enter
   (fn [context]
     (log/info ::log-request)
     (log/info (with-out-str (clojure.pprint/pprint (:request context))))
     context)})
#2018-11-0616:12mtnygardThanks.#2018-11-0616:17mtnygardI can confirm that don't automatically call io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor on that key in the service map.#2018-11-0616:18mtnygardSorry for the confusion, and I'm adding an issue to the docs repo so we can clarify.#2018-11-0616:19mtnygardhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/117#2018-11-0616:38ccannawesome thanks!#2018-11-0616:39mtnygardLMK if you run into anything else. I travel a lot so I'm not usually this quick to respond, but I'll see it eventually. üôÇ#2018-11-0616:39ccannit also looks like the before, after etc. functions have two arities [f] and [f & args] but then in the source code you can use it like so (interceptors/before ::foo-bar (fn [ctx]...#2018-11-0616:42mtnygardThe second arity tries to be too clever. If f is not a function, then the macro uses it as the name. Then it deconstructs args to use as an existing function name and additional arguments to that function.#2018-11-0616:42mtnygardIt was not a good idea, and I'd recommend avoiding it.#2018-11-0622:54ccannthis might just be demonstrating my lack of mature docker / networking knowledge, but I couldn‚Äôt get my pedestal app to respond when running in a docker container with ports mapped appropriately and hitting it with curl. e.g.: 
docker run -it -p 3080:3080 008940197b83
then 
curl --request GET \
           --url
#2018-11-0622:54ccannuntil I added ::http/host "0.0.0.0" to my service map, curl would just report curl: (52) Empty reply from server. but running outside a docker container I don‚Äôt need that key.#2018-11-0622:55jvtriguerosAh yes, this bit me once! I opened a PR to updates docs.#2018-11-0622:55jvtriguerosIt's a safer default, but needs to be documented.#2018-11-0622:55ccannwhat‚Äôs going on exactly?#2018-11-0622:56jvtriguerosIf I understand correctly, only hosts calling from localhost are allowed to connect to the server.#2018-11-0622:56jvtriguerosHow are you routing traffic the service in Docker?#2018-11-0622:57ccannohhh. uhh, I‚Äôm just running java -jar server.jar in my container. and running with docker run as above not sure if that answered your question#2018-11-0622:58jvtriguerosYeah so when you do java -jar server.jar on your physical machine, you are localhost, so executing the curl command works.#2018-11-0622:59jvtriguerosWhen running inside the Docker container, the app sees you as not localhost but some other host.#2018-11-0622:59ccannokay, great. thanks!#2018-11-0622:59ccannI‚Äôll upvote that PR#2018-11-0622:59jvtriguerosüëç#2018-11-0623:00ccanndo you have a link to it?#2018-11-0623:00jvtrigueroshttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/pull/115#2018-11-0814:19souenzzoTIP: You can force [org.clojure/core.specs.alpha "0.2.36"] to use io.pedestal with clojure 1.10-betaX#2018-11-1015:23orestisAny tips on how to determine how large a Jetty thread pool should be? I‚Äôd use the same version that pedestal uses.#2018-11-2019:40martinklepsch@ddeaguiar thanks for https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/602 üëç#2018-11-2612:12ddeaguiarnp!#2018-11-2718:39ccanna couple quick takeaways on my beginner experience with pedestal (not with clojure, just pedestal) - I found it hard to debug constraints. When my request 404'ed because a query param constraint in a parent route (using terse syntax) didn‚Äôt match for a child route that doesn‚Äôt use that query param I was confused. I understand how they work now. I ended up pretty printing the routes in full form to see the constraints on the route and it clicked. - as mentioned previously, the :io.pedestal.http/host key defaulting to something more restrictive than 0.0.0.0 was surprising coming from having used jetty before with compojure - It took me a bit to find a doc that said defroutes is preferred over expand-routes except in the case where you need to dynamically create routes - I‚Äôm not entirely sure what the scheme, host, port etc. optional args in the route syntax do and how they interact with the server config - it wasn‚Äôt immediately obvious to me that you can use a ring handler as an interceptor without explicitly using interceptor or the map form#2018-11-2919:37jvtriguerosThanks for the summary, I had a very similar experience to yours. I've been using Clojure for a while, but recent user of Pedestal.#2018-11-2817:08johnjwhat's the verdict? ring or pedestal? üòâ#2018-11-2817:08Joe Lanepedestal#2018-11-2817:08johnjcan pedestal do sync only too?#2018-11-2817:09Joe Lanewhat do you mean?#2018-11-2817:10johnjrequests are handled asynchronous (multiple requests per thread in an event loop) or one thread per request (synchronous) ?#2018-11-2817:11johnjI know its async, but wondering if it can do sync only too#2018-11-2817:11Joe Laneyour choice#2018-11-2817:11Joe Laneit does either.#2018-11-2817:12johnjgood#2018-11-2817:12Joe LaneIt also streams back SSE with resumable checkpoints.#2018-11-2817:21johnjthanks, that might come in handy#2018-11-2817:22johnjThe ability to utilize Ring Middleware as Pedestal Interceptors#2018-11-2817:22johnjis that done much in practice? utilizing ring middleware?#2018-11-2817:25orestisAll the time, sometimes even by pedestal core. #2018-11-2817:25johnjok#2018-11-2817:27orestisAnd a lot of the time simple routes will be ring-style handlers (get called with a map, return a response map)#2018-11-2822:44ccannI sometimes get caught up debating if something is complex enough to warrant splitting into interceptors vs a ring-handler. #2018-11-3020:18jaihindhreddy-duplicateI think spec is complaining about this:
(ns io.pedestal.log
  "Logging via slf4j. Each logging level is a macro: trace, debug,
  info, warn, and error. Each namespace gets its own Logger. Arguments
  are key-value pairs, which will be printed as with 'pr'. The special
  key :exception should have a java.lang.Throwable as its value, and
  will be passed separately to the underlying logging API.
  One can override the logger via JVM or ENVAR settings."
  (:require clojure.string)
  (:import (org.slf4j Logger
                      LoggerFactory
                      MDC)
           (org.slf4j.spi MDCAdapter)
           (com.codahale.metrics MetricRegistry
                                 Gauge Counter Histogram Meter
                                 Slf4jReporter)
           (com.codahale.metrics.jmx JmxReporter)
           (io.opentracing Scope
                           Span
                           SpanContext
                           Tracer
                           Tracer$SpanBuilder)
           io.opentracing.log.Fields
           (io.opentracing.util GlobalTracer)
           (java.util Map)
           (java.util.concurrent TimeUnit)
           (clojure.lang IFn)))

#2018-11-3020:30mkvlrtry this#2018-11-3020:31mkvlrcurrent stable doesn't work with 1.10 because https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/591 and https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/592 hasn't been released yet#2018-11-3020:32mkvlrwe work around this by importing pedestal.log via deps.edn as seen above#2018-11-3020:34jaihindhreddy-duplicateworks. Thank you sir. Should have looked at the Github issue tracker picard-facepalm#2018-11-3020:35mkvlrglad to hear#2018-12-0219:44devurandomIs there an interceptor which can turn the path /foo/bar into /bar and /foo/bar/baz into /bar/baz and so on? Basically strip a static part of the path off?#2018-12-0414:36ddeaguiarAFAIK, the only interceptor that does this is for serving resources.#2018-12-0501:42devurandomWhich one does it? (ring-middlewares/resource document-root)?#2018-12-0514:12ddeaguiar@U368JQA01 it‚Äôs based on the bits of ring‚Äôs resource middleware. When :io.pedestal.http/resource-path is present in the service map, the value is used as the resource path root.#2018-12-0600:32devurandomi.e. the resources are mounted into the route at :io.pedestal.http/resource-path? And hence the middleware treats every path it sees in the route as relative to that resource-path?#2018-12-0600:34devurandomi.e. with a route containing "/my/resources/" -&gt; resource-middleware and resource-path=/my, the resource-middleware would look for "/resources/" in the resource directory / classpath?#2018-12-0401:12mvThat seems like a routing issue, no?#2018-12-0501:41devurandom@mv: Possible. I have a /staticpart/*file route and I mount a (ring-middlewares/file document-root) interceptor there. From experience it appears that this interceptor will use the full path, including the /staticpart to locate files on the filesystem. I mitigate that using string/replace on the :path-info.#2018-12-0522:52martinklepschis anyone using io.pedestal.http.ring-middlewares/not-modified? I'm noticing that it doesn't return 304 responses when the following interceptor does: 
(def test-interceptor
  {:name ::test
   :leave (ring-middlewares/response-fn-adapter
           (fn [response request]
             (not-modified/not-modified-response response request)))})
#2018-12-0523:23ddeaguiar@U050TNB9F weird. I‚Äôm not using it anywhere but it‚Äôs based on the ring not-modified middleware. There‚Äôs also a test for it here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/09dd88c4ce7f89c7fbb7a398077eb970b3785d2d/service/test/io/pedestal/http/ring_middlewares_test.clj#L140-L150#2018-12-0523:36martinklepschThanks, I guess I‚Äôll keep digging then :)#2018-12-0609:50schmeewhat‚Äôs a good pattern to make requests in parallel in an interceptor chain?#2018-12-0609:51schmeeright now I have two interceptors that make outbound requests by attaching a future to the context and then returning immediately, but I‚Äôm wondering if there is a more idiomatic way#2018-12-0609:54schmeedoes returning an asynchronous context help? my understanding is that even if the first interceptor returns an async context, the second one will still block until the first one is done#2018-12-0616:11jaihindhreddy-duplicate^ Using core.async perhaps?#2018-12-0617:05martinklepschAlright, classic middleware issue: at first I didn't call not-modified and somehow added the interceptor constructor function as an interceptor to the chain. Fixing that didn't immediately work but I then realized that the interceptor order was wrong, the etag was only set after the not-modified interceptor ran. üôÇ#2018-12-0617:05martinklepschProblem solved üôÇ#2018-12-0619:29ccannhas anyone ever gotten pedestal‚Äôs response-for to work with multipart-params? (ring-mw/multipart-params) as an interceptor doesn‚Äôt add the :form-params when using response-for to test, but works when actually hitting the server#2018-12-0619:43ccanni‚Äôm not 100% sure but it almost looks like the content type gets explicitly overridden? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/test.clj#L141#2018-12-0717:25souenzzoThere is a helper to make {:foo "bar"} => foo=bar to turn form-params into a "body string"?#2018-12-0717:35souenzzoI think that I need a example of pedestal.test/response-for doing a HTTP POST with form-params#2018-12-0720:17ccannhere‚Äôs my rough example using peridot to construct the multipart headers and body 
(require '[peridot.multipart :as multipart])


(let [{:keys [body headers]}        (multipart/build {:graphic (io/file "foo.bar")
                                                      :user-id 1})
      {:keys [status body headers]} (-> (::http/service-fn (http/create-servlet server/config))
                                        (response-for :post "/notes"
                                                      :body body
                                                      :headers headers)
                                        (decode))]
  (is (= 201 status))
  (is (= foo body)))
#2018-12-1418:04ccannanyone else have issues with response-for not behaving the same way as the server does outside of the test environment? e.g. my buddy authorization middleware doesn‚Äôt add the identity to the request e.g. my multipart params middleware doesn‚Äôt add the params to the request the interceptors are in the chain, and they run, but downstream the data is missing edit: the authentication works#2018-12-1418:29ddeaguiar@ccann not as far as I know#2018-12-1418:29ccannokay, I will file a ticket for the multipart issue when I find the time!#2018-12-1522:13yefoakiraHello, just starting with pedestal. web_1  | 22:11:32.242 [main] INFO org.eclipse.jetty.server.Server - Started @2471ms
web_1  | 22:11:32.242 [qtp1315795813-24] DEBUG org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool - run acceptor-1@408a247c
web_1  | 22:11:32.242 [main] DEBUG org.eclipse.jetty.util.component.AbstractLifeCycle - STARTED @2471ms org.eclipse.jetty.server.Server@7c0da600[9.4.10.v20180503]
And nothing comes out when I go the url location.#2018-12-1522:20mtnygardURL being something like http://localhost:4001/ ?#2018-12-1522:21yefoakirayep#2018-12-1522:22mtnygardWell, that was the obvious stuff. Give me a minute to try to replicate the problem.#2018-12-1522:22mtnygardWhat OS are you on?#2018-12-1522:24mtnygardIs your project.clj straight from the leiningen template?#2018-12-1522:26yefoakiraLinux Mint. Other than adding midje, yep.#2018-12-1522:33mtnygardI've more or less reproduced the problem.#2018-12-1522:33mtnygardI'm on Windows with WSL rather than Linux, so there's bound to be a little variation.#2018-12-1522:33mtnygardInstead of connection reset, I get an empty response.#2018-12-1522:34mtnygardThe issue is that Jetty only binds to a server socket on "localhost".#2018-12-1522:34mtnygardTo get it to listen for connections on any other IP address than 127.0.0.1, you can set the ::http/host key to "0.0.0.0" in service.clj#2018-12-1522:35mtnygardWith that, I'm able to get a good response from the host.#2018-12-1522:42yefoakiraOooooohhh. Completely missed that. Thanks üòä#2018-12-1522:42mtnygardyw#2018-12-1621:20bobcalcoI am using pedestal for API with a front end in re-frame/reagent. I need to have different layout for the landing page and the logged in "admin" console. I am using for routing in the front end and struggling to get its routing to play nice with pedestal's. The desired behavior is: "/" goes to a static landing page written in plain ol HTML; "/admin" goes to the portal front-end in re-frame using bidi; /api/ do what you expect. When I used the re-frame-starter project at github, it was wired to route / to the SPA, and everything that didn't start with /api was routing to the correct bidi routers. now that my app is off /admin, I can't get the :homepage route to render - just goes to Not Found, and any sub-path off /admin goes to pedestal's "not found" handler. I am not sure how to get pedestal to ignore anything off the /admin root, or to get bidi to recognize it's proper "base" url. Examples at its README all show hard-coding the whole domain root, which is not practical at all. Ideally, I'd like to use pedestal as a back end to multiple front-end SPAs so really the question is, how best to do that? I know pedestal was designed for API back ends but surely other people have gotten this to work. Any help/thoughts appreciated.#2018-12-1622:01mtnygard@bob592 Hi Bob. A lot of detail there... a bit hard to build the mental model from text. Are you able to pull out the routing portion into a repro case that I could look at?#2018-12-1702:07bobcalco@mtnygard Let me try first more simply to describe what I want: A static "landing" page at "/", an api root of /api/* which is handled server side, and an admin console at /admin that itself has many logical sub-"routes" using bidi with re-frame. The static page at "/" has different style completely from the admin console at "/admin" (which is a SPA). Currently I'm slurping up two different starter index.html files, but I'd rather make the entire page rendering dynamic (looking at rum for that). I have not changed the code much from what you find at https://github.com/pdlug/re-frame-starter. Anyway.... the abstract question is, how to get pedestal routes to play nice with bidi routes in the case where the SPA is not being created off root "/" but rather off "/admin" (for example). I am refactoring things a bit right now so code posts aren't practical at this precise moment. I'm trying to think differently about my problem and see if I can't find a solution that doesn't fight the frameworks expected behavior. For example: I'd be happy putting every page in the SPA if I could render entirely different CSS styling/JS for logged in vs not logged in scenarios. This is why I separated them in the first place - the need to have different stuff in the <head> and different JS at the bottom.#2018-12-1703:25mtnygard@bob592 I see. I just took a look at bidi‚Äôs code. They don‚Äôt directly support Pedestal, but I think you could make a very simple interceptor to glue a Pedestal route to the bidi router. That would be the sole interceptor on ‚Äò/admin‚Äô. Then that interceptor would call the bidi router directly and pass it the request map from the context.#2018-12-1712:19bobcalco@mtnygard Thing is, I don't want the admin console SPA reloaded every time Pedestal detects a route that "belongs" to it, as it would be harder (if not impossible or in any case highly non-performant) to maintain application state. Might as well do MVC post-backs (ahem). The request shouldn't even be making it to the server if bidi has it "covered," no? Maybe I should just use a different routing engine. The more interesting problem is, how do I support more than one CSS theme/design? I'm coming to the conclusion that I should just run two separate instances of pedestal - one HTTP and the other (once in production) HTTPS. Usually routing could split those hairs with interceptors but I don't know a way to generate the CSS I need in the <head> on the fly, as reagent is mounting the "app" div in the <body>, although I can probably do it by generating my own <link> tags since hiccups doesn't. A flask of Rum is sounding good perhaps for this. Alas, frameworks are as much a source of incidental complexity as language syntax...#2018-12-1718:06mtnygard@bob592 I'm lost. How does bidi affect your SPA state at all? I thought it was a back end routing framework.#2018-12-1718:21bobcalco@mtnygard It's a front-end routing library AFAIK, and on the #re-frame channel I'm getting some help that seems to be on point by @mateus.pimentel.w... he recommends I combine bidi with pushy on the client. Apparently it can prevent the call to the server for subroutes but I'm still not entirely clear myself how it is supposed to play nice with pedestal's server-side routing. The link the the article he pointed me to talks only about compojure. However, if it does require server side cooperation, your original idea about an interceptor for /admin may be the key after all. I still feel like I need more fundamentally to rethink what I'm trying to do. The motivation for all of this is simply to have different styling for a not-logged-in landing page, and a separate styling for the logged-in admin SPA.#2018-12-1718:33madstapBidi is portable between clj/cljs and only cares about translating string paths to/from data structures.#2018-12-1718:34madstapBoth using it on the backend with pedestal and on the frontend with pushy make sense, but are different things.#2018-12-1718:35ddeaguiarHi @bob592! I think it‚Äôs best to distinguish between front-end and service api here. There will be some endpoints provided by your service api to satisfy app needs. How you coordinate that interaction is an orthogonal issue.#2018-12-1718:36bobcalco@ddeaguiar Yes, I'm trying to think that through. Here‚Äôs where folks stumble on too coarse-grained or fine-grained service apis and what implementations like graphQL try to solve.#2018-12-1718:52ddeaguiarI don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs one good answer because it‚Äôs context-specific#2018-12-1719:02bobcalco@ddeaguiar In concept I agree of course. But development and deployment are two different worlds with their own exigencies and "incidental compexities"... Alas, the language can't really help us with those as much as we might like, especially once we start having to live with various design decisions and their sometimes unforeseeable consequences. I won't even mention the incidental complexities of development on a platform like the JVM with diverse tooling options and related ceremonies, and the seemingly infinite smorgasbord of library choices with varying interdependencies and version complexities... never a dull moment. üôÇ#2018-12-1719:08Whiskas@bob592 are you developing a non-spa ?#2018-12-1719:09Whiskashere i just switch views using re-frame/dispatch#2018-12-1719:09Whiskasand the url is synced#2018-12-1719:09Whiskasthe url is synced in case you want to copy paste the url for that specific url#2018-12-1719:09Whiskasif you want to use the cached index i think you will have to add # to the url#2018-12-1808:12mkvlrmight I suggest again that it would be good to cut a pedestal release that‚Äôs compatible with Clojure 1.10 now that‚Äôs been released?#2018-12-1808:12mkvlrin the meantime people that want to upgrade Clojure can use io.pedestal/pedestal.log {:git/url "" :sha "5ab1c9770472694f94d0835cda412ba753b28809"} if they‚Äôre using deps.edn#2018-12-1811:09souenzzo@mkvlr you can also force a old version of core.specs org.clojure/core.specs.alpha {:mvn/version "0.2.36"}#2018-12-1813:25ddeaguiarYep, I will work on cutting a release. We‚Äôve previously just enqueued map values as interceptors (which worked fine) but now the pre condition fails.#2018-12-1910:07mkvlrbut looks like this was never intended. Would there be interest in accepting a change which makes enqueue also take values and converts them into an interceptor record?#2018-12-1910:11mkvlrif not maybe we should update the interceptors guide http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors and change the code to produce interceptor records?#2018-12-1912:39mavbozo@mkvlr I encountered the same problem months ago and also asked in this channel#2018-12-1912:39mavbozohttps://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/pedestal/2018-09-20#2018-12-1912:39mavbozohttps://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/pedestal/2018-09-21#2018-12-1912:42mavbozochain/enqueue is indeed intended to work only with Interceptor records#2018-12-1913:39ddeaguiarYep, that is the intended behavior. We want to avoid interceptor xform and validation during chain execution.#2018-12-1913:58mkvlrbecause of performance considerations?#2018-12-1914:02mkvlrhttps://github.com/nextjournal/pedestal/commit/a5b69d376a30f8baefa1695789eaec7bf2144eed#2018-12-1914:02mkvlrseems pretty minimal to me‚Ä¶#2018-12-1914:02mkvlris there some performance benchmarks I can run to see the impact?#2018-12-1914:29martinklepschYou may want to vote for https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-1473 to ensure that malformed pre/post conditions aren't silently skipped#2018-12-1915:07mkvlr@martinklepsch I want them to be skipped because they break my app üòº#2018-12-1915:09mkvlrbut I see I want to upvote your comment re breaking change#2018-12-2715:00ikitommiThose who would like to try pedestal with reitit routing, there is now a integration module for it: [metosin/reitit-pedestal "0.2.10-alpha1"]. (defn index [req]
  {:status 200
   :body "hi"})

(def routes
  (route/expand-routes
    #{["/foo" :get index :route-name :index]}))

(http/create-server {:routes routes
                       :type :jetty
                       :port port})
#2019-01-0420:49ddeaguiar@U0W0JDY4C can you point me to the docs you are following? The service map keys need to be fully-qualified keywords (i.e., io.pedestal.http/routes or, if you have io.pedestal.http aliased to something like http then ::http/routes, etc‚Ä¶)#2019-01-0420:52ddeaguiarI‚Äôd also assoc ::http/join? false to the service map when so that you can stop the server when running from a repl#2019-01-0420:53ddeaguiarFinally, I‚Äôd not invoke expand-routes directly. That‚Äôs done for you by the io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors fn when create-server is invoked. Your routes should instead be 
(def routes
   #{["/foo" :get `index :route-name :index]})
#2019-01-0420:54ddeaguiarrefer to https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs/issues/66#2019-01-0420:54ddeaguiarI need to update the docs#2019-01-0420:55ccann> Finally, I‚Äôd not invoke expand-routes directly. good to know#2019-01-0420:57lwhorton:thumbsup: i was working off the http://pedastal.io/guides , but i see now that the ::http/ was missing#2019-01-0421:11ddeaguiarJust an FYI, I went back and looked at the source and you can call pass in routes expanded by expand-routes. Not sure what issue I ran into when I created that Github issue ages ago but I do still think you should let Pedestal‚Äôs internals expand routes for you unless you are explicitly not leveraging the defaults provided by io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors.#2019-01-0421:12lwhortoni‚Äôm still poking around the interceptor stuff, checking out content negotiation and coersion etc.. the whole thing looks like a great paradigm#2019-01-0421:18ddeaguiarInterceptors are great. The core set of interceptors provided by Pedestal is intentionally kept small. Application-specific needs can be implemented as interceptors pretty easily.#2019-01-0420:33lwhortonthe create-server fails with `Execution error (IllegalArgumentException) at io.pedestal.http.route/eval13846$fn$G (route.clj:426). No implementation of method: :router-spec of protocol: #‚Äôio.pedestal.http.route/RouterSpecification found for class: nil`. not really sure what this means without digging into src, but so far just following the tutorial / docs has gotten me to here üòï#2019-01-0900:39ccannis there a way to ensure *url-for* is bound when using the testing facilities like response-for?#2019-01-1114:12souenzzoI'm trying to do this https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/http2/src/hp/service.clj But I'm getting
