Might be folded into a json encoder one. I filed an issue some time ago about this, which resulted in that example. #2019-01-2919:17donaldballWhen using the table routing syntax, what is the suggested way of applying a seq of interceptors to e.g. all routes under a given path?#2019-01-2919:20donaldballI had thought that registering the interceptors as metadata in a wrapping vector would do it but that seems not to be true#2019-01-2919:27ddeaguiarHi @donaldball! You can create a var bound to the vector of common interceptors and conj your handler into it. With the table routing syntax, you‚Äôll need to do this for each route#2019-01-2919:27ddeaguiarA project created using the service template will have an example of this#2019-01-2919:28ddeaguiar
(def common-interceptors [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body])

;; Tabular routes
(def routes #{["/" :get (conj common-interceptors `home-page)]
              ["/about" :get (conj common-interceptors `about-page)]})
#2019-01-2919:30donaldballYeah, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm doing now, but it‚Äôs ergonomically less appealing than earlier syntaxes allowed. Then again, that‚Äôs what fns are for. üôÇ#2019-01-3117:48ccann@donaldball you could also set interceptors at the server config level with the key :io.pedestal.http/interceptors with a vector of common interceptors, if that factoring works for your setup#2019-01-3117:50ccannso my routes looks like this: 
(def routes
  #{["/custom/notes"                     :get   [auth    owner    `notes/filter-by-user]]
    ["/custom/notes"                     :post  [auth-un any-user `notes/create-one]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id"                 :get   [auth    owner    `notes/read-one]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id"                 :patch [auth-un owner    `notes/update-one]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id/graphic"         :get   [auth    owner    `notes/read-graphic]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id/production-file" :post  [auth    owner    `notes/create-production-file]]
    ["/custom/health_check"              :get   `healthy]})


(def interceptors
  [(multipart-params)
   (body-params)
   json-body
   authorization
   exception-handler])
#2019-01-3117:50ccannwhere the interceptors vector is pulled into the server config#2019-01-3122:49caleb.macdonaldblackI'm trying to access my pedestal service from my web app but the preflight OPTIONS request returns a 404. But it looks like it won't deal with preflight at all if it doesn't have that key#2019-02-0821:38asilvermanHi #pedestal users, I am in need of guidance regarding the function below 
(defn create-servlet
  "Creates a servlet given an options map with keyword keys prefixed by namespace e.g.
  :io.pedestal.http/interceptors or ::bootstrap/interceptors if the namespace is aliased to bootstrap.

  Options:

  * :io.pedestal.http/interceptors: A vector of interceptors that defines a service.

  Note: Additional options are passed to default-interceptors if :interceptors is not set."
  [service-map]
  (-> service-map
      default-interceptors
      service-fn
      servlet))
I am looking at some legacy code that is exercising this function in order to create a test servlet, but that seems to be opposed to this guide -> http://pedestal.io/guides/pedestal-with-component#2019-02-0821:38asilvermanCan somebody help me understand what is this pattern of use of create-servlet?#2019-02-0822:28ddeaguiar@ariel.silverman it‚Äôs common to use response-for to test your service implementation. That constructs a servlet request under the covers which is used to exercise your implementation.#2019-02-1117:25asilverman@U0FL657GR - Would you be open to helping me out with this subject? I wasn‚Äôt really able to find any good resources‚Ä¶#2019-02-1214:13ddeaguiar@ariel.silverman sure! Here‚Äôs a start. A new pedestal project created via the pedestal-service template contains some initial tests. Here‚Äôs a trimmed down version of one of those tests in the ‚ÄòHello World‚Äô sample: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/hello-world/test/hello_world/service_test.clj#L19-L25#2019-02-1214:13ddeaguiarI‚Äôll work on fleshing out the reference for unit testing in the http://pedestal.io docs.#2019-02-1214:14ddeaguiarresponse-for can be used to test all HTTP methods. If you are testing :post you can specify a :body.#2019-02-1214:14ddeaguiarHeaders can also be passed#2019-02-1217:49asilverman@U0FL657GR thank you for your help üôÇ I will review the project for inspiration and clarification and follow up if any questions arise. Thanks again!#2019-02-1022:42caleb.macdonaldblackcan i put a namespaced key in a route url? like :foo/bar?#2019-02-1022:43caleb.macdonaldblack/users/:user/id/contacts Where the namespace key is :user/id#2019-02-1023:36ddeaguiarHi @caleb.macdonaldblack! That won‚Äôt work as you‚Äôre expecting. :user will be interpreted as the path parameter, not :user/id.#2019-02-1023:37caleb.macdonaldblackOkay cool. I didn't expect that to work however I wasn't sure if there was another way to achieve that. Perhaps by escaping or something#2019-02-1109:42ikitommireitit-pedestal will support bracket-syntax and because of that, qualified path-params, should be out it few weeks. Would be /users/{user/id}/contacts. Also enables silly things like /public/file-{name}.pdf#2019-02-1212:09TKis it ok to have two different interceptors about (in memory) database, one for a "table" X and other for "table" Y?#2019-02-1214:15ddeaguiar@leandrotk100, I‚Äôll hesitantly say yes but I don‚Äôt know your use case#2019-02-1215:08TKI have a in-memory database: 
{:users [...]
 :connections [...]}
I implemented a simple CRUD to the users, and I used a db-interceptor specific for the users Now I was thinking about the connections and (maybe) another db-interceptor, something like db-connection-interceptor#2019-02-1215:10ddeaguiarIn general, I implement an interceptor to create/get a connection and make it available on the context for other interceptors#2019-02-1215:11ddeaguiarI may also implement an interceptor which fetches an entity from the db and makes it available on the context/request as well.#2019-02-1215:12ddeaguiarIn general, I think it‚Äôs good practice to limit handlers to response formatting and push data retrieval to interceptors#2019-02-1502:23caleb.macdonaldblack500 errors/exceptions don't seem to add the cors header using ::http/allowed-origins. All other requests do. Is there any way to add this without creating an error interceptor to repeat what the ::http/allowed-origins param does. Or something else wrong here?#2019-02-1515:23ddeaguiar@caleb.macdonaldblack while Pedestal provides default error handling, I‚Äôd recommend implementing your own error handling interceptor which associates a more informative and, possibly, context-specific response. Adding such an error handling interceptor to your common interceptor collection will create a response which will be returns with the relevant CORS headers.#2019-02-1515:28ddeaguiarHere are some more details: Default error handling is considered last resort and is interceptor chain provider specific. The servlet interceptor chain provider provides a catchall but it‚Äôs implemented within the internal response processing logic. CORS is implemented as an interceptor and only supports the :enter and :leave keys. On :leave it merges the relevant headers to the response :headers map. There is no :error support because, what should it do in the case of an error? This is an application-specific concern. Explicitly handle your errors and you‚Äôll get the result you are looking for.#2019-02-1515:30ddeaguiarBTW, when I talked about context-specific error handling, I was referring to the error-dispatch helper provided by Pedestal (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/interceptor/src/io/pedestal/interceptor/error.clj#L17).#2019-02-1515:31ddeaguiarIt allows you to provide both general and specific error handling in one place#2019-02-1515:38caleb.macdonaldblackThank you for for your response. I left my question up to see if there were any other solutions. I did end up using error-dispatch though which is exactly what I needed#2019-02-1521:47ddeaguiarI just added a Unit Testing reference to the http://pedestal.io site (http://pedestal.io/reference/unit-testing). @ariel.silverman you may find it useful.#2019-02-1600:34asilvermanThank you so much, I tried this approach but in my case since our service is wrapped inside a component I ended up creating a macro I am using as a fixture to exercise the response-for function 
(defmacro with-mock-ds-system
  [[sym ds-factory] & body]
  ;; Create a system map with a mock datastore and a mock auth-checker, set ::http/join == false so
  ;; that the system doesn't block execution.
  `(let [temp# ~ds-factory]
     ;; Store a reference to this system, perhaps unnecessary but done for the sake
     ;; of future debuggability.
     (reset! mock-svc (component/start-system (service/consent-service
                                                (env/get-api-config)
                                                (create-mock-auth-checker (env/get-api-config))
                                                {:type   :mockstore
                                                 :config temp#}
                                                {:env         :dev
                                                 ::http/join? false})))
     ;; Pull the servlet function that is used for testing out of the newly created system.
     (let [~sym (get-in @mock-svc [:consent :service ::http/service-fn])]
       (try
         ~@body
         ;; Shutdown system.
         (finally
           (component/stop-system @mock-svc)
           (reset! mock-svc nil))))))
#2019-02-1716:48ddeaguiar@ariel.silverman, :thumbsup:. I‚Äôve done something similar in the past but leveraged a fixture.#2019-02-1916:23asilvermanI also had a fixture implementation but ended up abandoning that approach because I want to dynamically change behavior of the mock datastore based on test specific scenarios and realized that fixtures do not allow for arguments and it just seemed a bit clunky.#2019-02-1916:24asilvermanthank you for your help and for taking the initiative to write a guide on pedestal on testing. üôÇ#2019-02-1916:25ddeaguiarnp!#2019-02-1612:07TKAnd maybe an integration testing would be to compose "unit tests". for example - List resources: empty - Create resource: return resource - List resource: list with the created resource - Update the resource: return the updated resource ...and so on. Is this the idea of an integration testing?#2019-02-1716:51ddeaguiarI think that‚Äôs consistent with integration testing. In my experience, the term integration testing has been used to describe end-to-end tests which exercise the system in the context of backing infrastructure/dependencies (i.e., real database, externally deployed services, etc‚Ä¶)#2019-02-1612:19TKFor the unit test, we could also use let to get the response and use it to multiple "assertions" 
(let [response (response-for service
                             :post "/foo"
                             :headers {"Content-Type" "application/json"}
                             :body "{\"foo\":\"bar\"}")]
  (is (= 200 (:status response)))
  (is (= {"foo": "bar"} (:body response))))
#2019-02-1818:01souenzzoHello I'm using context-configurator to enable gzip, but it works just on "public" routes. I use csrf, so my get's are public and post's private 
::http/enable-csrf       {}
 ::http/enable-session    {}
On get's, gzip works, on post's not My context config: 
(defn context-configurator
  [^ServletContextHandler context]
  (let [gzip-handler (GzipHandler.)]
    (.setExcludedAgentPatterns gzip-handler (make-array String 0))
    (.setGzipHandler context gzip-handler))
  context)
https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/servlet-filters-gzip/src/gzip/service.clj#L61#2019-02-1818:04ddeaguiar@souenzzo, by private you mean that the csrf token is required?#2019-02-1818:04souenzzoyep.#2019-02-1818:05ddeaguiarHm, I‚Äôd expect that to behave similarly. includedMethods
List of HTTP methods to compress. If not set, only GET requests are compressed.

(def my-url-for (route/url-for-routes (route/expand-routes routes)))

 (my-url-for :show-named-profile :params {:profile-handle "foo"})

(def my-url-for (route/url-for-routes (table/table-routes routes)))
(my-url-for :show-named-profile :params {:profile-handle "foo"})

Tracking down where :context "" is being set is where I‚Äôd start looking#2019-02-1915:49kommen@ddeaguiar It looks like in pedestal 0.5.5 there is always a :context-path on the request in https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/0.5.5/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L209#2019-02-1915:49kommenwhich causes context-path-parts to be [""] instead of nil#2019-02-1915:51kommenso I guess this change here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/commit/1d9083421cb8fa407d2093212e048e8420009c29#diff-9be1af57b1dfcec8ea9df18ac98e6777R152#2019-02-1915:54ddeaguiarOk, thanks for digging through that. I‚Äôll likely update the release notes with breaking change info and possibly open an issue around it.#2019-02-1915:56kommenI‚Äôll file an issue with the info I found#2019-02-1916:03ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-02-1916:03kommenit also reproduces with the stock lein example in the context of a request#2019-02-1916:16kommenhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/610#2019-02-1916:19ddeaguiarthanks again üôÇ#2019-02-1920:18v3gaDoes anyone here have any basic examples of a pedestal CRUD project with mount/component and a database?#2019-02-1920:23ddeaguiar@decim creating such an example has been on my todo list for a while. If you have specific questions perhaps I can provide some guidance#2019-02-1920:26v3ga@ddeaguiar i‚Äôm very much at the beginning of it. I‚Äôve gone through the provided tutorials and I‚Äôm really just trying to figure out where to go, what all is necessary. Even something as simple as making a post. For starters i‚Äôd like to know how to just serve a basic index.html page from my resources folder. As I get a hold on things I‚Äôll start to make blog posts for people in the future interested.#2019-02-1920:28ddeaguiarTo serve files, add the :io.pedestal.http/resource-path key to your system map. This will serve any files which match url from that dir#2019-02-1920:30v3ga@ddeaguiar ok, nice. I really have to start looking through the source as well today. I‚Äôm coming from frameworks like ruby on rails so these libraries are very bare bones which isn‚Äôt a bad thing, it‚Äôs good to know exactly what‚Äôs taking place#2019-02-1920:33ddeaguiarI‚Äôve experimented with component and pedestal quite a bit on various projects and I‚Äôm now more discerning about bringing the two together.#2019-02-1920:34ddeaguiarPedestal provides a configuration map which you can append anything to at runtime, during system startup#2019-02-1920:35ddeaguiarThey key concept is to create interceptors which provide access to those things you need (i.e., db connection, etc‚Ä¶)#2019-02-1920:35ddeaguiarIf you need to start things, you already have the facilities to do it and append the started thing to the service map#2019-02-1920:35ddeaguiarsame with stopping#2019-02-1920:35ddeaguiarbut#2019-02-1920:36ddeaguiarIf you really want to use component or mount or whatever, you can#2019-02-1920:39ddeaguiarMy current line of thinking here is: - Define routes in one place - Limit components to external dependency needs (db, queueing system, etc‚Ä¶) - Use interceptors as glue to make those dependencies available on the context map and/or request - Do more processing in interceptors and limit handlers to formatting responses - With Component, have the Pedestal component depend on all other components and be responsible for putting their interceptor glue on the interceptor chain#2019-02-1920:41ddeaguiarHere are some examples of component+pedestal that I‚Äôve tinkered with: https://github.com/pointslope/elements/blob/master/src/pointslope/elements/pedestal.clj#L1, https://github.com/ddeaguiar/component-pedestal#2019-02-1920:41ddeaguiarTBH, I‚Äôm not happy with either of them but you can use that for inspiration#2019-02-1920:47v3gaHmm ok, I see. Looking at ‚Äòelements‚Äô now. It almost seems as if it‚Äôs better to start from scratch opposed to lein new pedestal service app-name#2019-02-1920:48ddeaguiaryeah it‚Äôs a different way of building a service#2019-02-1920:50ddeaguiarAgain, take it with a grain of salt. Those projects are old and I‚Äôve not had the need leverage component + pedestal lately#2019-02-1920:50ddeaguiarBut if you are just learning pedestal, then stick with the service template#2019-02-1920:56ddeaguiarIt‚Äôs perfectly acceptable to provision dependencies on system startup via -main or run-dev and add the interceptors which provide access to those started resources at that point.#2019-02-1921:09v3ga@ddeaguiar yeah i‚Äôm wondering if using component or mount is overkill as well. I may be experimenting with too many things at once. long term for this toy project i‚Äôd like to use it but I suppose I shouldn‚Äôt fear a complete rewrite after I know what‚Äôs taking place. So you do prefer component over mount? I‚Äôve seen a bit of discussion about that.#2019-02-1921:41mkvlr@decim I prefer integrant#2019-02-1921:42mkvlr@decim check out https://lambdaisland.com/episodes/integrant#2019-02-2002:38v3ga@mkvlr taking a look over that as well now#2019-02-2018:11ccanncan anyone offer advice on how to disambiguate these routes? 
["/custom/notes/images/storage-parameters" :post [...]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id"                 :get   [...]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id"                 :patch [...]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id/graphic"         :get   [...]]
    ["/custom/notes/:id/production-file" :post  [...]]
#2019-02-2018:11ccannthe first one always 404s#2019-02-2018:28ccannDo I have to resort to the linear router here? Can I change routing syntax instead?#2019-02-2023:16ddeaguiar@ccann, This behavior to be independent of routing syntax because routes all get expanded to the verbose form. What you are observing is expected behavior for the prefix tree router. As per https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/330 > The prefix-tree router also changes some of the routing behavior. In the linear-search, you could have routes like /one/:wild and /one/two, the latter being a hard match and the former picking up any wildcard URL matches (not /one/two). In the prefix-tree, this isn‚Äôt allowed, and one/:wild will always be matched. This change also encourages ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù and removes the possibility of subtle bugs introduced by human error.#2019-02-2023:16ddeaguiarI realize that this documentation is buried deep in the bowels of Pedestal. I plan on updating the routing docs to make this info more visible#2019-02-2023:17ddeaguiarIf you decide to continue with your existing routes then the linear search router is the way to go.#2019-02-2116:21ccannthanks very much, that makes sense. I am going to change my route#2019-02-2214:53ujjwaltHi. New to Clojure and Pedestal. Looking at Vase. Can someone explain why the template doesn‚Äôt match the instructions on building your first API?#2019-02-2214:54ujjwaltAlso is Pedestal and Vase ready for production use?#2019-02-2215:04ddeaguiarHi @ujjwalt and welcome üôÇ. I‚Äôll take a look at the Vase docs. It could be that they are out of date. I‚Äôm not sure what your definition is for production use but both have been used in production systems. Pedestal predates Vase by a number of years, is highly configurable and supports high traffic usage scenarios#2019-02-2215:05ujjwaltYeah I meant if people have used it in production and that it won#2019-02-2215:05ujjwalt*won‚Äôt crash#2019-02-2215:05ujjwaltLittle confused with Vase because of the mismatch. Any suggestions on what path to follow to understand it and start using#2019-02-2215:06ddeaguiarI‚Äôd start with Pedestal first and understand it‚Äôs concepts#2019-02-2215:07ddeaguiarUnderstanding Vase is much easier once you‚Äôve got the basic concepts down#2019-02-2215:07ddeaguiarThen I‚Äôd peruse Datomic docs to get a high-level understanding#2019-02-2215:08ddeaguiarI tried to capture the learning path here https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase#before-you-get-started#2019-02-2215:12ddeaguiar@ujjwalt, sorry you ran into issues with the Your first API doc. I can see that it uses the Fern api description format but the vase template is emitting the edn format. I‚Äôll work on rectifying that but you can try working with an older version of that guide in the meantime https://github.com/cognitect-labs/vase/blob/6332b633c174fcfa40efef56d3cd0a57cd2033f8/docs/your_first_api.md#2019-02-2215:15ujjwaltThanks a lot @ddeaguiar. I‚Äôll start there. Will get back if I encounter something else.#2019-02-2215:15ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-02-2215:40ujjwaltQuick questions: Specifically when does one use ions vs Vase? What would be the ideal use cases for both provided we are on AWS.#2019-02-2216:01ddeaguiarIt‚Äôs on my todo list to put out an example of Ions + Vase now that datomic client api support has landed on Vase master. Note that we‚Äôve yet to push out a release of Vase with those changes#2019-02-2216:02ddeaguiarVase‚Äôs value proposition is in data described services. Using it, you can build services quickly#2019-02-2216:12ddeaguiarIons allows you to deploy code that runs on the Datomic infrastructure - close to your DB. In the process, it facilitates deployments.#2019-02-2216:12ddeaguiarIf you are working with Datomic Cloud, then there‚Äôs likely a place where Ions are a fit for you#2019-02-2216:13ddeaguiarIn fact, re: Ions, they run within the Datomic process#2019-02-2216:14ddeaguiarso your application is running in the database. You can‚Äôt get much closer to your data than that#2019-02-2216:14ddeaguiarand you benefit from autoscaling, etc‚Ä¶#2019-02-2216:15ddeaguiarThere are some caveats, you may run into dependency conflicts but the tooling around identifying, describing and resolving those has improved#2019-02-2216:27ujjwaltI see. So there‚Äôs a use case for using Ions + Vase? Like deploying Vase services as ions? That would be pretty cool. Or maybe deploying it as an API gateway?#2019-02-2216:30ddeaguiarI‚Äôve not tried deploying Vase via Ions yet but see no reason why that wouldn‚Äôt work. It‚Äôs just a Pedestal service and we have a Pedestal Ions interceptor chain provider https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal.ions#2019-02-2216:30ddeaguiarbut we‚Äôd need to release an updated version of Vase first containing Datomic Cloud support (currently on master)#2019-02-2216:35ddeaguiarI also think Vase + Ions is cool!#2019-02-2217:08ujjwaltThat sounds very interesting. Any possible timeline on Vase Datomic Cloud support release?#2019-02-2217:10ddeaguiarI‚Äôm hoping in the next few weeks#2019-02-2217:15ujjwaltAnd any update on the pedestal docs on the website. A lot of links don‚Äôt have articles#2019-02-2217:18ddeaguiarOngoing work in progress#2019-02-2217:21ujjwaltCool. We‚Äôre aware of it and looking into it#2019-02-2518:21demonshreder@ddeaguiar :thumbsup:#2019-02-2714:20donaldballBy default, the pedestal dev interceptor pprints the context when an exception occurs. Sometimes, the context can be Very Large, which makes for a hot cpu locally. Have others been sad about this, and what strategies have you employed to mitigate it?#2019-02-2717:07souenzzoI store datascript db in ctx When my repl freezes, I know that pedestal is trying to print it üòû#2019-02-2717:32donaldballha ha the struggle is real#2019-02-2718:22ddeaguiarI can see two ways to deal with this and there both applications specific: 1. Leverage the existing print vars to control how much is printed. Clojure‚Äôs pprint impl respects those. 2. Implement your own dev interceptor variant which does not pprint the context.#2019-02-2717:07souenzzoI store datascript db in ctx When my repl freezes, I know that pedestal is trying to print it üòû#2019-02-2718:21ccannI also occasionally find this more noisy and confusing than it is helpful, but I keep thinking for some gnarly issue one day I‚Äôll be thankful the information is all there#2019-02-2719:33souenzzoHow to configure a /* in AWS API Gateway to get pedestal working in IONS?#2019-02-2719:42ddeaguiar@souenzzo /{proxy+} is not sufficient?#2019-02-2719:43ddeaguiarHave you tried this sample? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-ions-sample#2019-02-2720:13souenzzo@ddeaguiar I'm using proxy+ (generated by clicking in proxy checkbox) when I call it send's me {"message":"Missing Authentication Token"} when I call it return my handler, as expected when I call it returns {"message":"Missing Authentication Token"} again#2019-02-2720:15souenzzoATM I'm with #{["/*" :get hello]} that returns {:body (pr-str path-info) :status 200}#2019-02-2720:27ddeaguiarhrm /proxy+ should route any child path to the ion#2019-02-2720:28ddeaguiarto get / to work, you need to set up the ANY method on / to proxy requests to the lambda. Apparently /proxy+ doesn‚Äôt handle that#2019-02-2720:28ddeaguiarThere‚Äôs probably a better way to do that‚Ä¶#2019-02-2720:30souenzzoshould all my routes be ["/:app/my-actual-path/..." :get ,,,] ?#2019-02-2720:31ddeaguiarno, the relative path should suffice#2019-02-2720:31ddeaguiarExample: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-ions-sample/blob/master/src/ion_sample/service.clj#L142-L148#2019-02-2721:06souenzzoOh, I need to "deploy" my api gateway config#2019-02-2721:07souenzzosorry @ddeaguiar. Now it's working#2019-02-2721:07ddeaguiarAh yes, deployment is important üôÇ#2019-02-2721:07ddeaguiarThat‚Äôs bitten me before‚Ä¶#2019-02-2721:22souenzzoChoose Add Binary Media Type, add the */* type. It will solve the fact of everything comes in base64 ?#2019-02-2721:32ddeaguiarMy understanding is that by setting that, API gateway passes the data through to the ion unaltered#2019-02-2721:32ddeaguiarwell to the lambda proxy‚Äôing the ion#2019-02-2722:08ddeaguiarBTW, that last bit is an important point. Most meaningful logs will not be in the lambda logs but the compute group logs#2019-02-2722:08ddeaguiareasy to forget that#2019-02-2722:29JonathanCan pedestal still use ring middlewares as interceptors? I found the ring_middlewares sample repo but it‚Äôs in terms of pedestal 0.1.2#2019-02-2814:11ddeaguiarHi @U9UQ36CJJ! Pedestal uses interceptors instead of middleware but there are a number of middleware that have been wrapped by interceptors (https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http/ring_middlewares.clj) and, in most cases, it‚Äôs pretty straight forward to create interceptor wrappers of your own. Here‚Äôs a sample which does just that https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/buddy-auth/src/buddy_auth/service.clj#L51-L72.#2019-02-2807:29TwiceHey, everyone! While trying to incorporate Sente library into Pedestal, I'm getting No implementation of method: :default-content-type of protocol: #'io.pedestal.http.impl.servlet-interceptor/WriteableBody found for class: org.projectodd.wunderboss.web.async.ServletHttpChannel error. Can't figure out how to deal with it#2019-02-2815:21ddeaguiar@UFEQ5L1NK, I‚Äôm not familiar with Sente but based on that message, it seems like you‚Äôll need to implement an interceptor chain provider to support it. The default servlet-specific implementation supports Tomcat, Jetty and Immutant.#2019-02-2819:49JonathanI haven‚Äôt used Sente but I recently evaluated it for a project. It‚Äôs a fairly comprehensive websockets library but it‚Äôs not compatible with Tomcat or Jetty. I ended up using http-kit‚Äôs built-in websocket library. Thanks for advice anyway!#2019-03-0509:51manandearthHi there. New to pedestal. Happy to be corrected. I was extending the example in the official pedestal guide (specifically the rest api example: http://pedestal.io/guides/your-first-api) Wanted to implement a :delete interceptor (just in order to understand). tried the following: 
(def list-delete
 {:name :list-delete                                                                                                  
  :enter
   (fn [context]
      (let [nm (get-in context [:request :query-params :name]) 
            db-id (filter (comp #{nm} (:tx-data context)) (keys (:tx-data context)))] 
        (update context :tx-data dissoc db-id)))})
the original interceptor that creates the list is: 
(def list-create   
   {:name :list-create 
    :enter
    (fn [context]
      (let [nm       (get-in context [:request :query-params :name] "Unnamed List")
            new-list (make-list nm)
            db-id    (str (gensym "l"))] 
        (assoc context :tx-data [assoc db-id new-list])))})
the original route for the :post is: ["/todo" :post [db-interceptor list-create]] so my :delete root is: ["/todo" :delete [db-interceptor list-delete]] But trying the test: (test-request :delete "/todo?name=some-list") when the state is: 
{"l30491" {:name "my-other-list", :items {}}, "l30517" {:name "yes-list", :items {}}, "l30520" {:name "no-list", :items {}}, "l30527" {:name "no-list", :items {}}, "l30618" {:name "some-list", :items {}}}
does not delete the list in question.... Note that some-list is the :name value in a map which is a value of the string "l30618" ... I think that my list-delete function should do the job, but I suspect that I don't understand something basic either about interceptors or about how :delete should be called in a REST api....#2019-03-0522:06ddeaguiar@adamgefen At a glance, it doesn‚Äôt look like your list-delete impl is correct#2019-03-0522:06ddeaguiarthe filter expression looks wrong#2019-03-2718:00souenzzoThere is docs about error-handling inside ions?#2019-03-2718:00souenzzoIons has a nice logging that I can see in cloudwatch#2019-03-2718:01souenzzobut there is no logs about pedestal on there#2019-03-2718:03ddeaguiarOnly ERROR logs are available in ions. (def join-headers
  (io.pedestal.interceptor/interceptor {:name  ::join-headers
                                        :leave (fn [{{:keys [headers]} :response
                                                     :as               ctx}]
                                                 (if (map? headers)
                                                   (assoc-in ctx [:response :headers] (into (empty headers)
                                                                                            (map (fn [[k v]]
                                                                                                   [k (if (coll? v)
                                                                                                        (string/join ";" v)
                                                                                                        v)]))
                                                                                            headers))
                                                   ctx))}))
https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal.ions/blob/master/src/io/pedestal/ions.clj#L169#2019-03-2720:21ddeaguiarHmm yeah that looks like an issue. I can take a look at it in more detail on Friday. (let [routes #{["/sync" :get {:name  ::sync
                              :enter (fn [ctx]
                                       (assoc ctx :response {:body   "sync"
                                                             :status 201}))}]
               ["/async" :get {:name  ::async
                               :enter (fn [ctx]
                                        (async/go
                                          (assoc ctx :response {:body   "async"
                                                                :status 202})))}]}
      h (-> {::http/routes         routes
             ::http/chain-provider provider/ion-provider}
            http/default-interceptors
            http/create-provider)]
  (h {:uri            "/sync"
      ;:uri            "/async"
      :request-method :get}))

Every Lambda call must have a timeout, after which the connection will be terminated no matter what we try to do inside the Ion.#2019-04-0619:23ujjwalt@mtnygard Sure once I actually understand Pedestal üôÇ#2019-04-0619:23ujjwaltIn the mean time what would be my best bet at building a full fledged API with Datomic Ions.#2019-04-0619:28ujjwaltSo if I‚Äôm not doing anything async then pedestal and ions work well together? Literally the most breakage I've seen without code changes has occurred due to changes in the JVM. üòÑ#2019-04-1116:40martinklepschI think you can also combine the two but probably easier to just use one#2019-04-1116:40martinklepschAlso reitit is the default thing in the new Luminus so if you're familiar with that might be worth looking there for more info#2019-04-1116:40macrobartfastah ok... so I'll go with frankiesardo/route-swagger and pedestal to dive into, on your recommendation.#2019-04-1116:41martinklepschnot sure if Luminus has an "API" option that would generate some of that setup code for you#2019-04-1116:41macrobartfastI think I should go with pedestal over luminus in general, if only because it seems like a better thing to learn for enabling microservices to be able to talk to each other.#2019-04-1116:43macrobartfastand that said I guess the luminus reitit would also possibly do that.#2019-04-1116:44macrobartfastit's just hard for folks like me to just get beyond figuring out which frameworks/libraries (I'm not even sure what to call them) to use lol.#2019-04-1116:59martinklepsch
lein new luminus myapp +reitit +swagger +service

Besides swagger, it adds spec & schema coercion, and lot of other things.#2019-04-1117:24mtnygard@ikitommi That's very cool.#2019-04-1120:45macrobartfastawesome... trying all this now.#2019-04-1419:54emccueI got lacinia-pedestal working with some hello world stuff#2019-04-1419:54emccuebut I really don't understand pedestal all that well#2019-04-1419:55emccueso I don't know how to add routes outside of the graphql stuff#2019-04-1419:55emccue(def service-map (lacinia/service-map #'load-schema {:graphiql true}))#2019-04-1420:14emccueI know its a very vauge question#2019-04-1420:14emccuebut i am definitely missing some fundamental bits here#2019-04-1501:20donaldballI‚Äôm doing this by calling graphql-routes instead of service-map, adding it to my other routes, and building my own pedestal service#2019-04-1501:22donaldballYou could call service-map with a :routes arg that you build with graphql-routes yourself#2019-04-1510:11sooheon@emccue mine looks like this: 
(def extra-routes
  #{["/tasks/update-articles" :get update-articles :route-name :tasks/update-articles]})


(mount/defstate service
  :start
  (let [{profile :profile} (mount/args)]
    (-> schema/footballpedia-schema
        (lp/service-map {:graphiql (not= :prod profile)})
        (update ::http/routes set/union extra-routes)
        (assoc ::http/allowed-origins (if (= :prod profile)
                                        allowed-origins
                                        (constantly true)))
        (assoc ::http/host "0.0.0.0")
        (assoc ::http/port 8080)
        http/create-server
        http/start))
  :stop (http/stop service))
#2019-04-1612:08hmadelaineHi everyone ! I am planning to use Pedestal and Component to start en new micro-service. I have done some research on the idiomatic way to bootstrap Pedestal with Component using the reloaded.repl flow. I found those libraries so far : https://github.com/ddeaguiar/component-pedestal https://github.com/grzm/component.pedestal But did not find any clear answer. Did I missed some articles ? Thank you very much#2019-04-1615:45donaldballI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôm answering your question exactly, but I use component and pedestal and have been happiest using a :router component that builds its pedestal :routes dynamically, closing over any other stateful components; and a :jetty component that‚Äôs responsible for the jetty http/s service.#2019-04-1618:36ddeaguiarHi @U0508R629, glad to see that you‚Äôll be using Pedestal. I authored ddeaguiar/component-pedestal and co-authored pointslope elements (https://github.com/pointslope/elements). I‚Äôve not formally released the former and the later has not been updated in a while. As I‚Äôve worked through various iterations of applications based on component and pedestal, I‚Äôve become less inclined to mix the two.#2019-04-1618:36ddeaguiarLet me explain#2019-04-1618:37ddeaguiarPedestal already provides a service representation that is extensible - the service map. You can assoc whatever you like to it and use that info during service initialization#2019-04-1618:38ddeaguiarStart/stop entry points are pretty clear. Pedestal‚Äôs extension point is also very clear - the interceptor.#2019-04-1618:38ddeaguiarAll you need to do is create interceptors that make the dependency you are interested available in the context/request#2019-04-1618:38ddeaguiarYou don‚Äôt need component for that#2019-04-1618:39ddeaguiarI found that all the machinery I built around this for component basically involved how to create such interceptors and where should such code exist in a project#2019-04-1618:40ddeaguiarI don‚Äôt feel it adds much value.#2019-04-1620:07hmadelaine@ddeaguiar thank you very much for your answer. I am not a pedestal expert so I stick to the tools I am comfortable with. I will dig deeper to understand the true philosophy of pedestal :-)#2019-04-1616:30manandearthHow would you add params for testing a route with response-for? or a different way to test request maps?#2019-04-1616:33ddeaguiar@adamgefen http://pedestal.io/reference/unit-testing should clarify this. If not, let me know so I can update it.#2019-04-1616:34manandearthperfect! @ddeaguiar, I overlooked it.#2019-04-1616:35ddeaguiarnp!#2019-04-1618:50manandearth....and how would you inject a session for testing session authentication :session {:identity {:username foo}}?#2019-04-1618:53ddeaguiar@adamgefen how is authentication wired into your service now?#2019-04-1618:54manandearthbuddy session#2019-04-1618:56ddeaguiarbasically you want to use a stub auth store, right?#2019-04-1618:56manandearthyes#2019-04-1618:59ddeaguiarWhat is your auth store? A db? How is that wired in?#2019-04-1618:59ddeaguiarbecause you can stub that on service initialization#2019-04-1619:01manandearthit is a table in a postgresql, the project is component with a pedestal component and a postgres component (juxt.modular)#2019-04-1619:02ddeaguiarSo the db is assoc‚Äôd to context by an interceptor?#2019-04-1619:02ddeaguiaruse a fake store in your system to return what you want#2019-04-1619:03manandearthYes you are right. I don't need to test the db connection.#2019-04-1619:04ddeaguiarin regards to injecting session, need to think on that part#2019-04-1619:04ddeaguiarideally you wouldn‚Äôt have to first ‚Äòlog in‚Äô then run tests#2019-04-1619:05ddeaguiarbetter to have system set up in ‚Äòlogged in state‚Äô, I think anyway#2019-04-1619:06manandearthI see.#2019-04-1619:06ddeaguiarmaybe I‚Äôm making it too complicated#2019-04-1619:06ddeaguiarPerhaps can pass in cookie with identity info, exercise stub auth and test what you want#2019-04-1619:06ddeaguiarit‚Äôs just a header#2019-04-1619:07manandearthYes . I just need a way that it can be passed as a header.#2019-04-1619:08ddeaguiarheaders can be passed via response-for#2019-04-1619:08manandearthBut it can't be just the session map, can it?#2019-04-1619:09ddeaguiarhmm, don‚Äôt recall#2019-04-1619:09ddeaguiartry üôÇ#2019-04-1619:10manandearththanks! üòÑ#2019-04-1700:37ddeaguiar@adamgefen here‚Äôs an example of testing with a stub session store https://gist.github.com/ddeaguiar/defa8b2634c35cdf4db2ca626637db2f#2019-04-1700:38ddeaguiarI‚Äôll look into updating the docs soon#2019-04-1808:08olleHi I'm trying to serve a static js using 
::http/resource-path   "public"
in the service map but I get an csp error 
Refused to load the script '' because it violates the following Content Security Policy directive: "script-src self". Note that 'script-src-elem' was not explicitly set, so 'script-src' is used as a fallback.
.#2019-04-1808:09olleAny tips üôÇ#2019-04-1808:30IvanIt seems to me you have to configure CSP for your use case#2019-04-1808:30Ivanhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/499#2019-04-1809:27olleTnx yes I managed to solve it by adding 
::http/secure-headers {:content-security-policy-settings {:script-src "https://*.}}
to my service map.#2019-04-2302:33v3gaWhat‚Äôs a good way to visualize interceptors in general? I‚Äôm looking for a common analogy that even a non-tech person may understand.#2019-04-2313:03ddeaguiar@decim, perhaps this document will clear things up? http://pedestal.io/reference/interceptors#2019-04-2313:59pfeodrippeHi, is there any example using InputStream at response body? I want to support streaming from it and I'm using a PipedOutputStream connected to a PipedInputStream, but it's sending everything only after everything processed. I'm using future to handle what I have to process, some ideas?#2019-04-2314:14souenzzo{:body (io/input-stream (.getBytes "foo")) :status 200} works.#2019-04-2314:17pfeodrippeYes, but I want to write to the client while processing, not only when it ends, so the client does not have to wait all the processing#2019-04-2314:48v3ga@ddeaguiar yeah the guide is fine, I was just trying to think of other ways to describe it so even someone thats not a programmer can understand, for my notes#2019-04-2315:41ddeaguiar@pfeodrippe can you elaborate on your use case?#2019-04-2316:12pfeodrippe@ddeaguiar I'll write a simplified code 
(def streamed-interceptor
  (interceptor
   {:name ::interceptor
    :enter
    (fn [context]
      (let [pout (PipedOutputStream.)
            pin (PipedInputStream. pout)]
        (future
          (with-open [pout pout]
            (doseq [_ (range 10)]
              (Thread/sleep 1000)
              (.write pout
                      (.getBytes "Eita\n")
                      0 (count "Eita\n"))
              (.flush pout))))
        (assoc context
               :response {:status 200
                          :body pin})))}))
#2019-04-2317:00ddeaguiar@pfeodrippe to clarify, why do you need an input stream?#2019-04-2319:53pfeodrippeSorry, just saw it now, I have a function where I'm making requests to other endpoints and I want to notify the client right after the processing of 1 endpoint (of N)#2019-04-2319:54pfeodrippeSo the client does not have to wait until the end of the request to get all the responses#2019-04-2319:54pfeodrippeIf it's not clear, I can try to explain again üòÉ#2019-04-2316:14pfeodrippeBased on this code, I'd like to see a new line with "Eita" each second#2019-04-2316:17pfeodrippeI've tested with a lot of data and it was streaming each 32768 bytes... I'm now looking for a way to reduce this buffer size for the streaming response, any idea @ddeaguiar?#2019-04-2317:49donaldballThe docs say you can use a core.async channel for your response body to get the effect you want: http://pedestal.io/reference/streaming#_using_a_core_async_channel_as_the_response#2019-04-2317:50donaldballI have never used this mechanism though.#2019-04-2320:02pfeodrippeYes, I have saw this, but we prefer more controlled threads instead of go blocks#2019-04-2402:30donaldballYou don‚Äôt have to use go blocks to return a channel of course, you can use the double bang fns and your own threads.#2019-04-2416:51pfeodrippeGreat o/#2019-04-2316:43Braden ShepherdsonI've seen one metaphor: passing through a succession of gates or checkpoints, maybe for a flight.#2019-04-2316:43Braden Shepherdsonsome of the tasks are one-sided, others double-sided.#2019-04-2316:45Braden Shepherdsoneg. you check-in (`:enter` only), drop your bag (`:enter` of a double-sided one), go through security (`:enter` only), fly (the real handler), clear customs (`:leave` only), get your bag (`:leave` of the bag-handling interceptor) and done.#2019-04-2316:45Braden Shepherdsonactually, an even better metaphor there: the check-in process gives you a token (your boarding pass) that you show to several successive checkpoints (bag drop, security, at the gate)#2019-04-2509:47v3ga@braden.shepherdson yes now that really works. Thanks#2019-04-3016:25souenzzoCan I/Should I use ELB > exported pedestal-ions? Or it should be always APIGateway > exported pedestal-ions ?#2019-04-3017:35ddeaguiar@souenzzo pedestal.ion leverages the request map produced by Datomic Ions‚Äô datomic.ion.lambda.api-gateway/ionize impl. You can create an ion that consumes events from any event source but it‚Äôs up to you to implement the relevant handler.#2019-05-0620:53jacksonHowdy all, is there documentation somewhere, or an example, of running pedestal with https on Jetty or is that a Jetty config thing?#2019-05-0621:01ddeaguiarHi @jackson.reynolds, the documentation is lagging behind on that topic but you‚Äôll be able to configure ssl support via the service map. If you create a service using the pedestal-service lein template, you‚Äôll see the ::http/container-options that you can specify https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-template/src/leiningen/new/pedestal_service/service.clj#L72-L78#2019-05-0621:02jackson@ddeaguiar perfect, thanks!#2019-05-0621:03ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-05-0718:45jacksonIs there an idiomatic way to preserve cookies between test/response-for calls for things like csrf tokens?#2019-05-0720:49donaldballI fire up a pedestal jetty instance and use clj-http with a cookie-store when I have such needs#2019-05-0923:41weihow do you serve static resources with pedestal?#2019-05-1000:57souenzzo@wei ::http/file-path "target/public" << files not in your classpath ::http/resource-path "public" << files in your classpath ::http/mime-types mime/default-mime-types << useful (require '[ring.util.mime-type :as mime])#2019-05-1007:40wei@souenzzo thanks! and how does that file path get associated with a URL route to serve it? sorry, fairly new to pedestal#2019-05-1007:47weior alternatively, if there's a link to a complete example that'd be great#2019-05-1013:19souenzzoUsing ::http/resource-path "public" with :paths ["src" "resources"] (in deps.edn) or :resource-path ["resources"] (in project.clj) resources/public/app.html will be available in :8080/app.html I think that it first try to find a file, then try to find a route in your router.#2019-05-1013:29ddeaguiar@souenzzo is correct (thanks!), here are some more details. When default interceptors are added, if the ::http/resource-path is present in the service map, then an interceptor wrapping the ring resource middleware is conj‚Äôd onto the interceptor chain. This interceptor executes it‚Äôs :enter impl prior to routing.#2019-05-1016:44jmvhi all, i've been playing around with vase and i'm wondering if there's a way for the pedestal service to reload the configuration if i change a dynamic interceptor in the fern file. e.g., i realize there is an error with my query and i want to fix it. can i do that and have the change take effect without having to stop and start vase?#2019-05-1017:09asilverman#pedestal , Hi everyone. Vase does have more opinions but not involve spec and headers (that I recall anyway).#2019-05-1405:37ikitommiI would say Pedestal is a framework, as it calls your code üòâ There is also reitit-pedestal add-on, which allows one to describe header-params with spec. With request-coercion interceptor mounted, validation, coercion (string->edn) and api-docs are pulled from those definitions. Would be something like: 
["/headers"
 {:get {:summary "playing with header-params"
        :parameters {:header {:x-int pos-int?}}
        :interceptors [(coercion/coerce-request-interceptor)]
        :handler (fn [req]
                   {:status 200
                    :body {:value (-> req :parameters :header :x-int inc)}})}}]

Right?#2019-05-2808:54Ahmed Hassanhttps://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/security/csp/#the_meta_tag#2019-05-2808:56souenzzoYep. Choose one method (headers or meta-tags). https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/meta#attr-http-equiv#2019-05-3020:39ccanncould anyone recommend a way to have the allowed-origins interceptor skip a particular route?#2019-05-3020:45ddeaguiar@ccann, you have full control over what interceptors are added. Leveraging Pedestal‚Äôs default-interceptors impl should be considered a convenience and may not be suitable for some use cases. By setting the :io.pedestal.http/interceptors key on the service map you take full control over what interceptors are added when. If you do this, though, you‚Äôll need to add the router interceptor yourself.#2019-05-3020:46ccannokay yeah, thanks#2019-05-3020:46ddeaguiarOr you can just add the allowed-origins interceptor yourself in your routes and skip specifying the allowed-origins in your service map#2019-05-3020:47ddeaguiarthe later is probably more confusing#2019-05-3020:51ccannthe problem I‚Äôm having that led me to ask the question is that for my health check route (a GET request) I‚Äôm getting a NPE from my allowed-origins function#2019-05-3020:51ccannwhich is because there is no Origin header (i‚Äôm parsing the header with a regexp)#2019-05-3020:51ccannbecause the health check is coming from an AWS server not a browser#2019-05-3020:52ccannand apparently the pedestal cors interceptor calls the allowed-origins function before determining if the request type is :options https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/09dd88c4ce7f89c7fbb7a398077eb970b3785d2d/service/src/io/pedestal/http/cors.clj#L82#2019-05-3020:55ddeaguiarYep, the allow-origin interceptor is added prior to the router and it is within the router where method-based matching is done#2019-05-3020:58ccannso I guess the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù behavior then for a missing Origin header is for the allowed-origins function to return truthy#2019-05-3021:00ccannbecause a browser is going to send Origin, and that‚Äôs what CORS is concerned with. If a server or curl doesn‚Äôt specify an origin that‚Äôs outside the concern of CORS#2019-05-3021:00ccannthinking out-loud here üôÇ#2019-05-3021:05ddeaguiarsounds reasonable#2019-05-3118:35hlshipWhen using table syntax for routing, is there an simple/idiomatic way to remove the common prefix: 
(route/expand-routes
      #{["/api/job/:job-id" :get
         (get-job client)
         :route-name ::get-job]
        ["/api/jobs" :post
         (create-job client)
         :route-name ::create-job]})
I'd like to wrap these in something that 'supplies' the /api part.#2019-06-0413:15ddeaguiar@U04VDKC4G, you can use a different routing syntax. The terse route syntax supports hierarchical route definitions.#2019-06-0415:24hlshipI want my cake and to eat it too. I generally prefer table syntax except for that bit of repetition. #2019-06-0415:30ddeaguiarYes, I prefer table syntax as well.#2019-05-3120:38ccannooh, I would love that as well#2019-06-0206:20Ahmed HassanMy application is giving a lot of unnecessary logging, how can I stop it? I have put logback.xml file in /config directory. and added :paths ["src/main" "resources" "config"] in deps.edn file.#2019-06-0206:29Ahmed HassanI commented out com.fzakaria/slf4j-timbre {:mvn/version "0.3.13"} in deps.edn. And It's now in INFO mode.#2019-06-0719:48donaldballIs anyone aware of a fairly uninvasive way to, given pedestal routes, an interceptor name (e.g. ::json-response), and an event name (e.g. :leave), of recording the timing of every such event?#2019-06-0720:28orestisIs the :leave event the interceptor chain event :leave? as in :enter, :leave, :error?#2019-06-0720:29orestis(I don‚Äôt have an answer, just want to understand the question)#2019-06-0720:32donaldballYea. There are a few interceptor events I‚Äôm interested in getting performance metrics on and I‚Äôd like to do it declaratively. Pedestal‚Äôs architecture facilitates this, but I‚Äôm almost a little surprised it doesn‚Äôt already have such a feature.#2019-06-0720:33donaldballMy current impl thought is to walk the results of io.pedestal.http.route/expand-routes and wrap the target interceptors in each route individually#2019-06-0723:37ddeaguiarHi @donaldball, Pedestal‚Äôs interceptor chain execution is managed by the io.pedestal.interceptor.chain ns. The current implementation does not support that level of instrumentation. While there‚Äôs an option to get more information regarding interceptor chain execution by using a more verbose logging level (i.e., DEBUG, TRACE), it doesn‚Äôt sound like that‚Äôs what you are looking for. Your best bet is to either instrument the interceptors yourself or, if you‚Äôd like to get metrics for a production service, leverage an instrumentation library (i.e., New Relic) which is compatible with pedestal.log‚Äôs metric implementation. If you do the later, you likely need to add write an interceptor to identify requests (i.e., name transactions in New Relic). The benefit of using an instrumentation lib is that you‚Äôll be able to collect information for all your apis and filter them as you see fit.#2019-06-0723:40ddeaguiarAlthough I‚Äôve no experience with this, it may be useful: https://metrics.dropwizard.io/3.1.0/manual/servlet/##2019-06-1016:05TravisIs anyone generating swagger apis using spec with pedestal ? If so are there any examples around?#2019-06-1016:37ikitommihere is one example: https://github.com/metosin/reitit/tree/master/examples/pedestal-swagger#2019-06-2120:52ddeaguiarI just release Pedestal 0.5.7. Check out https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/releases for details.#2019-06-2120:54ddeaguiarIn case you were wondering, the lein pedestal-service template was broken with the 0.5.6 release so I addressed that and bumped to 0.5.7.#2019-07-0314:59Renan OliveiraHi Guys, I have a doubt, what do you using to response in json?#2019-07-0315:15renanHi @renanrboliveira i use json-body interceptor , here a example https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/json-api/src/json_api/service.clj#L59#2019-07-0320:40Renan Oliveirahey @renan and for validates params, if null e etc, how do you work in this case?#2019-07-0321:32renan@renanrboliveira normally i see examples using schema or spec to validation nulls... but when i was learning pedestal the some helpful me to this things#2019-07-0319:13Renan Oliveira@renan thank you üòÉ#2019-07-1020:03souenzzoanyone else using #fulcro #pathom and #datomic ? :io.pedestal.http/routes is a fn#2019-07-1216:03ddeaguiarAlso, the service template using ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes)) in run-dev to facilitate local dev#2019-07-1216:03ddeaguiarso that should work for you#2019-07-1216:03ddeaguiarI don‚Äôt recommend using a fn for routes outside of dev because it‚Äôs evaluated on every request#2019-07-1216:09Braden `service/about-page
; where they needed
`about-page
#2019-07-1217:14Braden Shepherdsonwhich produces no error, but of course those symbols are not defined.#2019-07-1217:15Braden Shepherdsonthanks for the help debugging. (interceptors/defbefore takes-time
      [context]
      (let [channel (chan)]
        (go
         (let [result (lengthy-computation (:request context))
               new-context (assoc context :response (ring-resp/response result))]
           (>! channel new-context)))
        channel))
... is there a reason to create channel explicitly, rather than use the implicit channel that receives the result of the go body? In other words, why do the above instead of this: 
(interceptors/defbefore takes-time
      [context]
      (go
        (let [result (lengthy-computation (:request context))]
          (assoc context :response (ring-resp/response result)))))
#2019-07-1520:53stacktracerThe example in question is here: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/guides/documentation/service-async.md#asynchronous-processing#2019-07-1521:08ddeaguiar@stacktracer I can‚Äôt think of a reason in this case. There are no options being passed during channel creation in this example.#2019-07-1523:50stacktracer@ddeaguiar Thanks for the sanity check!#2019-07-1618:08Braden Shepherdsondo people generally test their interceptors in isolation, test the entire stack (below the router) for each action, or both?#2019-07-1710:51DaoudaHey folks, I am trying to use expand-route with no success.   (route/expand-routes
   #{["/" :get [common-interceptors] `home-page]
     ["/about" :get [common-interceptors] `about-page]
     ["/user" :post [common-interceptors] `create-user]}))

#2019-07-1711:02Daoudathe error seems obvious but i don`t know how to get right of it, anything I tried so far, I get other kind of error. Any help about the right way to use expand-routes ?#2019-07-1713:16ddeaguiar@quieterkali, your service is based on the pedestal-service template then io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors is being called then you don‚Äôt need route/expand-routes. In terms of your routes, it looks you are using the table route syntax but it‚Äôs not complete correct. It should look something like this: 
(def routes
  (route/expand-routes
   #{["/" :get (conj common-interceptors `home-page)]
     ["/about" :get (conj common-interceptors `about-page)]
     ["/user" :post (conj common-interceptors `create-user)}))
#2019-07-1713:19Daoudaoh, how did you noticed that my project was based on pedestal service template? curiosity üòÑ Can I use nested level route with this template?#2019-07-1713:55ddeaguiarLucky guess üôÇ. Table route syntax does not support nested routes. However, I find it to be the preferred route syntax because it‚Äôs easier to reason about (for me anyways).#2019-07-1713:55ddeaguiaryou‚Äôd have to create a separate route vector for, for example, /about/foobar#2019-07-1714:12Braden Shepherdsoncurious, I find the hierarchy more difficult to follow once it grows beyond a handful of layers or a dozen routes total. I like being able to see all the routes laid out in full.#2019-07-1819:06Braden ShepherdsonI had it in my head that Pedestal stops processing interceptors once someone defines the :response key. is that true? do I need to do something to configure that behavior?#2019-07-1819:06Braden ShepherdsonI can't actually find this in the docs, now that I'm looking for it.#2019-07-1819:07donaldballYou need io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate#2019-07-1819:14ddeaguiarFor servlet-based services the termination impl is present and it checks for a :response key in the context#2019-07-1819:15ddeaguiarif you are testing interceptors in isolation with an empty context then you need to add that#2019-07-1819:16ddeaguiarI‚Äôd prefer that over calling io.pedestal.interceptor.chain/terminate if you are going to be sending back a response#2019-07-1819:52Braden Shepherdsonah, I figured out my problem, I think. it uses the ring response? function, which requires that :headers be a map. that wasn't always true in my code.#2019-07-1819:59ddeaguiarAh yep, sorry about that. I should have double checked the source.#2019-07-1821:41donaldballHey, if you use :strict-path-params? with url-for, it throws on what seem to be a lot of false positives. Digging in a little bit, it seems that if your current route has path-params, and you do not dissoc them when calling url-for on a route that does not use all of those path-params, pedestal will throw: https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/aa71a3a630dd21861c0682eeeebec762cbf3f85c/route/src/io/pedestal/http/route.clj#L257-L258 I would fairly expect this to be a subset check, not an equality check. Is there a wrinkle I‚Äôm missing?#2019-07-1913:18ddeaguiarHi @U04V4HWQ4, :strict-path-params? used to be less strict. For the full story see https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/572.#2019-07-1913:23donaldballMy take is that the combination of features here - that the path-params seems to default to those of the current route, and that strict mode throws on unexpected params - results in a strict mode that‚Äôs not usable in the general case. The only thing I want from a strict mode is validating that the params a route needs exist and are valid#2019-07-1913:40ddeaguiarSorry this doesn‚Äôt seem to meet your needs. I‚Äôm not sure what you mean by not useable in the general case. If a path param is present on a route then the assumption is that it is needed. The current implementation of strict mode verifies this. Validation is a separate issue and is service specific. Service interceptors can handle that.#2019-07-1913:50donaldballI mean that if you‚Äôre working on a traditional server-rendered html webapp, for example, and you‚Äôre in the context of a deeply nested resource (e.g. /org/:org-id/loc/:loc-id/zone/:zone-id), and your navbar generates links to ancestor resources, you either can‚Äôt use strict mode, or you have to manually dissoc the extraneous params at every call site.#2019-07-1913:52donaldballM take is just that strict mode is doing two things that could and should be separated is all#2019-07-1823:31Braden Shepherdsonanother oddity: the docs say that :params is the combined :body-params, :path-params and :query-params - I'm only using :path-params and it isn't being set. I'm not sure what interceptor does that behavior, if it isn't just the docs being out of date.#2019-07-1913:45ddeaguiar@UCY0GT0QM the docs are not correct, sorry you were caught by this. In general Pedestal abides by the following principle: If something is separate, keep it separate. If something can be customized via an interceptor, keep the base code as basic as possible I‚Äôll create an issue in the pedestal.docs repo and update the docs.#2019-07-1913:46Braden ShepherdsonThanks, I appreciate it.#2019-07-1913:46ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-07-1912:25orestisI had the same experience with docs etc about this ‚Äî I resorted to looking at the source to figure out the correct interceptors for what I want.#2019-07-1913:46Braden ShepherdsonI'm loving the power and flexibility of Pedestal, despite the friction of the incomplete and sometimes inaccurate docs.#2019-07-1913:47Braden Shepherdsonin particular, I'm delighted with how I can use all of the interceptor machinery in some code intended to handle actions taken in a turn-based game.#2019-07-1913:48ddeaguiar@orestis, yeah the docs are a lagging and a constant wip. Please create issues in the https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal-docs repo whenever you encounter incorrect information! It‚Äôs greatly appreciated üôÇ#2019-07-1914:51orestisOh, I didn‚Äôt realize it‚Äôs a separate repo. I‚Äôll have a look once I‚Äôm back in that area of my app. #2019-07-1914:53ddeaguiarnp, thanks!#2019-07-1913:48Braden Shepherdsonusing a "router" that matches action keywords to their interceptor chains. that lets me write interceptors that eg. check it's your turn, or that a move is legal before enacting it.#2019-07-1913:49Braden Shepherdsonand unlike in most languages, where this kind of thing is a "pattern" I have to reimplement, it's just code I can reuse.#2019-07-1920:53Braden ShepherdsonI'm struggling with reloading the server. sometimes it seems to get wedged, and even though I'm doing a reload-all of my top-level server, and then restarting it, I'm getting the old set of routes and interceptors.#2019-07-1921:01ddeaguiar@braden.shepherdson you may want to give pedestal.service-tools watch a spin. (defn- session-options
  [options]
  {:store        (options :store (mem/memory-store))
   :cookie-name  (options :cookie-name "ring-session")
   :cookie-attrs (merge {:path "/"
                         :http-only true}
                        (options :cookie-attrs)
                        (if-let [root (options :root)]
                          {:path root}))})
#2019-08-2814:46souenzzoso your map should contain #{:store :cookie-name :cookie-attrs :root}#2019-08-2814:39erwinrooijakkers>:enable-session: A settings map to include the session middleware interceptor. If nil, this interceptor is not added. Default is nil.#2019-08-2814:43ddeaguiarAs per ring session opts: https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/blob/master/ring-core/src/ring/middleware/session.clj#L16-L18#2019-08-2814:43erwinrooijakkersPerfect. That‚Äôs the default?#2019-08-2814:43erwinrooijakkersCan I just add true?#2019-08-2814:44erwinrooijakkersThanks#2019-08-2814:44ddeaguiarThose are the defaults so should be able to add :enable-session {} to service map#2019-08-2814:57erwinrooijakkersThanks works üôÇ#2019-08-2815:29ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-08-2815:34erwinrooijakkersHmm actually the cookie is not stored#2019-08-2815:37erwinrooijakkersI expect a ring-session cookie, but it is not added#2019-08-2815:37erwinrooijakkersI use the default settings, probably miss something#2019-08-2815:37erwinrooijakkers
(ns my-service
  (:require [io.pedestal.http :as http]
            [io.pedestal.http.body-params :as body-params]
            [io.pedestal.http.route :as route]
            [ring.util.response :as ring-resp]))

(defn start
  [request]
  (println "start" request)
  (ring-resp/response (format "Clojure %s - served from %s"
                              (clojure-version)
                              (route/url-for ::start))))

(defn auth
  [request]
  (println "auth" request)
  (ring-resp/response "Hello World!"))

(def common-interceptors
  [(body-params/body-params) http/html-body])

(def routes
  #{["/start" :get (conj common-interceptors `start)]
    ["/auth" :get (conj common-interceptors `auth)]})

(def service
  {:env :prod
   ::http/routes routes
   ::http/enable-session {}
   ::http/resource-path "/public"
   ::http/type :jetty
   ::http/host "0.0.0.0"
   ::http/port 8080
   ::http/container-options {:h2c? true
                             :h2? false
                             :ssl? false}})
#2019-08-2815:39erwinrooijakkersIt does add :session/key#2019-08-2815:39erwinrooijakkersAlways nil#2019-08-2815:39erwinrooijakkersAnd a :session that‚Äôs also nil#2019-08-2815:39erwinrooijakkersNo cookies in response#2019-08-2815:40erwinrooijakkersWhat else do I have to add? Or return a different type of response?#2019-08-2815:42ddeaguiar@erwinrooijakkers have you looked at https://github.com/ring-clojure/ring/wiki/Sessions?#2019-08-2815:44erwinrooijakkersYes saw it. I also saw https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/samples/ring-middleware/src/ring_middleware/service.clj#2019-08-2815:45erwinrooijakkersThere‚Äôs an example there so I apparently have to do more#2019-08-2815:45erwinrooijakkersCreate an interceptor#2019-08-2815:47erwinrooijakkersDon‚Äôt know how it related to the service map#2019-08-2815:47erwinrooijakkersAnd ::http/enable-session {}#2019-08-2815:47ddeaguiarIf you use io.pedestal.http/default-interceptors without setting the :io.pedestal.http/interceptors kw then it should create the session interceptor for you when ::http/enable-session is provided#2019-08-2815:47ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L208-L209#2019-08-2815:48ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L257#2019-08-2815:48erwinrooijakkersAh ok so I need default inerceptors#2019-08-2815:48ddeaguiaryep, sorry. Assumed that you were using that#2019-08-2815:49erwinrooijakkersHmm how do I add those?#2019-08-2815:50erwinrooijakkersOh Is ee#2019-08-2815:50erwinrooijakkersthere are already added#2019-08-2815:50ddeaguiarhttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-template/src/leiningen/new/pedestal_service/server.clj#L27#2019-08-2815:51erwinrooijakkersAt least in run-dev#2019-08-2815:51erwinrooijakkersNot in -main it seems like#2019-08-2815:51erwinrooijakkersFrom the pedestal-service template#2019-08-2815:51ddeaguiarthey are#2019-08-2815:51erwinrooijakkers
;; This is an adapted service map, that can be started and stopped
;; From the REPL you can call server/start and server/stop on this service
(defonce runnable-service
  (server/create-server service/service))

(defn run-dev
  "The entry-point for 'lein run-dev'"
  [& args]
  (println "\nCreating your [DEV] server...")
  (-> service/service ;; start with production configuration
      (merge {:env :dev
              ;; do not block thread that starts web server
              ::server/join? false
              ;; Routes can be a function that resolve routes,
              ;; we can use this to set the routes to be reloadable
              ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes))
              ;; all origins are allowed in dev mode
              ::server/allowed-origins {:creds true :allowed-origins (constantly true)}
              ;; Content Security Policy (CSP) is mostly turned off in dev mode
              ::server/secure-headers {:content-security-policy-settings {:object-src "'none'"}}})
      ;; Wire up interceptor chains
      server/default-interceptors
      server/dev-interceptors
      server/create-server
      server/start))

(defn -main
  "The entry-point for 'lein run'"
  [& args]
  (println "\nCreating your server...")
  (server/start runnable-service))
#2019-08-2815:51erwinrooijakkersIn server.cljs#2019-08-2815:52ddeaguiarcreate-server calls create-provider which does this https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L323#2019-08-2815:52erwinrooijakkersOkay so I have the default-interceptors thnaks#2019-08-2815:52erwinrooijakkersAnd default enable-session {} should create cookie store#2019-08-2815:53erwinrooijakkersAnd a ring-session cookie#2019-08-2815:53erwinrooijakkersBut that does not happen#2019-08-2815:53ddeaguiarare you putting stuff in session?#2019-08-2815:53erwinrooijakkersNo#2019-08-2815:53ddeaguiarrefer to that doc#2019-08-2815:54erwinrooijakkersAh if I add something to the session, then there‚Äôs a cookie#2019-08-2815:54erwinrooijakkersGreat#2019-08-2815:54erwinrooijakkersThanks!#2019-08-2817:11ddeaguiar:thumbsup:#2019-08-2914:50erwinrooijakkersI want to add custom logging#2019-08-2914:50erwinrooijakkersThe goal is basically to ignore requests from a certain IP range#2019-08-2914:50erwinrooijakkers(Kubernetes master calling ‚Äú/‚Äù)#2019-08-2914:51erwinrooijakkersI‚Äôve got some Ring middleware to do that#2019-08-2914:51erwinrooijakkersIs there a way to include that in Pedestal?#2019-08-2914:51erwinrooijakkersNow I see this:

INFO  io.pedestal.http  - {:msg "GET /", :line 80}
INFO  io.pedestal.http  - {:msg "GET /", :line 80}

That needs to go#2019-08-2914:52erwinrooijakkersMiddleware looks like this: 
(defn logging-middleware [handler]
  (-> handler
      (middleware.conditional/if not-request-from-internal-ip? wrap-with-info-logger)))
#2019-08-2915:13ddeaguiar@erwinrooijakkers you can provide your own request logger. See https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service/src/io/pedestal/http.clj#L205-L206#2019-08-2915:13ddeaguiarAdd :io.pedestal.http/request-logger to your service map#2019-08-2915:14erwinrooijakkersthanks üôÇ#2019-08-2915:33erwinrooijakkersWorks like a charm#2019-08-2915:34erwinrooijakkersFor those interested: 
(defn- from-internal-ip?
  "Returns truthy when a request does not come from an internal IP (e.g., a
  Kubernetes node)"
  [{:keys [server-name] :as request}]
  (let [internal-ip-start "10."]
    (string/starts-with? (str server-name) internal-ip-start)))

(def log-request
  "Log the request's method and uri."
  (interceptor.helpers/on-request
   ::log-request
   (fn [request]
     (when-not (from-internal-ip? request)
       (log/info :msg (format "%s %s"
                              (string/upper-case (name (:request-method request)))
                              (:uri request))))
     request)))
#2019-09-0122:59jjttjjLet's say I want an interceptor that will check a cache for some value args that should already be in the context map. if it exists, the val for that args key should be the response. Otherwise, continue the interceptor chain, and when there is a response cache it. 
(def cache (atom {}))

{:enter (fn [{:keys [args] :as ctx}]
          (if (contains? @cache args)
            (chain/terminate ctx)
            ctx))
 :leave (fn [{:keys [response args] :as ctx}]
          (if response
            (do (swap! cache assoc args response) ctx)
            (assoc ctx :response (get @cache))))}
Is this the standard way this should be implemented? It would feel more natural to me to assoc the cached response if it exists in the enter function (but then i'd be updating the cache every time even when a value already exists for it). Are there any obvious better ways to handle this?#2019-09-0202:05jjttjjOn further thought, it makes more sense either seperating these two transducers, or probaly better yet, in :enter, if the value is cached, assoc the response and terminate, if not, enqueue a leave function that caches the result#2019-09-0609:09martinklepschAfter upgrading to 0.5.7 from 0.5.3 my service is no longer working inside docker. I‚Äôm assuming it is related to the now mandatory-ish ::host key in the services map. Did anybody else encounter this issue and if so, what value are you setting ::host to?#2019-09-0609:26martinklepschI guess 0.0.0.0 works but it‚Äôs a little bit annoying having to special case running the service inside docker.#2019-09-0612:21nitaaiHello everybody. The framework is used to create a server that serves user define APIs, State, Redis Processors, and Server Sent Events. Everything works greate, however, I noticed that when multiple clients are connected to the web app, the server sent events will only send data to one client at the time and it sends data in a particular order. The way the server sent events are implemented is with Core Async and the Pedestal library for SSE. such as 
(def sse (chan 2046))

(defn stream-ready
"Get data from the sse channel and put it in `channel`. this is how SSE are sent to the client"
[channel context-map]
(go-loop []
  (async/put! channel (async/<! sse)))

(defn stream-data
"Put data in the sse channel"
[data]
(async/put! sse data))
#2019-10-0915:53dadairHey, so I'm running into some behaviour that I can't quite explain. I have two routes defined in table syntax: #{["/foos/search" :get [..] :route-name :search] ["/foos/:foo-id/bar" :post [..] :route-name :bar]}; the presence of the second route makes the system return a 404 for the first. This leads me to believe they are conflicting, but both the verbs and the route-names are different? I can't seem to explain this. We are on io.pedestal/pedestal.route {:mvn/version "0.5.3"}.#2019-10-0916:24ikitommi@dadair it's by design: > The prefix-tree router also changes some of the routing behavior. In the linear-search, you could have routes like /one/:wild and /one/two, the latter being a hard match and the former picking up any wildcard URL matches (not /one/two). In the prefix-tree, this isn't allowed, and one/:wild will always be matched. This change also encourages "best practices" and removes the possibility of subtle bugs introduced by human error.#2019-10-0916:24ikitommihttps://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/pull/330#2019-10-0916:24ddeaguiar@dadair refer to http://pedestal.io/reference/using-the-builtin-routers. You‚Äôll want to use the Linear Search router instead#2019-10-0916:29dadairAh ok thank you; the reference docs on the website are a bit misleading, they state (iirc) that as long as verb and name differ, there is no collision#2019-10-0916:29dadairI‚Äôll take a look at the other routers#2019-10-0916:46isakcouldn't one just be linear for that part of the tree?#2019-10-1021:33Eduardo MataI am using https://github.com/logstash/logstash-logback-encoder to send logs to my logstash instance. I am using pedestal.log for logging#2019-10-1313:06DaoudaHey Folks, I am facing an issue with pedestal routing in little project. My routing work fine with this:

I think since wrap-reload returns a handler function that an interceptor created from wrap-reload would also necessarily be a handler, and would therefore have to go at the end of the interceptor queue. Is that right?#2019-11-0516:32ddeaguiar@ctamayo perhaps Pedestal‚Äôs service-tools dev tooling is a better fit for you? https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/blob/master/service-tools/src/io/pedestal/service_tools/dev.clj#2019-11-0516:35cobyaha, yeah that looks promising! Thanks!#2019-11-0516:37ddeaguiarnp!#2019-11-0516:50cobyI'm a little confused about how/where to use this, though...do I wrap the expanded routes var in run-dev? So something like... 
;; Routes can be a function that resolve routes,
              ;;  we can use this to set the routes to be reloadable
              ::server/routes #(route/expand-routes (dev-tools/watch-routes-fn (deref #'service/routes)))
#2019-11-0516:52cobyor ::server/routes #(dev-tools/watch-routes-fn (route/expand-routes (deref #'service/routes)))?? both of these throw runtime exceptions#2019-11-0517:49ddeaguiar@ctamayo, watch should be sufficient. The fact that the run-dev service map uses (deref #'service/routes) leads to the routes being evaluated on every request#2019-11-0604:26cobyAwesome, just tried that and it's working. üíØ#2019-11-0812:41orestisI'm running Pedestal under Elastic Beanstalk. Is there a way to configure the Logback logger to emit CloudWatch-friendly JSON?#2019-11-0812:42orestisI've found this: https://github.com/osiegmar/logback-awslogs-json-encoder which seems to be what I want but I'm not certain if that's the level of abstraction I should be using.#2019-11-0812:42orestisI'd also like to enhance the logs with various other stuff (e.g. Host, user-id, etc etc)#2019-11-0814:22orestisI saw that I can do something like :io.pedestal.log/formatter cheshire/encode when calling io.pedestal.log/log, and cloudwatch is smart enough to pick that JSON up#2019-11-0814:30orestisBut not in insights, sigh. Perhaps it's better if the whole log is JSON (as opposed to prefixed by other logback things)#2019-11-0817:34ddeaguiar@orestis I‚Äôve not used the logback-awslogs-json-encoder lib but if you do produce JSON formatted logs and use io.pedestal.log/log with a JSON formatter, then your log message will be a string albeit in JSON format. You could parse that string in CloudWatch Insights using the parse function it provides in order to create virtual fields which can be filtered on. That being said, info like Host, user-id seems better suited for MDC usage. You can use Pedestal‚Äôs io.pedestal.log/with-context impl to set a map of data in the MDC but it will be a single value under the io.pedestal key. You could format as JSON and parse as I described above, though. Alternatively, you can use the MDC directly. All values put into the MDC become separate fields prefixed by mdc in Insights which makes log analysis easy.#2019-11-0919:43Janne SauvalaI stumbled today to a very annoying thing. I was dockerizing my pedestal/lacinia server and somehow I wasn‚Äôt able to call it‚Äôs endpoint while it was running inside the container. After several hours of debugging/googling I found out about this issue https://github.com/pedestal/pedestal/issues/604#2019-11-1113:57ddeaguiarSorry you ran into that. I think the best thing to do is make the docs more clear about this.#2019-11-1114:14Janne SauvalaIt‚Äôs great Pedestal takes security seriously. A note to the docs would be really helpful. I haven‚Äôt ran into this kind of issue with other (lesser) frameworks+languages so it took me longer time to figure out the problem üôÇ#2019-11-0919:45Janne Sauvala::http/host "0.0.0.0" did the trick and I got it working. I don‚Äôt know if this is a feature or bug :man-shrugging::skin-tone-2:#2019-11-1015:04dvingohello, I'm running a server in dev mode and getting the following content security policy error in the browser:
